fields.headline: Ooh-aah, Fat Neck's a star...
fields.trailText: Sir Alex Ferguson is known to be shopping for new members of his Manchester United team - but Karl "Fat Neck" Power probably is not quite what he had in mind.
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson is known to be shopping for new members of his Manchester United team - but Karl "Fat Neck" Power probably is not quite what he had in mind.

Better known in Manchester circles as a close friend of the group Black Grape, who wrote the song Fat Neck in his honour, Mr Power emerged yesterday as the mystery 12th man who sneaked on to the pitch at Bayern Munich on Wednesday night and into the offical team photo.

To the obvious astonishment of the team, whose nerves were stretched before the European Champions' League game quarter-final match, the burly fan peeled off a tracksuit to reveal an almost perfect white strip, bearing the name Cantona on the back before joining in the team picture.

"The shorts weren't quite right," admitted a spokesman for the London-based lads' magazine Front, which organised what it called "the ultimate blag". "But we were just amazed to have got him in there - not to mention into the players' hotel and Alex Ferguson's car."

The magazine has pulled off a number of other scams, including a successful Front trip-up of Noel Edmonds and the smuggling of a stripper on to TV's Vanessa show.

Piers Hernu, editor of Front magazine, said he had thought up the scam with a man called the Imposter who has conned his way into every big Manchester United game over the past 10 years .

Four men were involved in Wednesday's stunt: Mr Power, Front writer Eddie Hardin, photographer James Stemson and the Imposter, who Mr Hernu refused to name. All four had managed to acquire Uefa bibs outside the Munich ground, the type usually worn by press photographers or television cameramen. They waited at the side of the pitch and as the teams emerged, Power unzipped his track suit and joined the United team. He then returned to his friends and watched the match.

Manchester United defender Jaap Stam said last night: "All I can say is that we walked out of the tunnel and then this guy suddenly appeared when we posed for photographers. A few of us were looking around thinking: Who the hell is this guy?"

webTitle: James finds Villa too cheap to rise

fields.headline: James finds Villa too cheap to rise
fields.trailText: The rumblings of discontent at Aston Villa resumed yesterday when David James warned the board that it would have to accept a mid-table team for as long as it paid mid-table wages.
fields.body:
The rumblings of discontent at Aston Villa about the club's ambition resumed yesterday when David James warned the board that it would have to accept a mid-table team for as long as it paid mid-table wages.

Villa were 12th in the league of Premiership wages published recently by Deloitte and Touche, with last season's bill of £21.55m amounting to less than half that paid by Chelsea and Manchester United.

The club retain a slim chance of qualifying for Europe. But James, talking on the day Villa announced they were freezing season-ticket prices for the third successive season, said that the wages budget was geared to mediocrity.

"That isn't obviously the barometer of a performance during the season," the England goalkeeper said. "But I just think that, if we are going to run our ship that way and the structure of the club is going to be that way, that is all that you can expect."

James, who stressed he was not asking for a pay rise, hinted that money on a new stand could have been better spent. "It will put us up with the top flight with regards to attendances next season . . . but, if you are paying mid-table wages and asking people to run mid-table budgets, then you get a mid-table side."

Villa's Lee Hendrie has been charged with misconduct by the Football Association for "over the top" goal celebrations as he jumped over hoardings to mingle with fans. He faces a fine if found guilty of the charge, which Villa's manager John Gregory said he would fight.

Frank Leboeuf has heightened speculation that he will leave Chelsea in summer.

"I still haven't closed the door on Monaco," he said of the club who pulled out of a deal in January. "When I was talking with them, there were no financial problems and there is still a possibility of a deal being reached. I've been at Chelsea for five years and it may be that I've done all that I can."

Bradford City's manager Jim Jefferies must decide whether to keep Benito Carbone after being given a £5m wages' budget for next season. Carbone, a possible target for Chelsea, would take up 40% with his £2m-a-year pay.

Nottingham Forest and Preston have each been fined £5,000 by the FA after a mass brawl at the City Ground in November. Brighton's striker Bobby Zamora has won the Nationwide player of the month award for March.

Bayern Munich's Jens Jeremies and Giovane Elber are undergoing knee operations but still hope to be fit for the European Cup semi-final with Real Madrid. Surgery could not be delayed further and they must be considered doubts for the first leg in Spain on May 1.

Real's Figo broke his nose in the win over Galatasaray and has an operation today.

fields.headline: John Wesley Harding
fields.standfirst:
Borderline, London
***
fields.trailText:
Borderline, London
***
fields.body:
Hastings-born but Seattle-based, the former Wesley Stace has carved out a niche for himself as the slightly plummy, ever-so-wry English songwriter abroad, pitched somewhere between Robyn Hitchcock and Elvis Costello. In the US, the results have included onstage duets with Bruce Springsteen and the inclusion of I'm Wrong About Everything on the US version of the High Fidelity soundtrack. But in Britain even the presence of his sister, Generation Game hostess Melanie Stace, cannot sell out his first British show in a decade with a band - here The Radical Gentleman.

Harding is a jocose stage figure, drinking pints of beer, wearing a shirt so gaudy Marti Pellow would have demurred, and repeatedly charging into the crowd. When he introduces I'm Wrong About Everything with a tambourine perched precariously on his head it seems strangely logical. Yet, while joviality is infinitely preferable to sullenness, it does vitiate his emotional resonance or the acerbic Warren Zevon-esque lyric to The Devil Inside Me, in which he claims, possibly untruthfully, to have assassinated John F Kennedy and polluted the oceans.

Perhaps Harding is simply too eclectic. He sings a couple of old English folk songs accompanied only by his guitar; for the encore he covers Matching Mole and updates Waterloo Sunset; and he is, by turns, country, powerpop and, inevitably, Loudon Wainwright III on Goth Girl, with its lines about her boyfriend looking like Pete Murphy and not being able to afford to take her to see Nine Inch Nails. Somewhere the essence of John Wesley Harding is lost.

Still, there are moments to savour, invariably taken from the new album. Our Lady of the Highways (a duet with Steve Earle on record, but with bassist Chris Von Sneidern on stage) is so beautiful Willie Nelson could cover it. The comforting Bad Dream Baby (with Von Sneidern covering for the record's Jimmie Dale Gilmore) is perfect, superior-period REM powerpop, while People Love to Watch You Die has the widescreen chorus the remainder of Harding's songs aspire to. He delivers it with his right foot astride his amp, as if he were James's Tim Booth. More where that comes from and things might just start to turn around.

fields.headline: Robyn Hitchcock's psychedelic flashback
fields.standfirst:
Soft Boys
Junction, Cambridge
****
fields.trailText:
Soft Boys
Junction, Cambridge
****
fields.body:
With their final album, Underwater Moonlight, recently reissued in time for its 21st birthday, the Soft Boys decided there could be no finer moment to attempt a belated reunion. If the Cambridge psychedelicists were ahead of the curve in the late 1970s, suddenly they sound like a lost legend from a mythical era.

Back at the helm is Robyn Hitchcock, somewhat greyer of hair but no less oblique in mind. He explained that the quartet had just returned from the US, and were grotesquely jet-lagged. "We don't look like this and we don't sound like this," he warned. But if you can live with Hitchcock's Lewis Carroll imagery and magic-mushroom logic, you can quickly appreciate that the Soft Boys offer as fine a brew of psychedelic pop and classic English whimsy as anybody has mustered since Syd Barrett went AWOL.

Refreshed by their 20-year lay-off, the Boys ripped through their set with energy and dazzling expertise. They limbered up with Sideways, a tricky instrumental in 7/4 time, then started piling on the harmonies and the meshing guitar parts through the likes of Sudden Town and the ingenious, devious Kingdom of Love.

With Matthew Seligman and Morris Windsor supplying simpatico support on bass and drums, the decks were cleared for the interlocking guitars of Hitchcock and Kimberley Rew. The pair never merely fill space with vacuous axeman bluster because the guitar parts are integral to the structure of the songs. Rew's muscular playing dovetails eloquently with Hitchcock's glassier, more quavering tone - nowhere more impressively than on Insanely Jealous.

The combination of instrumental guile and three-part harmonies gives the Boys options that the bog-standard guitar combo can never dream of. They handled the off-centre harmonies and ringing chords of I Wanna Destroy You with aplomb (it was dedicated to George W Bush), and comfortably embraced songs as different as the anthemic Mr Kennedy or the riffed-up Only the Stones Remain without breaking their stride. There was even a bonus Spinal Tap moment with Rock'n'Roll Toilet, which had Rew grinning idiotically from beneath his pudding-basin Brian Jones haircut. As reunions go, this one goes miles further.

 Soft Boys play the Waterfront, Norwich (01603 508050), on April 22, Rock City, Nottingham (0115-941 2544), on April 23, The Garage, Glasgow (0141-248 1661) on April 24, then tour.

fields.headline: Independent Insurance chief quits
fields.trailText: Michael Bright, founder of former stock market darling Independent Insurance, yesterday shouldered the responsibility for the collapse in the insurers' share price by resigning as chief executive.
fields.body:
Michael Bright, founder of former stock market darling Independent Insurance, yesterday shouldered the responsibility for the collapse in the insurers' share price by resigning as chief executive.

Mr Bright's move to relinquish day-to-day control prompted speculation that the 14-year-old company might attract a takeover bid.

The surprise announcement came at yesterday's annual shareholder meeting, immediately after the board had discussed the shares' drop in just two months from above £3.50 to yesterday's £1.33.

Chairman Garth Ramsay, who is to take a temporary executive role while a new chief executive is sought, said: "The share price has performed very poorly since the results in early March. It reflects a loss of confidence in the company in terms of the stock market".

He insisted that Mr Bright - whose personal wealth is tied up in the company - had not been pushed and that the decision was "mutual". Mr Bright, who built the company up from scratch, owns some 14m shares and did not take last year's bonus. He took home £650,000 against £1m the year before.

Until February, Independent Insurance was one of the stock market's favourites. It suffered a sharp reversal in its fortunes after a profits warning in February and the announcement in March of a 42% fall in its profits to £40m. The company has suffered from underwriting losses in France and "no fee, no win" insurance claims. It also has a complicated reinsurance arrangement in place which, it said, would cost £39m in cash.

While the step-down by Mr Bright caused concern because of his close association with the company, Barrie Cornes, analyst at ING Barings, said: "Michael Bright is very well known. He is surrounded by strong people."

fields.headline: Microsoft and Sun beat forecasts
fields.trailText: Leading North American hi-tech groups last night underlined the dilemmas confronting the US Federal Reserve in giving a clear sense of direction to the world's biggest economy by announcing a mixed set of results.
fields.body:
Leading North American hi-tech groups last night underlined the dilemmas confronting the US Federal Reserve in giving a clear sense of direction to the world's biggest economy by announcing a mixed set of results.

Both Microsoft and Sun Microsystems announced quarterly profits that surpassed - if only just - Wall Street expectations, while Canada's Nortel reported a hefty loss.

The figures, coming just a day after the Fed stunned markets with a half-point cut in borrowing rates, added to the confusing picture of US corporate health confronting policy-makers, with some of the bigger corporations performing well and others showing evidence of sagging profits and sales.

Microsoft said earnings had been boosted by stronger sales of its Windows 2000 software.

It said that for its third fiscal quarter, ended March 31, it made net profits of $2.45bn (£1.7bn), or 44 cents a share, compared with $2.39bn, 43 cents a share, a year earlier. It posted revenues of $6.46bn, against $5.66bn a year earlier.

Sun Microsystems, the network computer maker, beat lowered profit targets in its third quarter but sales missed analysts' target.

Sales at the firm, which scaled back its targets in February, rose 2% to $4.1bn from $4bn last year, while operating earnings were $263m, or eight cents per share, against $464m, or 14 cents, a year ago.

Nortel Networks, the world's biggest telecoms equipment supplier, reported a first-quarter loss in line with expectations. It said it lost $385m, or 12 cents per share excluding one-time costs, compared with year-earlier net earnings of $347m, or 12 cents per share.

PC maker Gateway posted a $503m loss, including $533m of restructuring charges, and said it expected to return to profitability in the second half.

webTitle: Official: we are a low-inflation nation

fields.headline: Official: we are a low-inflation nation
fields.standfirst:
Rate drops to 2.3% and will go even lower before election

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: The latest set of government figures for the cost of living published yesterday showed the annual inflation rate dropping to its lowest level in more than a year, down to 2.3%.
fields.body:
The latest set of government figures for the cost of living published yesterday showed the annual inflation rate dropping to its lowest level in more than a year, down to 2.3%. And if mortgage rates are excluded from the calculations - the index preferred by the government - then the figure comes down even lower, to just 1.9%.

But with polling day delayed for a month there was no set-piece press conference attended by Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, no tour of the TV and radio studios, no attacks on Tory "boom and bust".

On May 15 - the date when the data for prices in April is released - it be a different story. Cheaper mortgages and the chancellor's tax changes in the Budget will mean the inflation rate comes down a lot further, and with June 7 then only three weeks away there will be no holding back. The message will be that Labour, for so long haunted by the curse of high inflation, has taken the tough decisions needed to keep price rises low.

The figures released yesterday by the office for national statistics support the case that something fundamental has changed, despite the fluctuations caused by one-off events such as the foot and mouth epidemic and bad weather. The slaughter of livestock pushed up pork prices by 10%, bacon by 9.6% and imported lamb by 4.9%. Prices of cauliflowers, cucumbers, lettuces, tomatoes and cabbages have all been affected by the unusually wet weather this winter.

But over the longer term all the government's many different measures of inflation point to the same conclusion: that Britain is now a low inflation country. Measured by the all-items retail prices index - a basket of 650 goods covering 147 areas across the UK - inflation is 2.3%, compared with 27% at its post-war peak in 1975.

On an international basis, the picture is even better. The EU uses a different method to calculate prices across Europe, and on this basis Britain's inflation rate is 0.8%, the lowest in the union.

Falling inflation has been accompanied by much lower interest rates, something else for the government to revel in during the election campaign. A return to the inflation levels last seen in the 1950s and early 1960s has meant a return to the borrowing costs of 30 or 40 years ago. Interest rates, raised to 15% when inflation was nudging 11% in 1990, are down to 5.5%. Some City analysts believe they could be cut to 4.5% over the coming months.

Government figures show that this fall in inflation is not a flash in the pan. Inflation averaged 2.6% a year between 1993 and 2000, with no evidence that a prolonged period of economic growth, accompanied by a fall in unemployment from almost 3m to just under 1m, is leading to increased price pressure.

Overall, prices have risen by 72.2% since the retail prices index was last re-based at 100 in January 1987. But that increase disguises large disparities between different categories of spending. The prices of goods, where international competition has been ferocious, have risen much more slowly than inflation as a whole, but in large chunks of the service sector consumers are still getting a raw deal. The most spectacular example of falling prices is in audio-visual equipment, which now costs less than 40% of its price in 1987, largely as a result of the impact of cheaper and more powerful computer equipment.

Household electrical appliances such as washing machines are almost 10% cheaper than at the end of the 1980s, while women's clothing costs 88% of prices 14 years ago. Even those goods which have increased in price - such as toys, CDs and tapes, furniture, shoes and men's clothing - have tended to rise more slowly than inflation as a whole. Food is up by 46.7% since 1987.

So where is the inflation coming from? The answer is that prices in those parts of the economy sheltered from international competition or where the government has added to costs through taxation have risen sharply. Above-inflation increases in tobacco duties have meant that cigarettes have risen by more than any other item in the RPI basket, by 190% since 1987. Personal services such as dental examinations, eye tests and hairdressing follow a close second with a 177% rise, while the cost of entertainment is up by 167.6% and the cost of alcoholic drinks up 89.8%. The cost of taxing and insuring a car is up 164.8%, while rail fares are up 112%.

In some areas of the service sector, government involvement has been good. Strengthened regulatory control over the privatised utilities has led to a sharp reduction in prices. Gas is up by less than 15% since 1987, electricity by 27.7%, and telephone charges have fallen by more than 10%. Only water - up by more than 150% - has bucked the trend.

Given that rising prices helped to remove Labour from power in the elections of 1970 and 1979, it is hardly surprising that the party will seek to reap the political benefit of low inflation. But Roger Bootle, the economist who wrote the book The Death of Inflation in the mid-1990s, believes that longer term factors have been at work and that governments everywhere could soon have to grapple with the Japanese problem - falling prices.

Globalisation, technological advance, competition and a tougher approach to inflation have all contributed to a change in the inflationary climate, which has been under way for 20 years. "If this is what happens after 10 years of economic growth, it makes you wonder what would happen in a downturn," Mr Bootle said.

The spectre of deflation, when a whole economy suffers the equivalent of negative equity, is one thing that would certainly not be welcome to the government.

But over the longer term all the government's many different measures of inflation point to the same conclusion: that Britain is now a low inflation country. Measured by the all-items retail prices index - a basket of 650 goods covering 147 areas across the UK - inflation is 2.3%, compared with 27% at its post-war peak in 1975. On an international basis, the picture is even better. The EU uses a different method to calculate prices across Europe, and on this basis Britain's inflation rate is 0.8%, the lowest in the union. Falling inflation has been accompanied by much lower interest rates, something else for the government to revel in during the election campaign. A return to the inflation levels last seen in the 1950s and early 1960s has meant a return to the borrowing costs of 30 or 40 years ago. Interest rates, raised to 15% when inflation was nudging 11% in 1990, are down to 5.5%. Some City analysts believe they could be cut to 4.5% over the coming months. Government figures show that this fall in inflation is not a flash in the pan. Inflation averaged 2.6% a year between 1993 and 2000, with no evidence that a prolonged period of economic growth, accompanied by a fall in unemployment from almost 3m to just under 1m, is leading to increased price pressure. Overall, prices have risen by 72.2% since the retail prices index was last re-based at 100 in January 1987. But that increase disguises large disparities between different categories of spending. The prices of goods, where international competition has been ferocious, have risen much more slowly than inflation as a whole, but in large chunks of the service sector consumers are still getting a raw deal. The most spectacular example of falling prices is in audio-visual equipment, which now costs less than 40% of its price in 1987, largely as a result of the impact of cheaper and more powerful computer equipment. Household electrical appliances such as washing machines are almost 10% cheaper than at the end of the 1980s, while women's clothing costs 88% of prices 14 years ago. Even those goods which have increased in price - such as toys, CDs and tapes, furniture, shoes and men's clothing - have tended to rise more slowly than inflation as a whole. Food is up by 46.7% since 1987. So where is the inflation coming from? The answer is that prices in those parts of the economy sheltered from international competition or where the government has added to costs through taxation have risen sharply. Above-inflation increases in tobacco duties have meant that cigarettes have risen by more than any other item in the RPI basket, by 190% since 1987. Personal services such as dental examinations, eye tests and hairdressing follow a close second with a 177% rise, while the cost of entertainment is up by 167.6% and the cost of alcoholic drinks up 89.8%. The cost of taxing and insuring a car is up 164.8%, while rail fares are up 112%. In some areas of the service sector, government involvement has been good. Strengthened regulatory control over the privatised utilities has led to a sharp reduction in prices. Gas is up by less than 15% since 1987, electricity by 27.7%, and telephone charges have fallen by more than 10%. Only water - up by more than 150% - has bucked the trend. Given that rising prices helped to remove Labour from power in the elections of 1970 and 1979, it is hardly surprising that the party will seek to reap the political benefit of low inflation. But Roger Bootle, the economist who wrote the book The Death of Inflation in the mid-1990s, believes that longer term factors have been at work and that governments everywhere could soon have to grapple with the Japanese problem - falling prices. Globalisation, technological advance, competition and a tougher approach to inflation have all contributed to a change in the inflationary climate, which has been under way for 20 years. "If this is what happens after 10 years of economic growth, it makes you wonder what would happen in a downturn," Mr Bootle said. The spectre of deflation, when a whole economy suffers the equivalent of negative equity, is one thing that would certainly not be welcome to the government. webTitle: Leader: Europe should reduce interest rates now

fields.headline: Follow the leader
fields.standfirst:
Europe should reduce interest rates now

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: The Bank of England should shamelessly copy the tactics employed by America's Federal Reserve. The US central bank cut interest rates by 0.5% this week when no one was expecting any reduction, let alone such a big one.
fields.body:
The Bank of England should shamelessly copy the tactics employed by America's Federal Reserve. The US central bank cut interest rates by 0.5% this week when no one was expecting any reduction, let alone such a big one.

The strategy was clear: since interest rates would almost certainly have to go down by that amount during the next few months to stem the economy's slide into recession, then they might as well go down now. At a stroke this did two things. First, it restored the Fed's ability to move ahead of market pressures and not after them, a skill it was in danger of losing; and, second, it proved that the Fed can make decisions in "internet time" as speedily as US corporations can.

A new feature of this recession is that companies like Cisco, Dell and IBM, know almost instantly when sales drop or stocks pile up because they are monitoring them continuously online. This makes downturns happen more quickly and (hopefully) recoveries, too. The Fed has proved that it can also respond quickly to changing data about the economy. Britain and Europe should follow suit. In Britain's case, if the Bank expects interest rates to drop by 0.5% over the next few months, then it might as well get it all over with at its next meeting: that would also let it off the hook of changing rates during the election campaign.

Yesterday's encouraging figures show, too, that there is very little inflationary pressure ahead, except perhaps for rising petrol prices. This means that a reduction in interest rates could stimulate economic activity - and maybe reduce the value of the pound on the foreign exchange markets - without pushing prices up. The UK is in danger because of its exposure to the sinking US economy, aggravated by the fall in share prices and the fallout from foot and mouth disease. Britain's economic health is very sensitive to the success of two areas that are particularly vulnerable right now: financial services and the technology, media and telecommunications sector. As the Bank of England noted this week, this sector has accounted for all of the increase (paltry though it is) in UK manufacturing output since 1995.

It is sobering to be reminded that if Britain had been part of the single currency then we would not have been able to reduce interest rates at all because the European Central Bank (ECB) has kept rates on hold at 4.75% since last October and it is showing no sign of relenting. Yet the danger from higher inflation in Europe is much less than the danger of underestimating the pace of the economic slowdown. The ECB, unlike the Fed, is only required to contain inflation and not to take growth into account. It is now caught in the middle between countries like Germany, which desperately want lower interest rates to stimulate growth, and those like Ireland and Spain that do not. Germany is the largest economy in Europe with the biggest exposure to the US because of its success in exporting.

But Germany is the exception. The economy of the EU as a whole is remarkably self-sufficient. Well over 90% of gross national product is generated internally and for most of the recent past it has enjoyed a trade surplus (in contrast to the huge US trade deficit). It is time for Europe to test the potential of the new trading block it has created by lowering interest rates to stimulate activity. Nearly all of the increased trade will be importing and exporting from each other with little risk of igniting inflationary pressures. And if international investors are persuaded that Europe will expand at a sustainable rate, then the long suffering euro will be the first to feel the benefit.

fields.headline: Gillian Wearing
fields.standfirst:
Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris
****
fields.trailText:
Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris
****
fields.body:
It's spring and Paris should be gay: blossom, lovers kissing deep and long in the Tuileries gardens, nice exhibitions of pretty paintings. But it isn't. It's been raining since October, it's too cold to kiss outdoors and, instead of pretty paintings, Paris is being confronted with Under the Influence, Gillian Wearing's harrowing videos teeming with alcoholics and childhood traumas.

Wearing's first French solo show starts with a self-portrait, with the artist in a mask that apparently closely resembles the real Wearing, thereby raising interesting questions about self-presentation and the consumption of images that recur throughout the show.

It's oddly dislocating to see this Birmingham-born artist's work in Paris. One struggles not to unwontedly interpret her works as mere expressions of a very British malaise. That's how the French like to see us - two parts Ken Loach, one part barmy royal family, a dash of crazy livestock and an overwhelming sense that horrible things happen there without so much as a by-your-leave.

Wearing's art fits into this image of Britain. But each installation confounds this interpretation and insists on Wearing's universality. For me, the best work is the trilogy made during her two- year collaboration with a community of south London alcoholics. In the first, a woman recounts the death of her alcoholic twin sister. It's sometimes tender, the disjunction between this woman's speech and her image a poignant way of underlining her own alcoholism without judgment. (She has since died of cirrhosis.) In a middle section, a gang of drunk men spar - another abject ballet that could happen anywhere but that Wearing was able to capture. In the last, one of the men lies dead drunk.

The show is juxtaposed with the cunning video art of Swede Ann-Sofi Siden. In Britain, her interviews with prostitutes would make just another docusoap. Here, you sit in one of a line of booths listening on headphones to a prostitute's life story. You feel intimate with the subject and yet, at the same time, like a voyeur - not least because when you look down the line of booths where art lovers sit complicit, you realise the gallery has been transformed into a cultural peep show. Why do we come to galleries to feed on others' strife and give nothing back? Like Wearing, Siden makes going to see art a problematic, painful experience.

 Until May 6. Details: 00 33 1 53 67 40 00.

fields.headline: Flood costs put up premiums
fields.trailText: Home owners are starting to pick up the tab for last winter's floods through higher home insurance costs, a survey revealed this week.
fields.body:
Home owners are starting to pick up the tab for last winter's floods through higher home insurance costs, a survey revealed this week.

Over the past three months buildings and contents premiums have risen significantly for the first time in four years - by 1.6% for buildings insurance and 1.4% for contents.

The average buildings insurance policy now costs £134 while the average contents premium is £107, the report from the AA reveals. But it says that by shopping around you can bring these costs down to £92 and £70 respectively.

"After a period of stability these premium rises spell bad news for home owners," says Kerry Richardson at the AA. "This is the first sign that home insurers are starting to pass on losses from bad weather over the winter to their customers." It reckons we will see more increases as the year goes on.

Meanwhile, the cost of car insurance is continuing to motor upwards. Non-comprehensive premiums have risen by a hefty 6.2% since January, while fully comprehensive policies have risen by 4.4%.

A typical non-comprehensive premium costs £118 more now than a year ago - £641 compared with £523 in April 2000. Comprehensive premiums are up by £91 to an average of £629 from £538 this time last year. But by shopping around, motorists can typically save £230-£240 on these costs.

The AA says the cost of third-party insurance is rising particularly fast because those who opt for such cover tend to be higher-risk motorists, so insurance companies are having to charge higher premiums to cover the risk.

fields.headline: Europe's banker of the people
fields.standfirst: As the EBRD prepares to mark its 10th anniversary its French chief, Jean Lemierre, looks forward
fields.trailText: As the EBRD prepares to mark its 10th anniversary its French chief, Jean Lemierre, looks forward.
fields.body:
Imagine applying for a car loan and being asked not only which way you vote but whether or not you approve of elections. Or maybe how you feel about the rights of minority shareholders. Hardly standard questions on the average bank loan form.

Trot along to Jean Lemierre's bank, however, and expect a grilling on more than just your finances. But then Mr Lemierre is no ordinary banker - his priorities are profits, poverty and politics. His employer, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, is an international financial institution yet its role is of first mover, not lender of last resort. It is publicly funded but focuses on the private sector. Its mandate is to support the economies in central and eastern Europe (and beyond) as they change from central planning to a market orientation. And it has to do so while encouraging the development of democratic institutions.

Oh yes, and customers can range from industrial Russian behemoths seeking hundreds of millions of dollars, to wannabe entrepreneurs in Bosnia looking for a few bucks to rebuild the local cafe.

Sounds contradictory? Not to Mr Lemierre, an affable and relaxed former French civil servant. "The logic of the bank is very clear, very simple. This institution fits very well with a world where economic progress, investment are financed by private capital flows. What this bank is here to do is to reduce the risk to private investors, to help them invest where they believe to do so is still too risky. This is a very modern way, a very clever way.

"We don't compete with the private sector, we are an addition to the private sector. There are no contradictions."

To Anglo-Saxons that might sound a little French. No surprise there. Mr Lemierre is the third Frenchman to head the bank in the 10 years since it was set up in the aftermath of the collapse of the old Soviet bloc. French leadership has been interrupted only by Germany's Horst Köhler and a couple of brief interludes when presidential departures meant spells of vice-presidential sway.

This weekend the bank is holding its annual meeting in London - a gathering which marks the EBRD's 10th anniversary. The years have not been without problems. The first president, Jacques Attali, was big on vision but under his leadership the EBRD earned a reputation as a bank that liked to say "yes" - to itself. Unsurprisingly, he departed early, trailing accusations of extravagance - not least over an estimated £750,000 bill for remarbling the halls of the bank's London headquarters.

Enter Jacques de Larosière, a veteran of the Banque de France and the International Monetary Fund under whose leadership, as a Financial Times editorial noted, the bank grew "into its role as a facilitator of vital investments in the former Soviet empire."

But after all the publicity of the Attali era, Mr de Larosière appeared determined to keep the bank out of the spotlight, which may have made sense for much of the time but did, on occasion, create problems of presentation.

The bank's role is simply incompatible with a low profile. Its involvement in a controversial project to finance the completion of nuclear facilities in the Ukraine - as a quid pro quo for the closure of Chernobyl - has attracted considerable criticism from environmental campaigners. Inevitably, the bank's loan portfolio suffered considerably from the fallout from Russia's partial debt default in 1998.

Even as delegates fly in to London, CEE Bankwatch, a non-governmental organisation with members drawn from countries in central and eastern Europe, is holding a press conference under the heading "EBRD; a decade of misinformation and secrecy".

CEE Bankwatch is expected to criticise the bank either for not giving sufficient information or not insisting its clients give sufficient information about projects to allow effective public consultation.

Still the bank can put a positive enough gloss on its activities. Over the past decade it has invested or lent some 17.5bn euros (£11bn) of its own money, which it reckons brought a further 44.5bn euros from co-investors.

In recent years the EBRD has focused more on providing investment to small and medium sized enterprises - either directly or through specialist banks. Mr Lemierre is anxious to help the build-up of a base of new entrepreneurs who will help drive future economic prosperity.

It has been profitable for seven of its 10 years - it made losses in the first two and then again in 1998 when it was hit by the fallout from the Russian debt crisis.

As the politicians, bankers and entrepreneurs from east and west gather in London over the next three days, Mr Lemierre will be keen to deliver a forward looking message.

Inevitably, speeches from the finance ministers who represent the bank's sovereign shareholders will be peppered with strictures for the bank to operate on "sound banking principles". Mr Lemierre has no problem with that. "It is very good for the bank to respect sound banking principles. You can't built economies by making losses.

"We are using taxpayers money and, to talk like a technocrat, the allocation of capital must be done on a sound basis.

"If you have a project where you don't understand the financial and economic sustainability, there is a problem. There is something wrong. It would be a big mistake if the bank financed projects that were not sensible. That would send the wrong message."

Ensuring the future

There is, however, a "but" - and it is a significant one. For Mr Lemierre, making a profit is important in that it underpins the bank's long-term future - ensuring that it continues in operation, helping the transition process in central and eastern Europe.

But the bank is not in the business, he says, of profits maximisation. That, he believes, would affect its ability to take risks and so to act effectively. For Mr Lemierre the yardstick is the impact the bank's investments and loans - and the money of private-sector banks and investors it brings on board - has on the economies in which it operates.

"What is very interesting about this job is the people. You work with people and for people. You don't work for the balance sheet."

Not that the bank sees itself as a soft touch. While it may not look for a bench mark return on its investment, it is very keen on what Mr Lemierre calls conditionality. This is a tricky area and varies from country to country and project to project. "We don't have a tool box with already prepared conditions of choice. We have to look at what will have the best impact, what is credible."

Inevitably this is where the politics comes in. For the EBRD is not just about setting repayment conditions. If it is being asked to fund, say, an energy utility or transport system it will want to ensure that the tariff policy is sufficient to sustain the financial commitment. In other words, prices - traditionally set well below market rates under central planning - have to rise. For politicians that is never good news.

In broader terms, the bank also has to make an assessment of the progress individual countries are making towards democracy. As Mr Lemierre notes, the EBRD "is the only international financial institution to have to make this assessment". It is also a recipe for the bank to be caught in the crossfire between those who think its democratic mandate is a licence to interfere and those who think it does not interfere enough.

The EBRD has ruffled a few feathers in the corporate sector, too. It has had its clashes over areas such as corporate governance and transparency. Again Mr Lemierre sees it as a balance between standards that the EBRD believes are essential if progress is to be made but which must be understood and accepted by those seeking loans or investment.

"We must explain, we must have a real policy dialogue with the companies and countries. The conditions must be relevant and adapted to the project involved. If they are not understood they will not be expected.

"What we have to say is that we are ready to work with you - but there is no free lunch." Gazprom is a case in point. It would like some $250m (£180m) of the EBRD's money. The bank wants some questions answered first. So far, no answers, so no money, either.

Mr Lemierre is committed to the market economy model, not, he says, on ideological grounds but because it is the best way of creating wealth. But he acknowledges that the process of change has brought problems.

In the old days of central planning there was a popular joke among workers that "we pretend to work and they pretend to pay us". These days it is no joke, as enterprises close leaving workers and pensioners dependent on safety nets that, at best, are inadequate and at worst nonexistent.

Mr Lemierre acknowledges the problem and says it will be one of the messages he will deliver to the AGM.

"In the first stage [of transition], which can be long, sometimes you are creating jobs, creating new activities but at other times you are destroying the welfare system.

"When you restructure old systems you create poverty, despair and I think in our countries of operation there is a real need to work to address more the questions of poverty, health and education.

"We need to make a bridge between the old and new systems.

"People must know that when they have huge difficulties, there is some hope. At the end of the day people must know there is a small bank somewhere in London where people are trying to help."

Decade of highs and lows

May 1990: agreement to establish bank signed

April 1991: inauguration of EBRD headquarters, election of Jacques Attali as president

June 1991: first loan approved

November 1991: first regional office, in Warsaw

April 1992: first annual meeting - in Budapest

April 1993: scandal over 'extravagance' breaks

July 1993: Attali resigns

July 1993: Russia small business fund set up

Sept 1993: Jacques de Larosière elected president

April 1996: shareholders agree to double bank's capital to 20bn euros

June 1996: Bosnia Herzegovina becomes EBRD member

Dec 1996: bank now has loans in all 26 countries of operation

June 1998: Jacques Attali retires

September 1998: Horst Köhler becomes president

April 2000: Köhler steps down to become head of the IMF

July 2000: Jean Lemierre becomes EBRD president

French leadership has been interrupted only by Germany's Horst Köhler and a couple of brief interludes when presidential departures meant spells of vice-presidential sway. This weekend the bank is holding its annual meeting in London - a gathering which marks the EBRD's 10th anniversary. The years have not been without problems. The first president, Jacques Attali, was big on vision but under his leadership the EBRD earned a reputation as a bank that liked to say "yes" - to itself. Unsurprisingly, he departed early, trailing accusations of extravagance - not least over an estimated £750,000 bill for remarbling the halls of the bank's London headquarters. Enter Jacques de Larosière, a veteran of the Banque de France and the International Monetary Fund under whose leadership, as a Financial Times editorial noted, the bank grew "into its role as a facilitator of vital investments in the former Soviet empire." But after all the publicity of the Attali era, Mr de Larosière appeared determined to keep the bank out of the spotlight, which may have made sense for much of the time but did, on occasion, create problems of presentation. The bank's role is simply incompatible with a low profile. Its involvement in a controversial project to finance the completion of nuclear facilities in the Ukraine - as a quid pro quo for the closure of Chernobyl - has attracted considerable criticism from environmental campaigners. Inevitably, the bank's loan portfolio suffered considerably from the fallout from Russia's partial debt default in 1998. Even as delegates fly in to London, CEE Bankwatch, a non-governmental organisation with members drawn from countries in central and eastern Europe, is holding a press conference under the heading "EBRD; a decade of misinformation and secrecy". CEE Bankwatch is expected to criticise the bank either for not giving sufficient information or not insisting its clients give sufficient information about projects to allow effective public consultation. Still the bank can put a positive enough gloss on its activities. Over the past decade it has invested or lent some 17.5bn euros (£11bn) of its own money, which it reckons brought a further 44.5bn euros from co-investors. In recent years the EBRD has focused more on providing investment to small and medium sized enterprises - either directly or through specialist banks. Mr Lemierre is anxious to help the build-up of a base of new entrepreneurs who will help drive future economic prosperity. It has been profitable for seven of its 10 years - it made losses in the first two and then again in 1998 when it was hit by the fallout from the Russian debt crisis. As the politicians, bankers and entrepreneurs from east and west gather in London over the next three days, Mr Lemierre will be keen to deliver a forward looking message. Inevitably, speeches from the finance ministers who represent the bank's sovereign shareholders will be peppered with strictures for the bank to operate on "sound banking principles". Mr Lemierre has no problem with that. "It is very good for the bank to respect sound banking principles. You can't built economies by making losses. "We are using taxpayers money and, to talk like a technocrat, the allocation of capital must be done on a sound basis. "If you have a project where you don't understand the financial and economic sustainability, there is a problem. There is something wrong. It would be a big mistake if the bank financed projects that were not sensible. That would send the wrong message." Ensuring the future There is, however, a "but" - and it is a significant one. For Mr Lemierre, making a profit is important in that it underpins the bank's long-term future - ensuring that it continues in operation, helping the transition process in central and eastern Europe. But the bank is not in the business, he says, of profits maximisation. That, he believes, would affect its ability to take risks and so to act effectively. For Mr Lemierre the yardstick is the impact the bank's investments and loans - and the money of private-sector banks and investors it brings on board - has on the economies in which it operates. "What is very interesting about this job is the people. You work with people and for people. You don't work for the balance sheet." Not that the bank sees itself as a soft touch. While it may not look for a bench mark return on its investment, it is very keen on what Mr Lemierre calls conditionality. This is a tricky area and varies from country to country and project to project. "We don't have a tool box with already prepared conditions of choice. We have to look at what will have the best impact, what is credible." Inevitably this is where the politics comes in. For the EBRD is not just about setting repayment conditions. If it is being asked to fund, say, an energy utility or transport system it will want to ensure that the tariff policy is sufficient to sustain the financial commitment. In other words, prices - traditionally set well below market rates under central planning - have to rise. For politicians that is never good news. In broader terms, the bank also has to make an assessment of the progress individual countries are making towards democracy. As Mr Lemierre notes, the EBRD "is the only international financial institution to have to make this assessment". It is also a recipe for the bank to be caught in the crossfire between those who think its democratic mandate is a licence to interfere and those who think it does not interfere enough. The EBRD has ruffled a few feathers in the corporate sector, too. It has had its clashes over areas such as corporate governance and transparency. Again Mr Lemierre sees it as a balance between standards that the EBRD believes are essential if progress is to be made but which must be understood and accepted by those seeking loans or investment. "We must explain, we must have a real policy dialogue with the companies and countries. The conditions must be relevant and adapted to the project involved. If they are not understood they will not be expected. "What we have to say is that we are ready to work with you - but there is no free lunch." Gazprom is a case in point. It would like some $250m (£180m) of the EBRD's money. The bank wants some questions answered first. So far, no answers, so no money, either. Mr Lemierre is committed to the market economy model, not, he says, on ideological grounds but because it is the best way of creating wealth. But he acknowledges that the process of change has brought problems. In the old days of central planning there was a popular joke among workers that "we pretend to work and they pretend to pay us". These days it is no joke, as enterprises close leaving workers and pensioners dependent on safety nets that, at best, are inadequate and at worst nonexistent. Mr Lemierre acknowledges the problem and says it will be one of the messages he will deliver to the AGM. "In the first stage [of transition], which can be long, sometimes you are creating jobs, creating new activities but at other times you are destroying the welfare system. "When you restructure old systems you create poverty, despair and I think in our countries of operation there is a real need to work to address more the questions of poverty, health and education. "We need to make a bridge between the old and new systems. "People must know that when they have huge difficulties, there is some hope. At the end of the day people must know there is a small bank somewhere in London where people are trying to help." Decade of highs and lows May 1990: agreement to establish bank signed April 1991: inauguration of EBRD headquarters, election of Jacques Attali as president June 1991: first loan approved November 1991: first regional office, in Warsaw April 1992: first annual meeting - in Budapest April 1993: scandal over 'extravagance' breaks July 1993: Attali resigns July 1993: Russia small business fund set up Sept 1993: Jacques de Larosière elected president April 1996: shareholders agree to double bank's capital to 20bn euros June 1996: Bosnia Herzegovina becomes EBRD member Dec 1996: bank now has loans in all 26 countries of operation June 1998: Jacques Attali retires September 1998: Horst Köhler becomes president April 2000: Köhler steps down to become head of the IMF July 2000: Jean Lemierre becomes EBRD president

fields.headline: Starsailor steam ahead
fields.standfirst:
Starsailor
Ocean, London
****
fields.trailText:
Starsailor
Ocean, London
****
fields.body:
Getting yourself labelled "the best new band in Britain" carries the same fate-tempting risks as selling your wedding photos to Hello! Premature expectations have capsized so many young hopefuls' careers that you have to feel for Starsailor, who started 2001 with an NME front cover without having released a record. The Jeff Buckley and Radiohead comparisons suffered by every guitar-based group who err on the side of sensitivity does them no favours, either.

That said, Starsailor's James Walsh does possess the extravagant, angelic voice of a Wigan Buckley (whose father, Tim, recorded the 1971 album from which they took their name). How he found himself on the bill of this MTV-sponsored night of Brit testosterone-rock, stuck with warming up for the he-man Stereophonics and Feeder, is one of life's little mysteries. Bemused by the sight of four men buoyantly in touch with their feminine sides, the crowd gave off an air of sensibilities being roundly offended.

Emotions come in two sizes chez Starsailor - large and extra large. The 20-year-old Walsh may one day be mildly embarrassed by songs such as Alcoholic, which artlessly lay it on the line as only the very young can. "Don't you know you've got your daddy's eyes? Daddy was an alcoholic," he crooned with a heartfelt simplicity that will eventually be swallowed up by the tribulations of world tours and difficult seventh albums. But for now he's still wet enough behind the ears to give it his impassioned all.

Alcoholic and the debut single, Fever, set the agenda for their brief set. Hiding behind an acoustic guitar and curtains of hair, Walsh seemed separate from his voice, which rose and swooped almost independently of its owner, who looked as surprised as anyone else by the sound. At the end of Lullabye, he went quietly bananas, crouching and kicking furiously at the mic stand and monitors in a frenzy of release.

The closing Good Souls was a near-rock experience, all four members straining together in a riot of noise that never forgot there was a tune in there. Any resemblance to that other soul-stirring Wigan outfit, the Verve, was presumably intentional. Walsh left the stage with a cherubic smile, knowing his moment is nigh. Best new band in Britain? Well, certainly among the top 10.

fields.headline: Music pirates sink industry
fields.standfirst:
Global record sales drop for first time as US consumers succumb to Napster effect

More internet news
fields.trailText: The impact on the music industry of song swapping websites have taken their toll of sales of recorded music, writes David Teather.
fields.body:
The impact on the music industry of controversial song swapping websites such as Napster became apparent yesterday with figures showing that worldwide sales of recorded music fell last year for the first time.

According to the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry, the market in 2000 was worth $36.9bn, a fall of 1.3% on the previous year. Unit sales of 3.5bn represented a fall of 1.2%.

The biggest decline was in the US where the population is the most internet literate. The biggest dent in the US was the sale of CD singles which had been in gradual decline for the past three years but fell by 39% in 2000. Singles sales globally fell by 14%.

"It's difficult to quantify the effect of free online music but there is little doubt it has had some effect," said a spokeswoman for the IFPI.

"We are not blaming everything on internet piracy but in the US and Canada where internet penetration is very high it has to have had an impact."

The fall, the first since the IFPI began aggregating world wide music sales 10 years ago, underlines the urgency with which the music industry needs to attack the issue of online music piracy. The growth in popularity of websites such as Napster has led to lawsuits for breach of copyright as record companies sought to contain the damage.

Napster is in the process of removing copyrighted material from its site and hopes to reinvent itself as a legitimate business.

The big five music companies including Sony, EMI and Warner Music also recently demonstrated a change in mindset with the launch of their own online distribution joint ventures.

North America was down by 4.8% in unit sales and 1.8% in value. Sales of recorded music have been slowing for the past three years in part because most buyers have now fully replaced their old vinyl collections with CDs. The faltering US economy will also have had an effect.

The MiniDisc appears unlikely to drive the same kind of consumer desire to replace existing collections. The market for that carrier fell by a third during the year, notching up just 700,000 sales and suggesting the format has failed to grip the consumer's imagination.

Recorded music sales in Europe grew by 1.4% in value and 1.3% in volume with the most buoyant markets being Britain and Scandinavia. Britain showed a 3.8% increase in value from unit sales up 6.2%.

France, Germany and Italy all declined, in large part because of an increase in CD copying and piracy.

Industry experts also noted the dearth of new acts on the market last year and the growing influence of music which appeals to younger buyers with lower disposal incomes.

In Japan, another leading market in global terms, the value of sales fell by 4.5% despite a 2.5% rise in volume - attributed to the large number of low-cost compilation albums released during the year.

Sales in other parts of Asia and Latin America fell because of what the IFPI described as the "chronic piracy problem" in the regions.

Global cassette sales fell by 9% in value during the year while vinyl fell by 13.3% despite annecdotal evidence which suggested the format had been undergoing a mini-revival.

CD album sales increased by 2.5% to 2.5bn units.

fields.headline: Ericsson axes 12,000 jobs
fields.trailText: Swedish telecoms group Ericsson today said it would cut 12,000 jobs worldwide.
fields.body:
Swedish telecoms group Ericsson today said it would cut 12,000 jobs worldwide.

The company employs over 2,000 people in the UK, but has not said how many of its British workers will face redundancy.

Ericsson, which has been hit by a slowing telecoms market employs staff at sites in London, Basingstoke, Guildford and Brighton.

A spokesman said more than half of the job cuts would be outside Sweden.

Last month it announced plans to axe 1,200 jobs in Carlton, Nottinghamshire and Scunthorpe

Officials from the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union are planning to hold meetings with Ericsson today.

National officer Bob Shannon said: "We have made it clear to Ericsson that they cannot keep cutting jobs in this country. It is essential that the firm holds its nerve in the face of the current problems."

Details of the cuts came as Ericsson issued a first-quarter trading statement saying it was hit by the general economic downturn and an "abruptly slower telecom sector".

Sales for the period from January to March dropped 5% to £3.8 billion, while income before tax fell 90% from £418 million to £41.5 million.

A spokesman for Ericsson said: "The fact is the market in telecoms is hardly growing at all, and there is no way a company can ignore that fact."

To turn its business around, Ericsson plans to cut its costs by more than £1.4 billion a year, by reducing its selling and administrative expenses as well as cutting its number of offices, consultants and staff.

It will also spend less on IT, and will consolidate its number of research and development locations.

The cuts follow similar announcements by rivals Motorola, Siemens and Marconi.

However, EricssonÍs figures were in contrast to data from the Finish telecoms group Nokia, which showed that profits for its first quarter rose nearly 10%.

webTitle: Ericsson and Sony discuss mobile phone alliance

fields.headline: Ericsson and Sony discuss mobile phone alliance
fields.trailText: Ericsson and Sony are in talks over a possible alliance between their mobile phone businesses, writes <B<Mark Milner.
fields.body:
Ericsson and Sony yesterday confirmed they were in talks over a possible alliance between their mobile phone businesses. They refused, however, to comment on a Japanese report that the two were planning a joint venture which would be based in Britain.

"We are talking about possible cooperation in mobile phones. The talks are at an early stage and no final decisions have been taken," an Ericsson spokesman said yesterday. He declined to comment on how any tie-up between the two might work.

There are suggestions that it might concentrate on research and development for a new generation of high-speed mobile phones.

A statement from Sony said the two companies were "considering the possibility of business cooperation in the portable phone field".

Last year Ericsson sold 40m mobile phones, giving it 10% of the world market, behind Nokia and Motorola. Sony has around 1% of the market.

The Swedish group said some time ago that it was looking at a number of possibilities as it tried to bring its loss-making mobile handset business back into the black and did not rule out a partnership.

Analysts have suggested that the best option would be for the group to sell the business or merge it with that of a strong Asian partner. News of the talks with Sony saw Ericsson shares jump 7% yesterday.

Last month Ericsson announced that later this year it would halt production of mobile phones at two British plants, in Nottinghamshire and Lincolnshire, putting a question mark over some 1,200 jobs.

Last night, Swedish national radio reported that the company would announce a further 10,000 job cuts - about half of them in Sweden - when it reports first-quarter results today.

Just over a month ago the group shocked investors when it said it expected a loss of 4bn-5bn Swedish kronor (£290m -£360m). It blamed a slowdown in orders for telecoms equipment and mobile phones.

With the market primed for a poor first quarter, attention will focus today on the outlook for the next few months and the company's strategy for dealing with the downturn.

Nokia is also expected to report first-quarter results today. The Finnish company's shares put on 2.2% yesterday after days of slight rises. "Big surprises in Nokia's first-quarter result are unlikely, and if the outlook is good the share will hold its recent gains," one Helsinki broker said.

webTitle: CMG results dampen day of euphoria

fields.headline: CMG results dampen day of euphoria
fields.trailText: Punch drunk hi-tech investors looking for a relief from recent batterings had another roller-coaster ride yesterday.
fields.body:
Punch drunk hi-tech investors looking for a relief from recent batterings had another roller-coaster ride yesterday.

Anglo-Dutch information technology services group CMG put an immediate damper on Wednesday's US interest rate cut-induced stock market euphoria with a warning that a squeeze on spending by mobile phone companies would push its telecoms products business into the red in the first half of the year.

There was, however, more optimistic news from SAP, Europe's biggest software group. It turned in better than expected first quarter results, backed by an upbeat assessment of the immediate outlook and raising hopes that the slowdown in spending on software in the US might not be so dramatic in Europe.

CMG said its wireless data solutions business, which specialises in producing the software for text messaging, would post an operating loss of £30m for the first half of the year - after spending a similar amount on research and development.

The group said that after doubling sales last year WDS had got off to a slow start this year as telecoms operators put upgrades of short message services on hold.

CMG said it expected a pick up in WDS's business as operators were forced to upgrade but said it was difficult to be precise over timing. "WDS's performance through the remainder of 2001 will be dependent on a sustained increase in message volumes and consequent licence and systems upgrades," the company said.

The news gave the market a fright with CMG shares falling 83p to 360p in London, after touching a two year low of 337p at one stage.

"It may only be 20% of the business, but it is much more profitable. It is very worrying. The shares have already fallen sharply this year, possibly too much, but it has a rich rating." said one analyst.

Finance director David Robbie said he expected the WDS operation to be profitable in the second half of the year though profitability over the full year would be a "significant challenge".

There was no such caution from SAP. "Despite the difficult market environment, SAP is optimistic about the first three quarters of 2001," the group said in a statement.

Net profits in the first quarter more than doubled to €117m (£72m) on sales up almost 30%, with the group predicting that turnover for the first nine months would be 23% ahead of the same period in 2000.

"It was a very strong set of results, pretty much across the board," according to Daud Khan, an analyst at Merrill Lynch.

SAP's upbeat assessment follows warnings from rivals in the online business to business sector, such as Oracle and Ariba, which revealed that results were being affected by slowing US economic growth, causing a slowdown in software spending.

The worries from the United States had turned SAP's performance into a closely watched indicator.

"All [SAP's] important competitors have revised their outlook for the year while SAP has more or less continued theirs and said things will continue as they have been before," said Sal Oppenheim analyst Alla Gorelova.

SAP underlined its confidence by revealing that unlike some of its competitors which had laid off staff it had increased its head count by about 1,000 since the beginning of the year.

Shares in SAP rose €13.4 to €167.4 in Frankfurt.

"All [SAP's] important competitors have revised their outlook for the year while SAP has more or less continued theirs and said things will continue as they have been before," said Sal Oppenheim analyst Alla Gorelova. SAP underlined its confidence by revealing that unlike some of its competitors which had laid off staff it had increased its head count by about 1,000 since the beginning of the year. Shares in SAP rose €13.4 to €167.4 in Frankfurt.

fields.headline: McDonald's suffers from BSE scare
fields.standfirst:
Fast-food chain's European sales fall 6% but US appetite grows

Special report: the BSE crisis
Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: McDonald's said yesterday that fears over BSE in Europe were continuing to hurt profits at the world's largest fast-food chain.
fields.body:
McDonald's said yesterday that fears over BSE in Europe were continuing to hurt profits at the world's largest fast-food chain.

Jack Greenberg, chairman and chief executive, said the group was "optimistic that lingering concerns about beef will continue to lessen as the year progresses". European consumers started to shun beef last year once BSE spread across the continent.

Shares in McDonald's rose 1% yesterday to $27.78 in spite of a 16% drop in first-quarter earnings. The company has also blamed waning European sales for a rare profits decline three months ago.

Sales in Europe, which ac count for a quarter of the total, fell 6% in the first quarter to $2.18bn. Sales in the US market rose 4% to $4.68bn in spite of the weakening economy.

The 16% fall in profits to $378m, or 29 cents a share, met analysts' expectations, which were lowered last month because of fears about infected beef and the economic outlook.

Mr Greenberg said he was pleased with the company's performance given the "challenges" of the beef crisis as well as comparisons with a strong year last year.

Results should continue to improve by 6 -10% in constant currencies this year after a better second half.

"We continue to proactively educate our European cus tomers about McDonald's high food safety and quality standards, which lead the industry and provide the benchmark for safe food around the world," he said in a statement. "We are also promoting menu variety and value, and the results have been encouraging."

Comparable sales improved in several main European markets in March.

Beef sales have fallen in much of continental Europe as well as Britain since late last year when BSE was found in herds in several countries.

McDonald's, which operates more than 28,000 restaurants in about 120 countries, said little about the outbreaks of foot and mouth disease in parts of Europe, where farmers have been forced to destroy beef herds. That disease is also understood to have had a detrimental impact on beef sales.

Non-US restaurants account for more than 60% of the Illinois-based company's sales and more than 50% of profits.

 The McDonald's branch in the main street of Quebec city's old quarter adopted a policy of anonymity yesterday in anticipation of being a prime target for protesters during this weekend's Summit of the Americas.

McDonald's, frequently a target of the anti-globalisation movement, has removed its familiar red and yellow signboard. French farmer José Bové, who won fame damaging a McDonald's branch in France, has flown in to join the protesters' ranks.

webTitle: Pop review:  The Bush, the Tree and Me

fields.headline: The Bush, the Tree and Me
fields.standfirst:
Band on the Wall, Manchester
**
fields.trailText:
Band on the Wall, Manchester
**
fields.body:
If there is ever a competition for the worst record sleeve of all time, The Bush, the Tree and Me's debut EP for Epic - No Buses - will win hands down. The four-girl band are depicted in a gents' toilet, apparently dying of embarrassment. Flip the sleeve and a young couple - mercifully not members of the band - are pictured having sex on the toilet floor.

Such imagery might be almost understandable if the band were lad mag-friendly rockers, but it bears no relation to the Hertfordshire foursome's textured folk rock. They had nurtured a moderate following on the live circuit, but this seems to be the sort of rubbish they have to deal with now they have signed to a major record label.

In person the girls are more natural. After months of production-line bands, it's a relief to encounter a girl group (with the exception of a male drummer) who aren't stick-thin and haven't been styled like an FHM photoshoot. Comprising a guitarist, a cellist, a singer and a multi-instrumentalist in loose, functional clothing, they have a highly endearing, matey vulnerability. When lead singer Paula Cox's first words to Manchester are ripped apart by feedback, she grins sweetly and says, "A nice note!"

It's easy to understand Epic's attraction to a band who cover all bases from Corrs jauntiness to Alanis Morissette stridency to the acoustic purity of indie faves the Sundays. Cox has at least six voices, ranging from a delicate romanticism to a ballsy shriek that would terrify PJ Harvey. This early in their career, it's good that that the band can't be pigeonholed but it also means their set is confusing, and songs range from the moderately glorious to the ghastly; one is a bit Astrid Gilberto, another like Jane Siberry backed by Elvis's 1950s band. One fears for the psychological state of their "typical" fan.

The songs that sound like the Sundays, such as Peace of Mind, fare best, but elsewhere even the raven-haired singer covers her ears to fend off another discordant clarinet solo. There's real promise here but the Bush desperately need to take a firm hand and sort out a direction. They should start with their next record sleeve.

 The Bush, the Tree and Me play the Old Fire Station, Bournemouth (01202 503888), on Wednesday and the Scala, London N1 (020-7833 2022), on Thursday.

fields.headline: RLPO/Hughes
fields.standfirst:
Philharmonic Hall, Liverpool
**
fields.trailText:
Philharmonic Hall, Liverpool
**
fields.body:
Everyone has their off days, and geniuses are no exception. Some of our most venerated composers have proudly presented the world with pieces only they could love. The works remain safely in hiding until someone comes along to champion them, at which point their failings become glaringly evident.

Tchaikovsky's Second Piano Concerto is one such piece. Everyone knows Tchaikovsky must have written more than one piano concerto, since the popular B flat minor is always referred to as "the First". Yet who has stopped to wonder about the possible Second, or even speculated about the existence of others? In fact, Tchaikovsky wrote three piano concertos. So why don't we hear the other two more often?

With regard to the Second, the answer is that, despite a solo part of irresistible flamboyance and virtuosity, the orchestral writing - which also means the thematic material itself - is as dead as a dodo. The orchestral introduction alone is stultifying. Yet Lilya Zilberstein and the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra played as though it was the most exciting piece in the world. Zilberstein played down the first movement's more garish moments, occasionally helping things along with dynamic shaping, in wise contravention of Tchaikovsky's instructions.

While this work doesn't show soloist or orchestra to best advantage, technique like Zilberstein's can go a long way; coupled with unflaggingly dedicated orchestral playing (in particular from leader Thelma Handy and Jonathan Aasgaard), Tchaikovsky's ugly duckling came very close to becoming a beautiful swan.

If Tchaikovsky seemed over-indulgent towards some works, he was harshly self-critical with regard to his symphonies. Despite his private misgivings, the Fifth Symphony is undeniably a masterpiece, albeit one that demands sensitive handling if it is not to sound overblown and hollow. Where Tchaikovsky treads an uneasy path between manic over-confidence and inner collapse, conductor Owain Arwel Hughes so favoured the confident side that the brashness quickly wore very thin - going some way to explaining why the composer felt nauseated by his symphony after the premiere, damning it as insincere and horrible. Anyone not previously familar with it might well have formed the same impression.

fields.headline: CGNU profits in stakeholder style
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: CGNU, Britain's largest insurer, gave the government some cheer yesterday by announcing that sales of stakeholder-style plans contributed to a 69% jump in individual pension sales in the first three months of this year.
fields.body:
CGNU, Britain's largest insurer, gave the government some cheer yesterday by announcing that sales of stakeholder-style plans contributed to a 69% jump in individual pension sales in the first three months of this year.

Low-cost stakeholder pensions, aimed at those without access to a pension scheme, went on sale two weeks ago but in the run-up to their arrival many life insurers were selling so-called pre-stakeholder pensions, offering broadly the same terms.

CGNU, created by the merger of CGU and Norwich Union 11 months ago, said the figures showed it was well placed for a leading position in the stakeholder market.

The group's shares gained 31p to 994p after it said worldwide new life and pensions sales in the three months to March 31 rose 23% to £3.3bn. But jittery stock markets had caused a 46% drop in sales of investment products in the US, Australia and Canada.

In the Netherlands, investment sales slumped to £15m from £371m in the same period last year, reflecting "extreme volatility in investment markets, which resulted in negative consumer sentiment to equity-backed products".

Britain fared a lot better, with sales of investment products such as Isas up 25% and record life sales achieved - up 22% to £2.2bn.

The group is likely to have picked up business in recent months as a result of Equitable Life's troubles.

A spokesman said CGNU believed independent financial advisers and banks would be the main distribution channels for stakeholder pensions.

"We are the leading IFA provider and, together with our bancassurance relationship with the Royal Bank of Scotland, are well placed to achieve significant and profitable stakeholder sales," the company added.

Chief executive Richard Harvey said: "Despite volatile equity markets, which created difficult conditions for retail investment sales, our increased distribution capability produced record new business sales."

webTitle: But it's bad news for big borrowers and small savers

fields.headline: But it's bad news for big borrowers and small savers
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: If Britain really has returned to an era of low inflation it would be good news for those on fixed incomes, but bad for anyone tempted to borrow extravagantly.
fields.body:
If Britain really has returned to an era of low inflation it would be good news for those on fixed incomes, but bad for anyone tempted to borrow extravagantly.

In the days of double-digit inflation, pensioners saw their money buy less each year, while homeowners could expect to see the real value of their debt fall as a result of rising prices. Investors expected high returns on their savings accounts and endowment policies, while employees grew accustomed to hefty wage increases.

Evidence that times have changed came last week in a warning from the UK's financial watchdog, Sir Howard Davies, that investors should not expect unrealistically high returns in an era of low inflation and low interest rates. Sir Howard, chairman of the financial services authority, said headline inflation was expected to remain at around the government's target rate of 2.5% for the foreseeable future, so consumers must "adjust their expectations". He added: "Savers need to understand that low inflation means lower nominal returns."

Britain has had long periods of low inflation before. For most of its history, inflation has only occurred during wars, with the price level actually lower at the start of the first world war in 1914 than it was at the time of the Battle of Waterloo 99 years earlier. But during the 1970s and 1980s inflation rose sharply on three separate occasions, leading to the belief that it was ever-present.

Some homebuyers relying on endowment policies to pay off their mortgages at the end of 25 years have already been given a glimpse of what the new era means. Policy-holders have received letters telling them that low inflation and low interest rates mean that the returns may not be sufficient to provide a pot of money big enough to pay off the loan. They may have to top up their payments or make up the shortfall when their policy matures.

Wage bargainers are also coming to grips with annual pay awards well below those routinely granted in the 1970s and 1980s. Earnings, even when swelled by City bonuses, were 5% higher in the three months ending in February than they were a year earlier. Settlements in both manufacturing and services are running at a lower level.

Mortgage lenders are also beginning to adopt a more cautious approach to people seeking to borrow. In the days when house prices could be expected to rise rapidly year after year, a bank or building could lend, safe in the knowledge that even if it had to repossess a property it could be sold for a profit. In a low-inflation country, the risk of a loan turning sour is greater for both borrower and lenders.
