fields.headline: Welsh put the least aside
fields.trailText: The Welsh may be the weakest link, according to TV quiz show host Anne Robinson's controversial comments in a recent TV interview. But it seems that the Welsh are definitely the weakest link when it comes to savings, according to a new survey from online broker Halifax Share Dealing.
fields.body:
The Welsh may be the weakest link, according to TV quiz show host Anne Robinson's controversial comments in a recent TV interview. But it seems that the Welsh are definitely the weakest link when it comes to savings, according to a new survey from online broker Halifax Share Dealing.

Researchers quizzed 2,000 people on their money habits. And those that didn't simply reject the interviewer's questions with a Robinson-style goodbye owned up to an average £7,030 savings nest-egg.

But in Wales the figure was much lower. The savings shirkers from Cardiff to Colwyn Bay have just £4,320 a head stashed away in the savings bank, according to the survey. And just over one in three has up to £5,000 squirreled away.

Yet just across the border in the West Midlands, Britain's best savers sit in splendour. Birmingham folk claim to have average savings of £10,830 - more than twice the Welsh average.

The south-east is traditionally the home of stockbrokers and the better-off. But the Halifax probe presumably found very few of them at home - the average savings for this area came out at a surprising £8,900.

Mancunians and the north-west - including all that legendary Cheshire wealth - and East Midlanders came next with £8,530 and £7,710 respectively.

Londoners fell below average - perhaps because they have the most expensive housing in the UK with mortgage bills to match - with a below-average £6,890.

And if the Scots do have as many bawbees locked away as legend claims, then they are also keeping the traditionally Caledonian attitude of never discussing their wealth with strangers - let alone their family or friends. They admit to savings per head of just £5,010.

Overall, just one in five of those questioned confessed to being "savings free". And one in 11 owned up to a rainy day nest-egg topping £20,000.

fields.headline: McCartney wealth put at £713m
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: "I don't care too much for money" he once sang - but, for someone so disinterested in the filthy lucre, Paul McCartney has done rather well.
fields.body:
"I don't care too much for money" he once sang - but, for someone so disinterested in the filthy lucre, Paul McCartney has done rather well.

The former Beatle has seen his bank balance swell by £163m in the past year to cement his reputation as Britain's richest musician. With an estimated personal fortune of £713m, the singer-songwriter is worth nearly £300m more than Lord Andrew Lloyd-Webber - his closest rival in the rich musician stakes - and almost £600m more than his former surviving bandmates, George Harrison and Ringo Starr.

The details of Sir Paul's wealth will be published this weekend in the Sunday Times Rich List 2001, alongside details of the nation's richest landowners, entrepreneurs and sports stars.

Last year the list - which takes into account all identifiable wealth, including land, property, art, racehorses, shares in any quoted companies, and in the case of musicians, royalties - put the 58-year-old in top place with an estimated fortune of £550m.

But his wealth soared this year due to the £138m he inherited from his wife Linda, who died in April 1998, and sales of the Beatles 1 album, which had sold 12m copies by the end of last year, and the launch of the anthology book on the Beatles.

Royalties - huge in comparison with current stars, many of whom do not own the rights to words and music - and his fiscal prudence have also contributed. "McCartney is quite canny with his money, he doesn't spend a lot," explained Ian Coxon, the list's editor.

The multimillionaire musician's increased wealth now puts him 36th in the overall list of Britain's richest 1,000 people.

The richest female musician - and the sixth richest musician overall - is Madonna, who qualifies for the first time this year after her marriage in December to Guy Ritchie, the British director. The list places their combined fortune at £180m, with the majority of the wealth believed to come from the pop queen.

With the average age of those on the list being 53, the Rolling Stones' Mick Jagger, 57 and worth £150m, and Keith Richards, also 57 and worth £130m, remain securely in the top 10, while over-50-year-olds Phil Collins, George Harrison, Ringo Starr, David Bowie, the Bee Gees, Tom Jones and Eric Clapton make up much of the top 20.

Among sportsmen, world heavyweight boxing champion Lennox Lewis tops the list, with a fortune of £75m and an overall position of 455, while featherweight Naseem Hamed tops the list for wealthiest sportsman aged 30 or under with wealth of £30m.

Former England skipper Alan Shearer, worth £17m, comes second in the youthful rich stakes, followed by David Beckham - worth £30m with his wife, Victoria, but personally worth £12m.

But his wealth soared this year due to the £138m he inherited from his wife Linda, who died in April 1998, and sales of the Beatles 1 album, which had sold 12m copies by the end of last year, and the launch of the anthology book on the Beatles. Royalties - huge in comparison with current stars, many of whom do not own the rights to words and music - and his fiscal prudence have also contributed. "McCartney is quite canny with his money, he doesn't spend a lot," explained Ian Coxon, the list's editor. The multimillionaire musician's increased wealth now puts him 36th in the overall list of Britain's richest 1,000 people. The richest female musician - and the sixth richest musician overall - is Madonna, who qualifies for the first time this year after her marriage in December to Guy Ritchie, the British director. The list places their combined fortune at £180m, with the majority of the wealth believed to come from the pop queen. With the average age of those on the list being 53, the Rolling Stones' Mick Jagger, 57 and worth £150m, and Keith Richards, also 57 and worth £130m, remain securely in the top 10, while over-50-year-olds Phil Collins, George Harrison, Ringo Starr, David Bowie, the Bee Gees, Tom Jones and Eric Clapton make up much of the top 20. Among sportsmen, world heavyweight boxing champion Lennox Lewis tops the list, with a fortune of £75m and an overall position of 455, while featherweight Naseem Hamed tops the list for wealthiest sportsman aged 30 or under with wealth of £30m. Former England skipper Alan Shearer, worth £17m, comes second in the youthful rich stakes, followed by David Beckham - worth £30m with his wife, Victoria, but personally worth £12m. fields.headline: A heartfelt tale of Cape Town's homeless
fields.standfirst:
Suip!
Tricycle, London
**
fields.trailText:
Suip!
Tricycle, London
**
fields.body:
It is almost impossible to criticise this play about the lives of Cape Town's homeless people of colour, commonly known as Bergies, without feeling completely heartless. Like a great many of the shows that have come out of South Africa over the past 25 years it is as much to do with politics, compassion and social inclusion as it is about theatre.

In the apartheid era these productions came to London and we cheered not because they were necessarily great theatre - although a few, such as Woza Albert were - but because we wanted to assent to the struggle of the South African people. That was then, but the shows keep coming, and while the issues they deal with are equally pressing, it gets harder to make excuses for them when they fail as theatre. Sitting through Suip!, the overwhelming emotion I felt was guilt - that I didn't feel moved, just slightly irritated by its raggedness.

The piece certainly provides a useful history lesson in how poor farm workers were paid part of their wages in cheap wine - turning them into alcoholics - and how when the ANC came to power its well-meaning attempt to stop this practice lead to thousands losing their jobs because the landowners didn't want to pay them more wages. Many of these ex-workers flocked to Cape Town and took up residence on the streets.

All this the play tells well, but it is less successful when it tries to personalise the history lesson through the stories of Shaun, Rose, Koffie and Sophia, who are supposedly putting on a play about their lives, watched from a distance by the slightly sinister Boy.

The actors are all terrific, but perhaps part of the problem is that they are actors. The play grew out of a student drama school project and developed through talking to real Bergies and improvising. So it falls somewhere between genuine verbatim theatre, in which actors speak only the words of those interviewed, and the kind of social theatre in which the participants are the dispossessed and speak directly of their own experience.

Without these touchstones this heartfelt, well-meaning play is in danger of becoming manipulative. It lets the audience off the hook, by making us feel better for having sympathised, without having to get off our backsides and do anything.

 Until May 12. Box office: 020-7328 1000.

webTitle: O'Leary lines up a final surprise

fields.headline: O'Leary lines up a final surprise
fields.trailText: David O'Leary gives a hint as to how he will tackle the upcoming semi-final against Valencia.
fields.body:
Leeds United's players stand to earn in excess of £100,000 each from their European odyssey, but the perks of the job may be scant consolation unless they remember one of football's oldest adages. After all, nobody recalls the losing semi-finalists in any knock-out competition.

Considering that their season has been enacted simultaneously on the football field and in the courtroom, David O'Leary and his players are entitled to feel a certain amount of smugness that after eight tempestuous months they will represent the Premiership in next month's semi-finals.

Yet the Champions League can be an unforgiving arena, and the weight of anti-climax should Leeds stumble against Valencia would eclipse any of the remarkable achievements of O'Leary's side so far this season.

A downbeat tone, perhaps, but if Leeds are to prevail where Arsenal failed by eliminating the Spaniards, the fear of disappointment should be every bit as motivational as the potential for glory.

As O'Leary said yesterday: "To have got this far, having started out in the qualifiers and with all the difficulties that have plagued our season, if we were to go out now it would be heart-breaking."

Writing off Leeds has been a perilous occupation all season but it has become increasingly apparent that there has been a shift in opinion. After being eliminated by Valencia on Tuesday it was noticeable that Arsène Wenger and Patrick Vieira both stated that Leeds should be considered as favourites to reach the final.

Leeds, however, relish their role as perennial underdogs. "People accuse me of being a put-down manager when I say I'm amazed we have got this far," added O'Leary. "But, sorry, I'm just telling it like it is. When you look at all the great sides in this competition I never thought we would still be involved in April and May, not in a million years."

Valencia are unbeaten in their past 17 European matches at the Mestalla stadium but are prone to bouts of travel sickness and, in all probability, Leeds's fortunes will be determined by their ability to break down Hector Cuper's side at Elland Road on May 2.

It will be vital that O'Leary's team travel to Spain six days later with a first-leg lead and, perhaps even more important, having denied their opponents an away goal.

"I think the secret will be to defend well at Elland Road and hope they give us a chance at the other end," said the goalkeeper Nigel Martyn. "We knocked out Deportivo because we got a good start at home and we will need a similar platform against Valencia."

Should that go according to plan, Leeds would then have to muster the same sort of defensive resolution they displayed in their last semi-final, against Johan Cruyff's Barcelona 26 years ago.

Above all, that occasion will be remembered for a classic away performance in which Leeds, protecting a 2-1 first-leg win, reached the final courtesy of Peter Lorimer's goal in a 1-1 draw at the Nou Camp despite Gordon McQueen's sending-off reducing them to 10 men for the final 20 minutes.

It has been 35 years, however, since Leeds won in Spain and they have already lost three times to Liga sides this season. But though it might be dangerous to feel any sense of premature triumphalism, who would bet against them now?

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Liverpool 1 v 0 Barcelona
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Liverpool: Westerveld, Babbel, Henchoz, Hyypia, Carragher, Gerrard, Hamann, McAllister, Smicer, Heskey, Owen. Subs: Arphexad, Ziege, Fowler, Murphy, Berger, Vignal, Wright.

Barcelona: Reina, Reiziger, de Boer, Puyol, Petit, Luis Enrique, Cocu, Guardiola, Overmars, Rivaldo, Kluivert. Subs: Dutruel, De la Pena, Xavi, Gabri, Dani, Simao, Zenden.

Referee: Urs Meier (Switzerland)

1 Liverpool continue the hunt for their first European trophy in 16 years searching for goals on judgement night at Anfield. Liverpool kick off and immediately launch the ball long to Heskey.

2 Smicer finds Heskey on the edge of the area, who plays it out wide to Babbel, but his right-wing cross fails to find Owen in the box.

4 Liverpool win a free-kick following a Cocu block on Smicer on halfway.

6 A Babbel cross puts the 19-year-old Barcelona 'keeper Reina under pressure and he is forced to punch the ball out for a corner. McAllister's corner-kick comes to nothing.

7 Rivaldo's 35-yard drive is tipped over the bar by Sander Westerveld.

10 Smicer releases Michael Owen in the penalty area, but the 21-year-old's first touch lets him down, allowing Reina to smother the ball.

14 Rivaldo's ball from the left flank just eludes Kluivert, as the Dutchman got clear of the Liverpool defence.

15 Hyypia rises to meet a Babbel corner, but his clean connection is mis-directed.

16 Smicer's header from Heskey's left-wing cross brings a comfortable save from Reina. Liverpool's best chance to date.

18 Hamann's long ball into the box is controlled on the chest by Heskey, but his shot on the turn trickled wide.

19 Gerrard's free-kick - awarded for a foul on Owen on the edge of the area - is blasted over the bar.

24 A pulsating opening at Anfield that couldn't be further from the dreadful fayre served up in the Nou Camp two weeks ago. There have been chances for both teams in an open, end-to-end game, which promises goals.

26 A deep-lying Rivaldo is causing problems for Liverpool, and it seems only a matter of time before his probing passes to Overmars and Kluivert find their target.

28 A left-foot Petit shot from the edge of the area - he was played in by Luis Enrique - drifts harmlessly wide.

32 Luis Enrique shaves the Liverpool post with left-foot shot from the edge of the area, after great work by Overmars.

34 A great tackle from Hyypia on the edge of his own penalty area prevents Kluivert shooting from a menacing position. Barcelona are enjoying a period of prolonged possession with Liverpool struggling to contain their pace and movement.

36 De Boer heads a Gary McAllister corner behind but the referee awards a goal-kick, much to Emile Heskey's frustration.

40 Liverpool appeal for a penalty after Gerrard goes down in the box but the referee waves play on. The chance was made by the youngster himself, as his great touch took him past Luis Enrique and he ghosted into the penalty area.

43 A penalty is awarded to Liverpool after Kluivert handles the ball from a McAllister corner.

44 GOAL The former Scottish international strokes the ball home from the spot, placing it perfectly in the top-right hand corner.

Half-time: Liverpool 1 Barcelona 0 Gary McAllister, fresh from scoring the equaliser in the Merseyside derby, gave Liverpool a tremendous boost on the stroke of the interval after a first-half of great quality. There were chances for both sides in the opening period, but Kluivert's error gave the home-side the break they needed, setting up a mouth-watering second-half. With the onus now on Barcelona - who have come from behind to draw their last two games - to attack, anything could happen.

46 Barcelona start the second period and immediately put pressure on Liverpool. Patrick Kluivert shoots across the face of goal, with Luis Enrique unmarked six-yards out. A sign of things to come?

49 Liverpool are on the back foot at the start of the second period and the game is being played almost solely in their half.

50 Babbel goes down in the Barcelona half after a strong challenge by Petit. Liverpool win the free-kick and Babbel gets back on his feet.

54 Gerrard's right-wing cross is knocked down by Heskey, only for Reiziger to clear the danger. Once again Barcelona - and their 19-year-old 'keeper Reina - show themselves to be vulnerable to the high ball.

55 A lucky escape for Liverpool following a Westerveld howler. The Dutch 'keeper miscued a regulation clearance, but the ball just went out of play before the onrushing Kluivert could deposit it into the empty net.

56 Heskey's left-foot shot on the turn brings a sharp save from Reina.

59 Substitution Portugese international midfielder Simao replaces defender Reiziger as Barcelona look to attack.

61 Simao is booked in his third minute on the pitch for pulling back Smicer as Liverpool launch a counter-attack.

62 Substitution Liverpool make their first change with Patrick Berger coming on for Michael Owen.

65 Gerrard launches a screaming right-foot drive from 40-yards out which just goes past the far post.

70 The Anfield crowd show their appreciation as their heroes edge closer to their third cup-final of the season. It is far from over yet though, and Barcelona only require a single goal to send them through.

71 Kluivert heads a Luis Enrique cross over the bar, as Barcelona create their first opening for fifteen minutes. The Liverpool defence, expertly marshalled by Hyypia and Henchoz, is holding up well and clear-cut chances are eluding Barcelona.

74 Substitution Spanish international Dani replaces Marc Overmars as Barcelona move to three upfront for the final push.

76 A great ball by Petit finds Simao in the Liverpool penalty area, but he is pressured out by Henchoz.

77 Substitution Danny Murphy replaces Steven Gerrard as Liverpool make their second change. Barcelona's dominace of possesion is now almost total and they seem set to lay siege to the Liverpool goal for the final 10 minutes.

80 Substitution Club-captain Robbie Fowler comes on to a huge ovation in place of Vladimir Smicer.

82 Liverpool win a free-kick near Barcelona's right by-line as De Boer fouls Heskey. McAllister's free-kick is punched away by Reina and Hamann's 25-yard drive sails over.

84 Liverpool, cheered on by a rousing home crowd, are defending in increasing numbers and Fowler is required to help out, clearing a Luis Enrique corner. Simao narrowly avoids a second booking for a lungeing foul on McAllister.

86 Westerveld is booked for time-wasteing as the clock runs down and Liverpool move closer to glory.

89 Barcelona are battling on in search of an eqaliser - which would in effect be a winner - as four minutes of stoppage time are announced by the fourth official.

90 Luis Enrique launches a long ball into the box, firmly repelled by the towering Hyypia. The Finnish international has been a commanding presence all evening and his great efforts look like being rewarded.

92 Kluivert finds Dani by the by-line, but he is ushered into touch by Henchoz.

93 "You'll Never Walk Alone" reverberates around Anfield as the Liverpool fans sense their triumph. Robbie Fowler fires over from long range.

Full-time: Liverpool 1 Barcelona 0 Gary McAllister's first-half penalty is enough to take Liverpool to their ninth European final and first in 16 years. The 1-0 aggregate victory was built on towering defensive performance, epitomized by the efforts of Sami Hyypia and Stephane Henchoz, whose team have conceeded just one goal over six games against Roma, Porto and Barcelona. Liverpool will face Alaves in the Uefa Cup Final in Dortmund on May 16.

fields.headline: Fungus the far east bogeyman
fields.standfirst: China and Japan are squaring up over the humble mushroom, reports Jonathan Watts, and neither side looks likely to back down
fields.trailText: Tokyo dispatch: China and Japan are squaring up over the humble mushroom, reports Jonathan Watts, and neither side looks likely to back down
fields.body:
The first spores of a fungal trade war are being cultivated in the far east as Japan prepares to restrict imports of shiitake mushrooms from China.

Silly as it may sound, the dispute over this traditional ingredient in the Japanese diet is no laughing matter in this part of the world.

According to a flurry of anxious media reports and concerned analyses, Tokyo's refusal to make room for the mushrooms threatens dining habits, supermarket prices and the livelihood of thousands of impoverished Chinese farmers.

Even more worryingly, diplomats and economists warn that it could herald a rise of protectionism in Asia and worsen the already strained relations between the region's two powers, Tokyo and Beijing.

Shiitake are among the most popular of the many varieties of mushrooms eaten by fungi-mad Japanese diners. Each year, families and restaurants stew, fry and grill hundreds of tons of these brown umbrella-shaped vegetables. Battered shiitake tempura is a particular favourite.

Until recently, only domestically produced shiitake were considered of sufficient quality to satisfy picky Japanese consumers even though the prices were high as a result of agricultural protection and inefficiency.

But from the middle of the last decade, Japanese trading companies began encouraging Chinese farmers to use Japanese spores and modern cultivation methods, which rapidly closed the quality gap.

The policy was a huge success. In Fujian province, where the humid mountaineous climate was perfect for the mushrooms, farming families struck shiitake gold. From eking out an existence on $120 per head, they could suddenly earn 10 times that amount by growing mushrooms for export to Japan.

Not surprisingly, the same techniques have been applied for straw mushrooms, uckahoe, lentinus adodes, white jelly fungus and hedgehog fungus and expensive Matsudake mushrooms - which can sell for up to 30 pounds each in Japan.

As a result, from almost nowhere, China became a global mushroom giant. According to the Chinese Edible Fungi Association, 5.2 million tons of mushrooms - or more than half the world total - are now grown in the country, creating an export industry worth $2.4 billion.

Japanese consumers have been more than snap them up. With Chinese shiitake selling at less than half the price of home-grown produce, imports of the mushrooms last year, rose by 70 percent to 42,057 tons.

Understandably, Japan's 30,000 shiitake farmers fear annihilation. With the support of the politically powerful Agriculture Cooperatives Group, which boasts 8 million members, they have demanded protection from the government. Similar calls have been made by two other rural industries that have been hit by Chinese imports: scallion and rush matting producers.

That the adversary is China has no doubt helped their cause. Japan is - at least in theory - an advocate of global free trade, which is unsurprising as it is a huge net exporter, mainly of manufactured products to industrialised Western nations. Despite frequent complaints of dumping and invisible trade barriers, it has never threatened overt trade restrictions before.

But China is different. Last year, Japan notched up a 2.7 trillion yen trade deficit with China, the biggest it has ever had with any foreign country. Diplomatic relations are also strained as a result of differing interpretations of the war.

So for the first time since Japan joined the World Trade Organisation, it is considering use of a temporary "safeguard" restriction allowed by the institution's members. If it goes ahead, the top tariff rate for shiitake will jump from 4.3 per cent to 266 per cent for 200 days. Similarly prohibitive rates would be levied on scallions and rush mats.

Once released, however, the spores of protection could spread much further. There are already calls in Japan for tariffs to be imposed on Chinese towels and eels. Beijing has hinted that it may retaliate by restricting imports of Japanese electronic goods.

With economies around the world slowing and trade liberalisation talks stuck in a rut, who can be sure the fungus will stop in Asia?

Silly as it may sound, the dispute over this traditional ingredient in the Japanese diet is no laughing matter in this part of the world. According to a flurry of anxious media reports and concerned analyses, Tokyo's refusal to make room for the mushrooms threatens dining habits, supermarket prices and the livelihood of thousands of impoverished Chinese farmers. Even more worryingly, diplomats and economists warn that it could herald a rise of protectionism in Asia and worsen the already strained relations between the region's two powers, Tokyo and Beijing. Shiitake are among the most popular of the many varieties of mushrooms eaten by fungi-mad Japanese diners. Each year, families and restaurants stew, fry and grill hundreds of tons of these brown umbrella-shaped vegetables. Battered shiitake tempura is a particular favourite. But from the middle of the last decade, Japanese trading companies began encouraging Chinese farmers to use Japanese spores and modern cultivation methods, which rapidly closed the quality gap. The policy was a huge success. In Fujian province, where the humid mountaineous climate was perfect for the mushrooms, farming families struck shiitake gold. From eking out an existence on $120 per head, they could suddenly earn 10 times that amount by growing mushrooms for export to Japan. Not surprisingly, the same techniques have been applied for straw mushrooms, uckahoe, lentinus adodes, white jelly fungus and hedgehog fungus and expensive Matsudake mushrooms - which can sell for up to 30 pounds each in Japan. fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Richard
fields.trailText: I am not sure of your itinery in South America but here's what I did in case it's of use to you.
fields.body:
Hi Sue,

I am not sure of your itinery in South America but here's what I did in case it's of use to you.

I landed in Santiago and would recommend the old market where you can wander around and get the most amazing seafood meals. Look out for a shell fish the size of a golf ball... delicious.

I went to Valparaiso... hopeless, but really liked Vena Del Mar. Just a bit further north of there was beautiful... good surf, pretty pelicans, great food (with music). The bus ride is really easy, even with my appalling Spanish getting me off the bus at the wrong place!

From there I headed north to Atacama. I found the most amazing place called San Pedro di Atacama - the "tourist centre" for heading off to Bolivia or Peru. It's not that busy and everyone is very friendly. All the hostels are good (allegedly), mine was great, run by a Croatian and called, I think, The Sontek.

I got a tour from there with Colque Travel on a trip to Bolivia. There I found that I suffered very badly from altitude sickness, probably because I didn't spend enough time acclimatising.

I then got a bus to the Peruvian border (Tourbus) and a cab into Peru (sounds crazy, but it is the easiest way). Then I took another bus to Arequipe and did a fantastic trip which included the Colca Canyon, Cusco, and the Inca trail to Macchu Pichu. In some ways that was the highlight of the whole journey around the world. I sat at the Sun Gate and burst into tears!

If you are going anywhere near anywhere htat I have mentioned, give a shout and I will rack my brain for more relevant info.

Good luck.

fields.headline: Come in Cardinal Jedi - your church needs you
fields.trailText: The current internet appeals for those taking part in the forthcoming census to reply to the enquiry anachronistically demanding to know what religion they follow by replying 'Jedi' is the only cheerful religious news we've had lately.
fields.body:
The current internet appeals for those taking part in the forthcoming census to reply to the enquiry anachronistically demanding to know what religion they follow by replying 'Jedi' is the only cheerful religious news we've had lately. The concept is quite wonderful. Apparently, if more than 10,000 people claim to be of the Jedi persuasion, at the next census it will have official status and be offered automatically as one of the options alongside the more traditional faiths.

Should such a jolly event happen, perhaps Blair, and his repugnant campaign to impel the taxpayer to stump up for sectarian education, will mean that a state-funded Jedi school may appear in your area. The thought of middle-class dads dressing in brown robes like Liam Neeson trying to persuade their local Jedi headmaster that they are, and have always been followers of the Force, just to get little Jeremy a place in a school where they still teach reading and writing, is a sobering one. At least the 3.30pm double-parked four by fours at the gate won't be a problem as mum, or Yoda as she will like to be known, will simply threaten to lift the offending vehicles out of the way with the power of her mind.

Sadly, not all religious matters lately have had such amusement value. In fact, for a secular country, pesky old religion and its wicked and wanton ways, is pretty hard to avoid. The Nolan report is sadly not the title of an RTE daytime chat show hosted by the lovely Irish singing sisters, but a toothless 35-page document that flaps about like the robes of a priest running from the vice squad.

The report is in answer to the seemingly endless revelations and allegations of child abuse by Catholic clergy that have been slowly and horribly unravelling since the last set of useless guidelines were suggested back in 1994. But no need to get too excited. Unsurprisingly, all Nolan's recommendations are just that. Recommendations. His stating the bleeding obvious, that this corrupt, hypocritical and decadent institution needs grown-ups from the secular world to try and prevent any more children suffering at its hands, is merely there to be taken up on a voluntary basis by the church.

To précis for those of you too busy to plough through it, what it says is, "Aaaargh! Stop shagging children you bunch of perverts. Or else ... well nothing, actually." Some highlights include the fabulously original idea, just a recommendation remember, that if an abusing priest has had more than a 12-month sentence passed on him, he should be laicised. (That's fired to you and me.) So are we to assume then, that if some charming chap gets off with a mere six-month sentence for fiddling with the altar boys, he'll still have the future possibility of gainful employment administering wise words and advice to his eager flock?

Such a creature, who will have ruined the life of a young person forever, will theoretically be able to sit and lecture young couples about their marriage and sex lives, visit families and advise them on how to bring up their children, impose upon old people, sick people, desperate people and lonely people, his views on the meaning of life. It's quite bad enough that such a job is already done by perfectly innocent well-meaning men who, due to the quite wicked requirement of celibacy, have absolutely no idea at all what they're talking about. But the idea of a child-abusing, lying criminal doing it is chilling.

The most unpleasant aspect of the report is the respectful tone it adopts in dealing with the whole mess. There's little point in making polite suggestions to an institution whose arrogant behaviour both domestically and globally is so tainted with hypocrisy and duplicity. The only way to protect children is to introduce water-tight, compulsory legislation that is not up for any kind of debate among a bunch of bishops and cardinals, but must be enforced whether they like it or not. Since this is clearly not going to happen, it's worth keeping it in mind while mulling over the church versus state schools nonsense.

At least, if we all do the decent thing on our census forms, future Jedi schools will be safe for our children. Even though the knights are also tortured celibate men who wear daft robes, there has been no recorded incident of Obi Wan Kenobi ever trying to get under Luke Skywalker's tunic.

How to talk to celebs

Andy Green, the man who bafflingly became tongue-tied when forced to shake hands with Tony Blair, is now appealing to people for ideas about what to say when meeting a celebrity. This is surely round the wrong way. If properly and formally introduced, the onus is most certainly on the celebrity to make the effort, instead of standing there like a twerp.

Why should Green have made the opening gambit when Blair could have started a perfectly decent conversation, perhaps about decking in gardens or germ warfare? It only becomes an issue if a stranger approaches a celebrity unasked and is forced to speak first.

Here's an example. Say the celebrity is D-list, someone you can't quite place, like celebrity chef Gordon Ramsay, recently heard shooting his mouth off about coming up to educate us Scots about how to run restaurants. Simply approach and say: "Are you who I think you are?" He will doubtless snap: "Yeah". You are then at liberty to say: "Ah yes, I thought you were a complete prick."

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Hettie
fields.trailText: Zanzibar was amazing - in a nutshell, Jambiani on the east coast is stunning although at low tide its quite a walk to the sea, Nungwi on the north has incredibly cheap accomodation and the tide never really goes out far (yummy seafood too) - and you can arrange trips from Stone Town to swim with the dolphins on the south coast.
fields.body:
Dear Sam,

Your trip sounds absolutely fantastic... I spent six months in Tanzania in 1996 and loved it. I know things have probably changed now, but if you were planning on climbing Mount Kilimanjaro (which I really recommend) the cheapest deals at the time were found in the Moshi Hotel. Also the Newcastle Hotel (although v. basic) in Moshi made a nice change from the youth hostel - although the YH does have a swimming pool!

Zanzibar was amazing - in a nutshell, Jambiani on the east coast is stunning although at low tide its quite a walk to the sea, Nungwi on the north has incredibly cheap accomodation and the tide never really goes out far (yummy seafood too) - and you can arrange trips from Stone Town to swim with the dolphins on the south coast.

Hope some of the above may be useful; either way hope you continue having an amazing time.

fields.headline: United mystery man revealed
fields.standfirst: Click here to see how the players reacted
fields.trailText: The mystery man who lined up with Manchester United before their Champions League match with Bayern Munich can now be revealed. His name is Karl Power and he lives in Droylsden in Manchester.
fields.body:
The mystery man who lined up with Manchester United before their Champions League match with Bayern Munich can now be revealed. His name is Karl Power and he lives in Droylsden in Manchester.

This was confirmed for Guardian Unlimited Football by a source in Munich, as well as our reader Julie Hart. Her email added: "He is 34-ish and originally came from the Ancoats area, he still has family there. And it's just like him to do something like this."

When Power's flight from Munich arrives back in Manchester later today, he will be met by a battery of press photographers who are waiting at the airport for his return. Expect his picture - and his story - to feature in the morning papers tomorrow.

Piers Hernu, editor of Men's magazine Front, has tonight claimed responsibility for the stunt. He said Power used a Manchester United pass card to get near the pitch and then just coolly strode on to get his picture taken.

"We have done a feature on a bloke who blags his way into every football match Manchester United play abroad," he said. "It's just a question of having the right clothing in terms of bibs so you look official."

Mr Hernu said that a certain kind of Manchester United pass was also important. He added: "If anyone sees the card, they let you in." Describing Power's run to stardom, Mr Hernu said: "He timed his run perfectly."

After getting his picture taken, Power just coolly sat down at pitchside and watched the rest of the game. Mr Hernu said that he had not spoken to the man since he became the star of United's Champions League game last night. "We did it for publicity and just to amuse people. People like a bit of fun and audacity."

fields.headline: Foot and mouth 'under control'
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The foot and mouth outbreak is "fully under control", the government's chief scientist, Professor David King, said today after reporting a significant drop in the daily number of cases during the last two weeks.
fields.body:
The foot and mouth outbreak is "fully under control", the government's chief scientist, Professor David King, said today after reporting a significant drop in the daily number of cases during the last two weeks.

However, the issue of whether or not to proceed with cattle vaccinations was still troubling the government. Prof King made his statement after failing to persuade farmers' leaders to support the government's vaccination policy after a third day of talks ended without agreement.

Prof King said at the end of last month the daily tally stood at an average of 43 new cases a day, while that had fallen to 27 by last Sunday.

"On the basis of the fall in the number of cases being reported, the epidemic now is fully under control," Prof King said. "If 14 days ago we had 40 infected premises then today we should have 20 and in two more weeks we should have 10."

Prof King had earlier met the president of the National Farmers' Union, Ben Gill, who emerged from the talks claiming that both sides were "neither further away nor closer" to an accord on vaccination.

Mr Gill said he still opposed an immediate vaccination programme, particularly as the current culling scheme appeared to be working. The government does not need the NFU's support to go ahead with the plan but have admitted it would be far easier with it.

Mr Gill denied the NFU was dictating policy. He said: "I have not yet been convinced of the relevance of vaccination at this time. There are many questions which need to be resolved."

Mr Gill, who had participated in talks at the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) in London, said that the government was relying on the cooperation of farmers to make any scheme workable but denied a rift between ministers and his union.

He also denied that financial fears were behind the NFU's position, saying: "It is a matter of putting the scientific perspective against a broader picture. The market place is very important to us."

Before the talks, the union's policy director, Martin Haworth, had predicted that ministers would be persuaded to abandon their highly publicised vaccination policy "u-turn".

Prof King said the optimistic outlook could now also be applied to the worst hit area of Cumbria. Both there and elsewhere, he said, the nationwide policy of culling infected livestock within 24 hours and animals on neighbouring farms within 48 hours was working.

webTitle: Britain first to ban human cloning

fields.headline: Britain first to ban human cloning
fields.standfirst:
Special report: ethics of genetics
Talk about it
fields.trailText: Human cloning will be banned in Britain - the first country to do so - in a move calculated to allay ethical fears about how rapidly genetic science is advancing, the government announced today.
fields.body:
Human cloning will be banned in Britain - the first country to do so - in a move calculated to allay ethical fears about how rapidly genetic science is advancing, the government announced today.

However, genetic tests for diseases such as cancer are to be made more widely available on the NHS as part of £30m of government investment.

The number of specialist consultants in genetics in England is to double in the next five years and two new national laboratories dedicated to researching new treatments and tests for genetic disorders are to be established.

In his first major speech on genetics, the health secretary Alan Milburn, said he would lay to rest the "twin spectres" of human cloning and a genetics underclass caused by insurance firms discriminating against people with a higher genetic risk of certain diseases.

New laws to comprehensively ban all forms of human cloning are to be introduced and there is to be a moratorium on the use of genetic tests by insurance companies. Cloning work is currently restricted to those scientists granted licences.

Speaking at a conference in Newcastle upon Tyne, Mr Milburn said NHS genetics services were to be reorganised into a single, national network to ensure all patients had access to specialist services.

Mr Milburn said: "Genetic advances can be a force for good, but that requires active preparation. The genetics revolution has already begun. It is not going to go away."

He said that the Cancer Research Campaign has agreed to allow the NHS access to its cutting edge research on the BRCA2 breast cancer gene, meaning latest breakthroughs will be available on the health service.

The charity owns the patent on the BRCA2 gene, a major risk factor in breast cancer. More than 33,000 women are diagnosed with the breast cancer every year in the UK and more than 14,000 die from it.

The Department of Health is also beginning talks with US pharmaceutical firm Myriad over access to its gene research into breast cancer.

As some gene research has been patented by drugs giants in the hope of developing lucrative new treatments, potentially life-saving research is not widely available.

The number of specialist genetic consultants in the NHS in England will double from 77 to 140 by 2006, and 300 more scientists working in the field will come on stream in the health service.

A £10m Genetics Knowledge Challenge Fund to establish four "genetics knowledge parks" with medical and scientific expertise will also be set up.

Mr Milburn said: "Britain's system of socialised health care means citizens can choose to take genetic tests, free from the fear that should they test positive they will face an enormous bill for insurance or treatment, or worse still that they are priced out of care or cover all together.

"Genetic advances lay bare the fallacy that private health insurance is the way forward for our country. Genetics strengthens, rather than weakens the case for Britain's NHS."

webTitle: Ban is more political than practical

fields.headline: Ban is more political than practical
fields.standfirst:
It is decisive, it is momentous, it appeases the Roman Catholic lobby. But is it useful, asks science correspondent James Meek

Special report: patenting genes
fields.trailText: It is decisive, it is momentous, it appeases the Roman Catholic lobby. But is it useful, asks science correspondent James Meek.
fields.body:
The government's pledge to ban reproductive human cloning is a great political move. It sounds decisive, it sounds momentous, it doesn't cost any money, it appeases the Roman Catholic lobby (which, apart from anything else, makes up 50% of the nocturnal occupants of the prime minister's bedroom) and it has no material impact on a single voter.

Whether it is useful or necessary is doubtful. There are three good reasons why, if it weren't for the politics of it, Alan Milburn needn't have bothered with his announcement today.

Firstly, there isn't a queue of scientists in Britain waiting to carry out experiments on human cloning. Banning reproductive cloning in Britain is a bit like banning British missions to Mars.

Paying clients might be found - gay couples, parents of children who have died in accidents, 100% sterile men - but the science is not ready to clone a human without an unacceptably high risk of miscarriages or birth defects in the baby. (For those who skipped Cloning I, clones still have to be born, grow and learn in the conventional way.)

Secondly, there are laws and regulators already in place to make reproductive cloning all but impossible in practice. No-one could legally clone a human in Britain without the permission of the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority, the HFEA, and there are no circumstances foreseeable at the moment which would persuade that cautious body that cloning was acceptable.

Thirdly, a Britain-only ban shrinks into perspective against the background of other scientifically advanced countries which have no laws, HFEA equivalents or guidelines governing reproductive cloning, and no plans to introduce them. Russia and India are two examples; but even a country as close as Belgium has no rules to stop human cloning being carried out.

Milburn's pledge is more nuanced than it seems. Only reproductive cloning will be banned: therapeutic or, to be more accurate, limited human cloning will not be. Scientists will still be able to apply for permission to produce cloned human embryos for research, in the hope of using their findings to cure degenerative diseases and organ damage. But the embryos will not be allowed to develop beyond the stage of a microscopic ball of cells.

If the government's announcement is to have an effect, it will be to cast a pall over this work. Not only that: one day, the science of reproductive cloning may look more reliable, and the cautious use of the technology in specific human situations may start to seem attractive. Leaving the HFEA to make a judgement on when if ever that day came would have been a better move.

The HFEA, for all its flaws - it is excessively restrictive when it comes to novel IVF procedures - is widely admired as a model for other countries to follow. The government should have left it to be the arbiter on reproductive cloning.

webTitle: Drug giants made to swallow bitter pill

fields.headline: Drug giants made to swallow bitter pill
fields.standfirst:
Global opinion won in South Africa, but will it triumph when the US fights Brazil's cheap Aids medicine?

Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: Global opinion won in South Africa, but will it triumph when the US fights Brazil's cheap Aids medicine?
fields.body:
The drugs industry's court case against the South African government will go down in history alongside Shell's embarrassment by Brent Spar as one of the great corporate PR disasters of all time.

The hard lesson that the big pharmaceutical companies have been taught in South Africa, where they have been forced to retreat from their attempt to stop the country importing cheap Aids drugs, is that there can be no global marketplace without a world sense of right and wrong.

However much the industry insisted that the cost of patented drugs was not the main problem for African governments, the public perception was that the companies were more interested in protecting their intellectual property rights than in the health crisis in the continent.

South Africa, with the world's highest number of Aids sufferers, was precisely the wrong country at which to aim its campaign to prevent poor state buying cheaper generic copies of patented drugs.

Although Pretoria has a patchy record on facing up to the Aids crisis, it was prepared to stand by its right under international trade rules to import generic drugs during a national health emergency.

Now, belatedly, the companies have realised the damage the case has done to their public image. A settlement is expected today in which Pretoria will clarify its intention to interpret its 1997 Medicines Act under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules. But it will not rewrite the law, as the companies wanted.

The companies argued that the act allowed Pretoria to override patents at will. The government said it only planned to use the act in the spirit of the WTO's patent rules, which allow intellectual property rights to be overriden in exceptional circumstances.

Campaigners argued that the Aids crisis was an emergency as defined in the Trade Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (Trips).

The decision of the 39 drugs firms involved to halt the case, expected to be confirmed today, is a big defeat for US and European corporate lobbyists, in the agricultural as well as in the pharmaceutical sectors.

They thought it possible to exploit the rules for world trade in such a way as to make 6bn consumers dependent for redress on a handful of easily influenced regulators.

International public opinion and a worldwide web of activists, forces which the corpo rations had not counted on, appear to have made them change their minds this time.

Now attention switches to a more difficult arena: the case being brought by the US government, backed by the American Pharmaceuti cal Research and Manufacturers Association, against Brazil, which makes cheap copies of patent Aids drugs.

They say that Brazil is flouting Trips. The case will go before the nearest thing to a world court with teeth - the WTO in Geneva.

Campaigners cite Brazil as a successful example of how a relatively poor country can treat Aids if it has access to cheaper generic drugs. Aids deaths have halved since the government began providing cut-price treatment.

Merck and Pfizer, the companies leading the campaign against Brazil's generics industry, must be re-evaluating their strategy. But it will be harder for big drugs companies to admit defeat on this one.

South Africa's huge HIV problem, its tragic recent history and the saintly figure of Nelson Mandela made the companies" case look egregiously sleazy; on the level of hard-headed calculation, it is a relatively small market.

Brazil is different. Poor as it is, it is much richer than sub-Saharan Africa; it is a genuine potential market for the drugs giants. More significantly for the world, if the Trips tribunal backs Brazil, it will establish the principle that poor countries can override patent rules in the interests of public health.

Campaigners now want the safeguard rules in Trips to be clarified and trade negotiators to revisit the whole issue of patent protection in poor countries when the WTO discusses intellectual property rules in September.

Ominously for the drugs companies and their shareholders, the South Africa case and the forthcoming showdown in Geneva raise uncomfortable questions about big pharmaceutical companies' lack of financial transparency.

The arguments in favour of patents on drugs, which give corporations long monopolies on their production and sale, centre on the cost of the research needed to invent the medicine in the first place.

The companies say they need worldwide patent protection to recoup the millions spent on developing the drug.

But attention is now focusing on the lack of information about how much they spend on research, their huge profits, their dependence for many breakthroughs on publicly funded laboratories, the huge sums spent on marketing, and the disproportionate amount spent on developing drugs for lifestyle problems such as obesity in the developed world.

But the developing world's ability to defy the US on international trade is limited and it will be looking to Europe states, more resistant to corporate political power, to lead an attempt to draft a more just Trips regime.

fields.headline: Drop in language course applications
fields.trailText: Academics are worried by the severe drop in the number of undergraduates applying for language courses, but some argue that they simply reflect changes in the courses on offer.
fields.body:
Professors across the country are worried by a severe drop in the number of undergraduates applying for language courses.

However, universities have been adapting and some administrators argue that recent drops could reflect changes in the courses on offer not in the number of students applying.

Between 1996 and 2000 there was a 13% decrease in the number of applications for language courses, according to Universities and Colleges Admissions Services (UCAS). And the picture in some areas could be even worse.

The director of admissions at the University of York, Ms Connie Cullen, has collected statistics on applications to combined courses with a language from across the country. They show a drop of nearly 10% in the last two years, suggesting a swifter drop in applications to mixed degrees than to straight languages.

The trend is leaving academics worried. "Of course the drop in numbers is a concern. It worries people," said Dr Myriam Salama-Carr, director of postgraduate studies in the School of Languages at the University of Salford. "But a bigger concern is the discrepancy we see between employers and students' perceptions. Every year I get more job offers than I can deal with."

Universities are rethinking and redesigning their language courses. Even at Cambridge University there is now an increased emphasis on gender studies and film.

The University of York's head of the department of language and linguistic science, Mr Steve Harlow, believes language courses across the UK now involve less literature and more practice and speech. They are also becoming part of other degrees. Business studies with a year abroad is a popular choice.

Ms Cullen argues that this trend might actually be making the statistics look worse than the situation actually is. If students are listed under "business studies with a year abroad" they might not make it onto the UCAS language statistics.

Although there is a clear trend over the last ten years towards languages being taught with other subjects, it is unclear whether this move is continuing. Only 20% of the 2,420 language courses on offer this year were not combined degrees. That was a less than 1% change from last year.

fields.headline: 'Genetic knowledge parks' planned
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The government will today launch plans for four "genetic knowledge parks" as part of an investment worth tens of millions of pounds to make Britain a leader in the development of genetic technology.
fields.body:
The government will today launch plans for four "genetic knowledge parks" as part of an investment worth tens of millions of pounds to make Britain a leader in the development of genetic technology.

The parks will bring together researchers, NHS clinicians and pharmaceutical entrepreneurs in the hope of producing ideas for spin-off companies.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will say the "genetic valleys" should provide a critical mass of ideas in genetics in the same way that Silicon Valley in California was the springboard for advance in information technology. Regions will be asked to bid for the privilege.

During a speech in Newcastle on the impact of genetic science on health care, he will also promise a big expansion of genetic testing within the NHS. The Department of Health has so far approved only one genetic test, for the rare and fatal Huntington's chorea, but Mr Milburn expects to extend this to testing for a range of cancers.

He will promise enough extra consultants, medical staff, scientists and counsellors to increase the number of genetic tests within the NHS to more than 100,000 within five years. The number of patients being seen by genetic specialists should increase by 80%.

He will argue that the NHS is well placed to exploit the technology. As a "socialist medical service" treating people on the basis of need, it can encourage patients to be genetically tested without fear that the results may increase the cost.

The department is drawing up legislation to outlaw human reproductive cloning to allay public fears about scientists playing god.

Another safeguard will be a moratorium on insurance companies using genetic profiling tests to predict which of their customers were likely to die prematurely or suffer chronic disease.

If, as expected, the human genetics commission recommends a moratorium in a report due next month, the government would back it.

webTitle: Wildlife parks' antelope may be source of BSE

fields.headline: Wildlife parks' antelope may be source of BSE
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: BSE may have reached the food chain in Britain through exotic wildlife such as antelope and other African deer-like species, a government adviser claims.
fields.body:
BSE may have reached the food chain in Britain through exotic wildlife such as antelope and other African deer-like species, a government adviser claims.

Roger Morris, a professor who advises the Ministry of Agriculture on BSE and tuberculosis in cattle as well as on epidemics such as the present foot and mouth crisis, maintains that ground-up brains and organs from a diseased animal in a wildlife park were included in food eaten by cattle in the mid 1970s.

Evidence supporting the claims will be published by Professor Morris - who works at Massey university, in Palmerston North, New Zealand - in a scientific journal later this year. He believes a wildlife park, probably in south-west England where BSE seems to have started, may have been the unwitting host to an infected animal.

"The area of Britain where it started is the area where wildlife parks started up in the 1970s. I have got evidence that every step in the sequence could have occurred, and I know that various African antelopes are susceptible to the disease. We also know that lions get the disease."

He said the big challenge was finding the disease in Africa. "We don't know what antelope it was - there is a low rate of transmission from the antelope to their calves, and the lions that eat the infected antelope develop the disease as well."

In the wild, he said, a disease such as bovine spongiform encephalopathy "in Darwinian terms" would be beneficial since it would enable lions and other predatorsto catch older prey past their prime breeding age - "they then infect the lions, helping to balance [the cats'] population".

Prof Morris said that if his theory were true new controls might be necessary in African states to protect food, though no changes were likely to be required in the UK. He said he had considered the possibility that dead lions from zoos or wildlife parks had helped cause the disease in Britain, but noted that the cats' bodies were usually kept for scientific examination.

The theory is being looked at by other specialists who are reviewing all that is known about the disease.

The government is sceptical about the conclusion reached by Lord Phillips in last year's report on the BSE catastrophe that a mutation in cattle was initially responsible for the disease, and that the practice of recycling cows and sheep in animal feed sent the outbreak spiralling out of control.

The review is considering causes, including the old front-runner that it developed from scrapie, a BSE-like disease in sheep. Other theories include contamination from the remains of beached whales, manganese in the soil and organophosphates making cattle more susceptible to the disease, and the involvement of a common bacterium or virus.

Nearly 180,000 cattle in Britain have been diagnosed with BSE since late 1986. Sixteen antelopes in captivity, including gemsbok and two other types of oryx, plus kudu, nyala and eland, have been judged to suffer a similar disease, as have a bison, two ankole cows, three lions, five cheetahs, three tigers, three pumas, three ocelots and 89 domestic cats.

Roger Morris, a professor who advises the Ministry of Agriculture on BSE and tuberculosis in cattle as well as on epidemics such as the present foot and mouth crisis, maintains that ground-up brains and organs from a diseased animal in a wildlife park were included in food eaten by cattle in the mid 1970s. Evidence supporting the claims will be published by Professor Morris - who works at Massey university, in Palmerston North, New Zealand - in a scientific journal later this year. He believes a wildlife park, probably in south-west England where BSE seems to have started, may have been the unwitting host to an infected animal. "The area of Britain where it started is the area where wildlife parks started up in the 1970s. I have got evidence that every step in the sequence could have occurred, and I know that various African antelopes are susceptible to the disease. We also know that lions get the disease." He said the big challenge was finding the disease in Africa. "We don't know what antelope it was - there is a low rate of transmission from the antelope to their calves, and the lions that eat the infected antelope develop the disease as well." fields.headline: Bees can think say scientists
fields.trailText: Bees use their reasoning powers to get to the nectar, according to an international team of scientists.
fields.body:
Bees use their reasoning powers to get to the nectar, according to an international team of scientists.

In tests, the bees learned which signs led the way to something sweet and which did not, the researchers report in Nature today.

This discovery will have set the world of animal behaviour abuzz. Vertebrates - and especially primates - were thought to be the only creatures that could hold in their heads the concepts of "the same" and "different". Now the team from France, Germany and Australia say their research shows "that higher cognitive functions are not a privilege of vertebrates."

Bees are the cooperative go-getters of the insect world. The workers wake up, set off, search, find a source of honey, return, tell their colleagues where the best supplies are, then find their way back. Researchers have watched, noted and experimented for years to discover how bees navigate and communicate.

Martin Giurfa of the Free University in Berlin, and colleagues from Narbonne and Canberra, noted from earlier studies that bees can "interpolate visual information, exhibit associative recall, categorise visual information and learn contextual information" - do what in a human would be evidence of thinking. So they set the bees a test.

They trained the honeybees Apis mellifera to recognise particular colours and grating patterns, using a Y-shaped maze. In one trial, the bees saw either blue or yellow as they approached the entrance to the maze. When they got to the Y junction, they saw that one turning was labelled blue, the other yellow. They quickly learned that the sucrose reward was to be found down the turning that had the same colour code as at the entrance.

In further experiments they found that the bees could perform the same mental gymnastics with similar and different grating patterns. And when colours were swapped for odours - lemon and mango - they saw the same outcome. The bees could tell sameness from oddity in the abstract. They could think.

webTitle: Irving to speak at Oxford Union

fields.headline: Irving to speak at Oxford Union
fields.standfirst:
Holocaust denier will debate with libel case QC

Special report: the David Irving libel trial
fields.trailText: Holocaust denier will debate with libel case QC
fields.body:
The Oxford Union came under fire last night for inviting David Irving, the Holocaust denier, to address students in a debate with the barrister who faced him across the high court.

Mr Irving will contest the motion that "this house would restrict the free speech of extremists" at the famous university debating chamber on May 10.

Richard Rampton QC, who successfully defended the academic Deborah Lipstadt last year after her book had accused Mr Irving of being a Holocaust denier. The judge, Mr Justice Gray, agreed and ruled Mr Irving was "an anti-semite and a racist... a right-wing pro-Nazi polemicist".

Mr Irving, who represented himself in the libel trial, is due for a further court encounter with Mr Rampton when he seeks leave to appeal against the verdict.

An invitation from the union last year for Mr Irving to speak was cancelled after protests. The union said last night that this time it intended to fulfil the invitation and had contacted Thames Valley police. Claire Dissington, of the Anti-Nazi League, said her organisation would try to prevent the debate and would put pressure on other speakers.

"They know what they are doing and they are playing with fire," said Ms Dissington. "The only reason they have heard of David Irving is because he denied the Holocaust. There are plenty of other people who could debate freedom of speech. I'm appalled, I am quite amazed they are giving him a platform."

Michael Whine, spokesman for the Board of Deputies of British Jews, said: "I wouldn't have thought that the Oxford Union would learn very much of general importance from David Irving, considering that the courts have proved him to be a falsifier of history and a promoter of Hitler." He added: "I am really surprised that Richard Rampton is giving him any credence whatsoever by appearing on the platform with him."

Mr Rampton said last night: "I have no problem appearing in a debate of that kind against him. As a professional advocate, and for the purpose of this debate, I have no feelings about him at all.

"I think these arguments are best won largely speaking by open debate. He as a person is quite irrelevant to the topic I am going to discuss, as is the fact he was on the other side of a legal action last year. I don't think it prevents him or me from debating a general motion of that kind."

Mr Rampton added: "I'm obviously not going to discuss the case ... He may try, but I shall not respond. I won't be getting into that except by implication."

Mr Irving said: "I have a great speech prepared ... I don't think Rampton will be able to persuade the students of Oxford that opposing free speech will be a good thing." Asked about the likely protests, Mr Irving said: "These are worms. We've seen these worms before, and they have never managed to stop me speaking. But it is a problem that the university may be easily intimidated."

In a statement, Amy Harland, president of the Union, said: "These complex issues have not been properly debated for some time. I believe this line-up of speakers will reflect all viewpoints. I hope that something of substance will come from both sides.

"In this media dominated age, freedom of speech will always be a controversial issue. This is especially the case where this basic freedom comes into conflict with our common desire to live in a tolerant society. Whatever the outcome of this debate, if Britain is to be a free and diverse nation, this is an issue that needs to be addressed."

The union said that John Sentamu, bishop of Stepney, would also speak for the motion, and Rohan Jayasekera, director of the Index on Censorship, would speak against.

webTitle: Women urged to avoid the hard stuff

fields.headline: Women urged to avoid the hard stuff
fields.trailText: Women who want to keep up with men at the bar should stick to beer. According to US researchers, they do not have the stomach to go the distance with anything stronger.
fields.body:
Women who want to keep up with men at the bar should stick to beer. According to US researchers, they do not have the stomach to go the distance with anything stronger.

According to New Scientist today, a team from the Mount Sinai school of medicine in New York measured the activity of three stomach enzymes that get to work on alcohol. They were looking for the answer to an old puzzle - why, when the two sexes drink the same amount of alcohol, the levels of booze in the blood are higher in women than men, even after allowing for bodyweight differences.

They found that an enzyme called glutathione-dependent formaldehyde dehydrogenase, or c-ADH, was twice as effective at breaking down alcohol in men as in women.

It did not seem to matter when beer at 5% alcohol was being served, but when concentrations got to 10%, or 40% for scotch or vodka, the difference showed.

"In other words, women respond to beer in the same way as men, but not to wine or hard liquor," said Charles Lieber, of the Mount Sinai school. "In general both women and female animals are more susceptible to the negative or toxic effects of alcohol. This is true for the liver, heart muscle, skeletal muscle and it may be true for the pancreas and the brain."

webTitle: Shamed and humiliated - the drugs firms back down

fields.headline: Shamed and humiliated - the drugs firms back down
fields.standfirst: Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: The world's largest drug companies are today expected to make a humiliating climbdown and abandon their legal action against South African laws aimed at getting cheaper medicines to the poor.
fields.body:
The world's largest drug companies are today expected to make a humiliating climbdown and abandon their legal action against South African laws aimed at getting cheaper medicines to the poor.

The suit by 39 pharmaceutical companies in the Pretoria high court, which argued that the South African legislation infringed their patent rights, has ultimately achieved the very thing it tried to prevent - encouraging governments across the developing world to use the law to obtain more affordable drugs.

But the withdrawal of the drugs firms from the case, described by one government official as "unconditional surrender", will stave off another public relations disaster. The companies faced having to reveal some of their most closely guarded business secrets, including pricing policies, profit levels and the source of funding for research into key anti-Aids drugs.

The trial was scheduled to resume yesterday after a six- week recess. During that time a groundswell of public and government opposition to the legal action caused some of the largest firms to rethink their strategy. Protesters across the globe accused them of putting profits ahead of lives and Germany, France, Holland and the European parliament called for the suit to be dropped.

Last-minute talks between five big firms - including the world's largest pharmaceutical company, Britain's GlaxoSmithKline - and the South African government dragged on through Wednesday, causing the court to postpone the hearing until today.

The drug companies have now accepted virtually all of the legislation - including the South African government's right to import generic drugs at a fraction of the cost of brand names - but they are pressing the health ministry to rewrite a key section of the law to clarify and limit the circumstances in which it can grant compulsory licences for third parties to manufacture patented medicines at a lower price.

It is not clear if the South Africans will give ground on this issue but the government has already said that its primary interest is not in copying patented drugs but in importing generics from other countries or manufacturing them.

However, what is certain is that the big drug companies have lost all heart for the fight. Although some smaller firms could technically pursue the case, lawyers said it was highly unlikely that they will.

Mark Heywood, a legal strategist for the Aids pressure group, the Treatment Action Campaign, which played a key role in forcing the drug companies to drop the case, said: "The case was doing significant damage to the multinationals' image and investor confidence in them. The case was also forcing out of the woodwork certain aspects of their business practices they did not want exposed in court and aired before the world's media. They had no legal case."

A split has developed between some of the larger drug companies and the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association of South Africa (PMA), which headed the legal action.

Some drug firms are now saying the case should never have been pursued. They were also disturbed at the content of some submissions by PMA lawyers, which were a PR disaster. At yesterday's hearing, several drug firms sent in their own legal teams.

One submission, which was particularly heavily criticised in South Africa, argued that unless there were financial returns there was little incentive for drugs companies to develop new Aids treatments.

While international opinion was clearly an important factor in the firms' withdrawal, they had also realised they were on shaky legal ground.

The PMA effectively abandoned its argument that the South African law breached international patent protection agreements before the court case opened, after the World Trade Organisation and several governments said Pretoria's legislation was legitimate. Instead, the drug companies argued in court that the laws breached South Africa's own constitution by giving too much power to cabinet ministers to decide when to override patents and because they failed to define what "unaffordable" meant in a medical context.

The government recognised that some of the legislation was poorly worded and was preparing itself for a judgment that would uphold its right to introduce such laws but require that this one be rewritten with greater clarity.

As the first phase of the trial progressed, prospects of success steadily dimmed while the cost to the drug companies' reputations was huge.

"They might have thought all this shit was worth taking if they were going to win, but they knew they weren't," said one lawyer working on the case against the drug firms. "The best they could hope to do was hold up the implementation of the law a little longer during the appeals and maybe scare a few other governments off of following South Africa's lead."

South African health officials say they are ready to put the new law into practice within weeks once the legal challenge is finally dropped.

But despite international public opinion rallying around the South Africans over access to anti-Aids drugs, the government has no intention of importing anti-retrovirals in the near future even though one in nine of the population - 4.7m - is HIV-positive.

It will instead seek medicines to combat opportunistic infections brought on by Aids and drugs to deal with other diseases such as malaria.

Africa: the deadly toll

 25.3m Africans were living with HIV or Aids in 2000 and 2.4m people died of HIV-related causes

 Africa is home to nearly 70% of adults and 80% of children with HIV in the world

 In South Africa and Zimbabwe, Aids could claim the lives of around half of all 15-year-olds

 South Africa has more people living with HIV and Aids than any other country. Pretoria estimates that 4.7m people are carrying HIV. Experts warn the number may rise to 7m by 2010

 South Africa's neighbour Botswana has the highest rate of HIV infection, with an estimated 35.8% of all adults living with the disease. Life expectancy in Botswana has been cut to 44 years

 HIV patients occupy nearly 40% of the beds in the Kenyatta national hospital in Nairobi and 70% of the beds in the Prince Regent hospital in Burundi

 Aids deaths in South Africa are expected to rise from around 120,000 last year to an annual 635,000 in 2010

fields.headline: Geneticist proposes 'third way' on GM crops
fields.standfirst: Special report: GM food debate
fields.trailText: The growing world population will only be fed adequately if governments adopt "people friendly" farming methods which include GM technology, one of the world's leading scientists and humanitarians told industry scientists and academics yesterday.
fields.body:
The growing world population will only be fed adequately if governments adopt "people friendly" farming methods which include GM technology, one of the world's leading scientists and humanitarians told industry scientists and academics yesterday.

MF Swaminathan, a geneticist credited with being the father of India's green revolution - which prevented millions of people suffering food shortages and famine in the post war years - offered a 'third way' to warring proponents and opponents of GM technology.

He called for governments and scientists to back sensitive farming methods which would keep people on the land and avoid social or ecological harm. He said genetically modified crops did "have a place" in the future and could work well alongside organic systems of farming.

Professor Swaminathan's vision of world agriculture - which must cater for an estimated 2bn more mouths within 20 years - suggested that the corporate GM model of farming would not benefit the poorest.

He urged governments to provide more public funding of gene technology and called for community participation in science.

"We must adopt a precautionary principle", he told representatives of Monsanto, Syngenta, Dupont and other GM companies at an international conference at Britain's leading GM research organisation, the John Innes Centre in Norwich.

"If you want an inclusive society you must go to the poorest person and ask if they will gain anything from technological development," he said. "Farming cannot be left to the control of a few multi-national companies. The poor, who are most of the world's population, need fair and free trade. There must be ethics and equity in farming."

Prof Swaminathan is developing mixed GM and organic farming methods at his institute near Calcutta, where scientists are going into the community and trying to develop rice, tobacco and other crops that are tolerant to salt water. The experiment has been widely praised by governments and pressure groups.

He is backed by the influential Rockefeller Foundation in New York, which has also called for a "new green revolution" which includes GM foods. His comments will both please and worry corporations and anti-GM advocates. Most GM technology is in the hands of a few large companies who have been accused of trying to monopolise world agriculture - a situation which has prompted much of the anti-GM fervour around the world.

According to UN estimates, world food requirements will increase by 50% within 25 years and will have to be produced from less land with less water, fewer chemicals and less labour. Many governments see no option but to follow the corporate GM route which promises extra yields.

But several scientists at the conference said GM food production in developing countries was a more difficult issue than in Europe or the US. "Tropical countries face more complex issues including patent rights, the freedom of companies to operate and specific risk assessment," said Ana Sittenfeld, a geneticist at the University of Costa Rica.

The three day debate is the largest international conference so far on GM foods in developing countries. It is expected to reach a consensus that in some cases they will be crucial to feeding people, but in other cases they may be inappropriate.

At a separate meeting organised by British environment groups, some of the world's poorest farmers testified that GM foods had no place in feeding growing populations and might even destabilise societies.

"What we have built up slowly and surely will collapse with new GM seeds," said Laxmi Begari of Deccan Development Society in central India.
