The three day debate is the largest international conference so far on GM foods in developing countries. It is expected to reach a consensus that in some cases they will be crucial to feeding people, but in other cases they may be inappropriate. At a separate meeting organised by British environment groups, some of the world's poorest farmers testified that GM foods had no place in feeding growing populations and might even destabilise societies. "What we have built up slowly and surely will collapse with new GM seeds," said Laxmi Begari of Deccan Development Society in central India.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Tarun
fields.trailText:
Read with a great deal of interest your weekly reports. It brings back fond memories of my time in Australia and NZ. I also lived in Coogee!

Anyway... dropped in to tell you some must-see/must-do things in NZ.
fields.body:
Hi Milly,

Read with a great deal of interest your weekly reports. It brings back fond memories of my time in Australia and NZ. I also lived in Coogee behind the husband-wife team pizza place a bit away from the beach on Bay Road. How I would love to be back there!

Anyway .... dropped in to tell you some must-see/must-do things in NZ. I see you managed to do the sky dive! I couldn't do it in Queenstown since it was windy.

- Kaikoura - whale- and dolphin-watch - like nothing you've ever seen!

- Abel Tasman National Park - go kayaking there. Stay at the MacDonald Farm camping site.

- Go to a glass-blowing factory if you haven't seen one. There's one near Franz Joseph glacier and another on the north coast of the South Island... forget the name of the town.

- Waitomo caves... go tubing inside there ... gives me the chills even now.

- Wanganui - quaint little town.

- Orekai Koroko - volcanic springs site near Lake Taupo.

- Take a boat on Lake Taupo and see the hillside carvings.

Auckand is a must-miss! It was a let-down after I had fallen in love with Christchurch.

Have a great time!!!

Tarun

webTitle: Minority voices show strong instincts for survival

fields.headline: Minority voices show strong instincts for survival
fields.standfirst: Evaluating the economic strengths of 'smaller' languages could be their best protection in Europe
fields.trailText: Evaluating the economic strengths of 'smaller' languages could be their best protection in Europe
fields.body:
The debate about dominant and dominated languages in the European Union concentrates almost exclusively on the position of English versus the 10 other official languages. Yet the simplistic claim that English, the "international shark", is about to devour other state languages, ignores a far more diverse tapestry of linguistic diversity.

According to the Brussels-based European Bureau for Lesser Used Languages, about 40m people in Europe speak a language other than the dominant language of the country where they reside. These languages range in strength from the Catalan pike, with about 7m speakers, to the minnow of Saterfrisian, a minority language in Germany spoken by about 2,000 people. In between are more than 60 other language minorities, each one finding itself in entirely different circumstances and faced with its own specific predator.

Basques in the south of France are concerned at the continuing refusal of the French government to grant their language adequate protection in education and the media. While Frisians, an island in a sea of Dutch, have been shocked by a recent study revealing poor standards of teaching of their language in schools.

Despite these examples, it is not the case that all minority languages across Europe are being swallowed up by their own national sharks. Linguistic minorities in Italy this year achieved far-reaching national legislation allowing them to begin consolidating their education and media. Protection of minorities in the Danish-German border region is conducted on the basis of international reciprocal agreements between both countries. Yet this does not mean that minority language communities are ignorant about the dominance of English, oblivious to anything other than their own regional struggles.

Notwithstanding their problems with education, the Frisians last year began a pilot project dividing primary school hours between their own language, Dutch and English. A similar project was recently launched in the Basque Country with equal emphasis on Basque, Spanish and English. And in Luxembourg, English is indeed the first foreign language taught to schoolchildren, but not before they master Luxembourgish, French and German.

As these initiatives illustrate, speakers of minority languages cannot afford to resist learning the dominant languages surrounding them. They have no choice in the matter, as these languages are essential for communication with their neighbours, sometimes literally in the next house. However, this does not mean that they should discard their native language as if it were an impediment to progress. The acquisition of English or any other dominant language does not have to be at the expense of the language of the home or community.

Meanwhile the slow yet perceptible development of academic theories exploring the links between identity, language and socio-economic development is becoming another important support mechanism for minority language communities.

The Brussels-based Research Centre on Multilingualism has recently urged the development of "econolinguistics", a new academic discipline linking multilingualism and economic development. The centre's research could also point towards ways of developing an equitable language policy at EU level. It suggests the development of a language policy based on the same compensatory principles already used in agricultural and regional economic policies.

This would form the basis of an EU programme for all languages with limited geographical bases or facing other threats to their future vitality (which could, of course, include "smaller" languages such as Danish or Finnish). The central planks of such a programme would be: positive discrimination, such as providing financial support for producing materials or training personnel in the language; decentralisation, to allow enhanced use of the language at local level; and the overall promotion of multilingualism where no language is developed at the expense of another. Such a suggestion could help overcome the current narrow debate about the future of official languages in an enlarged Union.

Finally, to an issue that is increasingly gaining attention in the language debate, but with which EU leaders are showing little enthusiasm to engage: languages of immigrant communities. Most of the discourse about lesser-used languages focuses solely on indigenous or autochthonous minorities, referred to in some states as "national minorities". In a country such as Germany, where Turks far outnumber any indigenous language group, the issue can no longer be ignored.

Quite apart from the fact that the "new" immigrant communities will be the "old" minorities of tomorrow, their languages often face similar, if not more acute problems than "national" groups. In the Netherlands, which itself contains a high percentage of immigrants, research has begun into the common challenges facing both "old" and "new". Whether or not the EU is willing to include the thorny issue of immigration in a future language policy remains a point of debate, but neither "old" nor "new" are displaying willingness to be eaten by the international shark of English.

 John Walsh is editor of Eurolang, a Brussels-based news agency dealing with minority languages, www.eurolang.net.

webTitle: Be proud of your lingua franca

fields.headline: Be proud of your lingua franca
fields.standfirst: As a hybrid European English takes shape, teachers must be ready to make it welcome in their classes
fields.trailText: As a hybrid European English takes shape, teachers must be ready to make it welcome in their classes.
fields.body:
A Finnish scientist coming to Vienna for a conference on human genetics; an Italian designer negotiating with prospective clients in Stockholm; a Polish tourist chatting with local restaurateurs in Crete: they all communicate successfully in "English", but which "English"? Well, chances are that it is not the language you hear in chat shows and soaps on British or American television, but rather a range of "Englishes", with enough of a common core to make it viable as a means of communication.

It is even claimed that a European variety of English, sometimes labelled "Euro-English", is in the process of evolving to serve as a European lingua franca. As yet, however, this new variety of English has not been described, largely because it is at such an embryonic stage in its evolution. All we can say with any degree of certainty is that English as a lingua franca in Europe (ELFE) is likely to be some kind of European-English hybrid which, as it develops, will look increasingly to continental Europe rather than to Britain or the United States for its norms of correctness and appropriateness.

However, as long as there is no sound empirical basis for a description of how the language is actually used, the forms ELFE will take will remain an object of speculation.

This is why we decided to record interactions among "non-native" speakers of English from a wide variety of first-language backgrounds, and to investigate what happens linguistically when English is used as a lingua franca. The focus of our research to date has been on pronunciation and lexicogrammar (vocabulary plus grammar), and it has enabled us to make a number of educated guesses at emerging characteristics of ELFE.

Jennifer Jenkins gathered data from interactions among non-native- speakers of English to establish which aspects of pronunciation cause intelligibility problems when English is spoken as an International Language. This enabled her to draw up a pronunciation core, the Lingua Franca Core, and certain of the features she designates core and non-core provide evidence as to the likely development of ELFE pronunciation.

The features of the Lingua Franca Core are those that were found to be crucial for intelligibility. They include: consonant sounds except for "th" (both voiceless as in "think" and voiced as in "this") and dark "l" (as, for example, in the word "hotel"); vowel length contrasts (eg, the difference in length between the vowel sounds in the words "live" and "leave"), and nuclear (tonic) stress (eg, the stress indicated by capital letters in the following: "I come from FRANCE. Where are YOU from?")

Most other areas of pronunciation are then designated non-core, and these include many features on which teachers and learners often spend a great deal of time and effort, such as the exact quality of vowel sounds, word stress, or the "typical rhythm of British English", with lots of "little" words such as articles and prepositions pronounced so weakly as to be hardly audible.

Taking the Lingua Franca Core as our starting point, we predict that the pronunciation of ELFE will, over time, develop certain characteristics. For example, it is unlikely that "th" will be a feature of ELFE accents, since nearly all continental Europeans other than those from Spain and Greece have a problem in producing it. What is not clear at this stage is whether the ELFE substitute will be "s" and "z" (as used, for example, by many French and German English-speakers) or "t" and "d" (as used, for example, by many Italian- and Scandinavian-English speakers), or whether there will be scope for regional variation. However, given that users of "s" and "z" outnumber users of "t" and "d", we predict that ultimately the former will become the accepted ELFE variant.

On the other hand the British-English distinction between voiced and voiceless consonants is likely to be maintained in ELFE, since the loss of this distinction proved to be a frequent cause of intelligibility problems in the research. For example, a German English-speaker's devoicing of the final sound on the word "mug" so that it sounded like "muck" rendered the word unintelligible to an Italian English-speaker.

Barbara Seidlhofer's current research into ELFE lexicogrammar is based on a corpus of interactions in English among fairly fluent speakers from a variety of first-language backgrounds. This corpus, consisting of vast amounts of electronically stored written and spoken text, is called the Vienna-Oxford ELF Corpus.

So far our analyses of a variety of interactions such as casual conversations and academic discussions reveals that no major disruptions in communication happened when speakers committed one or more of the following deadly "grammatical sins":

 Using the same form for all present tense verbs, as in "you look very sad" and "he look very sad".

 Not putting a definite or indefinite article in front of nouns, as in "our countries have signed agreement about this".

 Treating "who" and "which" as interchangeable relative pronouns, as in "the picture who..." or "a person which".

 Using just the verb stem in constructions such as "I look forward to see you tomorrow".

 Using "isn't it?" as a universal tag question (instead of "haven't they?" and "shouldn't he?"), as in "They've finished their dinner now, isn't it?".

These characteristics, it will be noted, are described in a neutral way here: we are not talking about "dropping the third person -s" or "leaving out the -ing ending of the gerund", but this is not the way these "mistakes" are usually treated in English classrooms around Europe.

As many teachers of English as a foreign language will know, the time and effort spent on such features as the "third person -s", the use of articles and the "gerund" is often considerable, and nevertheless many learners still fail to use them "correctly" after years of instruction, especially in spontaneous speech.

What our analyses of ELF interactions suggest is that the time needed to teach and learn these constructions bears little relationship to their usefulness, as successful communication is obviously possible without them. It seems in fact that there is a good reason for many students' observed resistance to learning these characteristics of native-speaker English: like the "th" sounds, they are not communicatively crucial. Rather, speakers tend to tune into them only when they use English in a native-speaker community and want to "blend in" (which for some remains a desirable objective) while they seem to be redundant in much lingua franca communication.

As far as the implications for teaching are concerned, we would like to make two general suggestions. First, teachers and students need to be encouraged to adjust their attitudes towards ELFE and to accord it a status similar to that given to "native" varieties. Second, it is crucial for English language teaching in Europe to focus on contexts of use that are relevant to European speakers of English. In particular, descriptions of spoken English offered to these learners should not be grounded in British or American uses of English but in ELFE or other non-native contexts (depending on where the particular learners intend to use their English in future).

In this respect it is disappointing that "authentic" materials offered to learners continue to be based only on corpora of native speaker use. ELFE learners need descriptions drawn from interactions between non-native-speakers in the contexts in which they too will later participate.

To some, our proposal may seem to be a recipe for "permissiveness" and a decline in "standards". But what we are essentially seeking to do is to carry through the implications of the fact that English is an international language, and as such is no longer the preserve of its native-speakers. If English is indeed a lingua franca, it should be possible to describe it as such without prejudice. And that may well be the biggest challenge for ELFE in the 21st century.

 Dr Jennifer Jenkins is coordinator of teacher education and applied linguistics in the English Language Centre, King's College London, and author of The Phonology Of English As An International Language (OUP, 2000). Dr Barbara Seidlhofer is associate professor at the English department of Vienna University. She is working on a book on the description and pedagogy of English as a lingua franca.

webTitle: Bring the outside in from the cold

fields.headline: Bring the outside in from the cold
fields.standfirst: Is there still any point in going to Britain to learn English? Karen Adams investigates
fields.trailText: Is there still any point in going to Britain to learn English? Karen Adams investigates.
fields.body:
There is a common view that the best way to learn a language is to go to the country where it's spoken. By spending time in the target-language environment, it is assumed that we will almost automatically learn to speak the language - and we can hasten the process by going to language classes while we are there.

This assumption has made English language teaching one of the largest tourist-related industries in Britain. Every year thousands of people are drawn to the UK in the belief that the language-learning experience here is significantly different from that in their own country. But is this true?

From the mid-1970s until the beginning of the 90s dramatic changes took place in the field of ELT in Britain. Everyone, from publishers and language school owners to teacher training institutions and university departments, saw ways to develop the range of materials, courses and qualifications available to students and teachers. These developments meant that British-based ELT was often seen as exciting and different, with a focus on "real" communication in the classroom.

But gradually things changed. Like many other aspects of life, British ELT went global. By the mid-90s coursebooks published in Britain could be found in language classrooms in many other countries. Similarly, teacher-training courses that previously had run only in Britain and a few selected centres overseas started appearing all around the world.

As a result we now find that students from Buenos Aires to Budapest are being taught by teachers with "Cambridge" certificate and diploma qualifications using similar coursebooks. Many also have access to English-language media via satellite television or the internet, so the benefit of access to authentic materials is no longer confined to those studying in the UK.

So if what students find in language schools in their own country is so similar to what they might find in Britain, why come to Britain learn English? For many the answer is "to speak with British people". However, this is not as easy as it sounds. Meeting British people in tourist-filled central London, for example, is a task in itself, and often students find themselves making friends not with English-speakers but with people from their own country.

In the early days of the 21st century how can British ELT differentiate itself from the language-learning experience that students get at home? The answer lies in getting the students to use the English-speaking environment outside the classroom effectively. This is something teachers often do by bringing authentic materials into the classroom to make a bridge to the "real world". But with so much of this material available via the internet, teachers in Britain need to think more creatively.

Instead of bringing the outside world into the classroom, what about trying to encourage learners to take classroom strategies out into the real world? Through a systematic approach to learner training it should be possible for students to view their time in Britain not just in terms of tourist attractions, but also as a series of potential "language-learning events". By enabling students consciously to tune into and analyse the language around them - the "environmental approach" - students themselves form the bridge between the classroom and the "real world".

So how is this done? First, it is important that students know how to access events which can help their language learning. Language learners in Britain often find themselves visiting tourist attractions that require little or no interaction with language. However, places or events that require learners to listen and speak are often overlooked. These include exhibitions and markets - basically, anywhere where stalls are staffed by people eager to sell produce or distribute information. In London weekly flower markets and small, specialised museums see few tourists, and provide real opportunity for the contact with English that students seek. So a feature of class work could be to help students use listings magazines to identify language-rich events.

A second key strand of this type of learner training is the framework provided in class for out-of-class language learning. Features of this strand include the selection and teaching of key vocabulary that will enable students to listen and interact in their chosen events, and the discussion of the aims and relevance of classroom activities such as predicting the content of a listening or reading passage or working out the meaning of words from context.

Both types of activity are designed to help the students use "classroom" strategies to access and learn from what they see and hear outside.

The third strand in the promotion of an environmental approach is the opportunity for students to share what they have learnt with others. Asking individuals to record what they have learnt and providing class time for the exchange of information and the clarification of problems can allow students in a class in Britain a level of ownership over language that can be difficult to replicate in their own country.

The vocabulary they have brought to class is their own discovery, chosen for a wide range of reasons - it's useful, it's new, or it sounds funny. In all cases it is the student who is responsible for bringing the real world into the classroom, and it is this which lies at the heart of an environmental approach.

So what can British ELT offer that the student cannot find at home? In a nutshell it is the opportunity to seek out new language in the outside world with the safety net of a supportive classroom framework. And this is the challenge for teachers in Britain - to help learners find out what they need and want to learn, rather than simply select the language for them.

 Karen Adams is director of studies at International House, London.
fields.bodyText: There is a common view that the best way to learn a language is to go to the country where it's spoken. By spending time in the target-language environment, it is assumed that we will almost automatically learn to speak the language - and we can hasten the process by going to language classes while we are there. This assumption has made English language teaching one of the largest tourist-related industries in Britain. Every year thousands of people are drawn to the UK in the belief that the language-learning experience here is significantly different from that in their own country. But is this true? From the mid-1970s until the beginning of the 90s dramatic changes took place in the field of ELT in Britain. Everyone, from publishers and language school owners to teacher training institutions and university departments, saw ways to develop the range of materials, courses and qualifications available to students and teachers. These developments meant that British-based ELT was often seen as exciting and different, with a focus on "real" communication in the classroom. But gradually things changed. Like many other aspects of life, British ELT went global. By the mid-90s coursebooks published in Britain could be found in language classrooms in many other countries. Similarly, teacher-training courses that previously had run only in Britain and a few selected centres overseas started appearing all around the world. As a result we now find that students from Buenos Aires to Budapest are being taught by teachers with "Cambridge" certificate and diploma qualifications using similar coursebooks. Many also have access to English-language media via satellite television or the internet, so the benefit of access to authentic materials is no longer confined to those studying in the UK. So if what students find in language schools in their own country is so similar to what they might find in Britain, why come to Britain learn English? For many the answer is "to speak with British people". However, this is not as easy as it sounds. Meeting British people in tourist-filled central London, for example, is a task in itself, and often students find themselves making friends not with English-speakers but with people from their own country. In the early days of the 21st century how can British ELT differentiate itself from the language-learning experience that students get at home? The answer lies in getting the students to use the English-speaking environment outside the classroom effectively. This is something teachers often do by bringing authentic materials into the classroom to make a bridge to the "real world". But with so much of this material available via the internet, teachers in Britain need to think more creatively. Instead of bringing the outside world into the classroom, what about trying to encourage learners to take classroom strategies out into the real world? Through a systematic approach to learner training it should be possible for students to view their time in Britain not just in terms of tourist attractions, but also as a series of potential "language-learning events". By enabling students consciously to tune into and analyse the language around them - the "environmental approach" - students themselves form the bridge between the classroom and the "real world". So how is this done? First, it is important that students know how to access events which can help their language learning. Language learners in Britain often find themselves visiting tourist attractions that require little or no interaction with language. However, places or events that require learners to listen and speak are often overlooked. These include exhibitions and markets - basically, anywhere where stalls are staffed by people eager to sell produce or distribute information. In London weekly flower markets and small, specialised museums see few tourists, and provide real opportunity for the contact with English that students seek. So a feature of class work could be to help students use listings magazines to identify language-rich events. A second key strand of this type of learner training is the framework provided in class for out-of-class language learning. Features of this strand include the selection and teaching of key vocabulary that will enable students to listen and interact in their chosen events, and the discussion of the aims and relevance of classroom activities such as predicting the content of a listening or reading passage or working out the meaning of words from context. Both types of activity are designed to help the students use "classroom" strategies to access and learn from what they see and hear outside. The third strand in the promotion of an environmental approach is the opportunity for students to share what they have learnt with others. Asking individuals to record what they have learnt and providing class time for the exchange of information and the clarification of problems can allow students in a class in Britain a level of ownership over language that can be difficult to replicate in their own country. The vocabulary they have brought to class is their own discovery, chosen for a wide range of reasons - it's useful, it's new, or it sounds funny. In all cases it is the student who is responsible for bringing the real world into the classroom, and it is this which lies at the heart of an environmental approach. So what can British ELT offer that the student cannot find at home? In a nutshell it is the opportunity to seek out new language in the outside world with the safety net of a supportive classroom framework. And this is the challenge for teachers in Britain - to help learners find out what they need and want to learn, rather than simply select the language for them.  Karen Adams is director of studies at International House, London.

fields.headline: Speaking the same language levels
fields.standfirst: Bonnie Johnston on Canada's scheme to equalise standards
fields.trailText: Bonnie Johnston on Canada's scheme to equalise standards.
fields.body:
Within six months of immigrating to Canada from China, Xiaowei Wang had already attended three different English as a Second Language (ESL) institutions. And with three different schools came three different labels of her assessed level. First she was a low-beginner in a municipal school board conversation class. Then she was a Level Two in the federally sponsored Language Instruction for Newcomers to Canada (LINC) programme that is free for all new immigrants. But after she moved to the province of Alberta and enrolled in a programme at the local college, it got really confusing.

"I told them I was a Level Two. I thought they would understand, but they just looked at me like I was speaking Chinese," Xiaowei recalls.

The Canadian Language Benchmark Project has set out to tackle this problem and to get everyone in Canada to talk about language ability and level - in the same language. The federal department of citizenship and immigration saw a need for a "made-in-Canada" approach to the measurement and description of language skills that could be used across the country.

For the past decade Canada has accepted about 200,000 immigrants and refugees a year. In 1998 almost half of those newcomers came from the Asia-Pacific region. The federal department has been strong in providing settlement and support programmes for these newcomers. However, as education is a provincial responsibility, any ESL strategy has been hampered by distance, isolation and lack of communication. As a result there are regional variations in ESL demand, delivery and the participation of the 10 provincial governments.

In 1993 the department brought together a group of teachers, learners and administrators to oversee the design and field testing of a national set of language reference points. The group concluded that the most appropriate approach for assessing newcomers' English abilities should be task-based, and those tasks should be specific to settlement issues.

In 1996 the Canadian Language Benchmarks (CLB) were first presented to providers of LINC programmes, the only nationally available programme. The aim is that the CLB will eventually be used by all institutions: private schools, continuing education programmes and college programmes, increasing the portability of assessment designations.

But what are the Benchmarks? As a LINC instructor I was at first suspicious that just another testing tool was being introduced. But I discovered that the Benchmarks are not a test, nor are they a syllabus. They have become an invaluable means by which I can describe my students' language abilities to accomplish a set of tasks. I can also speak about my students' abilities with future instructors and institutions using a commonly understood framework of references.

As a general proficiency guideline I refer to the Benchmarks when planning my lessons to ensure that my students fit into the continuity of the LINC programme. Use of the Benchmarks is voluntary, but with instructors all across the country doing the same, some consistency in programme delivery can be achieved.

There are 12 continuous Benchmark levels, and each is divided into a description of communicative competencies of the four skill areas: speaking, listening, reading and writing. For example, Benchmark 2 for reading is "developing competence at reading simple texts".

Competencies are further broken down into general performance outcomes. These outcomes are observable, measurable and teachable behaviours that the student can demonstrate. Some general performance outcomes for Benchmark 2 in reading are reading and understanding short instructions, schedules and lists, and understanding public signs with common phrases.

Performance and situational conditions supplement each competency. In Benchmark 2 in reading, students should perform the tasks demonstrating their ability to act on the text or find places on maps and diagrams. The situational conditions are that context should be immediate and personally relevant, short and most content words should be everyday familiar words to the learner.

Sample tasks complement each Benchmark and give the instructor suggestions for lesson planning. An example to go with the reading Benchmark 2 is for the student to match a shopping list with pictures of items on the list.

Before entering my class my students have been assessed between Benchmark 2 and Benchmark 3 for their speaking and listening skills, but many have much higher Benchmarks for reading and some have much lower writing Benchmarks. Using the Benchmarks as my guide, I do not feel so haphazard in responding to so many variations in skill, not only within the class, but within one student.

Although the CLB is not a testing document, agencies and institutions are creating their own assessment tools based on the Benchmarks. We use On Target!, developed in Alberta, as a resource of tasks that can be assessed against the CLB standards. There is also a project starting in Ottawa for employers in hi-tech industry to use the Benchmarks as a means of evaluating their employees' language abilities, and direct them to the appropriate programmes.

The Benchmarks focus on the needs of new immigrants. For the moment private schools that work with visiting foreign students do not use the Benchmarks, arguing that their students need internationally recognised assessment. College- and university-based EFL programmes for the most part adhere to guidelines and standards set provincially. However, in British Columbia local articulation criteria are pegged closely to CLB but have been refined to suit the needs of foreign students.

We use a flexible and open English in Canada. We accept both British and United States spellings, British and US usages, and British and US textbooks and materials. But this time we have brought our unique experiences to come up with a much-needed solution to a national standard.

 Bonnie Johnston is an ESL teacher in Vancouver, Canada. For more information on the Canadian Language Benchmarks, go to www.language.ca.

fields.headline: Global English: the European lessons
fields.trailText: However English is being used, the demographics of Europe mean that no single country can claim exclusive sovereignty over the language
fields.body:
It is estimated that the European Union has more than 180m speakers of English, but English is the "mother tongue" of only a third of that number. For the rest it is either a tool for international communication or their second language - the linguistic equivalent of the business suit, slipped into for official occasions.

But however English is being used, the demographics of Europe mean that no single country can claim exclusive sovereignty over the language. So does this mean that English has cut itself free from the ties that bind language to personal and national identity, and is Europe mapping out a new relationship with English that could be followed in other world regions?

These are the questions that will be raised at a special debate to be held at this week's International Association of Teachers of English as a Foreign Language conference in Brighton, England, jointly sponsored by the Guardian Weekly and Macmillan Heinemann ELT. In this issue of Learning English we have invited the speakers to present their views on how Europe should respond to the challenges and opportunities presented by English.

What emerges is a clear call for Europe to reassess its attitudes towards English and to explore how the region's different language communities can preserve their identities while forging closer social and economic ties.

Longer versions of these articles and audio clips from the speakers' presentations will be available on the Guardian Weekly's website this month.

 We can also announce the first-prize winners in our teachers' competition, run in collaboration with the Association of Recognised English Language Services. In our January issue we offered "non-native" teachers the chance to win one of four teacher refresher courses at leading training programmes in Britain. The winners are Maria-Grazia Ariosto from Italy, Ildiko Ban from Hungary, Machiko Uehara from Japan, and Kadri Selim Kuvan from Turkey. Second and third prize winners will receive their Longman dictionaries by post.

fields.headline: English, yes,  but equality first
fields.standfirst: Whether English is seen as enemy or friend, the EU must redraw its language map
fields.trailText: Whether English is seen as enemy or friend, the EU must redraw its language map.
fields.body:
The 11 official languages of the 15 member states of the European Union have equal rights. These languages are Danish, Dutch, English, Finnish, French, German, Greek, Italian, Portuguese, Spanish and Swedish. The languages of each member state are official and working languages of the European Parliament and the European Commission.

However, there has never been a close fit between language and state in Europe: three of Belgium's languages are in use (Dutch, French and German) and two of Finland's, (Finnish and Swedish), whereas the only language from Spain is Spanish, even though there are more speakers of Catalan than of Danish or Finnish. So demography is less important than political clout, and many languages in Europe have no EU rights.

EU languages permeate the processes of creating a "union" of states. Language is a sensitive political issue, as it is a profound symbol of national and personal identity. As language, culture and education are in principle matters for individual member states rather than the Union, language policy at the supra-national level is largely implicit and covert. As some languages are more "international" than others, the equality of the 11 languages has in fact always been a myth.

The de facto hierarchy of languages in Brussels and Strasbourg is very different. English has gradually eroded the monopoly of French. Ironically enough this has happened during a period when successive British governments have kept "Europe" at arm's length. The language policies of EU institutions are influenced by many factors, the most important of which is globalisation. The advance of English reflects American commercial, political and military might, and the impact of Hollywood, CNN and McDonald's.

The British have always been keen to capitalise on English as a strategic and commercial asset. English is the most widely learned foreign language in Europe, because Britain's partners recognise it as a necessary communicative tool. In reality English is no longer a foreign language in several member states. It is a fact of working and social life for many EU citizens.

But the market forces that are propelling English forward affect the vitality and viability of other languages. English is capturing some of their territory, despite EU treaties and summit meetings proclaiming a commitment to diversity. The Amsterdam Treaty, Article 128.4, reads: "The Community shall take cultural aspects into account in its action under the provisions of this Treaty, in particular in order to respect and to promote the diversity of its cultures." The Nice summit acted on this to approve a programme to strengthen the European film industry.

In several member states there are voices protesting against Americanisation and cultural and linguistic homogenisation. The sociolinguist Ulrich Ammon has recently written a book exploring whether German, the leading language of the natural sciences a century ago, can still be considered a language of science.

The Norwegian transport minister has protested about the website of SAS airlines, which has the three Scandinavian governments as majority shareholders, being exclusively in English. The Swedish government recently commissioned a survey of Swedish in all key domains in Sweden and in EU institutions. It documents how English is taking over from Swedish, and work is now under way to ensure that Swedish remains a "complete" language.

Several countries are thus following in the steps of the French in registering that the advance of English is a problem, and identifying strategies to strengthen local languages. No one is suggesting that English should not be effectively learned and used, but policy should ensure that people learn and use English in addition to other languages rather than at their expense.

Language policy ought to be taken seriously because it is likely that big business is doing so. A recent doctoral study in international law in the United States concludes that French language protection measures are in conflict with the principle of a common market with free movement of goods, services, labour and capital. Such an interpretation could soon lead corporate lawyers to challenge national language legislation, and demand an English-only market throughout the EU.

Countries applying for EU membership have probably assumed that their languages will have the same rights as other official languages. This is most unlikely, since the current interpretation and translation services are ineffective, and will be even more unworkable when new states join the EU.

There needs to be a rethink of attitudes. Scoffing at French efforts to shore up French is myopic. If native speakers of French and English can use their mother tongues, how can one ensure equivalent rights for others?

What is urgently needed is clarification of the criteria that should guide an equitable language policy, and mechanisms that permit real equality of communication between speakers of different languages. We need imaginative and realistic scenarios. We need to see a coming together of the relevant constituencies in the political, business, academic, cultural and human rights worlds. There is a need for hard-nosed analysis of how to ensure efficient, cost-effective and democratic strategies for increased multilingualism. In this way English can be appropriated without other languages being marginalised.

 Dr Robert Phillipson is research professor at the Department of English, Copenhagen Business School.

webTitle: Country of the week: Czech Republic

fields.headline: Country of the week: Czech Republic
fields.standfirst: Paul Jones finds teaching in the Czech Republic an interesting and rewarding experience
fields.trailText: Paul Jones finds teaching in the Czech Republic an interesting and rewarding experience.
fields.body:
Finding jobs | Salaries | Accommodation | Teaching | Living | Visas and paperwork | Useful contacts and websites

Introduction
The Czech Republic is an attractive option for those interested in teaching English in Central Europe. Prague in post-Velvet Revolution times has often been compared to 1930's Paris, and living in this city is often a source of cultural and social enrichment. There is a huge demand for EFL teachers, and with the likely entry into the EU this will certainly increase in the years to come. Unfortunately, teaching in the Czech Republic will not earn you a lot of money. It will, however, make for an exciting and interesting experience. For those seeking a more adventurous experience, there are a lot of options to work outside Prague. Once you get away from the capital, the country is wonderfully undiscovered, and the people are open, friendly and welcoming.

Finding jobs
Most people coming to teach in the Czech Republic begin in a government institution, such as a school or university. There are a lot of positions available in "gymnaziums" (secondary schools) throughout the republic. The private sector is also attracting more and more EFL teachers and if you are genuinely seeking teaching work then it will certainly find you. Various internet sites regularly offer jobs in Prague and beyond. The two sites that are particularly useful are the Prague Post and David Catto's placement agency.

If you are interested in long term prospects then the Czech Republic looks to have a solid future for EFL professionals. Most teachers stay only a year or two, which means that if you are prepared to make a longer commitment, it is possible to find better positions. The demand for learning English currently exceeds the amount of teachers, and the situation looks as though it will continue for the foreseeable future.

Salaries
Teaching in Czech schools or universities is not well paid, even by Czech standards. Despite this, the salary is enough to live a comfortable life, and often includes accommodation - free or at a reduced rate - which is an important side benefit. It is important to remember that prices in the Czech Republic reflect the lower salaries in the community. As a quick example, a full meal with drinks in a good restaurant, will cost you less than five dollars. A basic net salary of 9,000Kc-10,000Kc (about US$250) per month is to expected for 20-23 hours work. This does leave time for more lucrative private lessons (200Kc-350Kc an hour), for which there is a huge demand. Private schools do pay higher wages than are available in government institutions, but rates and working conditions at these schools vary considerably, depending on the employer.

Accommodation
Accommodation is expensive in Prague and it is an important thing to consider when accepting a teaching position in the city. Free or severely reduced accommodation is a widely accepted side benefit for foreign EFL teachers, and should be considered central to any job organised from outside the country. Accommodation usually takes the form of a flat in one of the communist designed housing estates (panelak) that dominate the landscape in the outer suburbs of Prague, and are found throughout the country.

Teaching
In the 11 years since the Velvet Revolution the education system in the Czech Republic has undergone an overhaul, which is still continuing today. Teachers from a western background will find the students extremely well disciplined - for example, they all stand every time a teacher enters the room - but often lacking in creative skills and imagination. In languages, the students have a real problem with speaking, despite often possessing strong grammar skills and large passive vocabularies.

Schools are well equipped with computers, photocopiers, textbooks and materials. Class sizes for English are from 12 to 18 students, and the school day usually begins quite early - 7.55am in the secondary schools.

Despite the low salaries, Czech teachers have a high status in society and the atmosphere among teachers at school is very good. Younger staff are particularly enthusiastic about embracing new ideas and technology in their teaching.

Living
Naturally, life in the Czech Republic is a lot different to what it was before 1989. The Czechs are a resourceful and proud people, and are keen to make up for what they consider "lost time" under communism. Prague is an architectural delight and it is a constant joy just to explore the narrow alleys and byways. With its enchanting gothic atmosphere, the city quickly intoxicates foreigners and many can never bring themselves to leave.

Another intoxicating aspect of the country is its outstanding beer, which is also the source of much pride among the Czechs. Not only are excellent beers brewed here, such as Pilsen and Budvar, but the Czechs are the highest per capita consumers of beer in the world, at a staggering 160 litres per person each year. The vibrant pub and club scene in Prague is another important aspect of social life.

Bohemians have a strong artistic history which has carried through to the 21st century. Throughout the country there are a vast number of museums, galleries and other cultural outlets.

The Czech language can be a hurdle for foreigners. It is a complex, consonant filled language. Its difficulty is perhaps best illustrated by the fact that even President Havel cannot correctly pronounce one of the letters. Most people under 35 can speak a little English, but the older generations usually had to learn Russian at school.

Czechs are also keen sportsmen and a variety of winter and summer sports are available. Ice hockey and football are perhaps the most popular, but it is possible to participate in or watch any number of different sports and activities.

In general, there are a wide range of activities and events open to teachers outside the classroom. The people are initially a little imposing, but once you get to know them you can see what friendly, intelligent and interesting people Czechs can be. For most EFL teachers in the Czech Republic, life without chalk in the hand is an active, fascinating and enjoyable experience.

Visas and paperwork
People who wish to work in the Czech Republic require a work visa which should be acquired from outside the Czech Republic. These visas are issued on a one-year basis and you will require an employer to guarantee employment before a visa will be issued. It is important to organise this at an embassy outside the Czech Republic. Czech bureaucracy is notorious and it is important to bring all possible documentation with you to avoid any future hassles.

Useful contacts and websites
The British Council is always a useful contact.

The Prague Post and David Catto's teaching agency are the most useful sites for job vacancies.

Radio Prague is also a helpful source of information.

Every summer he teaches at the TASIS international school in Lugano, Switzerland. You can email him here.

Unfortunately, teaching in the Czech Republic will not earn you a lot of money. It will, however, make for an exciting and interesting experience. For those seeking a more adventurous experience, there are a lot of options to work outside Prague. Once you get away from the capital, the country is wonderfully undiscovered, and the people are open, friendly and welcoming. There are a lot of positions available in "gymnaziums" (secondary schools) throughout the republic. The private sector is also attracting more and more EFL teachers and if you are genuinely seeking teaching work then it will certainly find you. Various internet sites regularly offer jobs in Prague and beyond. The two sites that are particularly useful are the Prague Post and David Catto's placement agency. Despite this, the salary is enough to live a comfortable life, and often includes accommodation - free or at a reduced rate - which is an important side benefit. It is important to remember that prices in the Czech Republic reflect the lower salaries in the community. As a quick example, a full meal with drinks in a good restaurant, will cost you less than five dollars. webTitle: A 'stateless' language that Europe should embrace

fields.headline: A 'stateless' language that Europe should embrace
fields.standfirst: The language policy in the European Union is both ineffective and hypocritical, and its ideas of linguistic equality and multilingualism are costly and cumbersome illusions
fields.trailText: The language policy in the European Union is both ineffective and hypocritical, and its ideas of linguistic equality and multilingualism are costly and cumbersome illusions.
fields.body:
Why have these illusions been kept up for so long? First, because the French, with their traditionally superior position in Europe, cannot accept the decline of their own linguistic power. Second, because the politically correct ideologies of some sociolinguists constantly fuel opposition against the idea of English as a European lingua franca. And third, because powerful translators' lobbies fight for their raison d'être. In the name of the high ideal of linguistic equality a time-consuming, expensive and increasingly intractable translation machinery is maintained that is doing its best to translate the illusion of equality into illusions of multilingualism and translatability.

The EU's ostensible multilingualism sets it apart from other international organisations. Instead of having opted for a "workable" number of working languages, all the official languages of the member states were given equal status. However, for a smooth functioning of the EU institutions, whose legislation ordinary people do not understand anyway, the use of English as a lingua franca would be infinitely better.

English is particularly suitable as Europe's lingua franca because of its functional flexibility and spread across the world, and because English is already "de-nativised" to a large extent: the number of non-native speakers globally is now substantially larger than of native speakers (about 4:1). English is no longer "owned" by its native-speakers, because acculturation and nativisation processes have produced a remarkable diversification of the language into many non-native varieties.

We can no longer say that English is one monolithic, "hegemonic" voice; it is a diversity of different voices. True, there may still be attempts by "inner circle" English native-speakers to perpetuate old dichotomies of "us and them", of one-way translation avenues, of controlling access to professional organisations and publications. But this has nothing to do with the English language itself, which is neutral. Such imbalance simply reflects unequal power resulting from differences in social, economic, political or scientific conditions.

The multiplicity of voices behind English as a lingua franca implies that differences in interactional norms between speakers using English as a language for communication remain unaltered. And it is this deep diversity in the use of English by speakers with different mother tongues which invalidates the claim that English is an imperialist adversary, an eliminating "killer language" - which English, we may ask?

Is it those localised, regionalised or otherwise appropriated varieties of English whose speakers creatively conduct pragmatic and cultural shifts? Surely not. Arguments such as the ones brought forward by the anti-English league are simply outdated. The empire has struck back already. Non-native-speakers of English have created their own discourse norms and genres. And they do this out of their own free will, happily ignoring the "linguistic domination" ascribed to them. In other words there is no didactic-linguistic replay of formerly colonial and militaristic means.

But might not the use of English also change other European languages to the point of gradually destroying their identities? Is English maybe already "colonising" structural and discourse conventions in other European languages? Not at all. Research funded by the German Research Foundation has shown that German, Spanish and French texts resulting from multilingual text production are not influenced by the English language on these levels. And another research project investigating the nature of interactions in English between speakers of different European languages has revealed differences in culture-conditioned ways of interacting, which, however, do not lead to misunderstanding.

English as a lingua franca is nothing more than a useful tool: it is a "language for communication", a medium that is given substance with the different national, regional, local and individual cultural identities its speakers bring to it. English itself does not carry such identities; it is not a "language for identification". And because of the variety of functional uses of global English, English has also a great potential for promoting international understanding. Its different speakers must always work out a common behavioural and intercultural basis.

Paradoxical though this may seem, the very spread of English can motivate speakers of other languages to insist on their own local language for identification, for binding them emotionally to their own cultural and historical tradition. There is no need to set up an old-fashioned dichotomy between local languages and English as the "hegemonic aggressor": there is a place for both, because they fulfil different functions. To deny this is to uphold outdated concepts of monolingual societies and individuals.

German-speakers, for instance, keep their national language and regional varieties for identification while simultaneously benefiting from using English to establish "imagined communities" in science, economics, etc, for pockets of expertise.

In western Germany in particular English has been widely accepted as a language for communication since 1945 - not least because the "Anglo-Saxon" countries served as models of democracy, helping people to forget their own past. And a recent survey of German teachers' attitudes to English revealed unanimous support for using English as a lingua franca in Europe. No one thought English destroyed his or her mother tongue's identity, no one felt that communicating in English led to inequality between speakers of English and speakers of different languages.

Using English as a lingua franca in Europe does not inhibit linguistic diversity, and it unites more than it divides, simply because it may be "owned" by all Europeans - not as a cultural symbol, but a means of enabling understanding.

 Juliane House is professor of applied linguistics at the University of Hamburg.

fields.headline: A new era for schools
fields.standfirst:
Teacher unity paves the way to better pay

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: For once the rhetoric was not overblown. The decision by the three major classroom teacher unions to join forces in a campaign to end teacher shortages and improve working conditions is historic.
fields.body:
For once the rhetoric was not overblown. The decision by the three major classroom teacher unions to join forces in a campaign to end teacher shortages and improve working conditions is historic. Yesterday a joint motion, which two teacher unions had already passed unanimously, was endorsed (with only one delegate voting against) by the third.

There is now a united front on the two most crucial issues facing the profession: pay and conditions. Where for years the annual Easter conferences have only diminished the profession in the eyes of public, parents and other unions - with inter-union bickering, blatant rivalry, and a lack of leadership - this year has been different. It could mark the first step to an urgently needed union merger.

The critical teacher shortage, which ministers have belatedly acknowledged, is umbilically linked to both pay and conditions. Schools are finding it difficult to recruit and retain staff because of the drop over the last 25 years in teachers' pay. Time for another Houghton: the independent review which a generation ago lifted teachers' pay to 37% above the white-collar average. Today it is barely above it. But conditions are equally crucial.

One reason why private schools find it so much easier to recruit staff is because of the time, outside the classroom, teachers are given to prepare and organise lessons. Proper preparation time is the key to keeping a class attentive. There is nothing like successful lessons to raise teachers' satisfaction ratings and professional pride. But over the years preparation time has been eroded as teachers have been asked to cover for vacant posts or long absences due to sickness or maternity leave.

A government ready to honour its pledge to make education its first priority has two duties: restoring teachers' pay to its old position; and recruiting more teachers. This cannot be done in a year, but could be achieved over five. It will need a large investment, but not as large as the goal set out by the prime minister last week: equality of facilities in state and private schools.

Ministers have promised a review of working conditions. Unions want to widen this to include pay, which would be right. Where they are wrong is to demand a 35-hour week. Professionals should not ask for such restricted hours - particularly when they have 13 weeks holiday a year. They should not be so unprofessional. Ministers were right to refuse. Let serious negotiations begin.

fields.headline: More backing for teachers in fight for 35 hour week
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The campaign by teachers for a 35 hour working week received a boost yesterday, after members of the second largest classroom union, the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, overwhelmingly backed a joint motion recommending a strict limit on hours.
fields.body:
The campaign by teachers for a 35 hour working week received a boost yesterday, after members of the second largest classroom union, the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, overwhelmingly backed a joint motion recommending a strict limit on hours.

The latest support for the motion puts more than 400,000 teachers in English state schools on standby to take industrial action in the autumn, if the government refuses to meet their demands.

As well as a strict limit on their hours and an improved pay structure, teachers want a full independent inquiry into pay and conditions along the lines of a deal recently struck for teachers in Scotland.

The National Union of Teachers and the Association of Teachers and Lecturers also backed the motion at their annual conferences earlier this month. The motion goes to Welsh teachers belonging to the UCAC at their conference in Abersytwyth next month, where it is also likely to receive strong backing.

At the NASUWT's annual conference in Jersey yesterday, just one dissenter chose not to support the motion after a lengthy and passionate debate.

But Martin Johnson, the union's president last year, emphasised the enormous power of the motion. Alluding to claims that Tony Blair had attended the ATL conference last week in order to try and head off the threat of a work to rule, he told the conference to loud cheers: "If the government wishes to break up this partnership, there must be some value in it."

A succession of teachers then described how their mounting workload had taken its toll on their working and personal lives.

Tony Tool from Trafford - a relatively new entrant to teaching who was used to working a 60-hour week when he ran his own business - said he had woken up one morning, "covered in blood in the arms of paramedics" after he "headbutted" his bedside cabinet following a stress-induced seizure in the middle of the night.

Sue Rogers, a member of the union's national executive and head of history at King Edward VII school, in Sheffield, told how her free time had been eaten up by having to deal with a plethora of initiatives introduced by the Department for Education and Employment.

The school standards minister, Estelle Morris, told the conference on Tuesday that she considered it unprofessional of teachers to pursue their claim for a 35-hour week. Separate talks about an inquiry into teachers' workload will begin next week between ministers and leaders of the NASUWT and the NUT.

Responding to the vote, NASUWT general secretary Nigel de Gruchy commented: "I am delighted. It shows how wonderfully effective the threat of a little action can be. I totally reject Estelle Morris's claims that this is unprofessional. It will produce good results, including good results for the pupils."

In a separate move at the conference yesterday, delegates voted unanimously to make parents more responsible for the behaviour of their children, in a bid to reduce the growing number of allegations made by pupils against teachers relating to verbal, physical and even sexual abuse.

Speakers in favour of the motion described how teachers' lives had been ruined - in some cases even leading to suicide - after they were found to be innocent of such allegations following lengthy, damaging investigations which sometimes lasted years .

In a move designed to win staffroom support, shadow eduction secretary, Theresa May, will today tell the NASUWT in a speech to the conference that schools should be free to refuse to take back disruptive pupils.

webTitle: School toll of TB cases now 50

fields.headline: School toll of TB cases now 50
fields.trailText: The number of tuberculosis cases linked to an outbreak at a secondary school has climbed to 50, doctors said yesterday.
fields.body:
The number of tuberculosis cases linked to an outbreak at a secondary school has climbed to 50, doctors said yesterday.

Screening of students and staff not covered in previous checks at Crown Hills community college, Leicester, has revealed another 18 children with the disease and 40 who might have been exposed to the tuberculosis germ.

All are being treated with antibiotics but none has needed hospital treatment. Relatives and other close contacts of the pupils are being screened during the next fortnight.

Philip Monk, consultant in communicable disease control in Leicestershire, said there was no cause for undue public concern. "There is no need for children to be kept away from school. We are confident that this situation is being managed effectively and that we are detecting cases of tuberculosis early in the disease process. All of these people will have been exposed two or more months ago."

Dr Monk said the disease may have been spread by just one source and it was understood only two students had developed the infectious form. Officials had not speculated on where the disease originated, although the fact that 93% of the students were of Asian origin might be significant. It was thought that a child might have been infected on a visit to India.

The outbreak is believed to be the worst for 20 years. Although there are about 200 cases each year in Leicestershire, only 10 to 15 affect people under 15. The Crown Hills outbreak has involved 44 students, four relatives and two teachers.

A six-year-old at a Leicester school died last year. Three children at other schools in the county have been identified as TB cases , although none of the cases relates to each other or Crown Hills. Screening will take place at those schools over the next few weeks.

fields.headline: Starfish connects the slums
fields.standfirst: Education led from computer screens in shipping containers hopes to provide girls in the slums an alternative to prostitution.  Hazel Southam  reports
fields.trailText: Education led from computer screens in shipping containers hopes to provide girls in the slums an alternative to prostitution. Hazel Southam reports
fields.body:
Over the coming year, the Starfish Initiative plans to parachute three 20ft shipping containers into Malawi, and Nagpur and Assam in India. Each will house one computer with six screens that will form a classroom for the girls and young women of the area.

The Starfish Initiative began with a story. A young girl was walking along the beach. The tide was going out and thousands of starfish were stranded on the beach.

She went along, picking them up and throwing them back into the water. An old man saw her and asked her what she was doing. "Look at the hundreds of starfish along the beach," he said. "You can't do any good." "I can for this one," she said, and threw it back into the sea.

Today's launch of the Starfish Initiative at the Lord Chancellor's Residence at the House of Lords is aimed at bridging the digital divide by providing internet computer access for girls and young women in the world's poorest slums.

Behind the scheme is 76-year-old Helen Taylor-Thompson, a direct descendant of David Livingstone. And the pioneering work is motivated by the same fight against slavery. "Maybe it's in my genes," she says. "Whenever I see something that needs doing, I do it."

Just how does it hope to achieve that? And why is it specifically targeting girls and young women?

A 1994 report from the human rights group Jubilee Action showed that one million children worldwide are lured and forced into prostitution every year. As many as 10 million children are thought to be trapped in pros titution today. Taylor- Thompson sees prostitution as slavery and wants to see an end to it through IT education. "Slavery is abhorrent to me," she says. "And it's my job to stop it."

The Starfish container schools will be run by the community leaders, including a team of nuns in Malawi.

Through the computers the girls will learn about water, childcare, nutrition and disease control, as well as how to read and write.

The three pilot projects will run off electricity, like any standard PC. But, in the next couple of years, the aim is to run similar classrooms of computers on wind power, solar energy, water power, or even by donkey power. After all, how much use is a computer room to a poor community that can't afford the costs of the electricity bills to run it?

Internet access will be hard on the heels of basic learning techniques, but the three Rs and a sense of hygiene and nutrition must come first, according to the director of the Starfish Initiative, Stephen Clarke.

In Malawi only 42% of women are literate, in Assam, the figure stands at 43%. In Nagpur, just over half can read and write.

"It will give them a glimpse that things can be different," he says. "The fundamental aim is making them feel part of changing their circumstances. That kind of confidence is enhanced through knowledge and education."

In India, where two of Starfish's classrooms will go, there are an estimated two million prostitutes, 20% of whom are aged under 15.

By providing an education Starfish hopes to enable hundreds of young girls to earn a living without resorting to prostitution.

"Prositution is also one of the very best ways of getting Aids," says Helen Taylor-Thompson.

A member of the French Underground during the Second World War, Taylor-Thompson went on to run the Mildmay Hospital in London in the 1990s, then the first Aids hospital in Europe. She watched thousands of people die, and then more when Mildmay hospitals were set up in the developing world. It was on one visit to Africa that she heard the story about the starfish and the idea for the Starfish Initiative was born.

"I remember a woman who had died of Aids. She had five children. Three had already died of Aids. Two were still alive. There was no one to look after the children.

"The Starfish Initiative is my version of taking them home," she says. "This is giving them something to live for and to stop them getting the most terrible disease."

webTitle: Human error 'not the sole cause' of fatal cancer jab blunder

fields.headline: Human error 'not the sole cause' of fatal cancer jab blunder
fields.trailText: An official inquiry into the death of a teenager who died after doctors injected a powerful cancer treatment drug into his spine instead of a vein has concluded that "human error" was not the sole cause of the incident.
fields.body:
An official inquiry into the death of a teenager who died after doctors injected a powerful cancer treatment drug into his spine instead of a vein has concluded that "human error" was not the sole cause of the incident.

The Department of Health (DoH) inquiry report says Wayne Jowett, 18, of Keyworth, near Nottingham, died as a result of a "complex amalgam of human organisational, technical and social interactions" at the hospital where he received the injection.

The report details a series of errors including lack of training for staff and poor administration and safety procedures for administration of drugs on the ward at the Queen's Medical Centre, Nottingham.

It says although the ward had operated successfully for a "number of years" that success had led to "complacency and professional myopia", which meant staff failed to question procedures.

"Unfortunately, the safety culture surrounding Ward E17's patient chemotherapy supply and administration system does not appear to be all that it should," the report says.

Chief medical officer Liam Donaldson said the NHS would implement the report's recommendations - which involve an overhaul of training and safety procedures - in order to eradicate what he called "a rare but catastrophic medical error".

Professor Donaldson said the inquiry, by Professor Brian Toft, identified "classic systems failure".

But Mr Jowett's family said the doctors treating him were to blame for his death. They refused to say whether they would take civil legal action against the doctors involved.

In a separate move, Nottinghamshire coroner Dr Nigel Chapman today recorded a verdict of accidental death in the Jowett case. Mr Jowett died on January 4 just under a month after Vincristine was mistakenly injected into his spine while he was receiving treatment for leukaemia.

Today's inquest heard from two doctors, Dr David Morton, who had been at the hospital for four months and had never given the treatment, and Dr Feda Mulhem, who had been at the hospital for two days prior to the blunder.

Both men told the inquest that they had little or no experience in giving lumber puncture treatments to cancer patients and both men apologised unreservedly for the mistake which lead to Mr Jowett's death.

Wayne Jowett's father, also called Wayne, said after the verdict: "I do blame the doctors, there were a lot of procedures that failed."

Mr Jowett refused to say if the family was considering taking separate civil legal action against either the doctors or the trust involved.

However, the family's solicitor, Paul Balen, said later that the hospital had accepted legal liability for the mistakes in Mr Jowett's treatment.

Mr Balen also read a statement on behalf of the family, which said: "Wayne's family wait with interest to see what steps the authority now take against the doctors involved.

"For all the failures of the hospital systems and of the education and training of doctors highlighted by this case, nothing should disguise the fact that the doctors treating Wayne fell short of their professional responsibilities [and] are to blame for his death."

The DoH has also published a report, by Professor Kent Woods, setting out proposals for a "clear national policy" to prevent future injection errors.
