webTitle: NHS to provide more genetic tests

fields.headline: NHS to provide more genetic tests
fields.trailText: Genetic tests for diseases such as cancer are to be made more widely available on the NHS as part of a £30m government investment, the health secretary, Alan Milburn, announced today.
fields.body:
Genetic tests for diseases such as cancer are to be made more widely available on the NHS as part of a £30m government investment, the health secretary, Alan Milburn, announced today.

He said the number of specialist consultants in genetics in England is to double in the next five years and two new national laboratories are to be established for researching new treatments and tests for genetic disorders.

The Cancer Research Campaign will allow the NHS access to its research on the BRCA2 breast cancer gene, meaning the latest breakthroughs will be available on the health service.

The charity owns the patent on the BRCA2 gene, a major risk factor in breast cancer.

More than 33,000 women are diagnosed with the breast cancer every year in the UK and more than 14,000 die from it.

The Department of Health is in talks with US pharmaceutical firm Myriad over access to its gene research into breast cancer.

As some gene research has been patented by drugs giants in the hope of developing lucrative new treatments, potentially life-saving research is not widely available.

In his first major speech on genetics, Mr Milburn said he would lay to rest the "twin spectres" of human cloning and a genetics "underclass" caused by insurance firms discriminating against people with a genetic risk of certain diseases.

New laws to comprehensively ban all forms of human cloning are to be introduced and there is to be a moratorium on the use of genetic tests by insurance companies.

Speaking at a conference in Newcastle upon Tyne, Mr Milburn said NHS genetics services were to be reorganised into a single, national network to ensure all patients had access to specialist services.

The number of specialist genetic consultants in the NHS in England will double from 77 to 140 by 2006, and 300 more scientists working in the field will come on stream in the health service.

A £10m genetics knowledge challenge fund to establish four "genetics knowledge parks" with medical and scientific expertise will also be set up.

Mr Milburn said: "Genetic advances can be a force for good, but that requires active preparation.

"The genetics revolution has already begun. It is not going to go away."

He added: "Britain's system of socialised health care means citizens can choose to take genetic tests, free from the fear that should they test positive they will face an enormous bill for insurance or treatment, or worse still that they are priced out of care or cover all together.

"Genetic advances lay bare the fallacy that private health insurance is the way forward for our country. Genetics strengthens, rather than weakens the case for Britain's NHS."

The Cancer Research Campaign has spent 12 years and £10m researching the BRCA2 gene to develop a genetic test for breast cancer.

Professor Gordon McVie, director general of the Cancer Research Campaign, said: "Breast cancer affects the lives of 35,000 women in the UK each year and kills 13,200 annually.

He added: "This test, which we always hoped would be freely available to women at greater risk of inherited breast cancer, will go some way to addressing this."

fields.headline: 5 News pays for Kilshaws escape
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: 5 News is paying the couple at the centre of the internet adoption row to emigrate, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Channel 5's 5 News is paying the couple at the centre of the internet adoption row to emigrate.

Tonight's 5 News bulletin leads with the item "The Kilshaws are emigrating, and 5 News are paying for their flight."

ITN, which makes Channel 5's news programmes, refused to specify whether the money for the flight was coming from ITN or Channel 5, saying only that 5 News was paying for the Kilshaws' tickets.

In an exclusive interview, Channel 5's award-winning reporter, Peter Lane, will ask Peter and Judith Kilshaw where they want to go.

The couple will say they are considering going to the US, where, according to Mrs Kilshaw, "these adoptions are seen as normal."

In an embittered interview with Mr Lane, she will say: "I want a fair hearing, which I haven't had in Britain and that's one of my main reasons for wanting to go."

She and her husband will criticise the British press, whom they hold responsible for the row.

And she will say to Mr Lane: "To my friends who sold out for money, I'm going to say, 'I hope you enjoy your money'.

"To the rest of Britain, I'm saying, 'Morally you've turned me over, morally you've stitched me up."

The Independent Television Commission would not comment on whether the interview was in breach of its programme code.

But it is not believed that a payment made to anyone without a criminal record is in breach of the code.

webTitle: Q&A: the turf war between the National Audit Office and the Housing Corporation

fields.headline: Q&A: the turf war between the National Audit Office and the Housing Corporation
fields.trailText:
What are they fighting about?
As parliament's spending watchdog the National Audit Office (NAO) wants to be allowed to pore over the files of housing associations to ensure that public money is being properly spent.
fields.body:
What are they fighting about?
As parliament's spending watchdog the National Audit Office (NAO) wants to be allowed to pore over the files of housing associations to ensure that public money is being properly spent.

As the sole regulator of housing associations the Housing Corporation guards its turf jealously. It points to its successful record in preventing loss of funds in the sector and claims that any more scrutiny by another body would result in over-regulation.

Does the NAO want to take over the regulation of housing associations?
No. It just wants automatic access to housing associations files. At the moment it has to negotiate with the Housing Corporation each time it is concerned about the possible loss of public funds in a housing association.

Isn't that the Housing Corporation's job?
Yes, but as a regulator of regulators the NAO needs to satisfy itself and parliament that public money is being properly safeguarded. Under this role it needs to check up on the regulation of quangos such as the corporation.

Isn't that the Audit Commission's job?
Yes, but it is answerable to government, not parliament, which has its own spending watchdog - the NAO.

How long has this war been going on?
Several years, but it came to a head recently over allegations of fraud at Birmingham-based Focus housing association. As a case study in supervision, the NAO followed the way the corporation regulated the association after the fraud emerged.

The NAO was denied access to the relevant files for six months amid suggestions that corporation officials feared they would be blamed for failing to spot the fraud earlier. In private, the corporation described the NAO investigators as amateurish.

Have they come to blows?
Definitely not. This is a war waged mostly behind the scenes, but there have been public spats. For example, in a sarcastic dig, former corporation chief executive Anthony Mayer once told the public accounts committee (PAC): "If the NAO can improve on perfection, good luck to them."

The NAO is silent on the subject in public, letting the public accounts committee fight its corner. PAC chairman David Davis describes the current system as "pointless, wasteful and absurd".

Is this just a petty squabble?
No. Arguably, it goes right to the heart of a key constitutional issue - the separation of powers between the legislature and executive. The Housing Corporation regulates housing associations on behalf of the government (the executive). The NAO needs to ensure that public money is properly spent on behalf of parliament (the legislature).

Who is winning?
After fighting what seemed to be a losing battle for years, the NAO now appears to be winning. A report for the Treasury by a committee under Lord Sharman recommended that the NAO should have automatic access to the files of housing associations and a raft of other bodies.

The report noted the "strongly-held views" from the main players involved. It also noted the government's opposition to automatic NAO access. But the government has promised to implement the recommendations of Sharman.

fields.headline: Housing associations 'cannot be trusted'
fields.trailText: The Housing Corporation must improve its regulation of housing associations to prevent the loss of public money, according to a new study by the parliamentary spending watchdog.
fields.body:
The Housing Corporation must improve its regulation of housing associations to prevent the loss of public money, according to a new study by the parliamentary spending watchdog.

The National Audit Office (NAO) study, published today, will be seen as the latest shot in a long-running turf war between the NAO and the Housing Corporation over the regulation of housing associations.

It found that housing association boards could not be trusted to provide reliable information about their organisations.

Under the current system, boards self-certify the extent to which their housing associations comply with a set of standards for the sector.

The study found that when the corporation came to validate some of the self-assessments by housing associations last year, 45% had to be reclassified from a satisfactory status to a "cause for concern" or "cause for serious concern".

It pointed out that this system risked underestimating the number of housing associations in financial trouble.

The report says: "Weaknesses in self-certification might underestimate the extent of financial risk in the sector. We were concerned that many registered social landlords (housing associations) listed as satisfactory might have warranted reclassification as observation or supervision cases, had they been visited and their returns been independently validated."

The report will be used to help bolster the NAO's campaign to get automatic rights of access to housing associations files.

At the moment the NAO has to negotiate with the corporation if it wants to examine the possible loss of public funds at a housing association, as it did after allegations of a serious fraud at the Birmingham-based Focus housing association.

The NAO's argument that it should have automatic access to such information is supported by the Commons public accounts committee, which argues this would help assure parliament that around £24bn of public money invested in housing associations over the years is properly safeguarded.

The corporation has claimed that extra regulation would be unnecessary and bureaucratic. But earlier this year the Sharman inquiry, a review of regulation for the Treasury, backed the NAO's view.

Today's report concedes that the corporation's regulation has ensured that no housing association has gone bankrupt in the past 10 years. But it highlights the growing financial risks in the sector.

It says these include tougher rent controls, low demand for social housing in many parts of the country, more diversification and the increasing number of councils transferring their homes to housing associations.

The corporation has responded to these changes by reforming the way it regulates, but the NAO study says it should do more.

It recommends improving the training and calibre of regulation staff. In a survey for the study, 60% of housing associations disagreed or strongly disagreed that the corporation had the staff with necessary business experience to regulate the sector.

The NAO report also calls for an annual report on the financial health of the sector, greater openness and a new set of financial ratios and benchmarks for detecting risk.

The corporation will respond to the report when it appears to before the public accounts committee next month.

fields.bodyText: The Housing Corporation must improve its regulation of housing associations to prevent the loss of public money, according to a new study by the parliamentary spending watchdog. The National Audit Office (NAO) study, published today, will be seen as the latest shot in a long-running turf war between the NAO and the Housing Corporation over the regulation of housing associations. It found that housing association boards could not be trusted to provide reliable information about their organisations. Under the current system, boards self-certify the extent to which their housing associations comply with a set of standards for the sector. The study found that when the corporation came to validate some of the self-assessments by housing associations last year, 45% had to be reclassified from a satisfactory status to a "cause for concern" or "cause for serious concern". It pointed out that this system risked underestimating the number of housing associations in financial trouble. The report says: "Weaknesses in self-certification might underestimate the extent of financial risk in the sector. We were concerned that many registered social landlords (housing associations) listed as satisfactory might have warranted reclassification as observation or supervision cases, had they been visited and their returns been independently validated." The report will be used to help bolster the NAO's campaign to get automatic rights of access to housing associations files. At the moment the NAO has to negotiate with the corporation if it wants to examine the possible loss of public funds at a housing association, as it did after allegations of a serious fraud at the Birmingham-based Focus housing association. The NAO's argument that it should have automatic access to such information is supported by the Commons public accounts committee, which argues this would help assure parliament that around £24bn of public money invested in housing associations over the years is properly safeguarded. The corporation has claimed that extra regulation would be unnecessary and bureaucratic. But earlier this year the Sharman inquiry, a review of regulation for the Treasury, backed the NAO's view. Today's report concedes that the corporation's regulation has ensured that no housing association has gone bankrupt in the past 10 years. But it highlights the growing financial risks in the sector. It says these include tougher rent controls, low demand for social housing in many parts of the country, more diversification and the increasing number of councils transferring their homes to housing associations. The corporation has responded to these changes by reforming the way it regulates, but the NAO study says it should do more. It recommends improving the training and calibre of regulation staff. In a survey for the study, 60% of housing associations disagreed or strongly disagreed that the corporation had the staff with necessary business experience to regulate the sector. The NAO report also calls for an annual report on the financial health of the sector, greater openness and a new set of financial ratios and benchmarks for detecting risk. The corporation will respond to the report when it appears to before the public accounts committee next month. John Bourn, head of the NAO, said: "The corporation has a good record in preventing serious financial failure in the sector, but risk in the sector is changing. Although the corporation is reforming its approach, we recommend further steps to protect the interest of taxpayers and tenants."

fields.headline: No 14. Carlisle United
fields.standfirst: Al Woodcock, editor of CUFC Online, takes us on a tour around the club he loves
fields.trailText: What makes Carlisle so different?
fields.body:
What makes Carlisle so different?

We're the most isolated club in England, and Cumbria's only professional outfit. Our supporters have the furthest to travel, yet they tend to travel in greater numbers than any other club's from the Third Division. We like to think of ourselves as a "special" club that stands out from the crowd.

Visiting fans tend to remember their trips to Brunton Park and, far from the popular myth, they look forward to their return journeys. We have become a bit of a cult club. We're not Bury, Oldham or Mansfield - with all due respect, they are dull. We are Carlisle, Super Carlisle from the North.

The high point

Reaching the old First Division in 1974-75. More specifically, topping the whole Football League after three games. It's been virtually downhill all the way since then.

The low point

Finishing second bottom last season. We also finished second bottom the season before that, but last season was worse. We got fewer points, scored fewer goals and only survived on goal difference. I would rank it worse than 1991-92 when we actually finished bottom (no relegation that season).

What's going on at the moment?

It's slightly better than last season, but our future is still in the balance with five games remaining. We have played a lot better since Christmas and had Ian Atkins been given decent financial support all season, we'd now be solid in mid-table or even pushing for the play-offs.

Are we going to stay up?

Yes, on the whole I think we'll do it. We are past masters in the art of survival.

Last fixture

A fantastic 1-0 win over Blackpool. Eight of our 11 wins this season have been 1-0. We're becoming like George Graham's Arsenal - horrid, unspectacular, but grimly efficient. This was our first win over our old enemies since December 1990, so it was a win worth celebrating.

Next fixture

Scunthorpe away. Not the most glamorous of fixtures but if we were to win it, we'd be within touching distance of safety. Our last win in a league fixture on this ground was in 1994 when our supersub Jeff Thorpe scored two goals in injury time to give us a 3-2 victory. It's gone down in legend as Thorpey's Match because he hardly ever scored any other goals for us in his long career. I reckon we'll lose, based on our Rochdale form, but we are capable of nicking a point at our miserly best.

Sore point

Lack of support for the manager from the boardroom; confusion over true owners of the club (is Michael Knighton still in charge?); and a distinct lack of personnel - ie. no chairman and only two directors.

The manager

Ian Atkins is not that successful (yet) but well-loved. After a succession of unpopular/unsuccessful managers, he has the support of fans who sympathise with his position, but it's still not clear if he'll be with us next season. He wants to stay, but his contract has a clause that allows him to be sacked at the end of this season. Not since Mervyn Day have we had a manager whose name is chanted from the terraces.

Will Atkins still be manager this time next season?

I think so. We will be pushing for the play-offs, Akkers will be a demi-god and average gates will have doubled. Time to remove those rose-tinted spectacles, I think. But we are due a half-decent season, aren't we?

What's your chairman like?

See above - we don't have one. Some might say a very enviable state of affairs, but not one that can be allowed to last. In the absence of a chairman, we have a Management Consultant, David Low, who is effectively in charge. He has proved more adept at PR than Michael Knighton in recent years, has met the fans and has done his best to answer their questions. Some call him a Knighton puppet, but he seems to be working under difficult circumstances with the club's new owners (Mamcarr Investments of Gibraltar) remaining a mystery.

Who are your rivals?

Anybody down the M6 like Preston, Blackpool (turn right) or Burnley (turn left). They have always been bigger rivals than Darlington or Hartlepool, who are closer. We used to call Newcastle rivals, but we haven't played them for 17 years now.

Kit

The current kit is an exact copy of Middlesbrough's with a few colour changes. It's a little like the famous 1974-75 First Division strip, which was actually in use for six years during the 70s. However, not as close as fans had been led to believe in the summer. The most infamous kit of recent times was the 1992-93 "bird shit" number which appeared to have been designed by a bloke with a sick sense of humour. It only lasted for one year, unsurprisingly.

Most ridiculous piece of merchandise

We don't have much at the moment owing to the running down of the club shop. However, things are slowly starting to pick up again. We can probably claim a first by being the first club in England to offer coffins in club colours. I know others do it now, but at the time it was ground-breaking stuff (if you'll pardon the pun). We also used to offer a CUFC bunk bed, which seemed a shade naff.

Mascot

Olga the Fox, Olga being an anagram of goal. The modern Olga is a typical chunky, cuddly mascot, the type I don't particularly like, but that's just me. Olga used to be a stuffed fox that was placed on the centre spot before every home game by a fat bloke dressed in a blue and white suit known as Twinkletoes. The fox now sits in a glass cabinet in the club's reception area and there is supposed to be a curse on any one who moves her. Personally, I'd like to see the centre-spot ceremony revived, if only as an alternative to the modern Olga.

Players rated

Scott Dobie is our current most valuable player, which means he'll be sold as soon as possible, which in this case means the end of the season. Arsenal, Watford, Preston and Motherwell are all interested. He is fast, is good in the air and has finally managed to score consistently, with 12 goals up to now.

In all polls conducted on the subject of Carlisle's best-ever player, Peter Beardsley comes out top. He began his professional career at Brunton Park and was always a 100% trier, as well as his outrageous skill. You could see then that he would go on to the highest level. It's a shame perhaps that he never returned to finish his career here.

As for other teams: is there such a thing as an 'accepted player from other team' ? I don't know of such a person. We don't worry about other teams that much.

Players hated

We have had a few villains this season, most notably Carl Heggs and Darren Carr, but for the most part the fans have got behind the players, recognising that they are all giving their best, even if some of them are not of the quality we would like to see. Put that down to lack of money from the board.

The least popular player ever was probably Eric Gates. Not the worst mind, as we could name a good XI of absolute turkeys. However Gates was an ex-international and he just didn't seem to care. He trotted around the field like an old pro who was just picking up his last pay packet. Even so, he managed to finish as our top scorer, which was both a measure of his occasional flashes of class and the lack of quality in the squad at the time.

What's Brunton Park like?

Not at all bad for Division Three, but then again it was being redeveloped as a stadium fit for Premiership football no less, by a certain Michael Knighton when the money supply dried up. The East Stand is one of the biggest, perhaps the biggest, in the division. Away fans are well-catered-for and even the older areas of the ground don't look too bad compared to some other stadiums at our level. However it is time to start thinking about more new and upgraded stands as other clubs are beginning to catch up.

Atmosphere

The atmosphere at recent games (four wins on the trot) has been much improved with thousands of balloons and two resident drummers. 'Who let the Heggs out?' when Carl Heggs comes on (he's normally sub these days). 'Ian Atkins blue and white army' and all the usual ones.

Local knowledge

The place to drink is the Beehive, which is practically opposite the entrance to the ground. Other watering holes include the Woodrow Wilson down Botchergate, within 15 minutes walking distance. The Rugby Club also provides hospitality adjacent to the stadium. Food is generally good. It has improved in recent years and you get a good whiff of the stuff being cooked if you sit in the East Stand.

Fanzines, links, etc.

Virtually all our fanzines have died a death. The last one I heard of that was still going was called 'Land of Sheep and Glory', although it may be dead by now. The best one of years gone by was the famous 'Cumberland Sausage'. Two of the people who wrote for it are now working in the media.

The London Branch have a monthly newsletter called 'Hit the Bar' which probably qualifies as a fanzine and is highly thought of. Other websites I rate include Dave Atkinson's Reeves is offside again, Chris McFarlane's CUFC multimedia collection and Adam Sheridan's Carlisle Till I Die.

fields.headline: 13-year-old exhumed in child abuse inquiry
fields.trailText: Police in Ireland yesterday exhumed the body of a 13-year-old, 31 years after his death, as part of an investigation into alleged abuse over four decades at a Christian Brothers reform school in Co Galway.
fields.body:
Police in Ireland yesterday exhumed the body of a 13-year-old, 31 years after his death, as part of an investigation into alleged abuse over four decades at a Christian Brothers reform school in Co Galway.

More than 130 former pupils of the reformatory, at Letterfrack in the Connemara mountains in the west, have made statements regarding conditions from the 1940s to 1975, when the school was closed.

Gardai have spent five years on the investigation, one of the largest ever undertaken in the republic, and have sent more than 12 to the director of public prosecutions after questioning former inmates living in Britain, Germany and the US.

The school, set up by the Roman Catholic order in 1884, took in boys aged six to 16, who were either orphans, came from broken homes, or were deemed to be young offenders.

The inquiry started in 1996 when a man claimed he had been assaulted there as a child, following reports of past abuse in institutions run by the Christian Brothers in Ireland. Others came forward to police with harrowing accounts after hearing about the investigation on television and radio.

Martin Cawley, who spent five years in Letterfrack, said: "We were beaten on the head with hurley sticks, scalded with hot water, and then thrown into icy water. We were ordered to stay in the freezing tub, and if we tried to get out we were battered with a leather strap." Some of the alleged perpetrators, priests and lay staff, are dead. Others are very elderly. Court appearances are expected within weeks.

Yesterday, a deputy state pathologist, Marie Cassidy, carried out a postmortem on the body of William Delaney, sent to the school in 1967 when he was 10. He died a few days after returning to spend a holiday with his family in Kilkenny in July 1970. At the time, they were told he had meningitis but have always suspected a more sinister cause of death.

His sister, Kathleen, said it had come as a shock to her family to hear of the exhumation, but they hoped it would reveal what had happened.

"My father never really got over it," she said. "He always thought something happened to him. There was one rumour he got a clout to the head, there was some talk somebody beat him with a bunch of keys.

"My mother's hoping this will put an end to it, one way or another, and that it will help others if something comes out of it."

Mary Rafftery, author of a book on Ireland's industrial schools, claimed that Letterfrack had been a child labour camp from which the order profited while the boys received little formal education.

"There was an extraordinary range of services to the local community, from tailoring, blacksmithing, wiring mattresses, all sorts of agricultural produce."

There were always rumours of ill treatment, she said. "It's one of the most isolated and bleakest spots in the country. The children ran away all the time, and the local community traipsed around the mountains looking for them - because they would have died of exposure had they not been found."

She added that education department files of the 1940s described children with bruises on their faces from what was explained as "colliding with the elbows of Christian Brothers".

To date, the order has paid more than £1m to men living abroad who complained they were abused in the order's care. It is not known whether any similar settlements have been reached in the republic. The order has also appealed for forgivenessfor individual abusers.

webTitle: I wish I'd never said that

fields.headline: I wish I'd never said that
fields.standfirst:
Since his 'foreign land' speech William Hague has been accused of playing the race card - and at every turn, it has come back to haunt him. Simon Jeffery looks at some other political gaffes

Guardian Unlimited Politics
fields.trailText: Since his 'foreign land' speech William Hague has been accused of playing the race card - and at every turn, it has come back to haunt him. Simon Jeffery looks at some other political gaffes.
fields.body:
"It is time to get back to basics: to self-discipline and respect for the law [] to accepting responsibility for yourself and your family" (1994)
Who said it: John Major
Why? To rebuild the Tories from the bottom up as the party of decent and honest family values.
What happened next: Tim Yeo, a junior minister, was revealed to have an illegitimate daughter. Soon after a string of scandal-hit ministers, including Tim Smith, Neil Hamilton and Patrick Nicholls, were forced out of office and, years later, Jonathan Aitken was sent to prison. Mr Major left government in May 1997 widely perceived to be the head of a party tainted by sleaze.

"We're awriiiight!! We're awriiiight!!" (1992)
Who said it: Neil Kinnock
Why? Walking onto the stage at a pre-election victory rally in the Sheffield Arena, Mr Kinnock was overcome by the rapturous cheers and replied to the crowd with this enthusiastic outburst.
What happened next: Labour was leading in the polls but lost the election. Pundits said that the rally had cast Mr Kinnock as a demagogue and public opinion followed. Five years later he said: "If I had my time again I would take away those four seconds of my life."

"I believe it is peace in our time" (1938)
Who said it: Neville Chamberlain
Why? Returning from Munich, the then prime minister clutched a piece of paper signed by Adolf Hitler which, he said, was symbolic "of the desire of our two peoples never to go to war with one another again."
What happened next:The second world war.

"Read my lips, no new taxes" (1988)

Who said it: George Bush Senior
Why? To win the presidential election.
What happened next: He won the election and raised taxes, which made him unpopular among voters and his fellow Republicans in Washington. The Democrat candidate, Bill Clinton, beat Mr Bush to the White House in 1992.

"Who governs Britain?" (1974)

Who said it: Edward Heath
Why? It appeared to be an appropriate slogan for the Tories, who were seeking a fresh mandate to take on the unions after a period of industrial unrest. Mr Heath's strategy was based on the belief that the voters were "fed up to the back teeth" with the miners and favoured steps to control them.
What happened next: Labour swept to power under Harold Wilson while Margaret Thatcher replaced Mr Heath at the head of the Tories.

"Most egg production in this country is infected with salmonella" (1988)

Who said it: Edwina Currie
Why? There was a spate of salmonella infection and, as junior health minister, offered her expertise on the subject.

fields.headline: Robin Cook's chicken tikka masala speech
fields.standfirst: Extracts from a speech by the foreign secretary to the Social Market Foundation in London
fields.trailText: Extracts from a speech by the foreign secretary to the Social Market Foundation in London.
fields.body:
Tonight I want to celebrate Britishness. As Foreign Secretary I see every day the importance of our relations with foreign countries to the strength of our economy, to the security of our nation, to the safety of our people against organised crime, even to the health of our environment. A globalised world demands more foreign contacts than even Britain has experienced in the past.

I also know that we are likely to make our way more successfully in the world if we are secure in our British identity, and confident about its future. That security and confidence is important for the inner strength it gives us in our conduct of business with others. I want to argue the case why we can be confident about the strength and the future of British identity.

Sadly, it has become fashionable for some to argue that British identity is under siege, perhaps even in a state of terminal decline. The threat is said to come in three forms.

First, the arrival of immigrants who, allegedly, do not share our cultural values and who fail to support the England cricket team. Few dare to state this case explicitly, but it is the unmistakable subliminal message.

Second, our continued membership of the European Union, which is said to be absorbing member states into a country called Europe.

Third, the devolution of power to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, which is seen as a step to the break-up of the UK.

This evening, I want to set out the reasons for being optimistic about the future of Britain and Britishness. Indeed, I want to go further and argue that in each of the areas where the pessimists identify a threat, we should instead see developments that will strengthen and renew British identity.

Multicultural Britain

The first element in the debate about the future of Britishness is the changing ethnic composition of the British people themselves. The British are not a race, but a gathering of countless different races and communities, the vast majority of which were not indigenous to these islands.

In the pre-industrial era, when transport and communications were often easier by sea than by land, Britain was unusually open to external influence; first through foreign invasion, then, after Britain achieved naval supremacy, through commerce and imperial expansion. It is not their purity that makes the British unique, but the sheer pluralism of their ancestry.

London was first established as the capital of a Celtic Britain by Romans from Italy. They were in turn driven out by Saxons and Angles from Germany. The great cathedrals of this land were built mostly by Norman Bishops, but the religion practised in them was secured by the succession of a Dutch Prince. Outside our Parliament, Richard the Lionheart proudly sits astride his steed. A symbol of British courage and defiance. Yet he spoke French much of his life and depended on the Jewish community of England to put up the ransom that freed him from prison.

The idea that Britain was a pure Anglo-Saxon society before the arrival of communities from the Caribbean, Asia and Africa is fantasy. But if this view of British identity is false to our past, it is false to our future too. The global era has produced population movements of a breadth and richness without parallel in history.

Todays London is a perfect hub of the globe. It is home to over 30 ethnic communities of at least 10,000 residents each. In this city tonight, over 300 languages will be spoken by families over their evening meal at home.

This pluralism is not a burden we must reluctantly accept. It is an immense asset that contributes to the cultural and economic vitality of our nation.

Legitimate immigration is the necessary and unavoidable result of economic success, which generates a demand for labour faster than can be met by the birth-rate of a modern developed country. Every country needs firm but fair immigration laws. There is no more evil business than trafficking in human beings and nothing corrodes social cohesion worse than a furtive underground of illegal migrants beyond legal protection against exploitation. But we must also create an open and inclusive society that welcomes incomers for their contribution to our growth and prosperity. Our measures to attract specialists in information technology is a good example.

Our cultural diversity is one of the reasons why Britain continues to be the preferred location for multinational companies setting up in Europe. The national airline of a major European country has recently relocated its booking operation to London precisely because of the linguistic variety of the staff whom it can recruit here.

And it isn't just our economy that has been enriched by the arrival of new communities. Our lifestyles and cultural horizons have also been broadened in the process. This point is perhaps more readily understood by young Britons, who are more open to new influences and more likely to have been educated in a multi-ethnic environment. But it reaches into every aspect of our national life.

Chicken Tikka Massala is now a true British national dish, not only because it is the most popular, but because it is a perfect illustration of the way Britain absorbs and adapts external influences. Chicken Tikka is an Indian dish. The Massala sauce was added to satisfy the desire of British people to have their meat served in gravy.

Coming to terms with multiculturalism as a positive force for our economy and society will have significant implications for our understanding of Britishness.

The modern notion of national identity cannot be based on race and ethnicity, but must be based on shared ideals and aspirations. Some of the most successful countries in the modern world, such as the United States and Canada, are immigrant societies. Their experience shows how cultural diversity, allied to a shared concept of equal citizenship, can be a source of enormous strength. We should draw inspiration from their experience.

Britishness and European integration

To deny that Britain is European is to deny both our geography and our history. Our culture, our security, and our prosperity, are inseparable from the continent of Europe.

Underlying the anti-European case is the belief that there is an alternative future available to Britain. It used to be argued that the European Union is not Europe and that Britain could exist perfectly comfortably as one of a number of European countries maintaining a loose association with Brussels. But with the majority of non-EU states now clamouring for full membership, the changing geopolitics of Europe have consigned that argument to the past.

Some anti-Europeans now argue that Britain's destiny lies outside Europe, as part of the English-speaking world and a member of NAFTA.

Yet Britain trades three times more with the rest of the EU than we do with NAFTA. The reason why over four thousand US companies have located here is because they want to export to Europe. If they only wanted to sell to NAFTA, they would have stayed at home.

Europe is where our domestic quality of life is most directly at stake, whether the issue is environmental standards, the fight against organised crime, policy on asylum or stability on the continent.

But it is not simply a question of economic and political realism that ties Britain to Europe, compelling as those arguments are. Britain is also a European country in the more profound sense of sharing European assumptions about how society should be organised. The last international survey of social attitudes put Britain squarely within the European mainstream on our approach to social justice and public services, such as health.

There are strong ties of kinship between Britain and North America. These are an immense asset to us in the modern world. The US and the UK are each others closest allies. But our value as an ally to our friends in Washington is in direct proportion to our influence with our partners in Europe.

I do not accept that to acknowledge our European identity diminishes our Britishness. Nor do I accept that membership of the European Union is a threat to our national identity.

None of our European partners, with their own proud national traditions, seem afflicted by this self-doubt and insecurity. The idea that the French, the Germans or the Spanish are attempting to erase their national identities by constructing a country called Europe is the mother of all Euromyths. On the contrary, our partners see their membership of a successful European Union as underwriting, not undermining, their assertion of national identity.

For France, Germany and Italy, the European Community was central to the renewal of their nations and the regeneration of their economies in the post-War period. To Spain, Portugal and Greece, joining the European Community was an affirmation of their freedom from fascism and a guarantee of a democratic future. To Austria and Finland, joining the European Community was a celebration of the end of the Cold War, which enabled them to make a free choice in their national orientation.

The same is true of the dozen new candidates for membership from the former communist bloc. All of them aspire to membership of the European Union because it will be an affirmation of their regained independence. None of them see it as a threat to their national identity.

Ireland joined at the same time as Britain. Its period of membership has transformed Ireland into a country with a dynamic economy and a cosmopolitan society. The result has been a new assertiveness of national identity, and confidence in their culture. We can see that for ourselves in Britain through the new affection for Irish music and dance, and the attachment to Irish pubs.

Britain has everything to gain from being a leading partner in a strong Europe. All we have to lose is the timidity which prevents us from embracing our European destiny and from recognising that it is a source of confidence in our nations future.

In the aftermath of Nice, it is clearer than ever that a strong Europe requires strong nations. With the accession of up to twelve new member states, the European Union is set to become even more diverse. In the next Inter-Governmental Conference, the challenge is to find the right balance between European and national decision-making and to enhance the EU's legitimacy by harnessing the democratic traditions of its member states.

This is a debate that Britain can play a pivotal role in shaping. But we can only do so if we reject insular nationalism and the politics of fear by engaging fully and confidently in Europe.

Britishness and devolution

The last of the three perceived threats to Britishness is the new flexibility in our modern constitution.

The devolution of power to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland will stand the test of time as one of this Governments most radical and significant achievements. The creation of a Scottish Parliament and Welsh Assembly allows both nations to choose the policies that are right for them through their own democratic structures. In Northern Ireland, devolution was needed for a different reason - to enable the communities of a divided society to share power and to work together to build a common future. In all three cases, I am convinced that our reforms were essential.

Let us put to bed the scare stories about devolution leading to the Death of Britain. Devolution has been a success for Scotland and for Wales, but it has also been a success for Britain. The votes for devolution in the referendums were not votes for separation. They were votes to remain in the United Kingdom with a new constitutional settlement. By recognising the United Kingdoms diversity, devolution has guaranteed its future. It is striking that today opinion polls in Scotland show that support for separation from the rest of Britain is lower than at the time of the referendum four years ago.

Centuries of living together and working together have created enduring bonds between each of the constituent nations that make up Britain. Our future together in a single state is all the more secure if we each respect the distinctive identity that makes some of us Scottish and others Welsh or English. That mutual respect strengthens our common identity as British.

Our peoples already practise this subsidiarity of identity in their expressions of sporting loyalty. They watch Scotland, England, Wales or Northern Ireland at football. They cheer for the British team in the Olympics. And they support Europe at golf in the Ryder Cup. In context, each is a valid expression of our identity.

We should not fear the consequences of applying this principle in political life. In Scotland, the legal and educational systems are important expressions of Scottishness. At a British level, there is a strong attachment to institutions such as the National Health Service, the BBC and the armed forces. In Europe, we work with fourteen other nations to build the Single Market and to use our joint strength in trade negotiations. Action at one level does not invalidate our commitment to work at the other levels. On the contrary, they reinforce each other.

I get impatient when I see opinion polls that ask respondents whether they feel more Scottish or English than British, or more British than European, as if these choices were mutually exclusive. Identity is not a finite substance to be shared out between competing loyalties. It embraces numerous dimensions, each of which serves to amplify and reinforce the others.

Conclusion

In our thousand years of history, the homogeneity of British identity that some people assume to be the norm was confined to a relatively brief period. It lasted from the Victorian era of imperial expansion to the aftermath of the Second World War and depended on the unifying force of those two extraordinary experiences. The diversity of modern Britain expressed through devolution and multiculturalism is more consistent with the historical experience of our islands.

Far from making Britishness redundant, it makes the need for a shared framework of values and institutions all the more relevant. To act as a unifying force, that framework must be one that reflects the realities of contemporary Britain.

It is natural for every nation to be proud of its identity. We should be proud to be British. But we should be proud of the real Britain of the modern age.

Proud that the strength of the British character reflects the influences of the many different communities who have made their home here over the centuries. Proud that openness, mutual respect and generosity of spirit are essential British values.

We should be proud that those British values have made Britain a successful multi-ethnic society. We should welcome that pluralism as a unique asset for Britain in a modern world where our prosperity, our security and our influence depend on the health of our relations with other peoples around the globe.

Tolerance is important, but it is not enough. We should celebrate the enormous contribution of the many communities in Britain to strengthening our economy, to supporting our public services, and to enriching our culture and cuisine. And we should recognise that its diversity is part of the reason why Britain is a great place to live.

Labour MEP Claude Moraes, a former commissioner for racial equality, welcomed Mr Cook's words. He said: "It is a signal that recent immigration to the UK is valued and that we have to dispense with the anachronistic language of the Tories on race and immigration once and for all."

But the shadow Cabinet Office minister, Andrew Lansley, went on the offensive: "Robin Cook is the only person who wants to talk about race, perhaps because he wants to stir up anxieties in ethnic minority communities by misrepresenting us.

"When William was talking about the threat to Britishness and the sense of a foreign land that we might see in this country, he wasn't talking about race, he wasn't talking about immigration or asylum. He was talking about policy in relation to Europe."

A Conservative spokesman denounced Mr Cook's speech as "a laughable intervention".

He said: "We will take no lessons on alleged racism from a Labour government that has resorted to empty rhetoric about 'bogus asylum seekers', whilst failing to protect the interests of people who have a genuine case for asylum.

"We will remind Mr Cook that over the past four years, the asylum bill has doubled to more than £800m, as the Labour government has lost control of the problem."

fields.headline: Tory MPs reject anti-racism code
fields.standfirst: The pledge
fields.trailText: Turmoil within the Tory party over racist campaigning deepened last night after it emerged that three Conservative MPs have refused to sign up to a Commission for Racial Equality code of conduct committing them not to stir up racial prejudice during the coming election.
fields.body:
Turmoil within the Tory party over racist campaigning deepened last night after it emerged that three Conservative MPs have refused to sign up to a Commission for Racial Equality code of conduct committing them not to stir up racial prejudice during the coming election.

They include John Townend, retiring MP for Yorkshire East, last month disowned by Tory leader William Hague when he accused immigrants of "seriously undermining" Britain's Anglo-Saxon society.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, will today make British identity a central election issue by claiming Britain is not a single Anglo-Saxon race, but a gathering of different races.Chicken tikka masala, he will tell the Social Market Foundation, is now Britain's true national dish "not only because it is the most popular, but because it is a perfect illustration of the way Britain absorbs and adapts external influences".

The CRE compact, which calls on parties to police their MPs and prospective candidates to ensure they do not play the race card during the coming election campaign, was signed last month by Mr Hague and the leaders of all other parties represented at Westminster.

News that three MPs have rejected the offer to sign the compact, which has so far been signed by 380 MPs, will deepen embarrassment for the Conservative leader and Michael Ancram, the party chairman, who is charged with investigating complaints of racism brought against the Tories as a result of the agreement.

Mr Ancram wrote last month to all candidates, telling them they were obliged to work on behalf of all con stituents regardless of ethnic background.

He instructed them to "avoid using language which is likely to generate racial or religious hatred".

The CRE invited all MPs to sign the compact, which states: "The right to free political expression must not be abused in the competition for popular votes by causing, or exploiting, prejudice and discrimination on the grounds of race or nationality."

Mr Townend and Mr Ancram were unavailable yesterday for comment. The CRE declined to release the names of the other two MPs who refused to sign the compact.

fields.headline: Culling capacity in the north-west, A little lamb meeting a painful death, and A total lack of any foot-and-mouth references
fields.trailText: FAKES, PRETENDERS, AND THAT GEEZER WHO RAN ON THE PITCH
fields.body:
FAKES, PRETENDERS, AND THAT GEEZER WHO RAN ON THE PITCH

After licking the backs of several varieties of toad last night, the Fiver was finding it rather hard to distinguish the Manchester United players as they took their pre-match photo before their Big Cup knock-out by Bayern. "Who's that fella on the left?" we asked, "He's like Roy Keane but littler." "No, he's like Eric Cantona but fatter (just)," we then decided, "and with two walruses hanging off his ears and dancing." On awaking this morning, our confusion had hardly diminished. But then, just as we opened the bacon, it came to us: "It's that cheeky Carl Power from Droylsden," we thought. And we were right.

According to reader Julie Hart: "Carl is 34-ish and originally came from the Ancoats area, he still has family there. And it's just like him to do something like this." How Julie came to be versed in Carl's mischievous streak remains to be seen. But it seems Carl blagged his way onto the pitch using the most devious plan of wearing a coloured bib. Marked up as a photographer, Power then made a well-timed dash for the team shot, got his mug snapped (and the goats of several United players) and then ran off again, covered in glory.

Unlike United themselves of course ("What a beautiful segue!" - Barry Norman). After being properly beaten over two legs by Bayern, nobody appears to be pretending that they are the best team in Europe anymore. Roy Keane reckons, "We are simply not good enough", Ryan Giggs says, "We've got to rebuild for next year", and, er, Roy Keane believes, "We are just an average team." What that makes Manchester City is anyone's guess, but it looks like it's going to be an interesting summer for the newly-crowned champions. Is there any spare culling capacity in the north-west by any chance?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE BIGGEST AND NOT BEST

Everybody loves the final stages of the Big Cup. And it's not just the big-name players and teams that get the Fiver excited. Merely anticipating Manchester United's annual April capitulation does wonders for our winter SAD, enabling us to skip into spring like a little lamb yet to meet a painful foot-and-mouth-related death. But even the most ardent Big Cup fanatic would have to concede that the early rounds are about as flabby as an Uefa executive who's enjoyed too many junkets. Which is maybe why the powers that be today mooted the possibility of a change.

According to Uefa chief executive Gerhard Aigner, the future structure of the Big Cup is - like the competition - definitely up for grabs. And in a rare nod to democracy, he said it was up to the ordinary guy in the street to let Uefa know whether the two-group-stages-then-a-knockout format needs a cull (today's Fiver word of the day, sponsored by MAFF). "Our priority criteria is the judgement of fans. If fans think the competition is right then we are right," he twittered earnestly. "If they think it is not right then we have to do something about it."

The Fiver, for one, doesn't think the current structure is right. We'd like to see Big Cup revert back to the good old days of a straight knockout. But as we tried to have a word in Gerhard's ear, we realised the money men from the powerful clubs had stole, Elber-like, in front of us. Because Uefa's main man suddenly started talking caution, caution and yet more caution. "There is always the possibility of improvement but [Big Cup] remains the top club competition in the world and we will be very reflective before we touch the format," he blabbered, before heading back to his big castle. But that's not going to put the Fiver off. We're going to email gerhard.aigner@uefa.com ourselves, and - providing our message doesn't bounce - we're going to give Gerhard our two smokin' barrels worth. Maybe you'd like to chip in. It's only a suggestion.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I think United are a fantastic side despite what happened last night. You look at their bench and they will be pretty dangerous even though they are on the bench" - Joe Royle. What more can you say?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ARE LIVERPOOL THE NEW MANCHESTER UNITED? LET'S HOPE NOT

Less than a month after English football boasted of its return to football's top table, when four Premiership teams marched bravely into the final stages of European competition, it is becoming all too clear that we are in fact a bit useless. Arsenal flattered to deceive, while the less said about rickety old Manchester United the better. Now only Liverpool can assist the babbies of Leeds United in justifying the hype, by beating a Barcelona team including Rivaldo and five-goals-in-two-games Patrick Kluivert. Oh dear.

"We know that if we perform well we can beat anybody and we can get to the final!" boasted Gerard Houllier in one of those 'Bring on Barcelona!' rallying calls he's bound to live to regret. "Barcelona are a very experienced team, they are used to winning things. We know it's going to be a difficult task for us, but it is something that is achievable," he continued, hammering the last fate-tempting nail into the coffin-lid of hope. And we're not sure the return of Steven Gerrard, Michael Owen, Patrik Berger and Danny Murphy will be enough to prise it open again.

Liverpool may be helped by the likely absence of Barca left-back Sergi, who is struggling with an ankle injury, although that good fortune is totally negated by the news that Robbie Fowler won't hesitate to take another penalty despite being to blame for his team's 73rd penalty-miss of the season against Everton. "If I got the chance to take a penalty against Barcelona tonight, then I wouldn't hesitate to step forward," he smiled confidently, some would say foolishly. "I've missed penalties before and I'm sure that at times during the rest of my career I will miss them again. That doesn't bother me." You know exactly what he means, but it doesn't stop you feeling really uneasy, does it?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Leeds United chairman Peter Ridsdale has dismissed reports in the Yorkshire Evening Post linking the club with a move for Sol Campbell as a "pipedream". He added: "We have made no transfer plans for the close season apart from the Robbie Keane deal with [Internazionale], which should be considered as done."

Internazionale and Juventus are preparing £25m bids for Patrick Vieira.

Barcelona president Joan Gaspart is planning a £25m bid for David Beckham. However Michael Rummenigge, the brother of Bayern Munich vice-president Karl-Heinz Rummenigge, said today: "I heard about an interesting one - a swap between Beckham and Rivaldo."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Manchester United saw £17m wiped off their market value today after being knocked out of Big Cup. Shares in the club fell 4%, reducing the club's value to £445m.

Aston Villa's season ticket prices will be unchanged for a third successive year next season. Villa secretary Steve Stride said: "This is not a knee-jerk reaction to attendance figures. Our crowds are actually on a par with last season when we reached the FA Cup final. But we want to get them back to the level of two years ago - and hopefully even higher now that we have a 43,000 capacity."

PSV striker Ruud van Nistelrooy is back in the Dutch squad for next Wednesday's World Cup qualifier against Cyprus.

Brighton striker Bobby Zamora has won the Nationwide player of the month award for March.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

BBC1: Match of the Day Live - Liverpool v Barcelona (8pm) The story of The Littlest Bobo continues with our hero aghast. "This is getting ridiculous. I mean, look at that Lineker bloke. Knee high to a grasshopper, he is."

Channel 4: Football Stories (10pm) "I used to be on the BBC, you know."

Football Italia (3am) "And that - hic - James Richardson he's no younger than a child!"

Channel 5: Jonathan Pearce's Football Night (11.50pm) "I used to look better on television, sitting in my tweed suit, than this fat lummock."

Dutch Football (12.20am) "And as for that Peter Brackley, he'll get what's coming to him!"

Argentine Football (2am) " Even Archie MacPherson is on telly more often than me!"

Sky Sports 1: Football League Review (6.30pm) "That's it! I can't take any more! I'm jumping out of this dramatically handy window. Aaaiiiiiieeeeeeeee!!!"

Non-League Football Show (7pm) Falling

Fifa TV (7.30pm) falling

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm) falling

Australian Soccer League (11pm) fa - BUMP.

British Eurosport: Euro Vase Football (10.15pm) " zzz-wha-? Thank the lord, it was yet another bad dream. Ah well, I suppose I should thank my lucky stars. At least I'm still presenting ITV's Tuesday night Big Cup highlights programme."

Radio 5 Live: Sport on 5 with Ian Payne (7pm) "What was that? As both Leeds games will be covered live, the viewing figures for the highlights of the other semi-final will almost certainly be tiny, reducing my public profile to next to nothing?"

webTitle: When you wish upon a tsar

fields.headline: When you wish upon a tsar
fields.standfirst: A Lithuanian mushroom magnate has become one of the country's most despised and admired men, after opening a Disney-style Soviet nostalgia theme park, writes Kate Connolly
fields.trailText: A Lithuanian mushroom magnate has become one of the country's most despised and admired men, after opening a Disney-style Soviet nostalgia theme park, writes Kate Connolly.
fields.body:
Viliumas Malinauskas personifies the rich pickings available to entrepreneurs after the 15 Soviet states gained their independence a decade ago. The mushroom magnate, collective farm boss and former wrestling champion has made millions during that time.

Much of it was in evidence as he proudly showed me round his modern glass and marble mansion, his park grounds, collection of exotic birds, cabinets full of trophies for his award-winning mushrooms, and a preserves-processing plant, on a snowy day 18 months ago.

Now the gruff-voiced 59-year old, who physically resembles a bouncer, has further increased his status in his native Lithuania by opening a Disney-style theme park in his town of Druskininkai, 90 miles from the capital Vilnius. Guests invited to the opening ceremony earlier this month were greeted by a Stalin impersonator and an actor dressed as Lenin, who handed them shots of vodka and tin bowls of borscht soup.

When I met him, the park's working title was Lenin Land, but it has now been named Stalin World, increasing the criticism that Mr Malinauskas is exploiting the all-too recent history of his country. While most theme parks are decked with colourful roller coasters and ice-cream kiosks, Mr Malinauskas' park is characterised by the barbed wire that circles it.

Guard towers and loud speakers, which broadcast patriotic Soviet songs, add to the decor. Foundations for prison barracks have been laid, and plans are underway to build a replica of a 1941 Vilnius railway station where guards in Soviet uniforms would escort "visitors" on cattle trucks and send them to mock Siberian camps or gulags.

Depending on how the park goes, the mushroom king also wants to reconstruct the hunting lodges of communist apparatchiks, where visitors will be able to enjoy an array of sport and leisure facilities.

The highlights of Stalin World are Lithuania's old 65 Soviet sculptures perched next to wooden walkways built to resemble those in the gulags and which include decapitated Marxes, thumbless Lenins, and huge, seated iron Lenins.

Mr Malinauskas smelt the scent of a great moneymaking scheme two years ago, when the Ministry of Culture launched a competition searching for a way to deal with the old social realist structures which were rusting in backyards throughout Lithuania.

The mushroom mogul was the only entrant not to request state support, and offered to transport the fallen idols out of sight. "This is my contribution to history," he told me as we walked around the beginnings of the theme park and he lovingly wiped snow from Marx's face, and sat on Lenin's lap for a few minutes' rest.

"People must know about the past and you can't turn your back on history - if you do, it'll come back to haunt you." The Soviet figures previously held court in town squares across the country until Lithuania gained independence in 1991, when they were enthusiastically torn down. In the mid-90s a government-commissioned survey revealed over 70% of Lithuanians to be in favour of placing the statues in a park.

But Mr Malinauskas could hardly have chosen a more sensitive subject for his park. In June 1941 alone, an estimated 34,000 Lithuanians were sent to Siberia and about 80% of them did not survive their first winter there.

During the Soviet era an estimated 300,000 Lithuanians were deported to gulags. These horrors are still fresh in the minds of many. Scores of organisations representing former partisans and political prisoners have accused Mr Malinauskas of seeking to exploit their misery and of belittling the memory of those who were murdered by Stalinists.

"We need monuments which reflect the reality of how people suffered, not a park that puts these murderers back on their pedestals and pretends that Soviet repression was some kind of magical Disney-like experience," the local MP from Druskininkai, Juozas Galdikas, told me.

He has worked alongside the pressure group Labora, whose members have been on hunger strike to try to get the government to react to a project which is "covered in Partisans' blood".

Some of his critics have tried to discredit Mr Malinauskas, suggesting he is a former KGB agent and that he has financed Stalin World by running a brothel from his estate. But Mr Malinauskas has slammed his critics as "fascists" and said that he is vaguely sympathetic having lost his own father to the gulag.

"But exactly because 100 million people died due to the ideas of Marx, we have to remind people of the cruel times, otherwise new people will come to manipulate us in the same way." The Lithuanian tourist board has confirmed that Mr Malinauskas' creation could be a huge boost to the country's tourism industry, predicting up to 2.5m visitors a year.

Sweden is also believed to be in talks to put on an extra Stalin World ferry to deliver Scandinavian visitors. The locals are delighted. They see Stalin World as the key to revitalising the economy of a region which was once a popular spa resort, but where unemployment currently stands at around 18%.

fields.bodyText: Viliumas Malinauskas personifies the rich pickings available to entrepreneurs after the 15 Soviet states gained their independence a decade ago. The mushroom magnate, collective farm boss and former wrestling champion has made millions during that time. Much of it was in evidence as he proudly showed me round his modern glass and marble mansion, his park grounds, collection of exotic birds, cabinets full of trophies for his award-winning mushrooms, and a preserves-processing plant, on a snowy day 18 months ago. Now the gruff-voiced 59-year old, who physically resembles a bouncer, has further increased his status in his native Lithuania by opening a Disney-style theme park in his town of Druskininkai, 90 miles from the capital Vilnius. Guests invited to the opening ceremony earlier this month were greeted by a Stalin impersonator and an actor dressed as Lenin, who handed them shots of vodka and tin bowls of borscht soup. When I met him, the park's working title was Lenin Land, but it has now been named Stalin World, increasing the criticism that Mr Malinauskas is exploiting the all-too recent history of his country. While most theme parks are decked with colourful roller coasters and ice-cream kiosks, Mr Malinauskas' park is characterised by the barbed wire that circles it. Guard towers and loud speakers, which broadcast patriotic Soviet songs, add to the decor. Foundations for prison barracks have been laid, and plans are underway to build a replica of a 1941 Vilnius railway station where guards in Soviet uniforms would escort "visitors" on cattle trucks and send them to mock Siberian camps or gulags. Depending on how the park goes, the mushroom king also wants to reconstruct the hunting lodges of communist apparatchiks, where visitors will be able to enjoy an array of sport and leisure facilities. The highlights of Stalin World are Lithuania's old 65 Soviet sculptures perched next to wooden walkways built to resemble those in the gulags and which include decapitated Marxes, thumbless Lenins, and huge, seated iron Lenins. Mr Malinauskas smelt the scent of a great moneymaking scheme two years ago, when the Ministry of Culture launched a competition searching for a way to deal with the old social realist structures which were rusting in backyards throughout Lithuania. The mushroom mogul was the only entrant not to request state support, and offered to transport the fallen idols out of sight. "This is my contribution to history," he told me as we walked around the beginnings of the theme park and he lovingly wiped snow from Marx's face, and sat on Lenin's lap for a few minutes' rest. "People must know about the past and you can't turn your back on history - if you do, it'll come back to haunt you." The Soviet figures previously held court in town squares across the country until Lithuania gained independence in 1991, when they were enthusiastically torn down. In the mid-90s a government-commissioned survey revealed over 70% of Lithuanians to be in favour of placing the statues in a park. But Mr Malinauskas could hardly have chosen a more sensitive subject for his park. In June 1941 alone, an estimated 34,000 Lithuanians were sent to Siberia and about 80% of them did not survive their first winter there. During the Soviet era an estimated 300,000 Lithuanians were deported to gulags. These horrors are still fresh in the minds of many. Scores of organisations representing former partisans and political prisoners have accused Mr Malinauskas of seeking to exploit their misery and of belittling the memory of those who were murdered by Stalinists. But Mr Malinauskas has slammed his critics as "fascists" and said that he is vaguely sympathetic having lost his own father to the gulag. fields.headline: Newspaper Society loses marketing chief
fields.trailText: 4.15pm: Newspaper Society marketing director Chris Stanley is leaving to join advertising company MatchWork, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Newspaper Society marketing director Chris Stanley is leaving in June to become managing director of the UK division of the advertising company, MatchWork.

Mr Stanley leaves the Newspaper Society after six years, during which he has overseen the establishment of a marketing force for the regional press.

He has led a 25-strong team at NS Marketing, providing a range of support services to regional newspaper publishers and information for the media industry.

Among Mr Stanley's achievements at NS Marketing is the Creating New Perspectives campaign, a programme of solutions to make it easier for national advertisers to use the regional press.

He joins Danish company MatchWork, which helps media owners generate more revenue from the recruitment advertising market.

"It is hard to leave such a good team that is making a real difference, but the excitement of the new challenge was irresistible," said Mr Stanley.

"I wish Chris every success in the future. He has contributed enormously to the Newspaper Society's overall reputation since he joined us in 1995," said David Newell, the director of the Newspaper Society.

The society is now seeking Mr Stanley's successor.

fields.headline: ONdigital makes u-turn on internet TV
fields.trailText: 4pm: The TV operator is offering ONnet web-TV boxes to non-subscribers, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
ONdigital has done an about-turn on ONnet, the internet TV box it launched last September as an addition to the ONdigital set-top box.

The digital terrestrial operator originally stipulated that ONnet would only be made available to ONdigital subscribers.

But it is now offering ONnet boxes as standalone internet-TV products and has even cut the cost of subscribing to ONnet for non-ONdigital subscribers for the first three months.

ONdigital subcribers have to pay £5 a month to rent an ONnet box.

However, non-subscribers only have to pay £4 a month - although this goes up to to £8 after three months - and they have to sign a minimum 12-month contract.

ONdigital has signed a deal with Lastminute.com to be the exclusive distributor of ONnet, although this is just a short-term measure as other retailers are expected sign up shortly.

A spokeswoman for ONdigital explained the move was a "natural progression".

She denied the change of strategy had come about as a result of Granada abandoning its plans for Powerchannel, its own internet-TV product.

Nevertheless, industry pundits have questioned the move.

One said: "I think it's a clear sign of just how desperate ONdigital is. Nobody wants it [ONnet]. I think ONdigital wishes it never started with it."

Another said the move smacked of poor sales and implied ONdigital was not shifting enough ONnet boxes, despite its claims of signing up around 70,000 households.

webTitle: Mandy Rudczenko on her baby's cystic fibrosis

fields.headline: The trouble with Leo
fields.standfirst: Mandy Rudczenko  knew her baby was ill. But she was completely unprepared for the diagnosis: cystic fibrosis
fields.trailText: Mandy Rudczenko knew her baby was ill. But she was completely unprepared for the diagnosis: cystic fibrosis.
fields.body:
At four months of age, Leo started producing oil out of his bottom - it flowed out like pure sunflower oil when I changed his nappy. At first I thought I'd been eating too many curries. "Has anyone else witnessed this?" asked the health visitor. They hadn't. I was alone with the image of it - and the worry.

When Leo was born he weighed 9lb 9oz. "A real bruiser," announced the midwife proudly. "What is she so proud of," I remember thinking. "She hasn't just gone through 22 hours labour to have him sucked out with a sterilised Dyson attachment." I spent the next few days smugly telling everyone that Leo would soon outgrow his carrycot.

At three months, Leo weighed 10lb 3oz and had plenty of room in his carrycot. Other babies were getting bigger, but Leo seemed to be shrinking and my heart was breaking.

All his symptoms were put down to a bout of brochialitis at the age of five weeks. This meant an eye-opening stay in hospital; breastfeeding two hourly with no meals provided. The consultant was convinced Leo would "sort himself out", and said he had "seen a lot worse". I lay awake at night, raking up my limited knowledge of biology to try and work out what could be wrong - worms? In my heart of hearts I knew something wasn't right. I reported the oily nappies to the GP, who said: "Classic symptoms of cystic fibrosis ... but don't worry, I'm sure it's nothing serious." Yes, I did go home and worry my socks off and yes I did go home and grab every book with any fleeting reference to CF. That was a mistake: "... but now CF sufferers can live up to the age of 30 ..."; "... are generally unhealthy ..."; "... all males are sterile ..."

I cried on the phone to various people, who all reassured me he must be OK - no babies had slipped through the Guthrie heel prick test (done at birth) for years. I relayed my horror to the consultant who called Leo "fatty" and offered to arrange a "sweat test", which is the diagnostic tool for CF. The technician cheerily informed me that they assume the results will be normal; any problems and the whole world is phoned. I walked away and knew they would phone.

Finally, Leo is getting the treatment he needs and is starting to outgrow his carrycot. Everyone is being very positive, the medical team are the best thing since sliced bread; but every now and again my heart breaks.

From a factual point of view, CF is an inherited disease which results in too much mucus being produced in certain organs in the body, mainly the lungs and the digestive system. Hence Leo's constant cough and his "oil-rig" bottom - the mucus was stopping him from absorbing fat. The oil became apparent at four months when I introduced bottle feeding; apparently the fat in powdered milk is harder to digest than in breast milk.

CF is the UK's most common life-threatening disease, affecting more than 7,000 people. Genetically, both parents must be carrying the defective gene that causes CF, but even then you must be unlucky: you then have a one in four chance of your child being born with the disease.

I sometimes wonder: "What if we had had sex the night before or the next night?" The sexual lottery might not have thrown up CF ... But I've also come to realise that Leo's genetic combination also contains ... Leo. His placid, patient, smiley warmth.

We have seen the funny side: "life begins at 40", "he won't have to worry about a pension". We have to be positive for his sake; in 10 years' time, gene therapy may mean a more normal life expectancy - Leo can then expect what most of us take for granted.

 For more information, call the Cystic Fibrosis Trust on 020-8464 7211.
