fields.headline: James Meek
fields.standfirst: If you must drill a hole in someone's head, make sure it's worthwhile
fields.trailText: If you must drill a hole in someone's head, make sure it's worthwhile.
fields.body:
When Heather Perry of Gloucester had a hole drilled in her head by an amateur surgeon last year, she said she felt better afterwards. She said she had acquired more mental clarity.

Puncturing the skull - trepanning - has a long history in medicine. It goes back to the stone age: neolithic skulls have been found with holes punched out of them. But you don't need a lot of mental clarity to understand that the process is not a sensible idea, particularly when carried out by an amateur. You need a hole in the head like you need a hole in the head.

The two men who carried out most of the operation - Perry actually made the first cut herself, using a scalpel, with one of the men holding a mirror - have just been fined and put on probation in their native US after pleading guilty to practising medicine without a licence. They are also undergoing psychiatric tests.

Until the 19th century, no sawbones worth his salt would be without one or two trephines - small circular saws used to make a hole in the skull - in his black bag. In those days, the theory behind the practice was similar to the idea behind bloodletting: relieving the pressure. It wasn't a bad theory. Sometimes people do suffer bleeding inside the head which can cause dangerous pressure on the brain. But Perry was suffering from chronic fatigue syndrome.

Today there is a new form of trepanning, linked neither to old-fashioned bloodletting nor conventional modern neurosurgery. Medical researchers are beginning to drill into patients' heads experimentally, in order to implant nerve cells inside their brains.

In Sweden and, more recently, in the US, scientists have implanted foetal brain cells inside the brains of people suffering from Parkinson's disease in the hope that this will promote the production of dopamine, a natural substance of which victims of the disease are deficient. In San Diego earlier this month, a 60-year-old former teacher had holes drilled into her skull in order to receive implants of her own skin cells, genetically modified to produce a substance called nerve growth factor in the hope that it would alleviate the symptoms of Alzheimer's disease.

In Guildford and London, researchers with a company called ReNeuron are working towards trials which will involve treating stroke patients by implanting genetically modified nerve cells, grown in a lab, into their brains.

The first two methods have their critics. The results of the US Parkinson's trial have been sobering: a minority of patients suffered side effects so severe that one of the researchers said they were worse than the disease - and irreversible. The Alzheimer's trial, it is suggested, represents an excessively radical solution to treating symptoms when most modern researchers are focusing on the cause of the disease. And ReNeuron's project faces a regulatory mountain to climb before it gets the go-ahead to begin work in humans.

In all these cases, the scientists involved might object to their work being mentioned in the same breath as trepanning. But there are two similarities. One is that, as the US trial suggests, implanting cells inside the human brain is even more of a hit-and-miss affair than most trials of new therapies; even if it works, the mechanisms of the brain are so complex and mysterious that the scientists will have trouble saying exactly why it works. The other is that in the US trial, some patients did get holes in the head, and nothing else. The volunteers were all "trepanned", but some got foetal cell implants, while a control group did not.

ReNeuron believes that US researchers and regulators went too far in sanctioning such a step. They're right. If ReNeuron does get permission to carry out its first phase trials, British stroke victims, even volunteers, shouldn't be made to endure sham surgery. Let's hope good therapies come out of all the trials.

But those who license trials in Britain must be more demanding than usual of ReNeuron in establishing that they have powerful evidence from their lab work to make the risk of delving into the unpredictable brain worthwhile.

 Sarah Boseley is away.

fields.headline: Three days to go ...
fields.standfirst: For 12 weeks we've followed his gruelling training regime for this Sunday's marathon (and his obsession with isotonic drinks and toilet training). But with time running out, it's all going horribly wrong for  David Munk
fields.trailText: For 12 weeks we've followed his gruelling training regime for this Sunday's marathon (and his obsession with isotonic drinks and toilet training). But with time running out, it's all going horribly wrong for David Munk.
fields.body:
It is so near now my nose has begun to twitch. In less than 72 hours I'll have to start thinking about my running vest, my shorts, my nipple plasters, my Vaseline pot, my toilet. And thinking of 40,000 people dressed in Lycra and cotton standing behind a line worrying whether they'll ever experience pleasure again.

Just writing this is making me feel ill. That dry tongued, winded, ill feeling you get when you know something awful is about to happen, that you're about to go through a truly ghastly experience and you can't get out of it. I'm being reeled in like an unfortunate fish to the waiting net of hideousness. I don't think it can get much worse.

And then it does ... my mother calls from Taunton to spread the news that she's coming to London for the race. She's raised some sponsorship for me from a few bewildered friends.

"It's only £200. No one reads the Guardian down here you know," she says. My dad is apparently preparing a cheese sandwich packed lunch. I'm 34 years old, but suddenly I'm 14 again and my parents are coming to watch me compete. They'll probably bring a hamper and blanket. Can things get much worse?

The next blow comes in the form of a late injury. I was going along quite nicely the other day, dreaming of glory and beer, when I felt a twinge in my knee. In fact it was more than just a twinge, it was a dull, throbbing, deep pain - like someone was pushing a thick metal rod under my kneecap and was gently trying to lever it off. I was initially surprised. I stood there looking quizzically at my joint, not really connecting with what was happening. And then I understood and I was angry. I was injured. If I could have kicked myself without falling over I would have done so. How could this have happened? Did I not know what I had been through? Did I not appreciate what it had taken to get me here?

I worked it out. I've trotted 310 miles since this wretched training regime began - 310 miles. From London to the Scottish borders - fuelled by sandwiches, pasta and sickly sweet isotonic fluids. I've endured pain beyond my wildest fantasies, learned more about bowel movements than I'll be able to forget, fallen off one treadmill, had 237 conversations about running (four of them interesting), beaten one five-time olympic gold medallist in a half marathon, been attacked by one dog, subscribed to a running magazine and seen more of north London's streets than a north London street sweeper. In a short space of time - three months - I've become an expert. People have taken to asking for my advice about things: exercise regimes, sports injuries, gardening, origami.

Perhaps I'd missed it before, but now I realise the marathon has become the focus of my life. I've evolved around running.

So this is where it leaves me. I've not run for nearly 10 days. But although worried, I am also silently joyful; it's a medical fact - I can't get any fitter before Sunday. I've done the best I can. I have to take it easy, take the lift, not the stairs, treat myself to a Starbucks with full-fat milk. I need to rest, relax, enjoy. Besides, surely 90 days of hard training have benefited my body in other ways. I consult the mirror in the bathroom and my lightened mood darkens.

I see little difference. Previously I could get by being called slim with a baggy shirt on. Today I'd be called baggy if I wore a slim shirt. No change. My jaw line looks about the same. My ears still move when I chew. I have a split finger.

I suppose it should come as no surprise. After all, I've managed to drink or eat every calorie that I shed. My fridge has rarely been so popular - I've broken the handle twice and fixed it with superglue. After all, why was I doing the marathon - for the fun of it, charity, the challenge, to get fit?

I break off my thoughts to take in the latest piece of terrible news. The race organisers have made a mistake. I've been given my running number. It's 9,363. Fran, my flat and running mate, is in the 40,000s. We will be starting from different gates - literally miles apart. But Fran's my running rock. I know we'll get round together. There must be some mistake.

I go onto the Flora London Marathon website and call up last year's results. There is a device by which you enter an individual number and it brings up results for that runner, time, place. In 2000, number 9,363 was Ian Stidston, then 37 years old and British. He came 1,129th with a time of 2:59:46. That's a sprint. I'm in with the elite. Even if I get to the start with my dodgy knee I'll be ridiculed within five miles. My ears will be flapping with the breeze of passing runners.

I need some advice. So I give Ian a ring. This year he's sensibly appearing in an amateur dramatics production. He tells me of the joys of crossing the line, the camaraderie of the finishing tape when stranger talks to stranger in euphoric harmony. He warns me of downs - "the cobbles at Tower Bridge are the worst" - and tells me of the ups: "They give you a goodie bag at the finish and I ate everything." He tells me he followed a three-hour "marker" or pacemaker round the course and came in 14 seconds under his target time. I can tell he's still happy.

I'm being reeled in like an unfortunate fish to the waiting net of hideousness. I don't think it can get much worse. And then it does ... my mother calls from Taunton to spread the news that she's coming to London for the race. She's raised some sponsorship for me from a few bewildered friends. "It's only £200. webTitle: Kenyan medicine man cures drug addict

fields.headline: 'Heroin was killing our son. If he was a dog he would have been put down. The Maasai was our last chance'
fields.standfirst:
James Astill on the Kenyan medicine man and the drug addict from Devon

Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: James Astill on the Kenyan medicine man and the drug addict from Devon.
fields.body:
Down in the Maasai Mara, two skinny men are conferring over a goatskin, a pile of stones and liberal gobbets of spit. Kasaine ole Musanga, the shorter by a foot, is an oloiboni - a Maasai medicine man. Cameron Kirk, a heroin addict from Devon, is his patient.

Musanga chuckles as he turns the prophetic stones with his forefinger. There are 400 of them: yellow, blue and black, the size of broad beans, all polished by the swirl of the Mara river. But it is not clear whether it is the stones that have pleased him, or something the younger of his two wives has said. She is pointing at the middle-aged white couple, Cameron's parents, John and Sue. They are staring fixedly at Musanga, though their hands are in constant motion; wiping away sweat, flicking at flies.

Musanga is sitting in the shade of his manyatta, a squat one-room house of woven branches stuccoed with cow dung. His guests are crouching in the manure that is everywhere, under a fierce, midmorning sun.

Knowledge of natural medicines runs deep in Maasai culture. Fathers teach sons how to treat their cattle and themselves with the barks and leaves of Kenya's southern plains. The oloiboni, separate from but not inferior to the clan chief, is a sort of consultant to this tribe of general practitioners.

Before battle or a lion hunt, Maasai warriors go to the oloiboni for a stimulant - for medicine to make them brave. When their cows die suddenly - or when anything unexpected happens - the oloiboni finds an explanation in the stones.

Musanga scoops up the pebbles into a gourd, spits into it, and mutters something. Then he pours them out again and makes his diagnosis. Cameron has forgotten the bad medicine; but he needs to get stronger.

Cameron, 25, puffs nonchalantly on a cigarette, happy to believe him. Musanga's combination of mysticism and herbalism has achieved what years of methadone, rehab and psychiatric treatment could not. Cameron has been clean for three months; ever since his father, John, a retired RAF sergeant, bundled him off to the Mara. The needle marks peppering his forearms and feet have healed and they show pink through his tan. He no longer believes he will die a junkie.

Two years ago, the Kirks flew Cameron out to Nairobi, where Sue was working with the Foreign Office, to straighten him out. It was a disastrous move - Cameron was soon injecting up to a gramme a day of heroin, purer than he had dreamed possible in England. Nairobi's rehabs said he was a hopeless case and the police had started using his nickname, "kiketi [heroin] man", when they stopped him in the street.

It could not have been long before Cameron was charged and given a mandatory seven to 10-year sentence for heroin possession. Even the healthiest foreigner finds it difficult to survive Kenya's violent, typhus jails. And Cameron, who is 6ft 5in, weighed less than nine stone.

Reasoning that prison in England - to which Cameron was no stranger, let alone foreign - was a healthier option, John decided to send him back. Meanwhile, he kept Cameron in heroin to keep him from crime.

"They were the worst weeks of my life," he says. "I was watching my son killing himself and I was assisting him. If a dog was in that condition, you'd put it down."

But even as John was driving to pick up Cameron's ticket, he was hailed by two Maasai friends. "I told them what I was doing - they knew all about Cam," he says. "But they said, 'Don't bother. We'll take him.'"

"I wasn't thinking about an oloiboni. The idea was just to take him where escape would be impossible, let him live with the Maasai, and reinvent himself as a man - because they wouldn't put up with any shit from him."

High as a kite, Cameron was easily deceived. John drove him down to Narok, the last dusty town before the great plains. There he left him with the Maasai pair, and with seven vials of pethadin to see him through the worst of withdrawal. When Cameron realised what was happening, he reached into his sock for a wrap of heroin and a syringe.

Unfortunately, John's friends were not the noble warriors he had thought them to be. They dumped Cameron in a budget safari camp and went off to drink the money for his upkeep. For Rosemary Ngigi, who helps run the safari camp, his cold turkey was something else. "He couldn't walk, he couldn't talk, he couldn't eat, he couldn't sleep. Oh, he looked horrible!" she says.

"At first we were scared because we thought he had Aids. Then we saw he was out of his mind. He'd forget his cigarette until you could smell it burning his fingers. We thought he was about to die - that's what he was saying too."

In his six years as a heroin addict, Cameron had never experienced withdrawal for more than a day. In rehab, he had been given powerful opiates and sedatives, methadone, largactol, rohypnol, pethadin and mogadon, to mask the symptoms. Otherwise, the closest he had come was when accidentally locked into his second floor King's Cross flat, terrified by the rising nausea, he jumped out of the window, breaking his pelvis.

But for four days, and despite the pethadin he was jabbing frantically into his backside, Cameron experienced a full heroin withdrawal.

"I woke up in a tent, sweating, feeling very sick," he says, apologising for his jumbled thoughts: he is not used to remembering things, he says. "By evening, the goose-bumps had come up. And the next three days were just horrible. I was retching all the time, and shivering, sweating, lying there with this horrible smell inside my nose, like there was shit up my nostrils."

Musanga gave Cameron a basin of water, sprinkled with herbs, to wash with and powdered herbs to lick off his hand. "Within 15 minutes I felt totally different," says Cameron. "I still couldn't sleep, but I was relaxed. The sweats had halved, I'd stopped retching and after an hour I realised I was starving. I got up and ate till I thought I'd explode."

For the Maasai, the power of the oloiboni is beyond question. "I'm not surprised Musanga helped Cameron because I have seen it many times," says Salash Lealo, a local warrior. "The oloiboni can tell when the dry season is coming and when the rains are coming. I have seen him cure people who were so crazy we had to tie them up to stop them running off into the wild."

Cameron awoke from the worst of his cold turkey without any such faith: "But I thought, 'I've come here, and this bloke, whether he's legitimate or not legitimate, has washed me with something and given me something, and I feel better. Let's see what he can do.'"

Besides which, Cameron had no choice. There are no heroin pushers among the Maasai. And the lions prowling around the camp ruled out a hitch-hike back to Nairobi.

Musanga has been treating Cameron almost every day since. For a fortnight, Cameron moved into the smoky manyatta to live under the oloiboni's eye. Twice, Musanga took his patient into the bush, slaughtered a lamb, and forced quarts of soup mixed thickly with herbs into him.

But generally, the treatment remains the same: a shamanistic diagnosis followed by a draught of herbal medicine. The Kirks say it has given them back their son. "When he used to come out of rehab, he looked wild, still full of drugs; now he looks like the boy I had."

Watching Cameron charming his way around the camp, chatting up backpackers, trying his Maasai out on the cooks, it is hard to believe that a few weeks ago a coherent sentence was beyond him. Watching his turn of speed running the hyena gauntlet between two campsites, it is hard to remember that, because of overdoses, over the past two years his heart has stopped a dozen times.

But Musanga is not surprised at all. Whittling away at his moustache with his new Swiss army knife, a present from the Kirks, he says simply, "Cameron came here with white man's medicine. It didn't work, so I helped him."

Musanga says he could do the same for other addicts - but they would not be Maasai. "Young Maasai don't do these things," he says. "How could they? They have to respect their parents; they could not fight with them as Cameron does."

And what are the herbs Musanga prescribes? What does he see in the stones? "These things are secret because you do not need to know," he says, with a thoroughly mischievous grin.

John Kirk, an embittered man who has watched his finances shrink and his marriage suffer under the strain of his son's addiction, has transferred all his disappointments into something close to adoration for the Maasai. "The oloiboni has done for Cameron what western medicine could not, the Maasai have what the west has not," he says. "If I had the choice again of sending my boy to an English public school or to the Maasai, I'd send him straight here."

Cameron has a more balanced view. Looking out over the endless horizons of the Mara plain, he says his environment must have played a part: it is hard to make sense of mainlining in earshot of a lion's roar.

But that would not be enough for long, says Cameron. "If I'd wanted to, I could have stolen a car and got back to Nairobi. I don't know what the stones are about, but I know he's not pulling a fast one - rehab just doped me; but Musanga has changed the way I think. "

Understandably, Cameron is reluctant to leave the Mara for the temptation of Nairobi's bars. But his three weekends back in town so far have given cause for hope.

"It took them a while, but the taxi drivers recognised me," he says. "They were saying, 'Hey, kiketi man, come with us, we'll get you high.'

"I thought about it - I had money in my pocket. But I told them: 'No, that's not me any more.' To be honest, I just wasn't fucking interested."

fields.headline: Media Week
fields.standfirst: Publication date: April 20
fields.trailText: April 20: Channel 5 has been given an extra £6m to spend on original programming by its shareholders, RTL and United Business Media.
fields.body:
Channel 5 has been given an extra £6m to spend on original programming by its shareholders, RTL and United Business Media, in a bid to raise the station's profile.

Commercial radio has achieved a record 5.9% share of the total display advertising market for 2000, according to figures from the Advertising Association.

MPG has been awarded the £12m Credit Suisse global account.

OMD is set to pick up the media planning and buying for Dell Computers' £8m European branding assignment after sister creative agency DDB Worldwide was handed the £104m account.

Direct Line Home Insurance is to sponsor the new series of Better Homes in a deal worth £800,000.

Home & Away is to be sponsored on Channel 5 by Bodyform in a £3m deal.

Go Racing, the consortium bidding for the terrestrial rights to horse racing, has set course owners a deadline of May 11 to sign a deal.

fields.headline: Stringfellow talks sport
fields.trailText:
3.15pm: TalkSport will add to its laddish credentials by signing Peter Stringfellow as a one-off 'shock jock' host, writes Jessica Hodgson.
01.02.2001: TalkSport sheds female listeners
fields.body:
TalkSport will add to its laddish credentials by signing the senior citizen of shagging, Peter Stringfellow, as a one-off "shock jock" host.

The owner of Stringfellow's nightclub and self-proclaimed bedder of over 2,000 women will stand in for that fellow purveyor of controversy-by-numbers, James Whale, on his midnight radio show on April 30.

Stringfellow has cut his teeth as a northern soul jockey in a variety of clubs.

"It's a wonderful life I've got," he said.

"I have all the toys, man. I have a club full of beautiful girls, eat and drink what the hell I want, go where the hell I want, when the hell I want. If there's a party I just ring up and say I'll accept.

"Now I've got a radio show on TalkSport and my life is complete," he added.

webTitle: A spoonful of sugar will not help

fields.headline: A spoonful of sugar will not help
fields.standfirst:
Drugs companies are global bullies, argues Charlotte Denny, and their climb-down in the court case against the South African government is a victory for people power.
Special report: HIV and Aids
fields.trailText: Comment: Drugs companies are global bullies, argues Charlotte Denny, and their climb-down in the court case against the South African government is a victory for people power.
fields.body:
Consumer power has chalked up another victory. Having trashed Monsanto, forced Shell to do a u-turn on Brent Spar and the rest of the energy sector to start to take sustainable development seriously, consumers have now given one of the worst corporate offenders of all a bloody nose.

The decision by 39 leading drug companies, including Britain's GlaxoSmithKline, to withdraw from their court case against the South African government today marks a humiliating climb-down for an industry that has established a reputation as a global bully.

Over the last few years, the drugs industry has combined its lobbying power with the US government to threaten poor countries importing cheap copies of patented drugs with the considerable might of American trade sanctions.

In theory, these countries were doing nothing wrong. Global intellectual property rules allow countries to override patent rights in the interests of public health. Patented drugs are beyond the over-stretched health budgets of most developing countries.

However, in practice, faced with the threat of losing privileged access to US markets, many countries were reluctant to exercise the safety provisions built into the World Trade Organisation's (WTO) trade-related aspects of intellectual property rights agreement (TRIPs).

The South African case was always on shaky grounds. The companies decided early on not to argue that the country's 1997 Medicines Act, which codifies the government's right to override patents, was wider than the scope of the TRIPs' safety provisions. Instead they argued that the act was in breach of South Africa's own constitution by giving ministers too much power to decide when to override patents.

webTitle: Hague and Portillo play happy families

fields.headline: Hague and Portillo play happy families
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, joined his party leader William Hague on a farm visit today in a bid to end speculation of an internecine war in the Conservative party ahead of a general election.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, joined his party leader William Hague on a farm visit today in a bid to end speculation of an internecine war in the Conservative party ahead of a general election.

After a week of damaging, if unsubstantiated, reports of increasing momentum for a Portillo challenge for the party leadership if Mr Hague fails to significantly overturn Tony Blair's majority, both men spoke of the shadow cabinet's "complete loyalty" to Mr Hague.

Mr Portillo - who returned to the Commons less than 18 months ago as MP for Kensington and Chelsea - told reporters: "Every member of the shadow cabinet, quite rightly, has given complete loyalty to William Hague, which is what William deserves. "I think William knows that he has received complete loyalty from every member of the shadow cabinet. I don't think there's been any doubt about that in any of our minds - neither William's nor mine nor anybody else's."

Unprompted, Mr Hague then said: "I absolutely agree."

Sidetracked from the purpose of the visit to a farm in Essex - to attack the government's handling of the foot and mouth epidemic - Mr Hauge insisted: "I have the complete loyalty of the shadow cabinet, they are loyal to each other and to me.

"We are not going to be side-tracked by media reports - which appear to be based on nothing - from the job of putting forward policies on this foot-and-mouth crisis and of fighting an energetic and united election campaign when that time comes."

The show of unity came after a week which saw reports of the Conservative left grouping behind Mr Portillo, if he should issue a leadership challenge after the general election, and a call from Tory backbencher Gerald Howarth for Lady Thatcher to intervene and restore harmony to the party.

Mr Howarth, MP for Aldershot, said: "I think it would help enormously if Margaret said something. She still commands huge respect and affection, and remains a commanding figure."

But that request has been declined by the Thatcher office.

Mr Hague today also faced criticism over his stewardship of the Conservative party from a more predictable source, when foreign secretary Robin Cook accused him of failing to give a lead against racism.

That allegation stems from the fact Mr Hague took no action against the Yorkshire East MP John Towend over inflammatory remarks made to his constituency party, where he praised Enoch Powell.

Neither Mr Townend, nor two other Conservative MPs - Jamie Cran and Eric Forth - have signed a pledge card from the commission for racial equality which binds politicians from using racially emotive language.

fields.headline: Breaking the child slave trade
fields.standfirst: An estimated 250m children worldwide are taken into slavery. Nicola Hill reports on what charities are doing to tackle the problem
fields.trailText: An estimated 250m children worldwide are taken into slavery. Nicola Hill reports on what charities are doing to tackle the problem.
fields.body:
Child slavery has been brought to the media's attention by the mysterious drama of the boat bobbing around the seas off the coast of west Africa.

But what happens when the spotlight moves away? Charities are left to tackle the problem, lobby governments, campaign against the might of global manufacturers and rehabilitate children.

There are an estimated 250m children aged between five and 14 engaged in unacceptable forms of labour across the world.

Andrew Pendleton, spokesman for Christian Aid, explains: "It is hard to be specific about figures because child slavery is a highly organised, criminal activity."

Unicef has also found it difficult to gather evidence in west Africa, where open borders promote free trade. Dr Rima Salah, Unicef's regional director for west and central Africa, says: "Even when cross-border movement of children is obvious, it is sometimes very difficult to distinguish between illegal and criminal activities and legitimate family, cross-border migration."

Dr Salah also points to internal trafficking. "Almost nothing is known about internal trafficking of children except that it is a substantial problem, largely unexplored, but one that places the child at the same risk as those being traded across borders."

Another difficulty faced by charities is the misconception of some parents that they are sending their children off to a better life.

Mr Pendleton claims: "It is like Dickensian England; people trapped by poverty are tricked into thinking they are doing the best for their children."

Unicef has identified poverty as the major causal factor of child slavery in two studies in west Africa. However, some countries that are most heavily involved in child trafficking do not have the worst social indicators, nor the worst cases of poverty. Unicef found a range of complex factors contributing to child slavery, including:

 Lack of vocational and economic opportunities for young people in rural areas
 Insufficient and/or inaccessible educational opportunities
 Ignorance on the part of families and children of the risks involved in trafficking, such as rape, torture, exposure to HIV and psychological harm of separation
 Traditional migration of adults within the framework of economic activities
 High demand for cheap and submissive child labour in the informal economic sector
 Opportunities to travel provided through easy means of communication and transport
 The desire of young people to gain emancipation through migration
 Inadequate political commitment, non existent national legislation and absence of a judicial framework.

Beth Herzfeld, spokeswoman for the non-governmental organisation Anti-slavery, explains that bonded slavery is also a norm in many countries.

This occurs when a family member borrows money and pays off the debt by working for the money lender. This can often involve offering the services of children.

Ms Herzfeld says: "This is a difficult cycle to break and charities have to work at a local level with parents and employers to raise awareness of the impact this has on children."

In parts of Asia, child prostitution has religious and cultural roots. Parents dedicate their young daughters to serve religious or ritualistic purposes in temples or shrines.

ChildRight Worldwide reports that this often results in children turning to prostitution - another form of child slavery.

So what can charities do to combat child slavery?

Unicef's Dr Salah believes charities must concentrate on raising public awareness, promoting education as a preventative strategy, strengthening partnerships, and establishing a legal and penal support system.

In India, Anti-slavery works with local voluntary organisations to declare bonded labour illegal. As the police are on the side of the organisations, they co-operate by freeing the slaves.

Unicef has set up a transit centre in Mali to receive repatriated children and to rehabilitate them. It is also setting up basic education programmes. Christian Aid supports local work in Nicaragua, providing educational and recreational activities.

In Brazil, it works with an organisation called Passage House to raise awareness and train and educate children.

However, local level activity needs to be combined with high level pressure. Mr Pendleton believes there needs to be an international effort on a par with the drive against drug trafficking.

"We are up against powerful players, as the money to buy children initially comes from big business. They may claim to have only heard about the problem in the last two months but that is nonsense, we have been campaigning for the last 10 years."

Anita Tiessen, deputy director of Unicef UK, says: "It is not enough for companies to say slavery isn't a good idea - they need to take action."

Christian Aid wants companies to report annually on labour standards in the areas where they work in the same way that they publish annual financial accounts.

However, many manufacturers subcontract work so they have less control over labour conditions. Ms Tiessen adds: "Companies need to accept that the onus is on them to monitor suppliers.

Mr Pendleton says: "In the long term companies will benefit as consumers become more discerning."

Christian Aid helped to set up the Day Chocolate Company that guarantees chocolate has been produced without child labour. "Through initiatives like these, we can show companies what is possible," says Mr Pendleton.

At the government level, 72 countries have ratified the UN International Labour Organisation's convention on the worst forms of child labour and only two countries haven't signed up to the UN convention on the rights of a child. But so far, only Burma has been held to account for human rights abuses.

Ms Tiessen believes the attack on child slavery needs to be multi-pronged. "NGOs can campaign and support, companies can use their economic power and governments can make laws but it takes all of them working together."

This simple incident of a boat in Benin has provoked debate and brought media attention to a complex issue which is entangled in religion, culture, corporate profits, legislative power and international relations.

fields.headline: Drug firms abandon court case
fields.standfirst: Special report: HIV and Aids
fields.trailText: Pharmaceutical companies have dropped their legal action against a South African law that allowed cheaper replicas of their patented drugs.
fields.body:
Pharmaceutical companies have dropped their legal action against a South African law that allowed cheaper replicas of their patented drugs.

The decision, announced in a packed Pretoria courtroom, marks a turning point in a battle by international human rights groups and Aids activists to secure medication for the 26m Africans infected with HIV.

"By the consent of all parties, we would simply ask your lordship to note that the application is withdrawn," said Stephanus Cilliers, the lawyer for the drug companies.

After the judge accepted the motion, activists erupted into cheers and singing.

South Africa's health minister, Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, said the government had not agreed to any deals in exchange for dropping the suit. "You can trust the government," she said.

More than three dozen pharmaceutical companies brought the suit, arguing that a 1997 South African law regulating medicine was too broad, and unfairly targeted drug manufacturers.

The government, Aids activists and human rights groups say the drug companies are trying to wring profits out of a public health nightmare that threatens to devastate South Africa and dozens of other impoverished countries.

More than 25m of the 36m people infected with HIV worldwide live in sub-Saharan Africa, one of the world's most impoverished regions.

In 2000, 2.4m people died there from the effects of Aids.

webTitle: Slavery: the chocolate companies have their say

fields.headline: Slavery: the chocolate companies have their say
fields.standfirst:
The charities and chocolate companies discuss the issue of child slavery on cocoa plantations, in the news this week after the hunt for a supposed slave ship off the coast of west Africa

18.04.01: Slave ship alert leads west Africa in confusion
fields.trailText: The charities and chocolate companies discuss the issue of child slavery on cocoa plantations, in the news this week after the hunt for a supposed slave ship off the coast of west Africa.
fields.body:
Day Chocolate Company, manufacturers of the fair trade Divine and Dubble bars
"Child slavery is still rife within the cocoa industry in west Africa. Unless western chocolate companies have transparent supply chains and actively monitor their sources, they cannot claim to be using cocoa free from forced labour. The UK chocolate market is worth £4bn a year - it is dominated by some of the biggest players in the global market. It is up to these companies to implement internal monitoring and standards and to ensure that they only accept cocoa from sources which can guarantee that they are not using child or forced labour."

Nestlé
"We are deeply concerned about this issue and are actively working with other manufacturers in our trade association to find a solution. These are illegal acts which must be stamped out and we fully support the efforts being made by the governments of Côte d'Ivoire and Mali to do so. Slavery is unacceptable and we intend to exert every influence to ensure such practices do not take place. We have been instrumental in getting clauses on working conditions incorporated in the international cocoa agreements and other contracts which are currently being negotiated. However, it is quite wrong to imply that slavery is either widespread or representative of conditions generally on cocoa farms. Members of our industry and the cocoa processors have been visiting the Côte d'Ivoire for decades and working closely with many cocoa farmers. In all that time we simply have not come across such practices. That is why we are confident that whilst illegal practices may exist, this is on a very limited scale indeed and confined to certain areas."

Fair Trade Foundation
"The debate in the media about this issue unfortunately has missed an important point. While the price of cocoa remains as low as it is, appalling cases like this will continue to come to light. The market price for cocoa now is much the same as it was 30 years ago. Unless chocolate manufacturers are willing to pay more for their cocoa, these conditions will persist. An increasing number of consumers want to be sure that the cocoa used in the chocolate they eat has been produced under decent social conditions - the Fair Trade mark is the only independent guarantee of this."

Anti-Slavery
"It is difficult to say whether slave labour or other forms of illegal exploitation are used in the production of cocoa. Because of the way that cocoa is bought on the international market, it is difficult to trace which plantation each bag of cocoa comes from. However, a number of cases of forced labour were exposed in a recent Channel 4 documentary but we don't know its extent, because there has been no proper research.

"The chocolate companies could purchase direct from plantations and work with governments and growers to ensure that international labour standards are met. Consumers can write to chocolate companies to voice their concerns over these allegations. They can also write to supermarkets and ask them to stock fair trade products, which are guaranteed to be produced without the use of slavery such as forced labour or illegal child labour."

fields.headline: Formula for trouble?
fields.standfirst: Tinkering with the Barnett formula, which has led to spending levels in Scotland 20% higher than those south of the border, could have serious consequences, writes Simon Parker
fields.trailText: Tinkering with the Barnett formula, which has led to spending levels in Scotland 20% higher than those south of the border, could have serious consequences, writes Simon Parker.
fields.body:
When the Scottish parliament promised to stump up the money for free elderly care earlier this year, it looked like a victory for good, old-fashioned collectivism north of the border.

In fact, the decision may have had a lot more to do with the fact that the country gets a very generous slice of UK funding. Every Scot is "worth" 20% more than his or her English counterpart.

This higher public spending has helped to shape the direction of Holyrood politics. As Colin Mair, director of the Scottish Local Authorities Management Centre at the University of Strathclyde, says: "I don't think that the executive would even have addressed free personal care unless the Scottish settlement was significantly above the per capita allocations in the rest of the UK."

The good times may, however, be coming to an end. Scotland's budget is already being squeezed, and calls are mounting for a fundamental review of the way public money is allocated in the UK.

The issue was raised during last year's London mayor campaign, and north-east council leaders, along with the pro-regional government Campaign for the English Regions (CfER), have called for change.

English city mayors, the first of which are likely to come into power towards the end of the year, will almost certainly add to this pressure for redistribution. In addition, regional government, on the cards for a second Labour term, will crank it up still further.

The controversy centres on the so-called Barnett formula, which was introduced in 1978 by the Labour government at roughly the same time as its failed attempt at devolution in Scotland.

In theory, the formula should have slowly brought Scotland's high per capita public spending into line with that of England. In practice, the gap is still huge.

CfER figures suggest that public spending per head in Scotland in 1999-2000 was nearly £1,000 more than in England. This masks regional differences south of the border, but even the poorest regions - the north-east and west - lag behind by more than £400.

There are real needs in Scotland that might justify higher public spending. The country has a geographically diffuse and ageing population, which is well-known for its poor health. All these factors push up the cost of delivering services compared with England.

Neediness is, however, a relative concept. Scottish GDP per head may be about 4% below the UK average, but it has nothing on the north-east, which is nearly 25% behind.

Many argue that Scotland's economic and social situation has improved since the last government needs assessment in the late 1970s, but that the country's funding share has remained unfairly high.

Barnett's failure to produce anything like convergence is partly explained by the same kind of fudge that gave Scotland a higher level of public spending in the first place. The formula has often been bypassed or only partially applied in order to hand the Scots extra money in a bid to stave off the threat posed by nationalism.

According to Iain McLean, professor of politics at Nuffield College, Oxford, Gordon Brown is the first chancellor to use Barnett as it was intended.

Mr Brown did not give the Scots any extras in his 2000 comprehensive spending review, with the result that increases in Scottish budgets are now being squeezed by around £350m a year, according to research prepared for the University of Strathclyde.

Because this figure is cumulative, it means the squeeze will total £1,050m by 2003-04. Around £200m of this will be lost from health spending, while transport will lose about £100m.

CfER's John Adams has called for a more radical redistribution of funds: "The regions of England are at the bottom of the spending league. The needs of the regions have not been addressed sufficiently, and it's time the issue was settled fairly - we need to completely re-examine the Barnett formula."

If it were based on need, such a re-examination would almost certainly see Scotland losing out, and the English regions gaining. Prof McClean suggests that even relatively prosperous areas such as the east of England could benefit from a review.

A new evaluation of regional public spending may seem like a fair move, but it would be politically difficult. Labour's traditional grip on power in Scotland would be badly shaken if the Westminster parliament whipped the spending rug out from under Holyrood's feet.

The big question for the government is whether ministers want to hand the Scottish Nationalist Party a thermonuclear electoral weapon.

The political price of changing Barnett will be, at best, a weakening of the union. At worst, it could be the election of an SNP government north of the border determined to dissolve it.

webTitle: Beer and sandwiches back on the menu

fields.headline: Beer and sandwiches back on the menu
fields.standfirst: The events of the past few weeks indicate that the prime minister has got a new deputy in town - although he doesn't seem too keen to admit it to his supporters. Matthew Tempest reports
fields.trailText: Poor old John Prescott. After seven years as Tony Blair's deputy, he would be justified in feeling a little spurned by the prime minister since Ben Gill rode into town.
fields.body:
Poor old John Prescott. After seven years as Tony Blair's deputy, he would be justified in feeling a little spurned by the prime minister since Ben Gill rode into town.

Who? Mr Gill, the head of the National Union of Farmers, who was seen yesterday after informing the prime minister with the largest majority this century that his preferred option of vaccinating cattle against foot and mouth was not a runner.

For a moment, it seemed like one of those TV nostalgia shows of archive clips, embarrassing haircuts and dodgy music, rather than BBC's Newsnight.

Add to that a series of tube strikes paralysing the capital at regular intervals, a national rail network virtually at a standstill and widespread flooding, and it's no surprise shudders are running down the spines of Labour strategists terrified of being painted as a return to the bad old days of the 1970s.

To put the current volt-face in context, it was the 1973/4 miner's strike which put the country on an enforced three day week as power generators ran out of coal, and prompted Tory prime minister Edward Heath to pose the question, "Who governs Britain?"

This supposedly rhetorical question, pitting the government against the recalcitrant National Union of Miners, blew up in his face as the nation answered "Not you, sunshine" and elected Labour's Harold Wilson to pull in the reigns of an overmighty Trades Union Congress.

After a series of strikes through the 1970s which cost 10,726,000 working days in one year alone, the unions' power reached its zenith, and its Waterloo, with the 1984 miners' strike. After a record 26,100,000 lost working days, NUM leader Arthur Scargill was forced to capitulate.

The unions had one last hurrah with the SOGAT protest against Rupert Murdoch's relocation of the Times and the Sun to Wapping, before the Thatcher government brought in a succession of highly restrictive trades unions laws, banning secondary picketing and insisting on full ballots of members before industrial action.

Tony Blair's first self-imposed hurdle as leader of the Labour party was to confront his paymasters and the party's forefathers - the unions - by scrapping clause IV of the party's constitution which committed the party to public ownership of the means of production.

Since then, Mr Blair has not looked kindly on the unions, allowing the trade and industry minister, Stephen Byers, to moot the possibility of a total break with them, and most recently at the 2000 party conference refusing to back down to union demands that state pensions be linked to average earnings.

Now, to the surprise and consternation of many union-affiliated Labour MPs, there is an open door policy for the NUF - the only union thought even by its members to represent big business rather than the small, independent farmer.

Farmer Andrew Tompkins, who has defected from the NFU to the much smaller National Sheep Association, said: "The NFU has been irritating the hell out of me. They put forward the views of the 20% of big farmers who get 80% of the subsidies, not family farms under 200 acres which form the majority.

"They are 10 to 20 years behind the times, clinging on to the past subsidy regime and obstructing change."

For many rank and file party members, relied upon to knock on doors and deliver leaflets in the coming general election campaign, this was one nostalgia trip they hoped had been consigned to the telly archives.

fields.headline: Chicken tikka masala
fields.standfirst: Robin Cook has praised the nation for taking Chicken tikka masala to its heart. Here's our online guide to the UK's favourite meal
fields.trailText: Robin Cook has praised the nation for taking Chicken tikka masala to its heart. Here's our online guide to the UK's favourite meal.
fields.body:
1. Robin Cook has come over all multicultural by making a speech praising the nation for its adoption of chicken tikka masala as its favourite dish.

2. Chicken tikka masala has a truly postcolonial history, produced when one of the world's greatest cuisines found itself confronted by a British palette unused to anything spicier than table salt. Legend has it that a Bangladeshi chef made it up when a British customer demanded gravy with his chicken tikka.

3. Detractors say the stuff is the worst dish on the menu in any Indian restaurant, taking a perfectly respectable traditional dish and dumbing it down with a can of instant tomato soup.

4. There is, of course, another group unimpressed by the nation's favourite dish: chickens. This group advocates a return to the good old days of fish and chips.

5. Most of us can't get enough of the stuff, though. The Queen herself is a convert to the new British way of eating, her favourite being the appropriately traditional choice of London's oldest Indian restaurant .

6. And with a few modifications, vegetarians can enjoy the national dish, too.

7. It has even managed to eat into sales of traditional British beers as curry lovers reach for that curry staple, Kingfisher.

8. It's all left the food critics back in India feeling quite pleased with themselves.

9. The catering industry has finally caught on as well, now offering NVQs that take Asian cooking into account.

10. Hungry? Well then switch off your computer and make or buy yourself some tikka masala. Robin will be proud.

fields.headline: Aromatherapists turn negative report to their advantage
fields.standfirst: Top 10 essential oils
fields.trailText:
2.45pm: Experts say a 'flawed' study that slams aromatherapy has given them a PR opportunity, writes Julia Day.
Top 10 essential oils
fields.body:
A new study that rubbishes aromatherapy has been panned as "poor science" by UK experts, who say the scientists responsible made a basic error in their investigation.

German scientists were trying to test the "reenergising" properties of aromatherapy oils but they used sedative oils instead of stimulating ones.

Of the three oils used in the study - peppermint, jasmine and ylang ylang - the last two are not used to stimulate brains but to relax them.

As the study was looking for increased alertness among volunteers, it used the wrong oils.

The report was called "a poor piece of science" by natural remedy retailer Neal's Yard and "hilarious" by the UK's Aromatherapy Organisation Council.

Susan Curtis, the training director at Neal's Yard, said the company would use the German report as a positive public relations opportunity to discuss aromatherapy.

"This one report won't affect people's opinions because there are hundreds of other reports backing claims aromatherapy works," she said.

"But it is puzzling why this report has made headline news - I think there is a bit of a backlash against alternative methods, like organic farming."

Ms Teddy Fearnhamm, the deputy chairman of the AOC, said of the report: "It's hilarious because it seems there probably wasn't an aromatherapist working with the scientists."

Ms Fearnhamm, an aromatherapist with 30 years' experience, said the research was unbalanced and gimmicky whereas aromatherapy will soon be prescribed on the NHS.

fields.headline: Human cloning
fields.standfirst:
The government has announced plans to bring forward legislation outlawing human reproductive cloning. Jane Perrone explains

Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The government has announced plans to bring forward legislation outlawing human reproductive cloning. Jane Perrone explains.
fields.body:
What is cloning?
The Human Genetics Advisory Commission has defined cloning as "producing a cell or organism with the same nuclear genome as another cell or organism".

What about cloning humans?
Scientists began cloning frogs in the 1950s. When a team from the Roslin Institute in Edinburgh successfully cloned an adult mammal for the first time in 1996, the possibility of human cloning came a step closer to reality. No one has managed to clone a human being yet, but several groups have announced that they plan to do so.

How is it done?
Dolly was cloned by transferring the nucleus of a body cell into an egg which has already had its nucleus removed. This is also known as nuclear transfer. It is likely that an attempt to clone humans would be based on the same method.

Why do it?
A supply of donor organs, eradicating genetic diseases and allowing infertile couples to reproduce are some of the more mainstream reasons to clone humans. Then there are the more outlandish reasons for cloning, including cloning dead people and seeking eternal life by cloning as old age approaches.

Who wants to clone humans?
After Dolly the sheep made her debut in 1997, maverick Chicago scientist Richard Seed achieved notoriety by announcing he was opening a cloning clinic - then by revealing that he planned to clone his wife. Then there's Severino Antinori, the head of a thriving Rome-based chain of IVF clinics. He claimed that his consortium would have the first cloned embryo ready for implantation in a mother's womb within one and a half to two years. But he will not say where, when or how they would clone a human being, who would do it or how much it would cost. A UFO-worshipping cult called the Raelians say they plan to beat Antinori in the race to produce the first human clone.

Why ban it?
Most mainstream scientists are set against attempts at human cloning, including Ian Wilmut, who led the team behind Dolly the sheep. The most persuasive argument at the moment is that the risks are far too great at present. It is feared that human cloning would be cruel, because the process results in a large number of miscarriages and deformities before a healthy human could be successfully cloned. For instance, it took 272 attempts to create Dolly. Many religious groups also object to cloning, including some Roman Catholic and Muslim organisations. There are many ethical arguments for a ban, including fears that cloning humans will lead to "designer babies" with genetic traits selected by their parents, or a black market for embryos, and the creation of a "genetic underclass".

What else did Alan Milburn announce today?
A £30m package to make genetic tests for diseases such as cancer more widely available on the NHS, doubling the number of specialist consultants in genetics in England in the next five years, a moratorium on the use of genetic tests by insurance companies and a £10m Genetics Knowledge Challenge Fund to establish four "genetics knowledge parks" with medical and scientific expertise.

fields.headline: Clive Tyldesley watch
fields.trailText: Clive Tyldesley. He's the ITV commentator who just loves to reminisce about Manchester United's 1999 European Cup final win over Bayern Munich.
fields.body:
Clive Tyldesley. He's the ITV commentator who just loves to reminisce about Manchester United's 1999 European Cup final win over Bayern Munich.

So what better opportunity to check out his Nou Camp reference-prising performance than a match between Manchester United and Bayern Munich in the European Cup?

Here is our detailed analysis of Clive's commentary:

Number of times Clive insisted before kick-off that he will "try not to mention the 1999 final too often" - 1

Number of times Clive reminded us about the 1999 final - 21

Number of times Clive dropped in yet another dreary reference to Turin or United's comeback against Juventus in 1999 - 4

Number of times Clive used the words "self-confident" or "well-oiled" about the "Germans" - 4

fields.headline: Radcliffe to host Sky One talent show
fields.trailText: 2pm: Radio 1 DJ Mark Radcliffe is set to be the new 'Nasty" Nigel after being signed up by to front a Sky One Popstars-style show. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC Radio 1 DJ, Mark Radcliffe, is set to be the new Nigel Lythgoe after he was signed up by Sky One for a new Popstars-style show.

He will front the talent spotting show, Next!, in which he will offer opinions on the talent or otherwise of more than 2,000 wannabe singers, dancers, magicians and performance artists.

Radcliffe will present Next! from a custom-built mobile mini-studio that will tour the country's shopping centres.

Sky One has ordered a 13-part run of Next! from independent production company Talent TV.

The BSkyB-owned channel has ordered two other new reality entertainment formats for its summer schedule.

Reps, made by Tiger Aspect Productions, will feature six holiday reps from 2wentys, a holiday company specialising in taking twentysomethings to Ibiza.

The show will follow the reps through training and induction in the UK and then on the job in Ibiza.

Reps will have a quick production turnaround so viewers can see all the action from the previous week.

Single Girls will follow the fortunes of four different women looking for the perfect partner.

The foursome will be brought together to live in a central London penthouse for seven weeks while they party, date and go on a romantic holiday.

Single Girls is being produced by Elisabeth Murdoch's new company, Shine Entertainment.

Sky One has also ordered a new series of the dating show, The Villa, from Talent TV.

fields.headline: Record companies hit by rogue music sites
fields.trailText:
1pm: Record companies are reeling after global sales figures revealed the damage caused by rogue music websites, reports Dan Milmo.
02.04.2001: Music giants join forces to rival Napster
fields.body:
Record companies are reeling after global sales figures revealed the damage caused by rogue music websites.

Music fans have shunned shops to download their favourite tunes from no-fee sites such as Napster and MP3.com, cutting last year's global record sales by 1.2% to £25.8bn.

The figures from the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry showed the US market was hit the hardest, with sales of singles falling 46% in a country which accounts for 38% of global record purchases.

Further pressure has been added by the downturn in the US economy, with consumers cutting back on luxuries such as CDs.

"The downturn in the US brought down the overall sales figures. We also saw the first evidence of the impact of free online music," said the IFPI.

However, the IFPI figures show the sixth successive year of decline in record sales, as mobile phones and video games compete with CDs for consumers' disposable income.

Napster has paradoxically thrown a lifeline to the record industry by offering it a new and innovative way to boost flagging sales.

But this did not stop the major record companies from suing Napster into submission for breaching copyright laws and then establishing their own online operations.

A new battle will now be fought to establish a standardised service, with Vivendi Universal and Sony forming Duet and EMI, Bertelsmann and AOL Time Warner backing MusicNet.

But analysts said the new sites may not be enough to solve the fundamental problems of a shrinking market.

"The industry has to find a way of turning it around. There will be interest in the new services, but we have no idea what the music industry will charge. We need to know what will be offered, so it is way too early to say," said Helen Snell, analyst at ABN Amro.

Consumers will also have to fight their way through a cluttered online music environment, with MTV and Microsoft also offering alternative downloading services.

Internet specialists Jupiter Media Matrix predicts that US online music spending could reach £1.02bn this year, increasing to £3.75bn by 2005.

fields.headline: 'Always on' Wap technology heads for the shops
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: A new technology that could kick-start Wap's fortunes will go on sale to the public next month, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
A new technology that could spark a reversal of fortunes for Wap services is just a month away from the high street.

After more than a year of hype, the GPRS 'always on' mobile internet technology will finally go on sale to consumers on May 18.

Previously, it was only available to the business community.

BT Cellnet will be the first mobile operator to offer consumer GPRS, effectively an internet-oriented upgrade to the GSM networks that currently power our phones.

GPRS, on the other hand, was designed for data exchange such as internet connections.

Prices for GPRS network phones will start at £199, although it is expected that, like Wap phones, they will start high and then come down in price as networks subsidise the handsets.

GPRS will kick off with two consumer tariffs: a basic £3.99 per month pay-as-you-go service that will allow users to download data at 2p per kilobyte, equivalent to two Wap pages or a 100-word email.

A basic bundle £7.99 per month gives users 1Mb of downloads every month, but any additional data downloaded will be charged at £3.99 per megabyte.

These packages are in addition to the regular monthly voice tariff subscription and the cost of voice calls.

The 'always on' capability of GPRS will put an end to the slow dialling-up to access Wap services and email and tediously slow browsing.

One added benefit will be that customers will also be able to answer voice calls while in the middle of emailing or using Wap services.

Later in the year, customers will be able to access traditional web pages via their GPRS phones and operators are working on mobile internet browsers that can handle graphics to give more of an normal internet-like experience.

GPRS is seen as an interim replacement for GSM, which was only designed as a digital voice network, until 3G phones hit the market in around two years.

The 3G licence frenzy has left mobile operators with massive debts they won't be able to pay back for many years.

As a result, GPRS - or 2.5G as it's termed - is a way of getting consumers to upgrade phones and spend more money on services and networks to help out cash-strapped operators.

fields.headline: 9m watch Man Utd defeat
fields.trailText: 1pm TV overnights: ITV got its biggest Champions League audience of the season last night, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV got its biggest Champions League audience of the season last night, as more than 9m viewers tuned in to see Manchester United being bundled out of the competition by Bayern Munich.

The Big Match: Champions League Live featured live coverage of the Reds' 2-1 defeat in Germany between 7.30pm and 9.45pm.

The programme had 9.3m viewers and a 39% share of the available audience overall, according to unofficial overnights.

It peaked at 10.5m between 9.15pm and 9.30pm as Man Utd chased the goals that would have kept them in the competition in the closing stage of the game.

British hopes, and the chance for ITV to pull in an even bigger audience, now rest with Leeds United, who take on Valencia in the two-legged Champions League semi-final in a fortnight's time.

Elsewhere last night, BBC1's Ground Force Goes East, featuring Alan Titchmarsh and the garden makeover gang in India, failed to beat ITV's football between 9.10pm and 10pm.

The Ground Force special had 6.3m viewers and a 26% audience share.

BBC2 scored with a nifty bit of counter-scheduling against ITV's football, in the shape of "chick flick" Baby Boom, between 8.30pm and 10.15pm.

The movie, which stars Diane Keaton as a New York career woman who gets lumbered with a 13-month-old baby, had 2.9m viewers and a 12% audience share.

fields.headline: Wound up, not wired up
fields.standfirst: Women's use of the internet is rocketing in the office. But mums at home are being left behind in the cyber race, says  Deborah Bee
fields.trailText: Women's use of the internet is rocketing in the office. But mums at home are being left behind in the cyber race, says Deborah Bee.
fields.body:
The bloke who used to be head of IT at my old office, Pete, had a very clear idea of why he spent so much of his time trying to undo the crashes that I, or other "laydeez" had caused by trying to log on. "They just ain't compatible, girls and computers," he used to whine, as he thundered across my keyboard for the fifth time in a week. "Women just don't have the right sort of brains."

The latest research studies in the US, however, show that there is now "gender parity" in internet use and at first glance, these statistics suggest that, far from being web illiterate, women are (surprise, surprise) just as competent as men.

At a recent conference organised by Marketing Week, entitled Women on the Web - reaching beyond gender stereotypes online - Philip Bird from Microsoft's MSN, gave these new statistics further relevance.

"What is happening with the net in the US today," he stated unequivocally, "will happen here 14 months later. In the UK at present there is still a male bias - but I expect it to be a 50:50 ratio very soon." (Cue a mass pinging of braces across adland)

Such conviction (or is it merely optimism?) was echoed by other speakers at the event - to the glee of the gathered managing directors and brand managers. According to Hilary Groves of iVillage UK, "Women are one of the fastest growing internet segments".

Her arrival in Britain is testament to her company's confidence. Her month-old website, a translation of a hugely successful US site, has stormed into the British market.

A closer study of American statistics reveals that 60%of American women go online everyday. This research, carried out by the Pew Foundation, a charitable trust looking at the sociological impact of the net, found that US women favoured sites where they can shop, chat, download music or get health or career advice. They also discovered that over half of the group was logging on from home. Could this be the key to the explosion in female web use? Because, in the US, high-speed access is very often unmetered and usually free. Can we really expect the US experience to be replicated in Britain any time soon when, unlike Americans, most of us still have to pay BT for our home internet access?

What we certainly can expect is that a large number of multinationals will take the US experience as gospel and forge into the British market, hoping to tap into the incredibly lucrative market segment that is the female consumer.

Current British figures show that 36.6% of the 10m people online are women. They are ordering their groceries, making Tesco the biggest success story in e-commerce history; they are checking out their healthcare facilities through sites such as Wellbeing, an alliance between Boots and Granada; they are buying exclusive fashion through sites like Net-a-porter; they can even check up on the latest celebrity gossip.

Jane Procter of Peoplenews.com has established that the majority of her users are women who are logging on from their offices.

"It is evident by the surge of user numbers at certain times of day that most are in an office. There is a huge push when people arrive at work and pick up their emails -then at lunchtime when they want something to read while they eat their sandwiches, and then again just before they leave. Our figures were 250,000 last month which is 30,000 higher than was projected - and we believe 60% are women.'

While the figures concerning women at work are very promising, by comparison, only a small minority are logging on from home.

Chad Wollen from consumer behaviour consultants, the Henley Centre, agrees that women in the home, most often mothers, are yet to be won over. "Everything about the internet is unbelievably fast," he says, "except the take-up by mums - which is unbelievably slow."

But why is this fact so unbelievable, given that many mother's experiences of the web are so often bad.

Take Jill. Jill is a freelance health journalist who should be swanning round the web picking up the most up-to-the-minute research. But what happens.

"I spend the half hour I have, before picking up my kids from school, hunting down Dr So-and-so from some university or other who appears to have done a study which is right up my street. And then I discover that the site hasn't been updated for three years and that Dr So-and-so moved on months ago. I can't afford to rely on information that can't be verified. I tend only to believe some thing now if it is between the covers of a book."

And then take Rebecca. Now admittedly she still hasn't managed to get her head around email - but taking my suggestion to order a book on line, Rebecca spent two-and-a-half hours trying to track it down while her two-year-old twins had a fight on the living room floor. Eventually she gave up and found it at her local bookshop, which took her 20 minutes door to door and got the children out of the house.

And finally, Liz, who is sick of her weekly shop in Tesco but is internet phobic. "You have to shop online," I insisted. "It's so simple - especially after you have done it once."

Liz stumbled at the first hurdle. She tried to order baked beans and was then offered too many choices of size, multipack, brand, etc that she gave up. Now she's even more phobic.

These women aren't stupid. Neither are they technologically incompetent. The Henley Centre has made significant findings in their research into this area.

"There are currently 4m mums online which is up 20% in the last six months," says Wollen. "But only half of them use it every week. This betrays a complete lack of engagement. The internet has not become important to their everyday lives."

There are many theories on why this is the case; that the PC is not accessible enough, hidden away as it often is, in a room at the back of the house; that the mum doesn't feel "techie" enough, particularly in comparison to her husband and offspring; that women don't trust the internet, particularly in terms of credit card security, junk email and viruses. But the most significant finding concerns time management.

"Women are not adventurous," continues Wollen. "They are task driven which means they get impatient. Working mothers, in particular, are so tired and exhausted by looking after their jobs, their kids and their homes that the internet becomes yet another responsibility which ends up being the straw that broke the camel's back."

With, on average, 15 hours less free time per week than their male counterparts, women simply don't have the time to boot up, download or surf. How deliciously ironic that something as archaic as the unequal division of household chores should be standing in the way of women embracing future technology and therefore multinationals embracing women.

Sam Phillips believes that lack of time has led men and women to differ on the fundamental point of the web - with men thinking of it as recreational and women seeing it as functional.

"From the figures I've seen - it seems true that some women don't relax with their PCs. If they don't quickly and easily find what they want, they won't surf the net like a man would - they just find it offline."

Women in offices, on the other hand, are becoming more and more web literate, treating it as yet another part of their media diet. Is this simply because they can do it all on the company's time at the company's expense?

One area of the net which women at home have embraced wholeheartedly, however, is email. But the key here is that email fits into a woman's time-saving strategies, because it's even more convenient than a phone. How ideal can a form of communication be when it allows you to send and receive messages quickly, effectively and whenever you choose?

The speakers at the Marketing Week conference predict that in the future, British mothers at home, like their American counterparts, will be treating the web as a new form of community. Not only will they be able to compare notes with other mothers, on how to get a baby to sleep or give up chocolate, they will also buy underwear, win holidays and get advice on health, beauty and fashion, all from the comfort of their own homes.

But in the meantime, if large multinationals are going to reach this largely untapped market they are going to have to get to grips with how women behave in their homes and the time- saving strategies that they have developed there. Most often they will be doing at least two things at once - whether it is listening to the news while cooking a meal, interacting with the children while paying the bills, chatting to a friend while doing the ironing. Even a visit to the supermarket is a way of entertaining children, certainly more so than watching mum sit in front of a PC for half an hour and then fail to get any Tweenies yoghurts.

The trouble with web access at the moment is that it demands 100 % attention - and many women can't afford to give that. "Technology needs to be better suited to mums," Chad Wollen sums up. "It needs to be as accessible as a PC loaded into a fridge door, always on, (so it doesn't need booting up) and non threatening in style and content."

Clichéd as it sounds, it is only when the internet is full-time, online, on the fridge door that it really will become useful. Until that time the internet is simply not smart enough to match up to women's expectations. So there, Pete.

"It needs to be as accessible as a PC loaded into a fridge door, always on, (so it doesn't need booting up) and non threatening in style and content." Clichéd as it sounds, it is only when the internet is full-time, online, on the fridge door that it really will become useful. Until that time the internet is simply not smart enough to match up to women's expectations. So there, Pete.

War correspondents drink more heavily and take more hard drugs than their domestic counterparts, according to a new study carried out by the University of Toronto.
