webTitle: Heroin was killing our son. If he was a dog he would have been put down. The Maasai was our last chance'

fields.headline: Heroin was killing our son. If he was a dog he would have been put down. The Maasai was our last chance'
fields.standfirst: James Astill on the Kenyan medicine man and the drug addict from Devon
fields.trailText: James Astill on the Kenyan medicine man and the drug addict from Devon.
fields.body:
Down in the Maasai Mara, two skinny men are conferring over a goatskin, a pile of stones and liberal gobbets of spit. Kasaine ole Musanga, the shorter by a foot, is an oloiboni - a Maasai medicine man. Cameron Kirk, a heroin addict from Devon, is his patient.

Musanga chuckles as he turns the prophetic stones with his forefinger. There are 400 of them: yellow, blue and black, the size of broad beans, all polished by the swirl of the Mara river. But it is not clear whether it is the stones that have pleased him, or something the younger of his two wives has said. She is pointing at the middle-aged white couple, Cameron's parents, John and Sue. They are staring fixedly at Musanga, though their hands are in constant motion; wiping away sweat, flicking at flies.

Musanga is sitting in the shade of his manyatta, a squat one-room house of woven branches stuccoed with cow dung. His guests are crouching in the manure that is everywhere, under a fierce, midmorning sun.

Knowledge of natural medicines runs deep in Maasai culture. Fathers teach sons how to treat their cattle and themselves with the barks and leaves of Kenya's southern plains. The oloiboni, separate from but not inferior to the clan chief, is a sort of consultant to this tribe of general practitioners.

Before battle or a lion hunt, Maasai warriors go to the oloiboni for a stimulant - for medicine to make them brave. When their cows die suddenly - or when anything unexpected happens - the oloiboni finds an explanation in the stones.

Musanga scoops up the pebbles into a gourd, spits into it, and mutters something. Then he pours them out again and makes his diagnosis. Cameron has forgotten the bad medicine; but he needs to get stronger.

Cameron, 25, puffs nonchalantly on a cigarette, happy to believe him. Musanga's combination of mysticism and herbalism has achieved what years of methadone, rehab and psychiatric treatment could not. Cameron has been clean for three months; ever since his father, John, a retired RAF sergeant, bundled him off to the Mara. The needle marks peppering his forearms and feet have healed and they show pink through his tan. He no longer believes he will die a junkie.

Two years ago, the Kirks flew Cameron out to Nairobi, where Sue was working with the Foreign Office, to straighten him out. It was a disastrous move - Cameron was soon injecting up to a gramme a day of heroin, purer than he had dreamed possible in England. Nairobi's rehabs said he was a hopeless case and the police had started using his nickname, "kiketi [heroin] man", when they stopped him in the street.

It could not have been long before Cameron was charged and given a mandatory seven to 10-year sentence for heroin possession. Even the healthiest foreigner finds it difficult to survive Kenya's violent, typhus jails. And Cameron, who is 6ft 5in, weighed less than nine stone.

Reasoning that prison in England - to which Cameron was no stranger, let alone foreign - was a healthier option, John decided to send him back. Meanwhile, he kept Cameron in heroin to keep him from crime.

"They were the worst weeks of my life," he says. "I was watching my son killing himself and I was assisting him. If a dog was in that condition, you'd put it down."

But even as John was driving to pick up Cameron's ticket, he was hailed by two Maasai friends. "I told them what I was doing - they knew all about Cam," he says. "But they said, 'Don't bother. We'll take him.'"

"I wasn't thinking about an oloiboni. The idea was just to take him where escape would be impossible, let him live with the Maasai, and reinvent himself as a man - because they wouldn't put up with any shit from him."

High as a kite, Cameron was easily deceived. John drove him down to Narok, the last dusty town before the great plains. There he left him with the Maasai pair, and with seven vials of pethadin to see him through the worst of withdrawal. When Cameron realised what was happening, he reached into his sock for a wrap of heroin and a syringe.

Unfortunately, John's friends were not the noble warriors he had thought them to be. They dumped Cameron in a budget safari camp and went off to drink the money for his upkeep. For Rosemary Ngigi, who helps run the safari camp, his cold turkey was something else. "He couldn't walk, he couldn't talk, he couldn't eat, he couldn't sleep. Oh, he looked horrible!" she says.

"At first we were scared because we thought he had Aids. Then we saw he was out of his mind. He'd forget his cigarette until you could smell it burning his fingers. We thought he was about to die - that's what he was saying too."

In his six years as a heroin addict, Cameron had never experienced withdrawal for more than a day. In rehab, he had been given powerful opiates and sedatives, methadone, largactol, rohypnol, pethadin and mogadon, to mask the symptoms. Otherwise, the closest he had come was when accidentally locked into his second floor King's Cross flat, terrified by the rising nausea, he jumped out of the window, breaking his pelvis.

But for four days, and despite the pethadin he was jabbing frantically into his backside, Cameron experienced a full heroin withdrawal.

"I woke up in a tent, sweating, feeling very sick," he says, apologising for his jumbled thoughts: he is not used to remembering things, he says. "By evening, the goose-bumps had come up. And the next three days were just horrible. I was retching all the time, and shivering, sweating, lying there with this horrible smell inside my nose, like there was shit up my nostrils."

Musanga gave Cameron a basin of water, sprinkled with herbs, to wash with and powdered herbs to lick off his hand. "Within 15 minutes I felt totally different," says Cameron. "I still couldn't sleep, but I was relaxed. The sweats had halved, I'd stopped retching and after an hour I realised I was starving. I got up and ate till I thought I'd explode."

For the Maasai, the power of the oloiboni is beyond question. "I'm not surprised Musanga helped Cameron because I have seen it many times," says Salash Lealo, a local warrior. "The oloiboni can tell when the dry season is coming and when the rains are coming. I have seen him cure people who were so crazy we had to tie them up to stop them running off into the wild."

Cameron awoke from the worst of his cold turkey without any such faith: "But I thought, 'I've come here, and this bloke, whether he's legitimate or not legitimate, has washed me with something and given me something, and I feel better. Let's see what he can do.'"

Besides which, Cameron had no choice. There are no heroin pushers among the Maasai. And the lions prowling around the camp ruled out a hitch-hike back to Nairobi.

Musanga has been treating Cameron almost every day since. For a fortnight, Cameron moved into the smoky manyatta to live under the oloiboni's eye. Twice, Musanga took his patient into the bush, slaughtered a lamb, and forced quarts of soup mixed thickly with herbs into him.

But generally, the treatment remains the same: a shamanistic diagnosis followed by a draught of herbal medicine. The Kirks say it has given them back their son. "When he used to come out of rehab, he looked wild, still full of drugs; now he looks like the boy I had."

Watching Cameron charming his way around the camp, chatting up backpackers, trying his Maasai out on the cooks, it is hard to believe that a few weeks ago a coherent sentence was beyond him. Watching his turn of speed running the hyena gauntlet between two campsites, it is hard to remember that, because of overdoses, over the past two years his heart has stopped a dozen times.

But Musanga is not surprised at all. Whittling away at his moustache with his new Swiss army knife, a present from the Kirks, he says simply, "Cameron came here with white man's medicine. It didn't work, so I helped him."

Musanga says he could do the same for other addicts - but they would not be Maasai. "Young Maasai don't do these things," he says. "How could they? They have to respect their parents; they could not fight with them as Cameron does."

And what are the herbs Musanga prescribes? What does he see in the stones? "These things are secret because you do not need to know," he says, with a thoroughly mischievous grin.

John Kirk, an embittered man who has watched his finances shrink and his marriage suffer under the strain of his son's addiction, has transferred all his disappointments into something close to adoration for the Maasai. "The oloiboni has done for Cameron what western medicine could not, the Maasai have what the west has not," he says. "If I had the choice again of sending my boy to an English public school or to the Maasai, I'd send him straight here."

Cameron has a more balanced view. Looking out over the endless horizons of the Mara plain, he says his environment must have played a part: it is hard to make sense of mainlining in earshot of a lion's roar.

But that would not be enough for long, says Cameron. "If I'd wanted to, I could have stolen a car and got back to Nairobi. I don't know what the stones are about, but I know he's not pulling a fast one - rehab just doped me; but Musanga has changed the way I think. "

Understandably, Cameron is reluctant to leave the Mara for the temptation of Nairobi's bars. But his three weekends back in town so far have given cause for hope.

"It took them a while, but the taxi drivers recognised me," he says. "They were saying, 'Hey, kiketi man, come with us, we'll get you high.'

"I thought about it - I had money in my pocket. But I told them: 'No, that's not me any more.' To be honest, I just wasn't fucking interested."

fields.headline: What's new
fields.trailText: Wear an MP3 and E-movie
fields.body:
Wear an MP3
Panasonic's pair of wearable MP3 players reach UK stores this week, more than a year after they were first paraded at the CES exhibition in January 2000. The two E-Wear models, the SV-SD75 and SV-SD05 are among the first audio players to go on sale in the UK that feature both AAC (advanced audio coding) and MP3 compatibility. Devel oped by Dolby and Sony the AAC codec offers superior sound quality and more efficient compression than MP3. Panasonic says that if CDs are converted using its AAC encoding software, the player's 64MB SD (Secure Digital) card can store around two hour's worth of "better-than MP3-quality" sounds.

One of the smallest players on sale, the £300 SV-SD75 is designed to be worn either on the wrist or hung around the neck. It is accompanied by a USB reader/writer and wrist and neck straps.

Panasonic is also offering the £300 SV SD05 - an MP3/AAC player built into a pair of foldable headphones. It, too, comes with a 64MB SD card. Neither player is Mac compatible.

E-movie
Sony has announced the imminent arrival of a trio of high-end digital camcorders.

Top of the range is the £1,500 DCR-TRV30E, the first Sony camcorder to sport a new facility called E-Movie. This enables the user to store moving images as MPEG files on the camcorder's accompanying 4MB Memory Stick card. The mini-movie can then be transferred to a PC and sent as an email.

The DCR-TRV30E's digital video image quality is superior to previous Sony camcorders. It boasts a 1.5 mega pixel CCD that delivers a moving horizontal image resolution of 530 lines and still pictures of 1,360 x 1,020 pixels. The camcorder also sports a 3.5inch LCD monitor, a 120x digital zoom, Super Steady Shot anti-shake facilities, and Super Night Shot, which enables the user to shoot images in complete darkness. Connection to a PC is via a supplied I-Link connector, which, for the first time on a Sony camcorder, offers both DV in and out. Sony says that the user can shoot for up to eight hours before they need to recharge the camcorder's battery.

The £1,000 DCR-TRV17E is similar to the DCR-TRV30E, but has a lower resolution CCD and has no DV in facility. A budget version, the £800 DCR-TRV15E, also shares many of its siblings' features, but has a smaller 2.5inch LCD monitor and has no MPEG movie or digital still capture facilities.

Toshiba joins in
Toshiba is also championing the AAC music format by delivering a joint AAC/MP3 player to stores this week. The tiny silver-cased £230 MEA210 features 32MB of embedded memory, enough for more than an hour of quality AAC music. It also sports a slot for a SD card which can increase the storage up to 96MB.

The player is accompanied by a Toshiba Audio Manager CD-rom, which includes software that converts music files (WAV/CD or MP3) to the AAC format. The unit, powered by AAA batteries, comes with stereo headphones, a USB interface and a selection of tone controls.

fields.headline: More reaction to United's defeat
fields.standfirst: Sean Ingle rounds up the reaction around Europe
fields.trailText: Sean Ingle rounds up the reaction around Europe.
fields.body:
"Bye-bye Man U" - German newspaper Bild.

"I don't care about the Bundesliga title. What we really want is to win the Champions League" - Bayern captain Stefan Effenberg.

"This was not about revenge but about a challenge we had to live up to" - Bayern coach Ottmar Hitzfeld.

"We aren't exactly in high spirits right now, but what can you expect? We had a realistic chance of going through to the semi-finals of the Champions League but it wasn't to be, so we're allowed to be disappointed. When Giggsy scored a really good goal, we believed again that we could do it. But for some reason we couldn't quite raise our game to the top level last night" - Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, on his personal website icons.com.

fields.headline: Protesters barricade Gloucestershire farm
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: More than 100 protesters today barricaded the entrance to a farm run by adults with learning difficulties and vowed to keep out Ministry of Agriculture slaughterers.
fields.body:
More than 100 protesters today barricaded the entrance to a farm run by adults with learning difficulties and vowed to keep out Ministry of Agriculture slaughterers.

Animals bred at Oaklands Park farm in Gloucestershire are facing death after neighbouring Bullo farm was confirmed as having foot and mouth disease two weeks ago.

One campaigner, Ken Watson, 58, from Gloucester, said: "I'm totally against the idea of slaughtering these animals. It is completely unnecessary and we are prepared to stay here until Maff come."

The farm, run by the charity Camphill Village Trust, has so far tested negative for foot and mouth but is deemed to have had dangerous contact with the farm next door.

Managers of Oaklands Park have insisted their animals are healthy. They said the proposed cull would destroy the 25-year tradition of rearing animals at the site, in Newnham-on-Severn, in the Forest of Dean, to keep the community in fresh meat and vegetables.

The farm has 116 farm hands living on site, 48 of whom have learning disabilities. They rear 60 dairy shorthorn cattle, which have been bred over 25 years, 100 sheep and two angora goats. The farm is self-sufficient and grows organic vegetables to sell alongside their organically produced meat in the community in which they live. Many of the protesters today included customers of the farm.

Farm coordinator Pat Thompson said: "These animals are bred to work with people with learning disabilities who live at the farm. We have been calling the whole time to be allowed to vaccinate. This is what we believe we should be allowed to do.

"We had noticed yesterday that our animals were under threat but if we go another week we would be in the clear. On Sunday April 8 we had a risk assessment, with a vet looking for signs of us being likely to have foot and mouth. We were clear, but there are no animals to pass it on to, because we are the only farm left in the area with animals.

She continued: "Everything we do is connected with the land. It gives people living here a sense of purpose. It is meaningful work which gives them an enormous sense of achievement. They get satisfaction of working with animals and producing food for people living here in the community. We could not do what we are doing without the animals because we depend on them for the fertility of the land. Many of the people here regard them as their friends."

She said the concept of the farm for the disabled had started during the second world war. It now operates with 10 households, with many of the disabled members referred either by their families or social services.

Fellow farm worker Jon Meligan said: "The animals are an integral part of the farm. If they were slaughtered we would want to restock, but it would take years for us to build up the herd again."

fields.headline: Michael Ritchie
fields.standfirst: Film director who satirised the American Dream
fields.trailText: Film director who satirised the American Dream.
fields.body:
Sport in the movies has always provided an ideal metaphor for American life, whether as an exemplification of America as the land of opportunity or of the philosophy that in America you must either win or die. The film director Michael Ritchie, who has died of prostate cancer aged 62, often used sport as a parable against the winning ethic. His films mostly explore the morality of competition in a satirical manner. In time, Ritchie said that he had learnt, in his own erratic career, to "treat success and failure as the twin impostors they are".

There was nothing in Ritchie's background to suggest an interest in either sport or films. His father was a professor of experimental psychology at the University of California, and his mother an art and music librarian. At Harvard, Ritchie gained a degree in history and literature, although he was interested in drama. There is a line in Semi-Tough (1977) that Ritchie relished, where a publisher trying to get a professional footballer to write a book about the sport from the inside says, "Intellectuals are the jocks of the mind."

In his senior year in 1960, Ritchie gained attention by directing the original production of Harvard-graduate Arthur Kopit's black comedy about all-American "momism" - Oh Dad, Poor Dad, Mamma's Hung You In The Closet And I'm Feelin' So Sad. After some years directing episodes of The Man From U.N.C.L.E. and Dr Kildare, Robert Redford gave him his first crack at making a feature film. The star had been so impressed by one of Ritchie's TV films that he asked him to direct Downhill Racer (1969). The film, which claimed to be "the first American movie to tackle the subject of ski-racing", was directed in a semi-documentary style, mixing 16mm with 35mm, and giving a rare insight into the sport. There was no studio filming, no back projection. A professional skier filmed most of the shots of flying skis at speeds of 60-80 mph while holding a 151lb camera. Redford, just breaking into super-stardom, gives one of his cool, self-centred, cynical performances, and the direction has some of the same characteristics.

Ritchie continued his theme of competition in The Candidate (1972) and Smile (1976), satires on Middle America. The first dug beneath the surface irony and realistic reconstruction of an election campaign, with Redford well cast as the bland lawyer who finds himself manipulated when he stands as a senator. Smile, virtually a series of sketches following the fortunes of the 32 entrants in the Young American Miss competition, was often amusing, despite the superior position adopted by the director towards the beauty contest.

A much lighter touch was evident in The Bad News Bears (1976), a delightfully wry comedy containing the un-American message that winning isn't everything. The Little League baseball team is the most individualisedbunch of kids since Our Gang, cute in the sense of smart, while beer-swilling Walter Matthau, as their misanthropic coach, never noticeably plays for laughs.

Semi-Tough, starring Burt Reynolds and Kris Kristofferson as footballers living in a platonic threesome with Jill Clayburgh until sex rears its head, had a witty, free-wheeling quality for most of the way with football only one target of the film's sharp jibes. Underneath Reynolds's hairy-chested macho exterior is a warm human being who would like to write a book and marry the girl he loves. The football games are mostly in slow motion, as if to demonstrate the unimportance of the result.

Another kind of competition was satirised by Ritchie in An Almost Perfect Affair (1979), a romantic comedy with Keith Carradine and Monica Vitti as producer and star at the Cannes Film Festival. Its dismal box-office takings drove Ritchie into making less interesting commercial products. These included The Island (1980), an unintentionally risible but intentionally gruesome modern pirate tale; The Survivors (1983), a surprisingly unfunny black comedy given that its stars were Matthau and Robin Williams; and The Golden Child (1986), mystical Oriental guff.

Ritchie found more satisfaction working on cable television, which he considered offered "opportunities to do the kind of interesting films that were done in the 1970s, films that are not quite mainstream but are very accessible. Directors used to think they were slumming when they worked on television. Not any more."

One of Ritchie's better TV movies was The Positively True Adventures Of The Alleged Texas Cheerleader-Murdering Mom (1993), with Holly Hunter in the title role of a woman accused of plotting to kill the mother of her daughter's cheerleading rival.

On the big screen, Ritchie continued to make comedies, although they lacked satirical edge. There was Fletch (1985) and Fletch Lives (1989), involving Chevy Chase in many disguises and silly situations, and The Couch Trip (1987), with over-the-top performances from Dan Aykroyd and Walter Matthau.

Diggstown aka Midnight Sting (1992) was a welcome return to the sport picture, this time a boxing yarn, in which Ritchie's snappy direction managed to keep the rather complicated story, in which there are as many double crosses as right crosses, as lucid as possible. One of his last projects was a video documentary about Albert Einstein.

Michael Ritchie is survived by his wife, a son and four daughters.

Michael Ritchie, film and TV director, born November 28 1938; died April 16 2001

fields.headline: Sick men of Europe
fields.standfirst: Britons, having long sneered at foreigners, are now being patronised by Europeans, writes  Jonathan Freedland
fields.trailText: It's a bit rich, isn't it? Europe, home to Jörg Haider and Jean-Marie Le Pen, scolding Britain for being the most racist nation of the bunch. Who are the Germans - longtime deniers of citizenship to Turkish  Gastarbeiter , even those born in the country - to declare our attitude to refugees and asylum seekers the worst in Europe? Where do the French, whose casual harassment of non-whites is noticed by every black traveller across the Channel, get off scolding us? Who made the Danes, with their own energetic right wing, Europe's PC-police?
fields.body:
It's a bit rich, isn't it? Europe, home to Jörg Haider and Jean-Marie Le Pen, scolding Britain for being the most racist nation of the bunch. Who are the Germans - longtime deniers of citizenship to Turkish Gastarbeiter , even those born in the country - to declare our attitude to refugees and asylum seekers the worst in Europe? Where do the French, whose casual harassment of non-whites is noticed by every black traveller across the Channel, get off scolding us? Who made the Danes, with their own energetic right wing, Europe's PC-police?

That would be one way of dealing with the latest European assault, a report from the Council of Europe diagnosing a "particularly acute" form of racism in Britain. We could protest that we're no worse than everyone else. Or we might slay the messenger, noting that the council is a glorified talking shop unrelated to the European Union, whose reports are usually consigned to the filing cabinet of history. We might tease the council's investigators, who came to Britain nearly a year ago for a grand total of four days.

All those lines of attack are open, and every one of them has been taken by politician and pundit alike. But there is another, less predictable response: we can listen. We can pause for a second and see ourselves the way our neighbours see us. We may be in for an unpleasant surprise.

So we might listen to the council's claim that we tend to think of economic migrants as parasites and "criminals trying to sneak into our country". We might consider, and not dismiss, the EU's racism and xenophobia monitoring unit in Vienna, which last month ranked Britain, of all the 15 member states, as the most hostile to political refugees.

We might decide that, judging by our present form, the Europeans have got us about right. Only this month the outgoing Tory MPs John Townend and Christopher Gill offered up a double-act of Powellite xenophobia and stale bigotry. No sooner had Townend sung the praises of old Enoch, lamenting that "Commonwealth immigration" had undermined our "homogenous Anglo-Saxon society," than Gill was backing him up. Rising numbers of asylum seekers were causing a "rats in a bucket syndrome", diluting our national character. "If you pour enough water on a double scotch," he said, "it ceases to taste like whisky."

Since neither of these men were denied the Conservative Whip in Parliament, we can fairly conclude that the Tory leader William Hague sees no great contradiction between their views and parliamentary service for his party. And why should he? Did not Hague authorise a leaflet for last year's local elections warning of "bogus asylum seekers . . . flooding" these shores? Did he not raise the alarm recently about Britain becoming a "foreign land"?

So maybe the Euro-inspectors were not so wrong about us after all. But there is an even juicier irony here than the notion of a continent that houses the Freedom party and the Front National ordering Britain to clean up its act. It is that, after years of suffering British Euroscepticism, Europe is finally getting its own back.

Call it Britoscepticism. From the European heads of government furious with British agriculture for once again infecting the continent with disease, to a foreign press that has branded Britain Plague Island, our neighbours seem set to make Eurosceptic dreams come true. The British right wing always longed for Britain to break from the continent; now, apparently, the continent wants shot of us.

It's not just the headlines announcing catastrophe and images of pyres and burning flesh; Britain's neighbours have connected the latest crisis, over foot and mouth, with a deeper malaise. We are, they say, the "sick man of Europe," the "septic isle". For them foot and mouth is not an isolated, freakish episode but part of a continuum - with BSE the defining event. It is because of mad cow disease, which did have lethal implications for humans, that foreigners have assumed the worst about F&M - even though the worst damage F&M might inflict on a person would be a cold sore. It's no wonder that NBC News warns Americans of "the killer disease now stalking Britain - and how we can stop it coming here". When it comes to food safety, we are not trusted: we have previous convictions.

But the problem is deeper still. Foreign observers are linking foot and mouth not only with our agricultural plight, but with the very way we function as a society. Italy's L'Espresso cited our stubborn rates of poverty, the Hatfield rail disaster and the Real IRA's ongoing bombing campaign, as well as the animal epidemics, as proof that Britain was a nation under a "curse". Doubtless they will now be adding the return of tuberculosis to their list.

Thomas Keilinger of Germany's Die Welt writes of the parlous state of our public services, particularly the hospitals and railways. One dispatch announced that Britain is "slowly disappearing in the mire of the real-existing chaos".

Keilinger has told his readers of our lack of patriotism, the vacuity of the Dome, the winter floods and our appalling weather. Germans are Anglophiles, he says, but they need to temper their fondness with the truth about Britain.

"I think we felt that, after Thatcherism, Britain was a shining example of America-style, go-getting entrepreneurial savvy. Now we realise there is so much that is still creaky . . . the Thatcher revolution left whole swaths of society destitute, struggling to survive." He has said that, after the Russians, the British may be the longest-suffering populace in the world - prepared to put up with sub-standard services when others would have revolted against them decades ago.

Of course, there is some journalistic hyperbole here, as there would be if the roles were reversed. But it's hard not to see a warning. For years we were like the old headline-writer who decided that, since the Channel was fog-bound, the continent was cut off. For years we assumed that Britain was the great catch, with Europe the pushy suitor desperate for our hand. The Eurosceptic case rested on a British arrogance that saw participation in the European Union as a kind of favour to those grasping, desperate continentals.

Now we can see that the true situation may be the other way around. Having heard the British press and politicians pour scorn on them for generations, the Europeans are exacting their revenge. They are seeing Britain as a charity case that needs their help. When the time comes for Tony Blair to make good his promise to be "at the heart of Europe," he may find that, far from welcoming him in as a young, energetic saviour, the neighbours might offer him pity and a cup of sweetened tea - but only after he's wiped his feet in a trough of disinfectant.

Now we can see that the true situation may be the other way around. Having heard the British press and politicians pour scorn on them for generations, the Europeans are exacting their revenge. They are seeing Britain as a charity case that needs their help. When the time comes for Tony Blair to make good his promise to be "at the heart of Europe," he may find that, far from welcoming him in as a young, energetic saviour, the neighbours might offer him pity and a cup of sweetened tea - but only after he's wiped his feet in a trough of disinfectant.

fields.headline: Email from netimperative.com
fields.trailText: Email from netimperative.com
fields.body:
SOS

Save Our Service

netimperative.com calls on the UK internet industry for support

netimperative.com, the UK's sole remaining web-based provider of news and analysis on the UK internet industry, is asking its industry for support.

Today the site launches a campaign to convert a percentage of its current free member base to a paid structure. If this figure is achieved within the next two weeks, the company will be able to continue to offer its daily service.

In the current market environment, the company has proved that solid revenues can be achieved for a content site in the UK market, despite the current advertising downturn, but the overhead of providing such depth and breadth of information is high and can be difficult to justify - as everyone knows from having read about the cutbacks happening across the information

industry.

Chief executive Felicia Jackson said "it's clear that making content pay is a difficult proposition. We believe that the best way to find out whether or not our audience values our service as much as we think they do is very simple - we decided to ask them."

The membership fee is low, at £50 for six months, which entitles members to full access to the archive (over 10,000 articles), a free subscription to the UK TMT Datasheet (a weekly analysis of the performance of the UK's listed internet-related stocks), free attendance at lunchtime events and discounts on all other events. netimperative.com has also been working on developing a range of offline content products, and founder paying members will always receive a reduction on these offerings.

Over the next two weeks, the site will only accept pledges of payment, ensuring that no money is taken until the target necessary to guarantee the continuation of the daily service on an ongoing basis is met. The site will be tracking the performance of this campaign via its online 'MembOmeter', where visitors and members alike can take the pulse of the matter at hand. If successful, the service will then collect the membership monies over the following weeks, and netimperative.com will continue to offer the most timely, expert and incisive information on the UK internet market.

With the industry's help, we can all move forward together.

webTitle: Jewish organisations hit by volunteer shortage

fields.headline: Jewish organisations hit by volunteer shortage
fields.standfirst: The Jewish community is suffering worse than most from the difficulty in recruiting and retaining voluntary leaders. Liza Ramrayka investigates
fields.trailText: The Jewish community is suffering worse than most from the difficulty in recruiting and retaining voluntary leaders. Liza Ramrayka investigates.
fields.body:
Politicians at home and abroad are putting faith-based voluntary organisations at the heart of their social regeneration policies, but a new report into the UK Jewish voluntary sector shows that it shares the secular community's problems around recruiting and retaining voluntary leaders.

Independent thinktank, the Institute for Jewish Policy Research (JPR) commissioned the report into governance in the voluntary sector as part of its ongoing research into issues facing British Jewry. The chairs of 36 Jewish organisations were interviewed for the survey, which also collected views from senior paid staff working in large and small Jewish groups across the country. Their responses highlighted a shrinking volunteer base, with particular concerns expressed about the issue of attracting young people onto the boards of Jewish organisations.

While this problem is prevalent across the whole voluntary sector, the report suggests it is compounded in the Jewish community by competition from organisations in the wider community for people's time. The Jewish community accounts for around 280,000 of the UK's population. Its size and internal religious differences make the pool of potential voluntary leaders even smaller, the report states. The findings are a warning signal to the Labour and Conservative parties, which have both stated their desire to harness the relationships fostered by faith-based voluntary groups to boost community life.

Report co-author Margaret Harris is professor of voluntary sector organisation at Aston Business School, which co-published the report with JPR. She said: "The Jewish voluntary sector is not immune to the issues facing the general sectorand the Jewish community has additional problems to do with the nature of the community."

JPR research estimates the UK Jewish voluntary sector comprises around 2,000 organisations that have a combined income more than £500m. The report calls on Jewish voluntary groups to adopt a more systematic approach to volunteer recruitment and leadership development. Nearly 60% of respondents said their organisation had no formal induction process for new board members; only 30% offered training to board members.

Prof Harris suggests organisations should "capture" active young people as they become too old for Jewish youth groups, to stop them disappearing when they start family life or get involved in a career. "This will help to meet the challenge of leadership succession," she said.

Melvyn Carlowe is the former chief executive of Jewish Care, the UK's largest Jewish voluntary organisation with around 2,500 volunteers and 1,600 staff. He has seen many groups suffer from what he calls "resident president" syndrome, where the chair is in post for so long that other, younger members of the board can't see any prospect of moving up the ladder so eventually leave.

While at Jewish Care, Mr Carlowe oversaw the introduction of Young Jewish Care, an initiative to involve younger people in the charity through fundraising events and giving them representation on the executive board. Training and support for new board members was also introduced.

"It is a way of fast tracking young people to the top level so they can have a say in the organisation and act as ambassodors for the charity with their peers," Mr Carlowe explains. Jewish Care is currently recruiting undergraduate volunteers to work on its Encounters summer programme which offers a range of work placements across the charity's activities.

The Jewish community's existing involvement in voluntary leadership is "overwhelming" though, said Prof Harris. "Putting something back into the community is taken for granted and family and friends are key factors in motivating people to become involved. One person said it was like being part of a family and doing their share of the washing up, which sums up this deep-rooted sense of community." Twenty-two per cent of chairs interviewed had held the position for more than 10 years. Working half a day each week was regarded as the "minimum" commitment; the average time given was between eight and nine hours a week while a quarter of respondents regularly worked more than two days a week.

webTitle: Drug giants made to swallow bitter pill

fields.headline: Drug giants made to swallow bitter pill
fields.standfirst: Global opinion won in South Africa, but will it triumph when the US fights Brazil's cheap Aids medicine?
fields.trailText: Global opinion won in South Africa, but will it triumph when the US fights Brazil's cheap Aids medicine?
fields.body:
The drugs industry's court case against the South African government will go down in history alongside Shell's embarrassment by Brent Spar as one of the great corporate PR disasters of all time.

The hard lesson that the big pharmaceutical companies have been taught in South Africa, where they have been forced to retreat from their attempt to stop the country importing cheap Aids drugs, is that there can be no global marketplace without a world sense of right and wrong.

However much the industry insisted that the cost of patented drugs was not the main problem for African governments, the public perception was that the companies were more interested in protecting their intellectual property rights than in the health crisis in the continent.

South Africa, with the world's highest number of Aids sufferers, was precisely the wrong country at which to aim its campaign to prevent poor state buying cheaper generic copies of patented drugs.

Although Pretoria has a patchy record on facing up to the Aids crisis, it was prepared to stand by its right under international trade rules to import generic drugs during a national health emergency.

Now, belatedly, the companies have realised the damage the case has done to their public image. A settlement is expected today in which Pretoria will clarify its intention to interpret its 1997 Medicines Act under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules. But it will not rewrite the law, as the companies wanted.

The companies argued that the act allowed Pretoria to override patents at will. The government said it only planned to use the act in the spirit of the WTO's patent rules, which allow intellectual property rights to be overriden in exceptional circumstances.

Campaigners argued that the Aids crisis was an emergency as defined in the Trade Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (Trips).

The decision of the 39 drugs firms involved to halt the case, expected to be confirmed today, is a big defeat for US and European corporate lobbyists, in the agricultural as well as in the pharmaceutical sectors.

They thought it possible to exploit the rules for world trade in such a way as to make 6bn consumers dependent for redress on a handful of easily influenced regulators.

International public opinion and a worldwide web of activists, forces which the corpo rations had not counted on, appear to have made them change their minds this time.

Now attention switches to a more difficult arena: the case being brought by the US government, backed by the American Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers Association, against Brazil, which makes cheap copies of patent Aids drugs.

They say that Brazil is flouting Trips. The case will go before the nearest thing to a world court with teeth - the WTO in Geneva.

Campaigners cite Brazil as a successful example of how a relatively poor country can treat Aids if it has access to cheaper generic drugs. Aids deaths have halved since the government began providing cut-price treatment.

Merck and Pfizer, the companies leading the campaign against Brazil's generics industry, must be re-evaluating their strategy. But it will be harder for big drugs companies to admit defeat on this one.

South Africa's huge HIV problem, its tragic recent history and the saintly figure of Nelson Mandela made the companies" case look egregiously sleazy; on the level of hard-headed calculation, it is a relatively small market.

Brazil is different. Poor as it is, it is much richer than sub-Saharan Africa; it is a genuine potential market for the drugs giants. More significantly for the world, if the Trips tribunal backs Brazil, it will establish the principle that poor countries can override patent rules in the interests of public health.

Campaigners now want the safeguard rules in Trips to be clarified and trade negotiators to revisit the whole issue of patent protection in poor countries when the WTO discusses intellectual property rules in September.

Ominously for the drugs companies and their shareholders, the South Africa case and the forthcoming showdown in Geneva raise uncomfortable questions about big pharmaceutical companies' lack of financial transparency.

The arguments in favour of patents on drugs, which give corporations long monopolies on their production and sale, centre on the cost of the research needed to invent the medicine in the first place.

The companies say they need worldwide patent protection to recoup the millions spent on developing the drug.

But attention is now focusing on the lack of information about how much they spend on research, their huge profits, their dependence for many breakthroughs on publicly funded laboratories, the huge sums spent on marketing, and the disproportionate amount spent on developing drugs for lifestyle problems such as obesity in the developed world.

But the developing world's ability to defy the US on international trade is limited and it will be looking to Europe states, more resistant to corporate political power, to lead an attempt to draft a more just Trips regime.

fields.headline: Chaudhuri Devi Lal
fields.standfirst: Controversial Indian politician proud of his rural roots
fields.trailText: Controversial Indian politician proud of his rural roots.
fields.body:
Chaudhuri Devi Lal, the "raging bull of Haryana", who has died aged 85, was one of Indian politics' most colourful, controversial figures and, between 1989 and 1991, at the time of the country's first minority government, the deputy prime minister. This was initially in Vishwanath Pratap Singh's National Front government, which ousted Rajiv Gandhi's Congress in the 1989 general election.

Indeed, the National Front had selected the populist Lal - then Haryana's chief minister - as prime minister, but after a series of feints and manoeuvres Lal proposed Singh for the job. By July 1990, following a string of confrontations, Singh had sacked Lal, who promptly organised grass roots opposi tion to Singh. In a new and shortlived governnment, Lal was confirmed as deputy prime minister, and added the tourism porfolio as well.

"Tau" (uncle) Lal was born in Chautala, Haryana, in northern India and had little education. He had left his studies at the call of Mahatma Gandhi to join the civil disobedience movement against British rule.

During a political career spanning more than five decades, Lal epitomised the grassroots leader. A champion of peasant farmers, and leader of the Jat community of Haryana, he served in the old Punjab legislature, then in Haryana's legislature for more than two decades, and was its chief minister between 1977-80 and 1987-89, playing a pivotal role in modernising the state.

For Lal, New Delhi's Byzantine politics were anathema. But he contrasted the first Indian parliament which, he said, had just five true representatives from rural India, with the more than 300 legislators in situ by 1990.

As for city-bred politicians, they were cunning, devious, selfish and "marginal to the nation's interests". Only journalists, Lal added, paid attention them, because they spoke the same language and "understood their silly ways".

The media, meanwhile, projected Lal as a devilish Jat out to maximise the gains from his office while the city folk hit back at the "village bully". K Natwar Singh, a sometime Congress external affairs minister, described Lal as a Haryana bull with his own china shop.

When Lal became deputy premier, he moved into a sprawling bungalow on the President's Estate in New Delhi, and decided on new embellishments for its walls. Snubbing art experts, he settled on a minor official who returned with a clutch of paintings of rustic beauties and grizzled old farmers in suitably bucolic settings.

No one in Indian politics combined rural charm with shrewd politicking as Lal did. Ill-health and seclusion followed his defeat in the 1996 parliamentary elections.

He is survived by a daughter and four sons - including the current Haryana chief minister.

fields.standfirst: Publication date: April 20
fields.trailText: April 20: Iceland head of communications Hilary Berg has resigned.
fields.body:
Iceland head of communications Hilary Berg has resigned, following chief executive Malcolm Walker out of the door.

McDonald's is staging a mega-pitch for its public affairs account, inviting almost every established public affairs firm to present credentials.

Age Concern has named Neil Churchill as its first communications and marketing director.

Former GlaxoSmithKline political lobbyist David Earnshaw is to join Oxfam International as EU representative. The charity has fiercely criticised the pharmaceutical industry.

BBC Publicity has poached ex-Paramount Comedy Channel marketing and PR manager Roberta Bridges as a publicist for BBC Choice.

The British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering has recruited Connect Public Affairs to handle lobbying work as the Adoption and Children's bill makes its way through parliament.

MTV Europe has appointed Firefly Communications on a pan-European business-to-business brief.

fields.headline: Broadcast
fields.standfirst: Publication date: April 20
fields.trailText: April 20: RTL Group and United Business Media have agreed a truce in their battle over Channel 5's programming budget.
fields.body:
Channel 5's warring shareholders RTL Group and United Business Media have agreed a truce in their battle over the station's programming budget by giving the green light to an extra £6m for original productions.

Lisa Clark, the former LWT head of comedy, has resurfaced at the BBC as an entertainment executive producer.

The five main industry regulators to be merged to form Ofcom are struggling to reconcile their differences despite public protestations of unity.

BBC News 24 has unveiled an ambitious plan to focus almost entirely on general election coverage in the run-up to polling day.

The Planet 24 production director, Paul Sandler, has left the company and is planning to launch a multimedia production company in the summer.

Sharon Powers, the Channel 4 commissioning editor, entertainment, has ordered a Big Brother-style series from Princess Productions that will attempt to discover a new supermodel.

webTitle: Review finds 'major gaps' in Ceredigion social services

fields.headline: Review finds 'major gaps' in Ceredigion social services
fields.trailText: Ceredigion council's social services department serves some people well, but its performance is inconsistent and there are uncertain prospects for improvement, an independent review has found.
fields.body:
Ceredigion council's social services department serves some people well, but its performance is inconsistent and there are uncertain prospects for improvement, an independent review has found.

The joint review by the audit commission and the social services inspectorate finds that there are important gaps in Ceredigion's service, particularly in its support for older people with mental health needs.

Waiting times for some services are too long and the council needs to learn more from complaints. It must also become more focussed on improving services and ensuring quality, the review said.

Sue Mead, assistant director of joint reviews, said: "The council recognises there is room for improvement in many areas. Those in charge need better information about what is going on in the service, so as to assess its strengths, weaknesses, pressure points and progress."

The report concludes that the council needs to learn more about the real level of need across the county in order to respond more effectively to it, and to target resources more accurately.

The report also highlights a lack of awareness among some people in Ceredigion about what kind of help is available to them, and calls on the council to improve the support and supervision it provides for its workforce.

webTitle: Ten die in Philippine election violence

fields.headline: Ten die in Philippine election violence
fields.trailText: At least 10 people, including two town mayors, have been killed by gunmen in the Philippines as the country prepares for next month's national and local elections.
fields.body:
At least 10 people, including two town mayors, have been killed by gunmen in the Philippines as the country prepares for next month's national and local elections.

Police also confirmed that five other politicians have kidnapped in the run-up to the May 14 polls, in which 13 seats in the senate, around 200 seats in the house of representatives and thousands of municipal posts are due to be decided.

Mayor Teodoro Hernaez was shot and killed on stage in the northern town of Santa Lucia on Wednesday night by an unidentified assassin. His three police escorts were also killed by additional gunmen.

webTitle: Colvin to see New York surgeon

fields.headline: Sunday Times to fly injured journalist to New York
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Foreign correspondent Marie Colvin is to consult a top eye surgeon following her injuries in Sri Lanka, writes Jessica Hodgson.
18.04.2001: Award-winning journalist may lose sight
fields.body:
The managing editor of the Sunday Times, Richard Caseby, has confirmed the paper hopes to move the foreign correspondent, Marie Colvin, to a New York hospital "by the end of the week".

Mr Caseby said the paper was trying to arrange for her to see a top eye specialist, following damage from shrapnel that threatened to leave her blind in one eye.

He was unable to confirm the extent of the damage to Ms Colvin's eye.

"We are concerned for her medical welfare," Mr Caseby said, "but at the moment it is far from clear what is going to happen to her."

He added, however, that she seemed in "good spirits".

Ms Colvin, who was honoured with an award for foreign coverage at the British Press awards last month, was injured in fighting between Sri Lankan government forces and the separatist Tamil Tigers.

Related story

fields.headline: more! for Jones
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Emap Elan has appointed Marianne Jones as new editor of 'sexy' young women's title more!, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Emap Elan has appointed Marianne Jones, the assistant editor of M magazine, to be more!'s new editor.

Ms Jones replaces Marina Gask, who has stepped up to become editor-in-chief of the women's title and will handle the publisher's youth group special projects.

A former features editor at Marie Claire, Ms Jones has also worked as a feature writer on IPC's Woman magazine.

The editorship of the title has been vacant since Ms Gask stood down after Emap seconded her to help work on the launch of a planned new teen title.

Emap Elan's chief executive, Barry McIlheney, welcomed Ms Jones's appointment.

"The combination of her experience across tabloid, glossy and high frequency women's titles makes her the perfect candidate to take on Britain's best-selling young women's magazine," he said.

more! has developed a reputation as the sexiest magazine for young women, with explicit sex tips a speciality.

webTitle: Steven Spielberg hires third writer for Tulip Fever

fields.headline: Steven Spielberg hires third writer for Tulip Fever
fields.standfirst: Plus: Veteran critic celebrates overlooked films; Ewan McGregor denies affair; Australian Jedi fans face census fines
fields.trailText: Plus: Veteran critic celebrates overlooked films; Ewan McGregor denies affair; Australian Jedi fans face census fines
fields.body:
Steven Spielberg appears to be acting as a ruthless gardener on the production of the DreamWorks movie Tulip Fever, weeding out his British screenwriters at an alarming rate. The film-maker optioned the rights to Deborah Moggach's middlebrow period novel two years ago and signed the writer up to adapt it for the screen. A few months ago, Spielberg decided to fire Moggach and bring on board Lee Hall, the Oscar-nominated writer of Billy Elliot. This week he axed Hall in favour of Dangerous Liaison writer Christopher Hampton. Hall's agent is baffled: "We were very proud of the script and it's upsetting when a new writer is brought on board. Lee put a lot of work into it and we have no idea why it didn't go ahead."

Having watched more films than is possibly healthy, veteran critic Roger Ebert is perhaps one of the best qualified people to select a season of movies that slipped by without enough people noticing. To this end, he has developed Roger Ebert's Overlooked Film Festival, which runs in his native Chicago from April 25-29. Deserving of more attention, reckons Ebert, are such films as Songs From the Second Floor, Such a Long Journey, Jesus's Son, The King of Masks, Girl on the Bridge and Woody Allen's oddball musical Everyone Says I Love You.

The hunt for the wicked Lothario who broke up Tom and Nicole's marriage alighted on a new suspect this week as Scottish star Ewan McGregor was impelled to defend himself against rumours that he became over-close with Kidman on the set of their new movie, Moulin Rouge. With Russell Crowe and Penelope Cruz having already undergone the tabloid scrutiny, it was the turn of the Trainspotting star to protest his innocence. "I didn't have an affair with Nicole Kidman," McGregor insisted to Details magazine. "It was nothing to do with me." The actor added that he had "no idea" that the pair's marriage was in trouble during the making of the movie.

Australian Star Wars fans risk being slapped with stiff fines if they persist in listing their religion as "Jedi" on the nation's official census forms. Officials have noticed a worrying number of such responses being posted in as a result of an international email campaign to force governments to recognise Jedi-ism (the mystical mumbo-jumbo espoused by Obi Wan Kenobi and the irksome Yoda) as an official denomination. But the Australian Board of Statistics is not amused. It threatens to slap each offending Star Wars fan with a $1000 fine.

webTitle: Addicts to benefit from fast-track care

fields.headline: Addicts to benefit from fast-track care
fields.standfirst: A pioneering GP practice in the north-east hopes to cut waiting times for drug treatment by providing dedicated medical services to help users kick their habit. David Batty reports
fields.trailText: A pioneering GP practice in the north-east hopes to cut waiting times for drug treatment by providing dedicated medical services to help users kick their habit. David Batty reports.
fields.body:
Drug users who want to kick their addiction often have to wait months for hospital treatment. During this time many continue to commit crime to pay for their habit while others simply lose their resolve to quit.

But a pioneering GP practice in Middlesbrough aims to break this cycle by providing a dedicated medical service to addicts and their families.

The scheme, thought to be the first of its kind in the UK, will act as the first stop for substance abusers to access general medical treatment and rehabilitation services. Their families may also register so they can receive specialist support as well as standard GP care.

Dr Ian Guy, who runs the practice with the help of a specialist nurse practitioner, believes fast-track treatment will minimise the harmful effects of substance misuse on addicts, their families and the community.

"The scheme will get more drug misusers into the system and treated more quickly, so they can make a quicker return to normal life, so reducing the level of crime," said Dr Guy. "Addicts continue to pay for drugs while waiting for treatment and the average cost of feeding a drugs habit is £100 a day, which amounts to a lot of crime."

The project aims to cut the waiting time for local drug treatment services from 12 to four weeks by 2002. It is hoped this will help reduce repeat offending among addicts by 25% by 2005.

At present the practice only has 60 patients but it will soon take on another 500 addicts and their children, many of whom will transfer from other local GPs.

"This area has one of the highest numbers of drug addicts in the north-east," said Dr Guy. "Over the last year a growing number of GPs have stopped prescribing methadone because of difficulties with patients, so have been happy to refer them to us. But we also support doctors who keep addicts on their list where they have built up a relationship with them."

Dr Guy said many GPs were worried about taking on drug users because they wrongly assumed they were more violent than other patients. But by providing a dedicated service, he and his staff have established a rapport with addicts that is often impossible in normal practices.

"Things go wrong when, for example, addicts lose a prescription or spend a night in police cells so can't take their medication. In normal practices GPs can't drop everything to deal with them immediately, which can cause friction. But as a specialist service we have that flexibility."

Staff at the surgery will be trained in self-defence and personal alarms will be installed in consultation rooms, but Dr Guy expects his work will be rewarding rather than dangerous.

"It's very gratifying when you get a physically decrepit patient who can't look you in the eye, and four weeks later, stabilised on methadone, they are a different person," he explained.

The practice intends to link up with a specialist drugs counsellor. But mental health nurse Daniel Ahmed, who has specialist training in addictive behaviour, already offers "talking therapy" to help drug users come to terms with the emotional repercussions of rehabilitation.

"As they come off drugs a lot of emotions well up, particularly guilt if they've stolen from their family to support their habit," he said. "I help them deal with those feelings or refer them to a psychiatrist if necessary."

Funding for the scheme has come from Middlesbrough and Eston primary care group, Tees and North East Yorkshire NHS trust, the health action zone and single regeneration budget.

The practice staff will work closely with the trust's addictive behaviours service, the probation service and social services.

Janet James, provisional manager of the addictive behaviours service, said: "The scheme has already proved very popular. Providing a full primary care service to drug users and their families helps us to meet all their physical and mental health needs, as well as offering social support."

"Many patients say they feel it's the first time that professionals have really cared about their welfare," said Mr Ahmed. "One told me they'd never been listened to by their GP before. Another said they look forward to coming in and for us that's half the battle."

fields.headline: You are the weakest link online
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The BBC is launching a website for Weakest Link as part of an effort to extend the popularity of the programme online. By Amy Vickers.
18.04.2001: Weakest Link storms US
Useful weakest links: weakestlink.i7.com.au
TWLOnline.co.uk
fields.body:
The BBC is launching a website for Weakest Link as part of an effort to extend the popularity of the programme online.

The site, to be launched at bbc.co.uk/weakestlink, is expected to be launched by the summer.

A spokesman for the BBC confirmed that a site was "in development" but wouldn't give details of proposed site contents, aside from saying it would be "community-focused".

It is likely that the official site will be similar in content and feel to the official Australian website, located at weakestlink.i7.com.au.

The Australian site contains a virtual tour of the studio, information about the show, games, screen savers, chat forums and even a downloadable MP3 of the theme tune.

The BBC spokesman confirmed it would be seeking to remove copyrighted material from the unofficial Weakest Link website TWLOnline.co.uk.

"We've written to them and the ISP and asked for removal. We would normally turn a blind eye to fan sites, but this has infringed copyright by having sound samples, the logo and even a version of the game," he said.

"If they removed the copyright material then we wouldn't have to be so heavy-handed."

In the meantime, the Weakest Link is hell-bent on world domination.

Yesterday it was announced that BBC Multimedia had teamed up with games developer Activision, to develop PC and console games around the gameshow.

It is thought that, like Who Wants to be a Millionaire?, these games will eventually be fed into the official websites.

webTitle: Which kind of Brit are you?

fields.headline: Which kind of Brit are you?
fields.standfirst:
This week Anne Robinson joined the small band of Brits who are Big Over There. But American ideas of Britishness have already been shaped by a handful of her compatriots. So will Anne go down as a Maggie or a Daphne? And are there really only six types of Brit? Tim Dowling, an American in London, puts us in our places

Special report: what is Britain?
fields.trailText: This week Anne Robinson joined the small band of Brits who are Big Over There. But American ideas of Britishness have already been shaped by a handful of her compatriots. So will Anne go down as a Maggie or a Daphne? And are there really only six types of Brit? Tim Dowling, an American in London, puts us in our places.
fields.body:
Roger Moore

If the frightfully posh gentleman is one of the types easily recognised in America, it is also subject to widespread confusion. Americans are notoriously unable to make class distinctions based on accent - confused by the fact that the people with the poshest English accents on US television invariably play butlers. When judging how upper-class a British person might be, Americans sometimes look for a reluctance to take physical exercise or the ability to raise one eyebrow, but in the first-come, first-served hurly-burly of American social assignation, poshness is based mainly on wealth, although a title doesn't hurt.

Qualifications: Cigarette holder, clean handkerchief in sleeve, love of golf, permanent residency in Santa Monica, pencil moustache.

Examples: Sir Michael Caine, Sir Peter Lawford, Sir Anthony Hopkins, Sir Paul McCartney, Sir Prince Charles, Sir Hugh Grant, Sir Alistair Cooke.

Chances of Anne Robinson joining this category: Fair, provided she gets an OBE soon.

Daphne from Frasier

The character of Daphne, the Cranes' scatty home help, along with the films The Full Monty and Billy Elliot, has at last enabled Americans to recognise northern Britons as a distinct category, and a surprisingly popular one. These days, extrovert Mancunians in bow ties litter US shopping channels, excitedly extolling the virtues of the latest electric juicer for the benefit of millions of couch potatoes in the first stages of deep-vein thrombosis. But "northern" is as specific as it gets. Americans do not know what Geordies are, and believe Sting to be half-Spanish. In the US, a Scouse accent is simply a John Lennon impression, and a West Country burr is universally recognised as pirate talk.

Qualifications: Northern, amusing stories about eccentric relations, background in mining.

Examples: Daphne, Billy Elliot, Bubbles from Absolutely Fabulous, Julie Walters, anyone Welsh apart from Sir Anthony Hopkins.

Anne Robinson's chances: None at all, even though she is from Liverpool.

Phil Collins

The success in America of Guy Ritchie's two films notwithstanding, Americans like their estuary English speakers cheeky and warm-hearted, more lovable than rogue, just like lovely Phil. Thanks largely to the pioneering efforts of Dick van Dyke in Mary Poppins, what constitutes a cockney accent in America is a matter of liberal, even personal interpretation, so this category includes many Scots and Australians. You don't have to be born within the sound of Bow bells any more, so long as you're cheerful, twinkly, devil-may-care and happy-go-lucky.

Qualifications: Routinely addresses members of the opposite sex as "love", must be able to wink and tolerate endless questions about what bubble and squeak is.

Examples: Mel Gibson, Rod Stewart, Rod Hull, Eddie Izzard, Bob Hoskins, Austin Powers, Greg Rusedski.

Anne Robinson's chances: Slim to none.

Margaret Thatcher

Baroness Thatcher is the archetypal dowdy British matriarch, a stereotype which has no perfect US counterpart, and which only serves to confirm the widely held American belief that all British men were raised by nannies and then beaten at public school, leaving them with a perverse sexual interest in stern and/or shrill women of a certain age.

Qualifications: Between-the-wars coiffure, strong moral convictions, handbag.

Examples: Sybil Fawlty, the Queen, Aunt Spiker and Aunt Sponge from James and the Giant Peach, Benny Hill, Dame Edna Everage.

Anne Robinson's chances: Better if she were played by Robin Williams.

Sid Vicious

Sid Vicious embodies the American idea of the great British punk: aggressive, foul-mouthed, depressing and silly. It takes more than attitude to be considered violent in America, it takes firepower - and British punks always seemed to be too fond of a cup of tea and a biscuit to be of any real threat to the old order. It's difficult for Americans to think of British people engaging in violence. Even the term "football hooligan" sounds quaint to American ears, just a step away from "lawn tennis ruffian", with none of the can-do impact of "disgruntled ex-postal worker".

Qualifications: Orange hair, facial jewellery, drug and/or alcohol problem, Doc Martens, an overly literal adherence to the concept of anarchy. Must live with Gran.

Examples: Gary Oldman, Billy Idol, Vyvyan from the Young Ones, Daphne from Frasier's inexplicably cockney brother.

Anne Robinson's chances: Not bad at all.

Darth Vader

Everyone in America knows that Satan is British, which is why anyone evil must be played by someone with a suitably sinister English accent. All right, so the actor who did Vader's voice, James Earl Jones, is from Mississippi, but that is beside the point. He sounds plenty evil, and that sounds British. From vampires and invading aliens to Bond villains and the bad animals in Disney cartoons, British is always best.

Qualifications: Evil incarnate, but easily vanquished in the end.

Examples: Alan Rickman in Die Hard, The Grinch Who Stole Christmas, Joan Collins, Liz Hurley in Bedazzled, Christopher Lee.

Phil Collins The success in America of Guy Ritchie's two films notwithstanding, Americans like their estuary English speakers cheeky and warm-hearted, more lovable than rogue, just like lovely Phil. Thanks largely to the pioneering efforts of Dick van Dyke in Mary Poppins, what constitutes a cockney accent in America is a matter of liberal, even personal interpretation, so this category includes many Scots and Australians. You don't have to be born within the sound of Bow bells any more, so long as you're cheerful, twinkly, devil-may-care and happy-go-lucky. Qualifications: Routinely addresses members of the opposite sex as "love", must be able to wink and tolerate endless questions about what bubble and squeak is. Examples: Mel Gibson, Rod Stewart, Rod Hull, Eddie Izzard, Bob Hoskins, Austin Powers, Greg Rusedski. Anne Robinson's chances: Slim to none. Margaret Thatcher Baroness Thatcher is the archetypal dowdy British matriarch, a stereotype which has no perfect US counterpart, and which only serves to confirm the widely held American belief that all British men were raised by nannies and then beaten at public school, leaving them with a perverse sexual interest in stern and/or shrill women of a certain age. Qualifications: Between-the-wars coiffure, strong moral convictions, handbag. Examples: Sybil Fawlty, the Queen, Aunt Spiker and Aunt Sponge from James and the Giant Peach, Benny Hill, Dame Edna Everage. Anne Robinson's chances: Better if she were played by Robin Williams. Sid Vicious Sid Vicious embodies the American idea of the great British punk: aggressive, foul-mouthed, depressing and silly. It takes more than attitude to be considered violent in America, it takes firepower - and British punks always seemed to be too fond of a cup of tea and a biscuit to be of any real threat to the old order. It's difficult for Americans to think of British people engaging in violence. Even the term "football hooligan" sounds quaint to American ears, just a step away from "lawn tennis ruffian", with none of the can-do impact of "disgruntled ex-postal worker". Qualifications: Orange hair, facial jewellery, drug and/or alcohol problem, Doc Martens, an overly literal adherence to the concept of anarchy. Must live with Gran. Examples: Gary Oldman, Billy Idol, Vyvyan from the Young Ones, Daphne from Frasier's inexplicably cockney brother. Anne Robinson's chances: Not bad at all. Darth Vader Everyone in America knows that Satan is British, which is why anyone evil must be played by someone with a suitably sinister English accent. All right, so the actor who did Vader's voice, James Earl Jones, is from Mississippi, but that is beside the point. He sounds plenty evil, and that sounds British. From vampires and invading aliens to Bond villains and the bad animals in Disney cartoons, British is always best. Qualifications: Evil incarnate, but easily vanquished in the end. Examples: Alan Rickman in Die Hard, The Grinch Who Stole Christmas, Joan Collins, Liz Hurley in Bedazzled, Christopher Lee.

fields.headline: Britain covets Celebrity Bodies
fields.trailText:
8.30am: It is understood that Emap's controversial celebrity diets magazine sold out within a day and a half, reports Jessica Hodgson.
29.03.2001: Minister slams Celebrity Bodies
29.03.2001: Emap women's mag condemned
29.01.2001: Emap to launch celebrity health title
Picture gallery
fields.body:
Celebrity Bodies, the controversial magazine that tells readers how to copy the diet and fitness regimes of celebrities like Geri Halliwell and Jennifer Aniston, proved so compelling to a nation of fitness freaks that it sold out within a day and a half in branches of WH Smith.

The retailer refused to confirm the figures, but said sales had "vastly exceeded expectations".

It is understood all 9,000 copies stocked by the high street retailer were gone within a day and a half.

Sources at the company say this is "almost unprecedented".

Alison Hall, the editor of Celebrity Bodies, was unavailable for comment, but there is speculation that the magazine will be published more frequently than once every quarter after the success of the first run.

The magazine has been dogged by controversy since its launch, with positive body image advocates saying it added to women's insecurity over their weight.

In its only issue to date, the magazine gave its readers a rundown of how to imitate the diet that took Aniston from a size 12 to a size six.

Tessa Jowell, the women's minister, branded the magazine as "grim reading".

The Celebrity Bodies editor, Alison Hall, defended the magazine, claiming it was full of "nutritionally sound diets".

Ms Jowell and women's magazine editors last year chaired a "body image summit" at which the editors of women's magazines were invited to discuss pressures on young women to lose weight and the role of glossy magazines.

The departing editor of the Marie Claire magazine, Liz Jones, lashed out at other magazine editors in a Mail on Sunday editorial.

In the article, Ms Jones named and shamed other women's magazine editors who she said "encourage eating disorders".

Among others, she named Vogue editor Alexandra Shulman, Elle editor Fiona McIntosh and Glamour editor Jo Elvin.

webTitle: Foot and mouth in the media

fields.headline: Day 59: foot and mouth in the media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk keeps you informed with a daily briefing on the press coverage of foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText:
Day 59: Several papers accuse the NFU and Tony Blair of ignoring small farmers' fears about vaccination.
Special report: foot and mouth in the media
fields.body:
The Guardian
On page eight, the National Farmers' Union is accused of ignoring small farmers' views over innoculation. Foreign tourism chiefs are being shown around Wales as part of a UK charm offensive, while army chiefs claim they should have been brought in earlier to deal with the crisis.

The Independent
The paper reports on page six that the pyres of dead animals could be producing as many carcinogenic chemicals as every factory in Britain combined. Tony Blair appears ready to override farmers' opinions and order vaccination in Cumbria and Devon.

The Daily Telegraph
The paper splashes on the revelation the government was warned two weeks ago vaccination could do more harm than good. On page nine, William Hague says local vets should be allowed to sanction the movement of herds on to fields to graze.

The Mirror
On page two, the government launches a campaign to persuade farmers to accept a vaccination programme.

Daily Mail
On the front page, the farmers' fury at the prospect of vaccination grabs the headlines, while Edward Heathcoat Amory argues on page eight that Tony Blair's dithering has worsened the crisis.
