webTitle: Shamed and humiliated - the drugs firms back down

fields.headline: Shamed and humiliated - the drugs firms back down
fields.trailText: The world's largest drug companies are today expected to make a humiliating climbdown and abandon their legal action against South African laws aimed at getting cheaper medicines to the poor.
fields.body:
The world's largest drug companies are today expected to make a humiliating climbdown and abandon their legal action against South African laws aimed at getting cheaper medicines to the poor.

The suit by 39 pharmaceutical companies in the Pretoria high court, which argued that the South African legislation infringed their patent rights, has ultimately achieved the very thing it tried to prevent - encouraging governments across the developing world to use the law to obtain more affordable drugs.

But the withdrawal of the drugs firms from the case, described by one government official as "unconditional surrender", will stave off another public relations disaster. The companies faced having to reveal some of their most closely guarded business secrets, including pricing policies, profit levels and the source of funding for research into key anti-Aids drugs.

The trial was scheduled to resume yesterday after a six- week recess. During that time a groundswell of public and government opposition to the legal action caused some of the largest firms to rethink their strategy. Protesters across the globe accused them of putting profits ahead of lives and Germany, France, Holland and the European parliament called for the suit to be dropped.

Last-minute talks between five big firms - including the world's largest pharmaceutical company, Britain's GlaxoSmithKline - and the South African government dragged on through Wednesday, causing the court to postpone the hearing until today.

The drug companies have now accepted virtually all of the legislation - including the South African government's right to import generic drugs at a fraction of the cost of brand names - but they are pressing the health ministry to rewrite a key section of the law to clarify and limit the circumstances in which it can grant compulsory licences for third parties to manufacture patented medicines at a lower price.

It is not clear if the South Africans will give ground on this issue but the government has already said that its primary interest is not in copying patented drugs but in importing generics from other countries or manufacturing them.

However, what is certain is that the big drug companies have lost all heart for the fight. Although some smaller firms could technically pursue the case, lawyers said it was highly unlikely that they will.

Mark Heywood, a legal strategist for the Aids pressure group, the Treatment Action Campaign, which played a key role in forcing the drug companies to drop the case, said: "The case was doing significant damage to the multinationals' image and investor confidence in them. The case was also forcing out of the woodwork certain aspects of their business practices they did not want exposed in court and aired before the world's media. They had no legal case."

A split has developed between some of the larger drug companies and the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association of South Africa (PMA), which headed the legal action.

Some drug firms are now saying the case should never have been pursued. They were also disturbed at the content of some submissions by PMA lawyers, which were a PR disaster. At yesterday's hearing, several drug firms sent in their own legal teams.

One submission, which was particularly heavily criticised in South Africa, argued that unless there were financial returns there was little incentive for drugs companies to develop new Aids treatments.

While international opinion was clearly an important factor in the firms' withdrawal, they had also realised they were on shaky legal ground.

The PMA effectively abandoned its argument that the South African law breached international patent protection agreements before the court case opened, after the World Trade Organisation and several governments said Pretoria's legislation was legitimate. Instead, the drug companies argued in court that the laws breached South Africa's own constitution by giving too much power to cabinet ministers to decide when to override patents and because they failed to define what "unaffordable" meant in a medical context.

The government recognised that some of the legislation was poorly worded and was preparing itself for a judgment that would uphold its right to introduce such laws but require that this one be rewritten with greater clarity.

As the first phase of the trial progressed, prospects of success steadily dimmed while the cost to the drug companies' reputations was huge.

"They might have thought all this shit was worth taking if they were going to win, but they knew they weren't," said one lawyer working on the case against the drug firms. "The best they could hope to do was hold up the implementation of the law a little longer during the appeals and maybe scare a few other governments off of following South Africa's lead."

South African health officials say they are ready to put the new law into practice within weeks once the legal challenge is finally dropped.

But despite international public opinion rallying around the South Africans over access to anti-Aids drugs, the government has no intention of importing anti-retrovirals in the near future even though one in nine of the population - 4.7m - is HIV-positive.

It will instead seek medicines to combat opportunistic infections brought on by Aids and drugs to deal with other diseases such as malaria.

Africa: the deadly toll

 25.3m Africans were living with HIV or Aids in 2000 and 2.4m people died of HIV-related causes

 Africa is home to nearly 70% of adults and 80% of children with HIV in the world

 In South Africa and Zimbabwe, Aids could claim the lives of around half of all 15-year-olds

 South Africa has more people living with HIV and Aids than any other country. Pretoria estimates that 4.7m people are carrying HIV. Experts warn the number may rise to 7m by 2010

 South Africa's neighbour Botswana has the highest rate of HIV infection, with an estimated 35.8% of all adults living with the disease. Life expectancy in Botswana has been cut to 44 years

 HIV patients occupy nearly 40% of the beds in the Kenyatta national hospital in Nairobi and 70% of the beds in the Prince Regent hospital in Burundi

 Aids deaths in South Africa are expected to rise from around 120,000 last year to an annual 635,000 in 2010

fields.headline: P&G crowned 'top corporate citizen'
fields.standfirst: Click here to see the whole top 100
fields.trailText:
11am: Procter and Gamble tops a list of the 100 best corporate citizens, despite criticism from animal rights activists, reports Julia Day.

Click here to see the whole top 100
fields.body:
Procter and Gamble tops a list of the 100 best corporate citizens, despite coming under attack from animal rights activists.

But Coca-Cola, Anheuser-Busch, Campbell Soup, US media firm Times Mirror and Wal-Mart dropped off the list altogether.

The 100 Best Corporate Citizens for 2001, a list of the most profitable and socially responsible major public companies in the US has been compiled by Business Ethics Magazine.

The list was compiled by examining 650 top public US companies and their stockholder performance and impact on local communities, minorities, employees, global stakeholders, customers and the environment.

Thirty-one companies fell off the 2001 list but Apple Computer (number 32), McDonald's (78), Dow Jones (79), and Eastman Kodak (82) were all new entrants.

P&G moved up from number four last year to take the top slot. It scored highly in service to international stakeholders as did Avon Products (20), and Starbucks (24).

P&G's international grants and gifts, including earthquake relief in Turkey and community building projects in Japan stood it in good stead.

But the company's use of animal ingredients and products, although it has banned testing on animals, continues to cause concern among activists.

The company's products include Sunny Delight, Fairy Liquid, Pringles and Pampers.

Hewlett-Packard came second, with its community development and education initiatives and an employee-friendly work environment that includes 52 weeks' maternity leave.

Gillette (56) earned the highest score for its proactive approach to environmental restoration with an innovative programme to restore America's wetlands.

IBM dropped from the top spot to number five largely as a result of its mishandling of changes to its pension plan, which cost some older employees as much as 50% of their pension.

Not one single car manufacturer or petroleum company made it on to the list, proving that the social and environmental impact of some products are hard to overcome.

fields.headline: Lucky charm deserts Ferguson
fields.trailText: Like a desperate fan squeezing a favourite good luck charm in the hope of conjuring an unlikely victory, Sir Alex Ferguson released Teddy Sheringham and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer from the bench in the hope that they could repeat the miracle of Barcelona 1999, when their goals allowed United to steal the European Cup from Bayern in the dying seconds.
fields.body:
Like a desperate fan squeezing a favourite good luck charm in the hope of conjuring an unlikely victory, Sir Alex Ferguson released Teddy Sheringham and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer from the bench in the hope that they could repeat the miracle of Barcelona 1999, when their goals allowed United to steal the European Cup from Bayern in the dying seconds.

By the final minutes last night, Fabien Barthez could barely be restrained from joining that pair and Andy Cole in a four-pronged United attack. But there was to be no miracle in the Olympic stadium, just a dose of harsh reality that made Fergie's Premiership celebrations curdle in his throat.

"The joy of winning the championship is gone now," he said. "I look at our European challenges to judge our progress and this is another big disappointment."

The truth is that, against a Bayern side whom even their president Franz Beckenbauer considers to be at a crossroads, United were at times made to look like a very ordinary Premiership side, which in many ways they are. They just happen to be ordinary in an era when their so-called rivals have ambitions only to reach such an exalted level. United did press gallantly forward to try to overturn a 3-0 aggregate deficit in the second half. But when your backs are pressed against the wall, there is no way to go but forward and it seemed as futile a gesture as running into the enemy guns.

Bayern, having scored the two first-half goals that wrapped this tie up, simply mopped up the pressure after Ryan Giggs gave United hope, blind hope at that, by striking before the second half was five minutes old.

Giggs had been identified by both sides beforehand as the potential matchwinner. But if the No11 was going to be raised in triumph after this encounter, it was going to be the shirt of Bayern captain Steffen Effenberg, who had vowed to cavort in red lederhosen if his side won.

And how Effenberg enjoyed his night of revenge against United, even if on the field he was as soberly efficient as he is flamboyantly over the top off it. Had he been in the stands, he would no doubt have joined German fans in their taunting English chants of "Football's Coming Home" and "Goodbye Manchester United". On the pitch, he knew he had to show maturity and discipline in the crucial central midfield area. This he did, controlling things manfully.

But there was no consoling Sir Alex, who somehow deluded himself into believing that United were the better side over the two legs. He has already said that to achieve true greatness a side must conquer Europe at least twice but, without major surgery, it seems unlikely they will do so in his final season as manager. Barring miracles, of course.

fields.headline: Online activists arrested in China
fields.standfirst: Special report: China
fields.trailText: Police in China have detained a veteran activist who printed out pro-democracy material from a website and an engineer whose site carried a vehement denunciation of communism, a human rights group said today.
fields.body:
Police in China have detained a veteran activist who printed out pro-democracy material from a website and an engineer whose site carried a vehement denunciation of communism, a human rights group said today.

Veteran activist Chi Shouzhu was picked up yesterday shortly after printing online material using a friend's computer, according to a statement from the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy.

Police would not confirm the report, which said he was carrying the materials when he was detained at a train station in the north-eastern city of Changchun. Mr Chi, a factory worker, was released in June after serving a 10-year prison term for taking part in 1989 pro-democracy protests.

Yang Zili, a software engineer, was detained on March 13 after he left his Beijing home, the Information Centre said. The reason was unclear, but Mr Yang had a site with essays on politics and sensitive issues such as Taiwan, which Beijing considers a breakaway province.

His last entry, dated March 2001, includes a condemnation of the "soul of communism", which he said had caused the Chinese people unprecedented suffering.

"Give the last deadly blow to that soul for the sake of freedom, power and the glory of our ancestors," it said.

The Information Centre said Yang's wife was angry that, after more than a month, she had not been told where her husband was or why he was being detained.

The news comes amid efforts by Chinese officials to block use of the interent to spread opposition to communist rule.

A schoolteacher was sentenced in March to two years in prison for criticising the communist party in an online discussion. The government also consistently attempts to block access to sites deemed subversive.

fields.bodyText: Police in China have detained a veteran activist who printed out pro-democracy material from a website and an engineer whose site carried a vehement denunciation of communism, a human rights group said today. Veteran activist Chi Shouzhu was picked up yesterday shortly after printing online material using a friend's computer, according to a statement from the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy. Police would not confirm the report, which said he was carrying the materials when he was detained at a train station in the north-eastern city of Changchun. Mr Chi, a factory worker, was released in June after serving a 10-year prison term for taking part in 1989 pro-democracy protests. Yang Zili, a software engineer, was detained on March 13 after he left his Beijing home, the Information Centre said. The reason was unclear, but Mr Yang had a site with essays on politics and sensitive issues such as Taiwan, which Beijing considers a breakaway province. His last entry, dated March 2001, includes a condemnation of the "soul of communism", which he said had caused the Chinese people unprecedented suffering. "Give the last deadly blow to that soul for the sake of freedom, power and the glory of our ancestors," it said. The Information Centre said Yang's wife was angry that, after more than a month, she had not been told where her husband was or why he was being detained. The news comes amid efforts by Chinese officials to block use of the interent to spread opposition to communist rule. A schoolteacher was sentenced in March to two years in prison for criticising the communist party in an online discussion. The government also consistently attempts to block access to sites deemed subversive. fields.headline: Slump hits Grey Interactive UK
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The UK interactive division of advertising agency Grey Worldwide is losing its chief executive and 19 staff, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The UK interactive division of advertising agency Grey Worldwide is losing its chief executive and laying off 19 staff, making it the latest company to fall victim to the economic slowdown.

Grey Interactive UK today confirmed it is making 19 of its 69 staff redundant, as the dot.com crisis continues to bite.

The chief executive, Brian Lee, has resigned and will be replaced by Simon Rule, the company's chief operating officer. Mr Lee does not have another job to go to.

The news means that Grey Interactive has seen its staff levels more than halved since the beginning of this year. In March, the company announced 34 job losses.

"I'm afraid that market conditions have caught up with us," said Mr Lee. "We had hoped to avoid any more job losses, but that has not been possible.

"I am resigning but I am confident the company will be well looked after. All we can do is try to weather the storm."

Several US advertising agencies have shed staff as a result of the slowdown, but the UK market has so far managed to avoid large-scale redundancies.

Comment

fields.headline: Too much too young?
fields.standfirst: At the age of 10 Liv Tyler realised the man she called daddy was not her father. At 14 she started modelling; at 16 she became an actor. Did it all turn her into yet another Hollywood brat? She talks to  Danny Leigh
fields.trailText: At the age of 10 Liv Tyler realised the man she called daddy was not her father. At 14 she started modelling; at 16 she became an actor. Did it all turn her into yet another Hollywood brat? She talks to Danny Leigh
fields.body:
Liv Tyler, coltish, barefoot, says hello. I say hello back. And then we sit facing one another in a harshly lit room with no windows until she, rocking gently like a bear at a zoo, stares straight at me with a fierce, spotlight intensity. Panic spreads across her face. "I'm totally freaked out," she says. "This room is freaking me out." She suggests we fake anxiety attacks and run screaming from the premises. Instead, once the crisis has passed, we find ourselves discussing Jamie Oliver. "The Naked Chef!" She is a big fan of his recipes. It's surprising and strangely depressing that she even knows who he is. "Of course I do. Hey, you know ... I'm with it."

Maybe we should talk about her latest film, the purposefully frothy One Night at McCool's. It is, after all, the reason she's here, tipping back and forth in what does resemble a well-appointed dungeon.

Revolving around the doomed fixation of three older men with her wide-eyed free spirit, McCool's may not unduly trouble next year's Oscar selectors, but it does provide its star with a showcase for talents more often submerged beneath her fame as the daughter of Steven Tyler, venerable frontman of rock roués Aerosmith. It also captures, in an accidental way, the nature of her own celebrity - specifically, her near-deification by a slew of male acolytes (in the film, they include Matt Dillon and Michael Douglas; in reality, they cluster on internet sites called, for example, "Wow! Liv Tyler!").

"I know," she says. "It's always me and a bunch of men." And she's OK with that? "Yeah. I mean, I think it's weird the way there's chick flicks, and then there's every other movie. But I've taken the parts I have because I loved the film, not because ..." She trails off. "Maybe it says more about the film industry than about me."

All the same, the central theme of McCool's - half-crazed male genuflection - is the one constant in a series of professional choices not so much diverse as seemingly made with a pile of scripts and a pin. In the seven years since her debut in the earnest drama Silent Fall, she has done - among others - a blockbuster (Armageddon), a Pushkin adaptation (Onegin), two Robert Altman movies (Cookie's Fortune, Dr T and the Women) and at least one project requiring her to sport pointed ears and speak Elvish (the forthcoming Lord of the Rings). Not for her the careful careerism of, say, Christina Ricci or Kate Hudson. She meets my eyes again, then lights a cigarette.

"I'm winging it," she says. "I mean, I'm still not sure about myself, so I'm constantly trying new things." She looks like she's going to faint. Everything all right? "Yeah ... no, it's just this room - the wallpaper's making me dizzy. Anyway, Armageddon. I really didn't want to do it at first and I turned it down a couple of times, but the biggest reason I changed my mind was because I was scared of it. I wanted to try it for that very reason. I mean, I'm not really in this to do amazing things in my career - I just want it to be special when I make a movie."

Having taken one drag on her cigarette, she stubs it out. When she says she's not sure of herself, does she mean professionally or personally? "Both. Yeah. Both. I mean, is anybody sure of themselves? I know I'm not."

The temptation, as ever, is to start putting two and two together. After all, Tyler is the product of an upbringing sufficiently fractured to have been lifted from soap opera. The daughter of one-time Playboy centrefold Bebe Buell - immortalised in Elvis Costello's Party Girl - she spent her childhood in Maine believing her father was singer-songwriter Todd Rundgren. Steven Tyler was simply another of her mother's friends - a playfully Bacchanalian presence who dropped by between narcotic fugues. She was 10 when the realisation dawned that she, Tyler, and the latter's daughter Mia were, in many respects, physically identical. Finally, Buell told her the truth.

Rather than spiral into pre-teen crisis, Tyler immediately adopted her father's name and "just adjusted. You get used to things when you're young." Her relationship with her father has been close ever since - in a detail hovering somewhere between touching and icky, they bonded while giving each other facials at "slumber parties". Is she bored with talking about her parents? "No, not at all. I love them to death. It's just interviews are weird, because there's always going to be stuff I'm never going to talk about in public. Because it's really nobody's business ..."

She lies on the sofa, I sit opposite, notebook in hand. From above, we look like patient and shrink. Yet despite this room, and her early life, Tyler radiates nothing but sheer, beatific calm. While the boys on the net may have a different vocabulary, there is, in truth, a single word for Tyler: "centred".

"These things are all relative to your experience," she says. "If everything is one way and then it all changes, then yeah, you're going to get freaked. But I always had this array of family members, so for me it really wasn't that strange. I mean, my mother's this amazing, free-spirited woman, my dad's my dad, and my grandmother's an etiquette consultant. So that's what was natural to me, to be around all these different ways of life."

Your grandmother's a what? "An etiquette consultant. She owns this place called the Protocol School of Washington. She puts on seminars to teach people about table settings and how to conduct themselves. She's really big on tea."

Maybe the reason people have such a preoccupation with her childhood is that, with its overtones of vintage rock debauchery, it's all so weirdly innocent? So 1970s? Her face falls. "I'm so sad about Joey Ramone." She could, of course, simply be changing the subject - or maybe not. "So sad. I was thinking about it the other day, how that whole period of music was so amazing, and how lucky I was, 'cause I could meet all these people - Bowie and Iggy Pop and Keith Richard and Joey. And there's really not that many people left that I feel that way about."

It seems an oddly fogeyish sentiment for a woman still a month shy of her 24th birthday. Then again, given her accelerated development - modelling at 14, movies two years later - she has, in many ways, got years on her ostensible peer group. Does she feel she missed out her adolescence? "Oh no. It was good for me, because I always had a really hard time at school. Basically, I had a really bad attention deficit. I used to fall asleep all the time in class, and get kicked out. And when I started acting, it gave me a lot of self-esteem, because although most of what I did at school left me confused, it turned out I could really focus on acting. I realised I could memorise lines, not just mine but everyone else's. I finally had some confidence that I was actually good at something."

So where does she go next? Instinctively, she moves for another cigarette. "Life excites me. I'm not talking about appearing in movies or doing interviews, but just little, normal, everyday things. Getting out of bed. Getting dressed. Making food. I find it all exciting, you know?" And she gives another of the stares that have you cursing your own jaded lethargy. "But, really, I think where I'm going next is out of this room."

 One Night at McCool's is released tomorrow.

fields.headline: BMW gives film directors the wheel
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Ang Lee, of Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon fame, is one of five top directors hired by BMW for a new promotion, reports Claire Cozens
Useful link: www.bmwfilms.com
fields.body:
Gone are the days when a good-looking guy expertly tackling a series of hairpin bends in his immaculately shiny vehicle was all it took to sell a car.

Nowadays, car manufacturers have to be a little more inventive if they want the punters to sit up and take notice.

Which is why BMW has hired five of the world's hottest film directors to shoot a series of short films to promote the brand.

Ang Lee (Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon); Guy Ritchie (Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels and Snatch) and Wong Kar-Wai (In the Mood for Love) have been signed up to direct the films, which are being produced by David Fincher, director of Fight Club and Seven.

Madonna will appear in one of the films. Mickey Rourke is also taking part. But the star of the series will be British actor Clive Owen, who appears in all five films as a daredevil driver.

The shorts will be screened on a special BMW website. While BMW cars will feature, the directors have been given full creative control and BMW is stressing that they will be films, not adverts.

BMW is not the first advertiser to use film to promote its brand. Last year Adidas put together a series of documentary-style films entitled The Road to Olympics to promote its sponsorship of the games.

And the trend is likely to increase. As consumers become increasingly media-savvy, advertisers are having to find new, subtler ways of promoting their products.

Useful link
Sign up to see the films at www.bmwfilms.com

webTitle: US threatens to quit talks with China

fields.headline: US threatens to quit talks with China
fields.standfirst:
Special report: China
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The United States yesterday threatened to walk out of sensitive security talks with China after Beijing refused to discuss the return of a US spy plane, potentially sinking bilateral relations into a chill reminiscent of the cold war.
fields.body:
The United States yesterday threatened to walk out of sensitive security talks with China after Beijing refused to discuss the return of a US spy plane, potentially sinking bilateral relations into a chill reminiscent of the cold war.

In an attempt to improve ties frayed by a mid-air collision on April 1, negotiators held two and a half hours of talks in Beijing yesterday, described by the White House as "unproductive". The two sides restated their conflicting accounts of a collision on April 1 between the US EP-3 surveillance plane and a Chinese jet fighter.

The eight US negotiators then restated their demand for the return of the $80m plane which Chinese troops seized and stripped of its electronic equipment after it made an emergency landing on Hainan Island in southern China. But according to US reports, the Chinese delegation refused to discuss the issue and the American negotiators left.

China's official Xinhua news agency said that the talks would continue today but the White House said there were no such plans. Instead, the US ambassador to Beijing, Joseph Prueher, is due to visit the Chinese foreign ministry this morning to deliver an ultimatum: negotiate the EP-3's return or the talks are over.

Pursuing the negotiations "makes no sense from our perspective", a White House official said yesterday.

The US side also wants further discussion of the causes of the collision. Since the release of the 24 US crewmen last week, the Pentagon has been far more assertive in blaming the Chinese pilot, Wang Wei, who was killed in the incident, for "hot-rodding" antics. China insists the EP-3 swerved suddenly into its plane.

US officials yesterday expressed surprise at the Chinese position. The crew destroyed much of the eavesdropping equipment aboard before and just after landing. All that remains on Hainan is the propeller-driven plane's vintage fuselage.

"The issue of the plane is largely one of principal now," said Bryan Bender, a China specialist at the security thinktank, Stratfor. "The Chinese government wants to show the People's Liberation Army it won one."

The Pentagon had expected a more difficult exchange over future "rules of engagement" between US surveillance planes skirting the Chinese coast, and Chinese interceptors. China has demanded an end to the flights, but Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, insisted the US had the legal right to conduct flights in international airspace.

Analysts said yesterday that neither side had a long-term interest in pursuing the confrontation. Ruth Wedgwood, a fellow at the US Council on Foreign Relations, said: "The Chinese would be cutting off their nose to spite their face. They need long-term economic growth."

Before the talks began yesterday, the US made some conciliatory noises, leaking proposals to withold sales of advanced Aegis missile systems to Taiwan.

But Washington continues to pursue Beijing over its human rights record. In Geneva yesterday, the US tabled a UN motion to hold China accountable to the same human rights standards as other countries, but the motion was defeated 23-17 after African nations took China's side.

fields.headline: C5 to get £6m cash boost
fields.trailText:
10.13am: RTL and United Business Media have agreed to pour £6m into the channel's 2001 programming budget, reports Jason Deans.
11.03.2001: C5 alive and confounding the critics

18.01.2001: Channel 5 owners at war
fields.body:
Channel 5 shareholders RTL and United Business Media have agreed a £6m cash injection for the broadcaster's 2001 programming budget.

Dawn Airey, the Channel 5 chief executive, will spend the money on new high-profile reality and entertainment formats.

"The recent success of the Mole and Touch the Truck - plus the high hopes we have for the Jerry Springer-hosted quiz Greed - shows there is an appetite among our viewers for innovative popular programming that we are keen to satisfy," said Ms Airey.

This extra funding comes on top of a £20m increase on Channel 5's 2000 programming budget.

Ms Airey has also received £10m for a film deal with Universal that includes multi-Oscar winner Gladiator, but only after RTL took United to court to force the latter to pay its share.

fields.headline: Human cloning to be outlawed
fields.trailText: The government is drawing up legislation to outlaw human reproductive cloning in an attempt to reassure the public that its plans for fast expansion of genetic technology in the NHS will not breach ethical beliefs.
fields.body:
The government is drawing up legislation to outlaw human reproductive cloning in an attempt to reassure the public that its plans for fast expansion of genetic technology in the NHS will not breach ethical beliefs.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, has instructed parliamentary draftsmen to start work on a bill to ban human cloning. The proposal is likely to be in Labour's election manifesto and will be ready to put through parliament at an early date.

Under present rules, human cloning is prohibited because the human fertilisation and embryology authority refuses to license the practice, but Mr Milburn believes there needs to be a permanent statutory bar. The move will make Britain the first country in the world to ban human cloning.

He will explain the government's thinking in a speech in Newcastle today that gives the green light to spending tens of millions of pounds over the next four years to put Britain at the leading edge of developing genetic technology and expand genetic testing in the NHS.

"Our job is to prepare for changes so we can harness the benefits of genetic advance but avoid the dangers. We need to secure public approval for progress," he will say.

The Department of Health has so far approved only one genetic test, for the rare and fatal Huntington's chorea, but Mr Milburn expects to extend this to testing for a range of cancers.

He will also launch plans for four "genetic knowledge parks" that will bring together researchers, NHS clinicians and pharmaceutical entrepreneurs in the hope of producing ideas for spin-off companies.

Mr Milburn will say the "genetic valleys" should provide a critical mass of ideas in genetics in the same way that Silicon Valley in California was the springboard for advances in information technology. Regions will be asked to bid for the privilege.

As part of his plans he will promise enough extra consultants, medical staff, scientists and counsellors to increase the number of genetic tests within the NHS to more than 100,000 within five years. The number of patients being seen by genetic specialists should increase by 80%.

Mr Milburn will argue that the NHS is well placed to exploit the technology. As a "socialist medical service" treating people on the basis of need, it can encourage patients to be genetically tested without fear that the results may increase the cost.

The NHS would have to change to exploit the potential of genetics. "My job is to prepare for change so we can harness the benefits of genetic advance and avoid the dangers. We need to secure public approval for progress," he will say.

The department is drawing up legislation to outlaw human reproductive cloning to allay public fears about scientists playing god, and Mr Milburn acknowledged the concerns the public might have over genetic research. "We need to deal with public concern about those advances and recognise that public concerns are legitimate. There are boundaries which won't be breached."

Another safeguard will be a moratorium on insurance companies using genetic profiling tests to predict which of their customers were likely to die prematurely or suffer chronic disease.

If, as expected, the human genetics commission recommends a moratorium in a report due next month, the government would back it.

fields.headline: Rural Wales woos back tourists
fields.standfirst: Holiday executives from Europe and Scandinavia see 'business as usual'
fields.trailText: Holiday executives from Europe and Scandinavia see 'business as usual'.
fields.body:
Not a pyre, not a burial pit in sight. But there were plenty of sheep chomping the grass of north Wales yesterday as 13 tourism managers from Europe trundled through the Snowdonia national park on a bus named Georgina.

"I have only been to London before," said Katia Longevale, partner of Claude Perignon, quality manager of Belgium's biggest tourism group. "The nature here is very rough and there are a lot of sheep. We made a little joke that the tourist people had put them there for us."

The implication was that the sheep were stuffed; but then a fat ewe and her triplets moved. They were part of a total Welsh herd which used to be estimated at 10m, but no one is counting now.

Later a cloud of smoke drifted over trees in the Conwy valley near Llanwryst. It looked ominous but could have been innocent.

"I haven't seen any dead sheep and I didn't expect to see any," said Rolf Forsdahl, director of the Norwegian tour company HSH. "It has been exaggerated because of the press and television. The pictures have been repeated time after time. The message I will take back to Norway is 'business as usual'."

In the end, the only obvious evidence the visitors saw of the crisis facing British agriculture was the disinfected straw mat at the entrance to the National Trust's Bodnant Garden, which has 100 magnificent magnolia-filled acres overlooking the Snowdon range.

Jesper Ewald, general manager of FDM Travel in Denmark, wondered why no one had given him the Welsh hard sell before. "It's something special, something unique," he said. "Wales is just three hours away from Copenhagen but Danish people are much less aware of Wales than they are of Scotland and Ireland. You have nature, unspoiled nature. The accent is charming. Most Danes have no problem with English and the accent here is a bonus."

Bodnant Garden, explained tour guide Nia Jones, was begun by a Victorian industrialist who discovered how to make soap white. But neither Ms Jones, nor officials from the British Tourist Authority who had arranged the trip as an antidote to the foot and mouth crisis, was offering any soft soap.

"We want to be as truthful with you as we can," said John Gaudern, manager of BTA's op eration in France. "We have nothing to hide."

At Conwy Castle, where a guano-stained Red Dragon fluttered from a flag pole, the visitors met Neville Hortop, a guide in RAF beret, green anorak and black and white walking stick who, at 77, still leads up to nine tours a day and jumps on litter bins to sell the castle's glory. "Eight towers... 16 bedrooms... that's a lavatory... 1,500 English builders... Eleanor of Aquitaine came here."

The group whizzed on to Plas Mawr, the finest Elizabethan town house in Britain.

Before lunch (fish, no lamb or beef), Klaus Buhring, of a German tour company, had explained that German visitors were cancelling trips to Britain because they could not walk in the countryside they loved.

"The perception is that there are many restrictions on where people can go. Some have the idea that there will not be enough food, especially if they are self-catering."

As the visitors prepared to board a steam-hauled Festiniog Railway carriage to Portmadog, some reflected that foot and mouth was not the only problem affecting tourism to Britain. It was clear to them that the strong pound should be painlessly culled, and probably incinerated to be on the safe side.

fields.headline: McCann named top agency
fields.standfirst:
Top 10 agencies by income
Top 10 agencies by billings
fields.trailText:
10.30am: McCann-Erickson is Britain's highest-earning advertising agency, according to new figures. By Claire Cozens.
Top 10 agencies by income

Top 10 agencies by billings
fields.body:
McCann-Erickson is Britain's highest-earning advertising agency, according to new figures from the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising.

The agency, which counts soap giant Unilever, L'Oreal and Motorola among its clients, recorded an income of £74m last year, making it Britain's top-ranking group by income.

The figures mark the first time the IPA has ranked advertising agencies by income, and they paint a very different picture of the UK advertising industry to that shown by figures the trade body released last year.

Under the previous system, which ranked agencies according to billings - how much their clients spent on advertising - Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO came out as Britain's biggest agency.

McCann-Erickson ranked just ninth.

The IPA has for some time been trying to persuade agencies to release income figures, which it believes give a more accurate picture of their performance.

Other agencies that have done well under the new system include Saatchi & Saatchi, which leaps from seventh place in the billings table to second place in the income rankings, and the TBWA Group, which moves from 12th to fourth place.

Rupert Howell, the outgoing IPA president, made it his mission to change the system when he took on the role in April 1999.

webTitle: Billy Bragg drives in voting wedge

fields.headline: Billy Bragg drives in voting wedge
fields.trailText: His political anthems are synonymous with the Labour movement but age mellows even the hardest political heart - Red Wedge founder Billy Bragg is to vote Liberal Democrat at the next election.
fields.body:
His political anthems are synonymous with the Labour movement but age mellows even the hardest political heart - Red Wedge founder Billy Bragg is to vote Liberal Democrat at the next election.

As the driving force behind the leftwing political pop vehicle that railed against the Thatcher regime of the 1980s, Bragg was cast by Neil Kinnock's Labour party as the key to unlock support among the nation's brooding youth.

But those fearing Bragg has gone politically "soft" need not mourn the loss of a Labour voter. Bragg is now behind a campaign of tactical voting to unseat Tory MPs.

The musician is making the Lib Dem commitment as he launches a "voting valentines" website - www.votedorset.net - designed to pair up Lib Dem and Labour supporters in neighbouring seats who want to vote tactically to oppose Conservative candidates.

Denying that his decision betrayed his leftwing past, Mr Bragg asked: "Was Red Wedge pro-Labour, or did we just hate Tories?" He still wanted to see a second term of a Labour government, he said, adding: "Last time a lot of people voted tactically on a personal basis, and with a little bit of organisation that can increase. Until the voting system is genuinely proportional I don't think you can expect people to just waste their vote."

The Lib Dems were delighted last night, welcoming the songwriter whose best known work proclaimed "I don't want to change the world, I'm not looking for a new England", but who has been consistently outspoken on political matters. Campaign director Lord Rennard said: "We hope many other Labour voters will follow Mr Bragg's example in Lib Dem-Tory marginals."

Mr Bragg, who explains his tactical voting plans in today's New Statesman, is aiming to unseat Oliver Letwin, shadow chief secretary to the Treasury and MP for Dorset West where the singer lives with his family after moving from London several months ago. He also hopes tactical voting could oust Conservative Ian Bruce in adjoining Dorset South, where Labour's Jim Knight came within 77 votes of snatching the seat in 1997.

Mr Letwin, regarded as one his party's key intellects, fended off Lib Dem challenger Robin Legg in the traditionally safe Tory seat with a majority of just 1,840.

The Bragg website, one of several being set up to match up voters around the country who want to vote tactically but are keen that a compensatory vote for their party of choice should be cast elsewhere, will pair by email Labour supporters in Dorset West and Lib Dems in Dorset South.

They will then informally agree to vote for each other's party, though there will be no means of creating a binding commitment since this would break election law.

Another site - tacticalvoter. net - is operating the same vote trading concept on a national scale.

fields.headline: Phillips may sue newspaper
fields.trailText:
9.30am: GMTV presenter Fiona Phillips is considering suing the Sunday People over allegations she took cash for on-air plugs. By Julia Day.

18.04.2001: Phillips cleared of plugging charities for cash
fields.body:
The GMTV presenter, Fiona Phillips, and her agent, Nicola Ibison, are considering suing the Sunday People over allegations that Phillips took cash for on-air plugs.

The "Sofagate" stories, which ran in the newspaper in January, alleged that Phillips was paid to plug charities on the morning TV programme.

The reports caused the Independent Television Commission to investigate whether Phillips had breached its Programme Code.

But this week the ITC cleared Phillips of any wrongdoing.

"Both Fiona and I are pleased with the ITC report but are entirely unsurprised by its findings as we knew we had done nothing wrong," said Ms Ibison.

"The lawyers are all over it and it is highly likely that there will be a legal development now, but I am unable to say anything more."

The lawyers involved are operating on behalf of Phillips and Ms Ibison, rather than for GMTV.

"We are delighted with the outcome {of the ITC report," said a GMTV spokesman.

"GMTV and Fiona Phillips has been completely vindicated in this matter"

webTitle: Greenspan is too late to save the pain

fields.headline: Greenspan is too late to save the pain
fields.trailText: Commentary, Larry Elliott: The reaction of Wall Street to yesterday's half-point cut in US interest rates suggests that there are still plenty of believers in the myth of Greenspan's infallibility
fields.body:
This time last year Alan Greenspan could do no wrong. With US investors basking in the warm glow of a stock market close to record levels, the chairman of the Federal Reserve was hailed as the genius responsible for the longest period of economic expansion in America's history. Faith in Greenspan was complete.

The reaction of Wall Street to yesterday's half-point cut in US interest rates suggests that there are still plenty of believers in the myth of Greenspan's infallibility. Share prices went through the roof in the expectation that the Fed was taking the decisive action necessary to prevent the American economy suffering a full-blown recession.

But in reality, times have changed. Where once it seemed that Greenspan was omnipotent and omniscient, he is now fighting to regain control of an almost impossibly-difficult situation. More than that, he is trying to save his reputation as the man who transformed the US from basket case to miracle economy in little more than a decade.

In a sense, Greenspan is a victim of the hype about the "new paradigm" in the US, which was shorthand for saying that the old rules of economics no longer applied to the wired generation. The longer the expansion went on, the more exalted became Greenspan's status. So when interest rates were cut in response to the Russian debt crisis in the autumn of 1998, it was assumed that Greenspan was fully in control of events. Unfortunately, he was not. The Fed allowed the US bubble to inflate during 1999, keeping interest rates lower than they should have been in the misguided belief that the Millennium bug posed a real threat.

Caught up in the euphoria, US companies invested too much and US consumers lived beyond their means.

When interest rates were belatedly raised it became clear that the American corporate sector was suffering from over-capacity and falling profitability. The distress signals from companies prompted yesterday's move.

But it is unlikely to be enough. After its binge, America needs a period of belt-tightening. The strength of the dollar and the resiliance of consumer spending suggests that the reckoning may be delayed. But whatever Greenspan does, it will not be postponed indefinitely.

fields.headline: NFU 'ignoring' small farmers
fields.standfirst:
Vaccine stance 'dictated by agribusiness'

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Farmers in favour of a vaccination programme to fight the spread of foot and mouth believe that the National Farmers Union no longer represents their views.
fields.body:
Farmers in favour of a vaccination programme to fight the spread of foot and mouth believe that the National Farmers Union no longer represents their views, and yesterday accused it of being a mouthpiece for agribusiness.

In an increasingly fraught atmosphere, the NFU leader, Ben Gill, admitted he was under enormous "pressure" from the government to accept a vaccination programme. He refused to give ground, however, saying the union was still not satisfied that the government had answered all its doubts on vaccination.

The toll of animals to be destroyed continues to rise, with more than 2m condemned and 1,381 outbreaks. There are still more than 20 new cases a day, compared with 30 a week ago.

In Cumbria, where most outbreaks are still occurring and vaccination teams are standing by should the NFU change tack, the view that the slaughter must stop is gaining support.

Mike Downham, who farms 10 miles from the centre of the outbreak at Longtown, said: "There is no doubt this culling out of farms represents armageddon for this county. It has been obvious for the last month that farming opinion has swung behind vaccination."

He had his 20 pigs and 200 sheep culled to try to save pedigree cattle. "I would rather have them vaccinated to keep them alive and argue about any compensation for loss of sales or other unforseen consequences afterwards."

Mr Downham, a member of the NFU and the Soil Association, because he is switching to organic farming, said he had received 10 briefings from the Soil Association but nothing from the NFU. "They have not canvassed opinion. In my view, people who want to continue farming want to save their stock by vaccination; those who want to retire or get out want a generous compensation cheque."

A neighbour, Andrew Tompkins, who defected from the NFU, which cost him £300 a year, to the National Sheep Association, which has subscription of £10, said: "The NFU has been irritating the hell out of me. They put forward the views of the 20% of big farmers who get 80% of the subsidies, not family farms under 200 acres which form the majority in Cumbria.

"They are 10 to 20 years be hind the times, clinging on to the past subsidy regime and obstructing change." He is trying to keep 200 beef cattle alive and favours vaccination.

In Monmouthshire, David Maddocks, once county chairman of the NFU, who resigned because he felt it no longer represented small farmers, said: "The government and the NFU have always told us there is no alternative to slaughter, but that has not worked.

"Now the government has changed its mind, but the NFU has not. One has to ask who the NFU represent; they certainly do not look after the small farmer in Monmouthshire.

"Round here we have believed for some time that all this killing is outrageous, and we have favoured vaccination, but we have been subject to scare tactics and told it would not work."

But Karen Dent disagreed. She has seen her pigs culled in an attempt to contain outbreaks near Penrith, and still has 570 dairy cows. "Milk companies screw prices down, and down as it is I fear we would never be able to sell milk from vaccinated cows. There will be a stigma attached.

"I fear we would never be allowed to restock our pigs because our cows were vaccinated. I support the NFU... I believe they speak for the majority."

The NFU has rivals for farmer membership, including the Country Land and Business Association (CLA) and the National Pig Association. The NPA is against vaccination. But the CLA believes that if scientific advice, "as opposed to political expediency", favours it, it would not object on behalf of 40,000 members, many of whom were in favour.

Jim Scudamore, the chief vet, who was originally against vaccination, was wheeled out by Downing Street to give a briefing yesterday for the first time for four weeks. He thought a regional vaccination programme would help to eradicate the disease.

"Vaccination was ruled out [at first] because we had a clear stamping-out policy." But "in certain circumstances" it could protect animals, "dampen down" the disease and reduce the number of carcasses.

The NFU said there were around 100,000 farm businesses, and it had 60,000 members. There were a lot more small farmers than large ones. There were perhaps only 2,000 farmers with 1,000 acres. The typical NFU member had around 150 acres.

fields.headline: Drug price wars
fields.standfirst: Helping the poor will help the industry
fields.trailText: The biggest of the 39 international pharmaceutical companies trying to prevent the South African government from importing cheaper drugs to fight HIV/Aids and other diseases, privately confessed that it was sorry it had brought the law suit.
fields.body:
Last month the biggest of the 39 international pharmaceutical companies trying to prevent the South African government from importing cheaper generic drugs to fight HIV/Aids and other diseases, privately confessed to our health correspondent that it was sorry it had brought the law suit. Today, when the South African high court reconvenes after a six-week adjournment, GlaxoSmithKline (along with the other 38 companies in the suit) have an opportunity to begin repairing the damage they have wreaked in South Africa. The controversial case was adjourned by the judge to give the drug giants time to answer detailed and highly embarrassing questions on the industry's pricing policies. Here is an opportunity for the drug bosses to help the developing world - and themselves. If they withdrew from the suit today, they could signal their support for cheaper drugs for developing states - and save the notoriously secretive industry from divulging sensitive commercial information.

Rarely in the history of commerce has there been such a badly misjudged law suit. Even the industry now recognises what a PR disaster it has been. On the opening day of the civil trial there were protests and demonstrations against the drug companies round the world. Even before then, a succession of powerful international institutions had signalled their support for South Africa: the UN, World Health Organisation and the European Union. True, Tony Blair in a shameful and pusillanimous move sided with the drug giants three weeks ago, but GW Bush showed far more spunk than either Blair or Clinton. Initially, the US placed South Africa on its "watch list" of patent pirates, but Clinton relented and removed them. GW has gone much further. Even though the drug industry was one of his biggest backers, Mr Bush signalled he was not opposed to the new South African law that the drug companies are resisting.

The trial began with the drug industry arguing that "the case is nothing to do with blocking access to medicines, or price fixing. It's about patents. Patents do not block medicines. They stimulate research and development." Developments since that bold assertion have shown just how wrong it was. To select just one. Protests by students and academic staff at Yale, where a key ingredient of two Aids drugs sold by Bristol-Myers Squibb was invented (and earned the university $40m a year in royalties), prompted the company to drop its price from $20 to $2 for a daily dose. Better still, the company dropped its patent protection rights in South Africa. If Bristol-Myers can do this, why can the other 38 not follow? As the company noted: "This is not about profits and patents it's about poverty and a devastating disease."

We do not suggest cheaper drugs - or even free drugs - would solve the African HIV/Aids dilemma. Public health campaigns are much more complicated than that. As well as new clinics and staff, they need epidemiological surveillance, community education, training and distribution chains. But Africa faces a crisis. Cheaper drugs would be an enormous help as Brazil has demonstrated. There are 4.7m people infected in South Africa and 25m in sub-Saharan Africa. Drug prices have belatedly been cut and new partnerships begun. The long-term solution is a vaccine, which new international bodies are pursuing. Meanwhile, in the short-term, an industry which rightly sees the need to improve its image, has to demonstrate it is not just shareholder driven but recognises the public interest too.

Today, when the South African high court reconvenes after a six-week adjournment, GlaxoSmithKline (along with the other 38 companies in the suit) have an opportunity to begin repairing the damage they have wreaked in South Africa. The controversial case was adjourned by the judge to give the drug giants time to answer detailed and highly embarrassing questions on the industry's pricing policies. Here is an opportunity for the drug bosses to help the developing world - and themselves. If they withdrew from the suit today, they could signal their support for cheaper drugs for developing states - and save the notoriously secretive industry from divulging sensitive commercial information. Rarely in the history of commerce has there been such a badly misjudged law suit. Even the industry now recognises what a PR disaster it has been. On the opening day of the civil trial there were protests and demonstrations against the drug companies round the world. Even before then, a succession of powerful international institutions had signalled their support for South Africa: the UN, World Health Organisation and the European Union. True, Tony Blair in a shameful and pusillanimous move sided with the drug giants three weeks ago, but GW Bush showed far more spunk than either Blair or Clinton. Meanwhile, in the short-term, an industry which rightly sees the need to improve its image, has to demonstrate it is not just shareholder driven but recognises the public interest too.

webTitle: Analysis: European Right mute on job losses

fields.headline: Redundant, moi?
fields.standfirst: Centre-left governments in London, Paris and Berlin may have a muddled response to job losses but the right is totally tongue-tied
fields.trailText: Centre-left governments in London, Paris and Berlin may have a muddled response to job losses but the right is totally tongue-tied.
fields.body:
One day soon chances are that Gordon Brown will have to announce that the decline in unemployment since the mid-1990s has stopped and gone into reverse. If the US economy continues to falter and Japan fades as growth projections for the euro-zone tumble, wage earners will be hurt.

But joblessness is not part of the third way script, which is all economic benignity and worker-employer accord. As jobs are lost, neither the Blairites nor the centre-left governments of Paris and Berlin are likely to have a coherent response.

That much has become clear in France. On Tuesday Prime Minister Lionel Jospin dramatically went on television to damp down smouldering discontent about his leadership since the left lost unexpectedly in the March municipal elections. Everything is now bound up with the challenge to Jacques Chirac for the presidency next year. What the French public wants is a positive response to a recent spate of headlines about job losses, symbolised by the summary closure of Marks & Spencer. Unemployment among under 25s is still 16%. The chart shows long-term unemployment for the most recent year for which comparable figures exist; it has since gone down but remains a problem.

The French left does not lack a political vocabulary with which to respond. I believe in the public service, Mr Jospin told viewers. Look at what has happened to the railways in the UK and electricity in California: we are going to avoid that.

But Anglo-Saxon capitalism is not the only culprit. Philips, cutting 7,000 jobs, is a Dutch firm forced to rationalise production because the mobile phone market is saturated. Its factory in Le Mans will be a casualty of demand. Strikes to ward off redundancies at Air Liberté and Air Littoral - French-owned - will not win more travellers. Danone, also French, is cutting jobs in its biscuit division to concentrate on other food lines. All of that could sound like "normal" operations; Joseph Schumpeter called it capitalism's creative destructiveness.

Mr Jospin has talked about increasing the cost of lay-offs to employers and hinted at increasing the minimum wage, due to be revised in June. The logic of profit should not roll out at the expense of employment, he said. In terms of practical policies, however, the left response turns out to be upping civil servants' salaries, along with social welfare measures on housing and support in old age and subsidies to help small companies adjust to the compulsory 35-hour week. Public spending will rise as a result, pushing France close to the the Brussels' stability pact limit.

The picture is not all gloomy. French unemployment reached a 10-year low in January at 9% and job creation is set to continue this year, though only 15% of the likely 250,000-300,000 new jobs can be attributed to the government's special measures. Mr Jospin's supporters say that taken together his policies do represent a "traditional left" response, which should be contrasted with Tony Blair or Gerhard Schröder. But critics say the radicalism of Mr Jospin's words conceal the "immobility of his actions".

For the Jospin coalition of socialists, communists and greens is going to be no more able to arrest the economic cycle than the ideologically pallid Blair government. This week the Bank of France projected growth in French GDP this year at between 2.6% and 2.9%, down from the 3.3% plus achieved last year. Economists hope for a recovery to 3% in 2002 - which could well mean aggregate improvement in jobs. Schumpeter again. If France is, as some say, the most dynamic of Europe's leading economies, the government will have to take the rough with the smooth.

In Germany, Chancellor Schröder recently blotted his copybook with the left when he said unemployment pay should be tightened in order to get more people into the available jobs. "There is no right to idleness in our society. Someone who is able to work but doesn't want to cannot rely on other people's solidarity." Such sentiments, unexceptionable in Blairite Britain, caused a storm among the Social Democrats, who share federal power with the Greens.

Mr Schröder has tied his political fortunes to the promise to cut unemployment below 3.5m. It now stands at 3.8m or just over 9% of the labour force. Part of the effort will be undertaken by the labour ministry which is working on legislation to force local job centres to cut or freeze benefits to unemployed people who turn down job offers or fail to seek further qualifications.

German growth projections have had to be cut in response to the American downturn. Fingers have been burnt by the collapse of hi-tech stocks; the chart shows that many Germans have recently become shareholders. German GDP is predicted to rise by 2.1% this year, down from last year's 2.7%. Lower growth will cut tax revenues, pushing public finances into the red; the Germans may be reprimanded when EU finance ministers meet next month.

Despite all that, the centre-left in Germany - as in France and the UK - possesses a signal political advantage. The state of the right. Though the Christian Democrats did reasonably well in elections in Hesse and Baden-Württemberg, and the French right did creditably in mayoral races, in neither country are they convincing the public that they are an alternative to social democracy. As in the UK, conservatives are as tongue-tied as the left when it comes to explaining and justifying the ups and downs of employment.

webTitle: Aids charity has drug makers on the run

fields.headline: Aids charity has drug makers on the run
fields.standfirst: Climax near in South African case for cheaper medicines
fields.trailText: The world's big drug companies return to court in Pretoria today knowing that they have lost the first round of their battle to defend their profits at the expense of lives in the developing world.
fields.body:
The world's big drug companies return to court in Pretoria today knowing that they have lost the first round of their battle to defend their profits at the expense of lives in the developing world.

Last night some of them were scrambling to negotiate a settlement after being cowed not by the South African government but by a small militant aids rights group, the Treatment Action Campaign (TAC).

The companies went to court to challenge a South African law allowing the government to produce or import generic versions of patented drugs in certain circumstances. But the companies' case has been coming apart ever since they arrived in court.

A series of rulings by the judge questioned their right even to pursue the action. There has also been a barrage of international criticism about the moral and legal basis of the case.

They may come to regret bringing the case, not only because of the damage to their industry's reputation but also because it may result in the severe weakening of the patent rights they are trying to protect.

The court adjourned the trial six weeks ago after letting TAC make a submission which threatened to force the companies to reveal long-held secrets about their business practices.

Initially, neither of the other parties wanted TAC in court with them. But the government came to realise that it had a valuable if unconventional ally.

TAC is led by Zackie Achmat, a charismatic homosexual of 38 who attends court wearing a T-shirt with the slogan "I am HIV Positive".

He does not know when he contracted the virus. Perhaps it was during one of his stints in prison agitating against apartheid; by his own description, he had a vigorous sex life there. Or he may have picked it up as a male prostitute.

Either way, he refuses to take anti-retroviral drugs while they are not readily available to the rest of South Africa's people.

"Those of us who are privileged enough to have access to health care should use it to ensure that everyone gets treatment," he has said.

TAC was born a little more than two years ago in protest at the government's Aids policies. A number of hospitals, including the largest biggest in the southern hemisphere, Chris Hani Baragwanath hospital in Soweto, were giving anti-Aids drugs to HIV-positive pregnant women to reduce the number of children born with the virus.

For political reasons, mainly because President Thabo Mbeki's government refused to acknowledge the link between HIV and Aids, the programme was dressed up as research, but the drugs were available to all in the designated hospitals. Then the health department put a stop to the programme.

"That led to a lot of anger and was a direct reason for the formation of TAC," said Mr Achmat, who was head of the Gay and Lesbian Coalition at the time.

"But at the same time we realised that while we always condemned the government, the non-governmental organisations were spending millions of rands in Aids prevention, and it was equally limited.

"So we looked at where all this money was going, and we realised it was to the drug companies. We launched a campaign that would bring in everybody - the churches, the unions - to change the whole approach."

TAC was a driving force behind the legislation now being challenged in the high court. It publicised the drug companies' tactics, and found like minds in the South African department of health. But the government was divided.

Some officials opposed the legislation permitting the import of generic and other cheaper drugs, fearing that it would harm the confidence of investors, particularly after the US put South Africa on a "watch list" of patent pirates.

TAC's greatest victory may come in the next few days. Before the adjournment, the judge let it make a comprehensive submission as a friend of the court. When the drug companies insisted on time to prepare a response, Judge Bernard Ngoepe called their bluff. Fine, he said, but they must respond to TAC's submission point by point; any they failed to address would be taken as proved.

TAC's submission includes detailed affidavits challenging the drug companies' claim that medicines are priced to reflect the costs of research. TAC argued that the research and development bills for all five of the main anti-Aids drugs were met by American universities or the US National Institutes for Health, not the pharmaceutical producers.

"AZT was discovered 30 years before, at the Michigan Cancer Institute," Mr Achmat said.

"It was a cancer drug and the institute did all the initial research. It's the same with STC. The cancer institute met the major costs of discovery but Glaxo claims it is recovering costs. It's the same with all of them."

The companies answered this claim with their own figures. TAC's scientists argue that those numbers include a lot of spending not directly attached to the discoveries, such as marketing costs.

The TAC submission also alleges that the companies have engaged in price fixing and argues that in South Africa the constitutional right to health has greater legal weight than the constitutional right to protection of patents.

The companies have already submitted their response to the judge.

But they do not reveal the details of research funding, the profitability of individual drugs and other issues required by the court. Instead, they revive their previous argument that the new law is unconstitutional because it gives cabinet ministers too much power to decide what constitutes an "unaffordable" drug.

They also say that the government turned down an offer of cheaper medicines which would have obviated the need for generic imports.

TAC hopes the judge will focus on the companies' failure to comply fully with his order and deliver the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers' Association another legal blow.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: New Labour leaves the obsession with cute news management behind to concentrate on the substance and, with the election close, this includes a dialogue with union members.
fields.body:
 Standing on the threshold of that "historic" second term, New Labour leaves the obsession with cute news management behind to concentrate on the substance and, with the election close, this includes a dialogue with union members. So Nita Clark of the Downing Street political unit recently contacted in-house hacks on trade union journals to offer an interview with Mr Tony.

Amazed at their luck, all accepted and Nita instructed them to email her their questions for Mr T. This they did, and soon received back some almost self-parodically (almost: this is New Labour) on-message replies, presumably written either by chimps on work experience or Downing Street press officers. Only a few days later did the full cunning brilliance of the scheme emerge, when Nita invited each of them to present themselves at an undisclosed London venue with a notebook and pencil, so they could be lined up and snapped - production-line style - enjoying a searching, face-to-face chat with Mr Tony himself. Marvellous form.

 This week the Fabians published The End of Foreign Policy, a booklet with a preface observing that "defining trends is always risky, especially for a foreign office minister". Days after handing in the manuscript, Turncoat contender Peter Hain was shoved out of the FO into the tedious backwater of energy. "For a foreign minister (sic) to contemplate 'The End of Foreign Policy'," he wrote, "may seem like inviting redundancy." Well, yes.

 The Letter of the Day is from the Times. "Sir, how strange!" begins Milton Pratt. "Walkers Smoky Bacon Crisps are, according to the packet, suitable for vegetarians." My colleague Marina Hyde calls Milton in Swansea to say that some things transcend the usual bitter commercial rivalry, and this letter is one of them. Has he ever considered contributing to the Top Tips column in Viz? Milton says not, although he is intrigued at the sound of it. "But it's rather difficult with my commitment to the Times." Of course.

 Also enjoying a triumph in the Thunderer is leader writer Tim Hames, who contributes another of his promising fifth form essays to the paper. "The intervention from Colin Powell demanding a pull back of Israeli forces," writes the Israeli/Palestinian expert, "will force short-term domestic political and tactical complications for Mr Sharon, but the strategy will remain the same." Hence the Israeli withdrawal long before this edition went to bed (and how nice of his news desk to leave him buried in it). "Pieces are occasionally overtaken by events, you'll find," explains Tim when Marina calls for her chat. OK, but will you be carrying on there after the O-level? "I don't understand," he splutters. Well, we were under the impression you're writing for the Times as some sort of school project. "Then maybe we see things very differently," says Tim, and is gone.

 News that Tory 1922 chairman Archie Hamilton, arguably the most underrated political intellect of his era, leaves the Commons at the election saddens us. In the past we came close to arranging tests for Sir Archie, once against a talking chimp, so we ring his agent Stephen Owen, to say how awful it would be if one of his standing went without a fitting tribute. Would now, we wonder, be the time to stage his intelligence test challenge against a Mynah bird? "Are you serious?" Yes. We have such a bird on standby. "Look, I don't think it's Archie's cup of tea. We are Conservatives, you see. We have certain proprieties." Proprieties? We didn't beat the Hun with proprieties. And Archie a former guardsman. Good riddance.

 Jonathan Holborow to the Diary, please, Holborow to the Diary. We wish to hear how you and Oswald the white cotton hankie are doing in your joint advisory role at the Express, but no one there has a phone number for you. Call today, reversing charges if necessary.
