webTitle: Comment: Red Ken the Compromise Kid

fields.headline: Not so much Red Ken as the Compromise Kid
fields.standfirst: London's mayor is more New Labour than New Labour itself
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone is the dog that did not bite, barely barking during his first year as mayor of London
fields.body:
The spin doctors have been hired, lobbyists put on the payroll and giant posters of his face plastered across billboards to rally support and remind people why they voted for him in the first place. Transport and law and order are among his key policies, including a significant increase in police numbers and possibly the return of a school-based police cadet force. He preaches the value of working with business leaders and pursues "big tent" politics, discarding old left-right divides to seek consensus where possible.

The best of the private sector, on salaries the public sector can barely afford, have been hired to inject expertise and dynamism into ailing bodies while a prominent union leader was urged to call off a strike to avoid inconveniencing the public. He bows his head at meetings of the Queen and enjoyed cracking a joke with the Queen Mother. And yesterday, after a meeting with senior police officers, he rallied behind the boys and girls in blue and issued a strong condemnation of the planned May Day protests in London. All very New Labour.

Ken Livingstone is the dog that did not bite, barely barking during his first year as mayor of London. Even the tabloids rarely call him "Red Ken" these days. The Mr Livingstone currently presiding in the Greater London Authority's Romney House HQ is a very different beast to the Mr Livingstone of the Greater London Council and County Hall fame.

Perhaps power has brought its own responsibility, leaving Livingstone a prisoner of a political system that has prevented him making much difference to the lives of Londoners, squeezed by the Treasury and Whitehall from above while below the borough councils jealously defend their turf. The approach of the first anniversary of Livingstone's election on May 4 risks leaving Tony Blair's warning that a Livingstone victory would spell "disaster for London" sounding increasingly hysterical. Trafalgar Square's last licensed seller of pigeon seed has gone and Major General Sir Henry Havelock and General Sir Charles Napier are threatened with expulsion, but the removal from a piazza of birds and a couple of statues is hardly a record to crow about.

Livingstone has made most running on London Underground, opposing (with public support) John Prescott's plans to part-privatise the network in favour of a modernisation scheme that would use private funds to modernise a publicly owned network. Yet even here Livingstone has shown signs of New Labour largesse, appointing as transport commissioner Bob Kiley, a former senior CIA officer before he ran the New York subway, paying his recruit up to £500,000 a year and buying him a £2.1m house .

The mayor appeared to veer left by publicly refusing to condemn tube strikers earlier this year and proclaiming he might even join them on the picket line, but officials in the Aslef drivers' union report he was privately urging its general secretary to call off the stoppage.

The stand-off over the tube is the one area where there is real conflict with the government, Livingstone yesterday announcing another advertising campaign to highlight safety fears ahead of his threatened legal challenge. But privately Livingstone has disclosed that he is keen to compromise and anxious to avoid a showdown, telling a meeting with MPs in Labour's leftwing campaign group last month that a resolution would be the best solution. The mayor, who conceded that his lawyers had warned he could lose any court action, told the surprised MPs he had spoken to Blair's Downing Street "gatekeeper" Anji Hunter and held discussions with Prescott.

Yesterday's denunciation of May 1's monopoly board protesters, threatening to wreck shops and offices of the streets on capitalism's most famous board game, is also a change of tack in office. Livingstone was accused last year of encouraging riots. Mr Livingstone rejected the allegations and later branded the demonstra tors as "mindless thugs". In office, however, his uncompromising position - endorsing the police's "zero tolerance" response and urging protesters to stay away - was unequivocal. Then there are the speeches in the City, praising the value of the financial institutions to the capital, and arguing forcefully that Britain must join the single currency. And eyebrows were raised when Lord Rogers was appointed at £1,625 a day to advise on architectural matters.

The billboards of Livingstone peering at voters were devised under a £20m two-year campaign to win public support for congestion charges. With New Labour, lobbyists are never far away. Livingstone is paying Fishburn Hedges an estimated £100,000 a month for advice.

At the Westminster meeting with his old campaign group comrades, at least one disgruntled leftwing MP suggested that Livingstone was seeking an accommodation rather than confrontation with the government in the hope that a new-found respectability would pave the way for his return to the Labour party. Not so, said the mayor. That was up to Blair. For him, the priority was a second term as mayor. Whether it was as an independent or Labour candidate mattered less.

His performance so far, however, supporting the police and promoting business, is hardly likely to harm the prospect of an invitation. To some Livingstone will have been a disappointment; to others a relief.

Livingstone used to boast that he was a parent of New Labour, pioneering modern campaign techniques such as posters and concerts in his battle with Margaret Thatcher during the 1980s over abolition of the GLC. Others on the Labour left claim he was always New Labour in methods if not policies - singlemindedly promoting the Livingstone brand above the party, continually seeking alliances to advance himself and, according to former allies, prepared to dump supporters who have outlived their usefulness.

In many respects Blair failed to appreciate that Livingstone the politician, like himself, above all else would want to be re-elected. Derision has been repeatedly heaped on Blair for using public funds to produce an annual report applauding the government's efforts and lauding its achievements. Livingstone is now proposing to send out his own glossy document to London's 2.75m homes this summer, detailing his achievements during his first year in office.

The mayor is legally obliged to distribute a performance report so critics, particularly those inside the Labour party, quip that he should send out postcards. But Livingstone favours a £940,000 version including an interview of the mayor by actress Helen Mirren with his comments interspaced with pictures of Ali G and Jack Dee, who will declare why they love London. So very New Labour.

fields.headline: Inside the conspiracy
fields.standfirst: Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: By a neat symmetry the crisis in the Tory leadership, inaugurated by Sir Anthony Meyer's stalking horse campaign in 1989, has now lasted as long as the Thatcher premiership: eleven and a half years.
fields.body:
By a neat symmetry the crisis in the Tory leadership, inaugurated by Sir Anthony Meyer's stalking horse campaign in 1989, has now lasted as long as the Thatcher premiership: eleven and a half years. For much of that period it was the excluded "right" which challenged and then squabbled among themselves. Now, it appears, it is the alienated left which causes trouble. But here again what is striking is the internal enmity. There is now a split on the left.

The question of what Kenneth Clarke said or didn't say to John Stevens, founder and proprietor of the Pro-Euro Conservative party, is the story of a clique within a claque of a party. As main-stream Tories grow Taleban-like in their fundamentalism, conspiracies gain a natural appeal. Plots and rumours of plots have a natural charm for the dispossessed.

Mr Stevens is clever, principled and justifiably cross. Only a party of unappealing and very stupid Old Believers would have deprived him of his Thames Valley Euro-parliamentary seat. By openly speculating on a Portillo-Clarke- Patten axis he shows a sense of timing as the pre-general election period bores. How decadently passive our mass democracy has become. How easily the story is launched by the lunch with the commentator and the word in the lobby journalist's ear.

The initial version was that a number of ex-Euro Conservative candidates would stand in key marginals as spoiling independents. Malcolm Rifkind, seeking to regain Edinburgh Pentlands, was mentioned as particularly vulnerable. Next it became a question of re-alignment, of social liberals and sensibly tolerant Euro-sceptics joining forces to get rid of Haguery. It is all nonsense but it has achieved its main purpose - the embarrassment of Mr Clarke and the forces of respectable Europeanism.

They have always believed in waiting on events. That is why they irritate Mr Stevens so. He, after all, is the man who went out on a limb, left his party, spent money and campaigned for what other Tories said they believed in. Clarke and Heseltine, he thinks, encouraged his campaign in private and then withdrew when the moment of decision came during the Euro-parliamentary elections in 1999. They waited for an implosion which failed to arrive. Now, they wait for a referendum and promise that that will be the moment for the unfolding of political colours. But what, as Mr Stevens points out, if the Blair-Major policy of infinite postponement continues in all its power of equivocation. Won't they then be left looking foolish, the moment of declaration passed and never to return, the central belief of their political careers left undefended as they retreat to the boardroom?

The problem with Tory Europeans is that they were an established church for so long with all the laziness which goes with that. Holding what were effectively sinecures of ministerial office from 1979 onwards they were rarely tempted by resignation. And so they were easily sidelined and parodied as patrician toffs - a cruelly effective bit of Tebbit populism.

The Stevens conspiracy also recalls the meaninglessness of the labels used in the eccentric Conservative milieu. It takes a pretty odd definition of "left" to allow the word to be applied to Geoffrey Howe, architect of mass and unnecessary unemployment from 1979 to 1982, to Michael Heseltine, crudely inflammatory rhetorician against municipal socialism, and even to Kenneth Clarke, erstwhile hammer of the nurses. John Stevens's criticism of William Hague in domestic and social policy is that he has not been "rightwing" enough. The leader of the Euro-Tories harks back to an older time when Europe was "right", when Nicholas Ridley was ardently European, when Europe was presented as an external solution to Britain's refusal to be a properly capitalist country.

That failure to present a wider political picture of Europe as opposed to one which is "open for business" explains the current Euro-Tory collapse. Complacency lies behind the fantasy that the leadership could be fixed for Portillo by the endorsement of a few tired Olympians. By his own estimation, Clarke reckons that no more than 15 Tory MPs share his views. It may be fewer after June. He has always been detached from his own party in parliament. Now, he has more reason than ever for a genial yet increasingly sardonic withdrawal where he will be as remote as ever from the brave but isolated Stevens.

webTitle: Hugo Young: William Hague under fire

fields.headline: Hague: the endgame
fields.standfirst:
An atmosphere of intrigue gathers over the hapless William Hague's head as his enemies make plans

Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: An atmosphere of intrigue gathers over the hapless William Hague's head as his enemies make plans.
fields.body:
The Tory party has a leader, but it's out of his control. Six weeks short of an election, it can be seen careering into the far blue yonder. This is what desperation does to a party at all levels. The members are starting to say and do what they please. The Dagenham leaflet, charging the government with "importing foreign nurses with HIV", may be the first of many. We know that, because the party chairman, Michael Ancram, fears as much. He felt it necessary to send a memo cautioning every Conservative candidate against the use of "language likely to generate racial or religious hatred". An extraordinary thing for a British party boss to have to say. He seemed to understand what was coming.

It began, sure enough, with William Hague. Hague's Harrogate philippic against the foreign land that Britain had become excited his extremists. They saw their prejudices legitimised. He gave them a green light. But now he can't hold them back. They do not respect him. Crazed by the certainty of defeat, more Tories will start to believe that they can say anything. There are people like them at party headquarters. There the attack dogs want no truck with the manifesto that Hague has apparently tried to write, and look instead for wheezes to fire up xenophobia, especially against asylum seekers, or tickle the loathing their people have for Tony Blair. This is a party for which the medicinal balm of Lady Thatcher, now summoned to the bedside, seems unlikely to be the right prescription.

Rumours of a post-election alliance between Michael Portillo and Kenneth Clarke should be seen in this context. They did not need to be put about by the principals or close allies, and I do not think that they were. They're another product of the general desperation. Freed from the burden of victory, politicos think of little but the consequences of defeat. They always talk about it. We journalists collect it from the ether. A Portillo-Clarke alliance? Dream ticket back from the abyss! A link between the old left and old right. Could there be a heavier retort to the pipsqueak dogmatists about to lead the party to another huge defeat?

Actually, the scenario makes no sense. It's hard to believe it will ever come to pass. If it did, it would not meet the case. It's the wrong answer to the wrong question.

The deal, in theory, would be this. Portillo would contest the post-Hague leadership, strengthened by Clarke's support which had been bought with certain assurances, chief among them the promise that pro-euro Tories could campaign on that side of a referendum argument. There would be a new freedom of dissent, and Clarkeites would be able to exercise theirs from seats in the shadow cabinet. While retaining his hostility to the euro, Portillo would abandon the rest of the anti-EU baggage assembled by Hague, including the proposed referendum on the Nice treaty.

This is the minimum Clarke could live with and, if it happened, might start British conservatism on the path to the real world. But who could rely on it being delivered? Any secret arrangement would be vulnerable to Portillo betraying it. Yet a public compact would not survive the meltdown fury of the majority in the party - and for a reason not entirely lacking in pragmatism. For the euro-referendum will constitute the one early hope the Tories have of restoring their electoral fortunes. Whoever is leading them will know that a No victory offers the best chance of transforming the power relationship between the parties in a 2005 election. If the party leadership can't unite around that proposition, the leader will have to argue, anyone who breaks ranks is declaring against conservatism's last best hope of gaining some purchase on 21st-century politics.

Being sucked into that would surely not be attractive to the Tory left. Apart from giving too much credit to Portillo's own flexibility, it turns a blindly optimistic eye to the true state of anti-Europe feeling in the party. This has reached an extremity that any leader is likely to find irreversible for many years. Having surrendered all influence over the selection of parliamentary candidates, the left will find itself, whatever the scale of the election defeat, up against a wall of Europhobic MPs for whom every aspect of Europe has become a non-negotiable crusade.

Two strategies, in particular, are gaining ground. The first is for rejection of a Yes result in the referendum, and an unending struggle to repudiate it right up to the moment when notes and coins are changed into euros. Since that moment is unlikely to be reached until after a further election, such a tactic has the power to continue dividing the party for years ahead, as well as compromising an optimal hand-over in the markets. Second, whether before or beyond the euro, Tory ultras are looking for two more referendums, through which to realign the entire British membership of the EU: one to fortify a radically separatist negotiating position, the other to approve what the negotiators come back with, thereby hoping to blackmail the continentals on the other side of the table.

Such a ploy is transparent. Under cover of pseudo-moderation, it's the prelude to legitimising an exit from the EU if the British do not get what they want. That's what some in the shadow cabinet are secretly happy to contemplate. Such is the uncontrolled ferocity of opinion in the party - the righteous theological dogmatism into which a once rational political organisation has allowed itself to be seduced - that I would not risk a penny on the Tories, whoever is leading them, being able to compromise this extreme position before, or soon after, the euro referendum which Mr Blair is intending to hold.

How far Michael Portillo would go along with that is hard to say. It wouldn't fit with the new trajectory that all his conscience-stricken posturing on social issues seems to imply. The strategy of inclusiveness, apparently shuddering with distaste at the coarse populism of Widdecombe -Hague, surely doesn't need to exclude those poor benighted fools who happen to believe in Britain-in-Europe, and also happen to include names that are still the ones that most people remember from a party they've otherwise screened out. On the other hand, Portillo seems to loathe the EU. He has already said the referendum will be illegitimate. He is obviously not to be trusted.

The Tory left, therefore, have nothing to gain from dabbling with him. Far better to run their own candidate in a future contest, however quixotic the fight might be. They owe it to their conviction, and to backers who have not all faded away. They owe it to the case they're about to make, that Hague lost the 2001 election because his Euroscepticism helped ruin his credibility as a national leader. They also owe it to the referendum result they want. The plausible future that events should force upon them is not helping a party led by Michael Portillo, but leaving, and thus destroying, one led by Iain Duncan Smith.

He preaches the value of working with business leaders and pursues "big tent" politics, discarding old left-right divides to seek consensus where possible.

The best of the private sector, on salaries the public sector can barely afford, have been hired to inject expertise and dynamism into ailing bodies while a prominent union leader was urged to call off a strike to avoid inconveniencing the public. He bows his head at meetings of the Queen and enjoyed cracking a joke with the Queen Mother. And yesterday, after a meeting with senior police officers, he rallied behind the boys and girls in blue and issued a strong condemnation of the planned May Day protests in London. All very New Labour.

Ken Livingstone is the dog that did not bite, barely barking during his first year as mayor of London. Even the tabloids rarely call him "Red Ken" these days. The Mr Livingstone currently presiding in the Greater London Authority's Romney House HQ is a very different beast to the Mr Livingstone of the Greater London Council and County Hall fame.

Perhaps power has brought its own responsibility, leaving Livingstone a prisoner of a political system that has prevented him making much difference to the lives of Londoners, squeezed by the Treasury and Whitehall from above while below the borough councils jealously defend their turf. The approach of the first anniversary of Livingstone's election on May 4 risks leaving Tony Blair's warning that a Livingstone victory would spell "disaster for London" sounding increasingly hysterical. Trafalgar Square's last licensed seller of pigeon seed has gone and Major General Sir Henry Havelock and General Sir Charles Napier are threatened with expulsion, but the removal from a piazza of birds and a couple of statues is hardly a record to crow about.

Livingstone has made most running on London Underground, opposing (with public support) John Prescott's plans to part-privatise the network in favour of a modernisation scheme that would use private funds to modernise a publicly owned network. Yet even here Livingstone has shown signs of New Labour largesse, appointing as transport commissioner Bob Kiley, a former senior CIA officer before he ran the New York subway, paying his recruit up to £500,000 a year and buying him a £2.1m house .

The mayor appeared to veer left by publicly refusing to condemn tube strikers earlier this year and proclaiming he might even join them on the picket line, but officials in the Aslef drivers' union report he was privately urging its general secretary to call off the stoppage.

The stand-off over the tube is the one area where there is real conflict with the government, Livingstone yesterday announcing another advertising campaign to highlight safety fears ahead of his threatened legal challenge. But privately Livingstone has disclosed that he is keen to compromise and anxious to avoid a showdown, telling a meeting with MPs in Labour's leftwing campaign group last month that a resolution would be the best solution. The mayor, who conceded that his lawyers had warned he could lose any court action, told the surprised MPs he had spoken to Blair's Downing Street "gatekeeper" Anji Hunter and held discussions with Prescott.

Yesterday's denunciation of May 1's monopoly board protesters, threatening to wreck shops and offices of the streets on capitalism's most famous board game, is also a change of tack in office. Livingstone was accused last year of encouraging riots. Mr Livingstone rejected the allegations and later branded the demonstra tors as "mindless thugs". In office, however, his uncompromising position - endorsing the police's "zero tolerance" response and urging protesters to stay away - was unequivocal. Then there are the speeches in the City, praising the value of the financial institutions to the capital, and arguing forcefully that Britain must join the single currency. And eyebrows were raised when Lord Rogers was appointed at £1,625 a day to advise on architectural matters.

The billboards of Livingstone peering at voters were devised under a £20m two-year campaign to win public support for congestion charges. With New Labour, lobbyists are never far away. Livingstone is paying Fishburn Hedges an estimated £100,000 a month for advice.

At the Westminster meeting with his old campaign group comrades, at least one disgruntled leftwing MP suggested that Livingstone was seeking an accommodation rather than confrontation with the government in the hope that a new-found respectability would pave the way for his return to the Labour party. Not so, said the mayor. That was up to Blair. For him, the priority was a second term as mayor. Whether it was as an independent or Labour candidate mattered less.

His performance so far, however, supporting the police and promoting business, is hardly likely to harm the prospect of an invitation. To some Livingstone will have been a disappointment; to others a relief.

Livingstone used to boast that he was a parent of New Labour, pioneering modern campaign techniques such as posters and concerts in his battle with Margaret Thatcher during the 1980s over abolition of the GLC. Others on the Labour left claim he was always New Labour in methods if not policies - singlemindedly promoting the Livingstone brand above the party, continually seeking alliances to advance himself and, according to former allies, prepared to dump supporters who have outlived their usefulness.

In many respects Blair failed to appreciate that Livingstone the politician, like himself, above all else would want to be re-elected. Derision has been repeatedly heaped on Blair for using public funds to produce an annual report applauding the government's efforts and lauding its achievements. Livingstone is now proposing to send out his own glossy document to London's 2.75m homes this summer, detailing his achievements during his first year in office.

The mayor is legally obliged to distribute a performance report so critics, particularly those inside the Labour party, quip that he should send out postcards. But Livingstone favours a £940,000 version including an interview of the mayor by actress Helen Mirren with his comments interspaced with pictures of Ali G and Jack Dee, who will declare why they love London. So very New Labour.

webTitle: Tories split over promise of US scale tax cuts

fields.headline: Tories split over promise of US scale tax cuts
fields.trailText: The Conservative party is facing a fresh split over whether the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, should promise year on year tax cuts matching the scale of George Bush's tax cutting programme.
fields.body:
The Conservative party is facing a fresh split over whether the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, should promise year on year tax cuts matching the scale of George Bush's tax cutting programme.

Some Tories want to sell the party's planned cuts in public spending as equivalent to the tax cutting programme which helped Bush to victory.

The Conservatives have so far promised to spend £8bn less in 2003-04 than Labour proposed in the budget. However, Mr Portillo's deputy, Oliver Letwin, the shadow chief secretary, believes the party can gain votes in the election by promising additional spending and tax cuts in the succeeding years.

He has calculated, taking into account the relative size of the British and American economies, that the cuts could be portrayed as equivalent to the US trillion dollar tax cutting programme.

Other shadow cabinet members reckon the strategy will play into the hands of Labour and undermine the Conservative commitment to improving public services.

One said: "This is madness. If Portillo buys this, he can say goodbye to winning the support of the left in any leadership battle"

The row comes as Michael Ancram, the Conservative chairman, fought off claims that the party's election drive was being destroyed by internecine manouverings over its leadership after the election. Tory peers last night called for members to come to their senses and back William Hague's leadership.

There was a growing sense last night that Mr Hague's leadership within the shadow cabinet was being undermined by the camps of his rivals openly challenging his authority.

Mr Hague's position was not strengthened when Lady Thatcher conspicuously failed to back his leadership despite a call for her to do so by her former principal private secretary, Gerald Howarth. Lady Thatcher instead attacked Tony Blair's handling of the foot and mouth crisis.

Mr Ancram claimed the speculation had been initially fuelled by John Stevens, the pro-euro Conservative. He asserted he had been asked by the former chancellor, Kenneth Clarke, to drop plans to challenge Mr Portillo in his Kensington and Chelsea constituency.

Mr Stevens claimed this was part of a wider realignment between Mr Portillo and Mr Clarke.

Mr Clarke subsequently said he was bemused by such suggestions, but typically took days to come up with his denial, fuelling speculation about an alliance between himself and Mr Portillo.

Attention within the party is now focusing on the extent to which Mr Portillo could move himself to the centre and so ease a pact with Mr Clarke.

Mr Portillo's deputy, Mr Letwin, one of the rising stars of the party, believes the electorate will be convinced by a right of centre party.

Although the Conservatives are already committed to reducing the planned path of spending by £8bn a year less than Gordon Brown intends by 2003-04, Mr Letwin stresses this takes the Conservatives only to the middle of the next parliament.

He believes the Conservatives can promise further tax cuts in the later years of the parliament by keeping public spending growth within the growth rate of the economy.

Mr Letwin has pointed out that in the medium term his plans could match president Bush's plans for $1.6 trillion cumulative tax reduction for 10 years.

He claims that once these tax cuts have been divided by 10, and allowing for the fact that the American economy is seven-and-a-half times bigger than Britain's, the gap between Republican and Tory radicalism is "pretty small".

Mr Portillo has so far refused to say whether in principle he would want to keep public spending below the level of economic growth after 2003-04.

fields.headline: Pedal power for paramedics
fields.trailText: Britain's flattest city launched a pioneering new ambulance service yesterday - speeding to heart attacks and broken legs on two narrow wheels and 18 gears.
fields.body:
Britain's flattest city launched a pioneering new ambulance service yesterday - speeding to heart attacks and broken legs on two narrow wheels and 18 gears.

The country's first emergency bicycle tore down the narrow medieval streets of central York to prove that pedal power can be quicker and more efficient than four wheels or even a health authority helicopter.

The experiment's manager, Paul Brown, said: "The bike can get from one side of the walled city to the other much more quickly than a conventional ambulance.

"York lends itself very well to this initiative because there's a big pedestrian area."

The modified mountain bike also has blue flashing lights and extra baskets to carry life-saving equipment, mobile communications and a defibrillator for cardiac victims.

Patients will not, however, be slung over the back of the saddle in cavalry style, but will wait for a back-up ambulance if they need to be taken for hospital treatment. Nicknamed Life Cycle, the experiment is being run for six months by the Tees, East and North Yorkshire Ambulance Service.

webTitle: Test case likely after boy dies in graveyard

fields.headline: Test case likely after boy dies in graveyard
fields.trailText: Councils may face a legal test case over unsafe gravestones after an inquest yesterday on a schoolboy who was crushed to death by a stone memorial.
fields.body:
Councils may face a legal test case over unsafe gravestones after an inquest yesterday on a schoolboy who was crushed to death by a stone memorial.

North Yorkshire coroner, Jeremy Cave, said that he hoped lessons will be learned from the tragedy at Grove Road cemetery in Harrogate where Reuben Powell, six, died last July while playing with friends.

He recorded a verdict of accidental death after hearing from safety officers that only a small push or tug would have been needed to dislodge the heavy sandstone slab.

The boy's parents, Jeanette and Richard Powell, are considering a test case after launching a campaign for safer graveyards following their son's death. In a statement after the inquest in Harrogate, they said that the council had failed to act soon enough to prevent their son's death, and possibly others.

David Smith, an inspector with the health and safety executive, told the inquest: "Only a small force would have been necessary to cause [the gravestone] to fall, because it had not been built on a rigid foundation."

Councils nationwide have been in touch with Harrogate, which was in the midst of a five-year programme of improving safety in cemeteries when the accident happened. A spokesman said that the project had since been hastened.

webTitle: Two arrested over Euston mugging death

fields.headline: Two arrested over Euston mugging death
fields.trailText: Police arrested a man and a woman this morning in connection with the death of BBC costume designer Elizabeth Sherlock, who was run over by thieves who stole her handbag at Euston station on Monday.
fields.body:
Police arrested a man and a woman this morning in connection with the death of BBC costume designer Elizabeth Sherlock, who was run over by thieves who stole her handbag at Euston station on Monday.

Scotland Yard said today that a 35-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman have been arrested, and police are still appealing for witnesses to the incident.

Ms Sherlock was killed after she chased two thieves who had snatched her handbag while she sat in a café at the London train station. She jumped onto the bonnet of a white Ford Fiesta that was speeding away but then slipped under the car's wheels. She died on the scene from multiple injuries.

The thieves drove away. Police are still hoping to trace the black Mulberry handbag that was stolen from Ms Sherlock.

fields.headline: TV sting to catch thief put wrong man in frame
fields.trailText: Allan Dunne, 34, the man featured on Granada TV's Crimefile and billed as a thief, was an innocent man, writes Paul Kelsoe.
fields.body:
It was an elaborate sting. Officers from Greater Manchester police carefully positioned a hidden camera above a cashpoint machine at a branch of Lloyds TSB in Salford, and waited for their man, a known credit card thief, to make his move.

Viewing the tapes they couldn't believe their luck; here was footage of the thief caught in the act, and fit to be broadcast on a Crimewatch-style programme in the north-west. There was only one hitch: they had the wrong man.

Allan Dunne, 34, the man featured on Granada TV's Crimefile billed as a thief, knew this as he watched himself on screen. His misfortune had been to use the cashpoint to withdraw £20 moments after the real thief. A police officer then misread the withdrawal printout.

Shocked and keen to clear his name, Mr Dunne popped into his local police station the next morning with a bank statement and a clear conscience, only to be arrested on suspicion of burglary and handling stolen goods. Later that day he was suspended from his job at a Blackburn care home and since the incident has been dogged by stress.

"To be shown on television as a criminal is awful. Mud sticks and when I'm out I think people are looking at me because they saw me on the programme. I've been off ill because I am so stressed by the situation," he said.

Police eventually dropped the case after acknowledging their mistake but it wasn't until yesterday that Mr Dunne's trial by television came to an end.

A spokeswoman for Greater Manchester Police said: "I can confirm that an officer representing GMP has apologised to Mr Dunne and explained that a mistake had been made because a printout of withdrawals from the cash point had been misread by an officer. "We can now confirm that GMP discipline and com plaints department has received a letter from Mr Dunne and any complaint will be investigated thoroughly."

A spokesman for Granada television said: "The police gave us the wrong tape. We aired the footage which turned out to be the wrong time. We have explained to the gentleman involved and we will air a clarification for him. We have no way of checking the tapes that are given to us by the police."

Last night Crimefile did indeed apologise on air to Mr Dunne, describing him as "a bona fide customer of the bank". Even this is not entirely true; Mr Dunne has closed his account.

fields.headline: Fashion victim 'Dowdy' magazine to close
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: After more than 40 years of finding new ways to knit a jumper, Woman's Realm is giving in to old age. IPC, which published the magazine, is to merge it with Woman's Weekly.
fields.body:
After more than 40 years of finding new ways to knit a jumper, Woman's Realm is giving in to old age. IPC, which published the magazine, is to merge it with Woman's Weekly.

Mary Frances, the magazine's editor, admitted it had failed to shake off its "dowdy and old-fashioned image" and its "associations with knitting patterns".

For the past year, Ms Frances has been trying to reposition the magazine, but said that its association with a bygone age had been too great to overcome.

Recent circulation figures placed Woman's Realm, which was founded in 1958, at the bottom of IPC's weekly women's publications. Average sales had fallen by more than 15% year on year, to 152,053.

IPC believes that middle-aged women want something different: women over 35 have a total personal annual income of £99bn and 40% are the principal breadwinners in the family. They do not want to read about three ways to cook a chicken.

With this in mind, IPC will launch a weekly for 40-something women, called Your Life. It will be edited by Ms Frances, and targeted at the more upmarket readers of Woman's Realm.

Ms Frances said it would cater for "confident and financially independent" readers who grew up amid the bra-burning protests and sexual liberation of the 1960s.

"These are women who have always been at the vanguard of social change and they refuse to think of themselves as middle-aged."

Without dependent children or a hefty mortgage, these 40 and 50-somethings have a "huge disposable income" and are "completely guilt free about spending money on themselves", she added.

"By 2005, eight out of 10 women will be over 35 so it is an enormous market."

Your Life, which goes on sale next Tuesday, will feature sections on exotic travel, aspirational lifestyles and fashion.

From knitting to gigolos

Readers of the first issue of Woman's Realm on February 22 1958 could read:

 Can a husband want too much love? A man needs a woman who loves him to give him security at home.

 Violet Stevenson suggests a novel idea for making an austere bathroom more decorative.

 Knit teddy a scarf to keep him warm.

 Potato cut printing: colourful ways to smarten up your book collection.

The final issue of the magazine, aimed at 35 to 55-year-old 'empty nesters', offered:

 For drama queens: how to win in the games people play.

 Ignorance is no excuse: are you breaking the law by carrying a penknife in your handbag?

 What's that then? A rough guide to health foods.

 Beauty online - we scan the net's best beauty sites.

 Chances to win a car, cash or holiday.

 British gigolos: men who are paid to pleasure women like you.

 'I felt fat and became a bitch': what plastic surgery does to you body.

 Mothers who take cocaine.

 Seven secrets of super-youth.

Max Houghton

Recent circulation figures placed Woman's Realm, which was founded in 1958, at the bottom of IPC's weekly women's publications. Average sales had fallen by more than 15% year on year, to 152,053. IPC believes that middle-aged women want something different: women over 35 have a total personal annual income of £99bn and 40% are the principal breadwinners in the family. They do not want to read about three ways to cook a chicken. With this in mind, IPC will launch a weekly for 40-something women, called Your Life. It will be edited by Ms Frances, and targeted at the more upmarket readers of Woman's Realm. Ms Frances said it would cater for "confident and financially independent" readers who grew up amid the bra-burning protests and sexual liberation of the 1960s. "These are women who have always been at the vanguard of social change and they refuse to think of themselves as middle-aged." Without dependent children or a hefty mortgage, these 40 and 50-somethings have a "huge disposable income" and are "completely guilt free about spending money on themselves", she added. "By 2005, eight out of 10 women will be over 35 so it is an enormous market." Your Life, which goes on sale next Tuesday, will feature sections on exotic travel, aspirational lifestyles and fashion. From knitting to gigolos Readers of the first issue of Woman's Realm on February 22 1958 could read:  Can a husband want too much love? A man needs a woman who loves him to give him security at home.  Violet Stevenson suggests a novel idea for making an austere bathroom more decorative.  Knit teddy a scarf to keep him warm.  Potato cut printing: colourful ways to smarten up your book collection. The final issue of the magazine, aimed at 35 to 55-year-old 'empty nesters', offered:  For drama queens: how to win in the games people play.  Ignorance is no excuse: are you breaking the law by carrying a penknife in your handbag?  What's that then? A rough guide to health foods.  Beauty online - we scan the net's best beauty sites.  Chances to win a car, cash or holiday.  British gigolos: men who are paid to pleasure women like you.  'I felt fat and became a bitch': what plastic surgery does to you body.  Mothers who take cocaine.  Seven secrets of super-youth. fields.headline: Ford names new marketing chief
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Ford has raided the world of advertising for its new marketing chief, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Ford has raided the world of advertising for its new marketing chief.

Rich Stoddart, an executive at Fallon Worldwide Advertising, has been named as marketing communications manager for the Ford division of Ford Motor Company.

Mr Stoddart will be responsible for developing and implementing advertising and consumer marketing strategies for Ford's car, truck and sport brands.

He replaces Janet Klug, who was named vice-president of global marketing for Ford Motor Company last month.

Mr Stoddart joins Ford on May 1, after working as director of account management for Fallon Worldwide Advertising in Minneapolis

Previously, he was vice-president and account director on the McDonald's advertising account at Leo Burnett Company in Chicago, Illinois.

"Rich brings a vast range of experience and talent to the Ford team," said Cisco Codina, the general marketing manager at Ford.

"He has a great reputation for leadership and creative flair in cultivating powerful American brands like McDonald's, Ralston-Purina and Lee jeans."

fields.headline: City diary
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Basingstoke-based computer manufacturer Centerprise is supplying one of Europe's highest profile online retailers . . . we refer, of course, to Letsbuyit.com.
fields.body:
 Heartiest Diary congratulations to Basingstoke-based computer manufacturer Centerprise. Not only was it named Hampshire Business of the Year last year, but yesterday it emerged that the ambitious hardware firm is supplying one of Europe's highest profile online retailers . . . we refer, of course, to Letsbuyit.com. Centerprise, reports excellent website The Register, has agreed to build own-brand Letsbuyit PCs - to be labelled "Ants", after the animated creatures that appear in the retailer's television adverts.

With so many former suppliers giving Letsbuyit the cold shoulder, it warms the heart to see the e-tailer receiving a helping hand after an unfortunate spell in the Amsterdam courts earlier this year. Nevertheless, the company's cynical detractors - who, to this day, unfairly liken the firm to the living dead - will doubtless dredge up allegations submitted to the court by Dutch administrators, concerning Letsbuyit's former senior executives' understanding of the "financial obligations of the company". Not us. We salute Centerprise, who appear unconcerned with Letsbuyit's background, and wish it the best of fortune.

 Investing in the stock market is a grave matter. This is why we are grateful for an invite, from US online financial newswire TheStreet.com, to attend "one of the premier investment conferences in the country". Delegates will be able to take advantage of 200 workshops and five panel discussions "to hone your investment skills". "You will learn how to devise a clear-cut investment strategy that shows you how to invest for the reality of wealth - not the pipe dream of overnight riches," reads the sober invitation. How long before delegates tire and turn to some of the conference's fringe investment workshops one imagines on offer at the chosen venue - the Paris hotel and casino in Las Vegas - we dare not speculate.

 Excitement mounts in the run up to the UK oil and gas industry's publication of its Sustainable Development Strategy next week. Whether use of the word "sustainable" anticipates the unveiling of a miracle emissionless fossil fuel, or whether it denotes a cynical hijacking of tree-huggers' jargon, it is too early to say.

 So to the Diary's ongoing investigation into reports that staff at Vodafone's head office in Newbury are having trouble receiving a clear signal on their mobile phones - despite claims that the Vodafone network offers 99% coverage throughout Britain. During our initial inquiries, you will recall, a woman from Vodafone's service centre assured us that reception in Newbury town centre was quite sufficient, and that any problems "could be to do with building structures, and nothing to do with coverage provided by Vodafone". Not satisfied with this baffling response, we call the Newbury office direct, employ a cunning subterfuge. "Hello, hello? Can you hear me?" we begin. "Pardon? . . . What? . . . Look, this is a very bad line - can I have your mobile number, and I'll call you back?" "Er, no. You can't," comes the reply. "If you can't hear me on this line, I'm not giving you my mobile number." And with that, the rather nervous sounding staff member hangs up. Hmm.

 Our thanks to Jon Rhodes who emails to point out that the Harvard Business Review - which, we reported yesterday, has been voted "most influential magazine in America by 1,700 opinion leaders" - is not only exclusively available to "an elite corps of top of top business managers", as it may imply. In fact, Mr Rhodes writes, "WH Smith in Euston definitely has the most recent copy".

That may be so, Mr Rhodes but it will not stop us featuring an edited extract from HBR's impressive website tomorrow. The subject of the piece is corporate egos.

fields.headline: Channel 4 beams up Andromeda
fields.trailText: 1pm: Channel 4 has bought Andromeda, a new US sci-fi series from Star Trek creator Gene Roddenberry. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 4 has bought Andromeda, a new US sci-fi series from the creator of Star Trek, Gene Roddenberry.

Andromeda stars Kevin Sorbo as a starship captain who gets caught up in an intergalactic civil war.

Channel 4 has acquired the 22-part first run of the show, with an option to buy future series.

The deal was put together by Fireworks International, the TV distribution arm of the Canadian media company, CanWest Entertainment.

Andromeda is made by BLT Productions in association with Fireworks and Tribune Entertainment Group.

It is based on an idea that Mr Roddenberry, who died in 1991, had in the 1980s.

webTitle: Tibetan pipeline row dents BP's new image

fields.headline: Tibetan pipeline row dents BP's new image
fields.trailText: Gendun Rinchen has come a long way in seven years. In May 1993, the Tibetan tour guide was thrown into jail outside Lhasa for attempting to pass a document detailing human rights abuses by the occupying Chinese forces to a visiting European delegation.
fields.body:
Gendun Rinchen has come a long way in seven years. In May 1993, the Tibetan tour guide was thrown into jail outside Lhasa for attempting to pass a document detailing human rights abuses by the occupying Chinese forces to a visiting European delegation. He survived eight months without trial before an international campaign forced his release.

But this morning he faces a bigger challenge. At the Royal Festival Hall in London, he will stand before an audience of City investors and well-heeled home counties pensioners to challenge the might of the board of BP, the pride of British business.

In the latest international human rights row to hit one of Britain's biggest companies, Rinchen and his fellow campaigners will attempt to force BP to break off its lucrative links with a Chinese oil company amid allegations of complicity in China's attempts to consolidate its violent, 52-year occupation of Tibet.

The concern focuses on a 950km pipeline project to carry gas from the Tsaidam Basin in the Amdo region of Tibet to industrial Chinese cities in the Gansu province. The pipeline, which is 70% complete, is being built by a subsidiary of CNPC, the state oil company, PetroChina, in which BP is the largest foreign investor.

The project is opposed by the Tibetan Government in Exile, led by the Dalai Lama, and pro-Tibet campaign groups around the world.

They say the pipeline is a political project aimed at consolidating China's grip on Tibet. As well as employing a disproportionate number of Chinese settlers, it will damage Tibet's environment and deplete its natural resources, with no benefit for the local population, they claim.

Although BP is not directly involved in building the pipeline, the campaigners say that its $578m (£390m) investment in PetroChina, which remains under the operational control of Beijing, amounts to complicity in human rights violations.

The pipeline is being built against a backdrop of increasing human rights abuses by the Chinese. Since they invaded in 1949, the Tibetan culture and religion have been brutally oppressed. An estimated 1.2m people have died either directly or indirectly as a result of the Chinese occupation, while around 6,000 monasteries have been destroyed.

In a resolution filed by more than 120 BP-Amoco shareholders, representing nearly £3m of the company's shares, the Free Tibet Campaign is demanding that the company end its investment in PetroChina.

The resolution, which will be moved by Rinchen, states: "We believe Tibetans ... will derive little or no benefit from the exploitation of their resources, which will facilitate population transfer and pose a significant threat to their culture and environment. No known consultations or social and environmental impact assessments have been carried out, and the environmental record of existing resource extraction projects in the Tsaidam ... is very poor."

BP's decision to take a stake in PetroChina in 1999 secured the flotation of the company on the New York stock exchange when other investors were questioning whether it was a good bet.

BP appears to have already been amply rewarded by winning a $180m (£120m) contract to build China's first liquefied natural gas (LNG) terminal at Guangdong in southern China. China, with its massive population moving from bicycles to cars, is considered a huge future prize.

There is virtually no chance that the campaign's resolution will pass, not least because BP's board has changed the rules for AGM motions so that the Free Tibet resolution now requires 75% support.

In the board's response to the Tibet resolution, the directors say: "The resolution and supporting statement ask BP to walk away from a commercially attractive venture that forms one of the main building blocks of our China strategy and to diminish or destroy our ability to influence the way in which one of the world's most important markets will develop. That is not in the best interests of shareholders."

It continues: "BP's shareholder interest in PetroChina is a symbol of our commitment to build a long-term relationship with a leading Chinese energy group. BP has no management role in the company and has no operations in the areas which the resolution claims present human rights and environmental concerns."

But having its human rights record publicly called into question yet again will come as a major embarrassment for a company which has attempted to brand itself as a leader in environmental and social responsibility.

BP is still recovering from a public relations disaster three years ago when the Guardian revealed that a private security firm it employed to protect a pipeline in Colombia had given lethal training to an army brigade which had been implicated in massacres of civilians.

Since then, the company has been at pains to present a more responsible image. An international study on corporate citizenship and social responsibility published recently by communications research group, Echo, placed BP at the top of the tree. BP even beat the Co-op bank in its level of political correctness.

Sir John Browne, the chief executive, has also poured significant amounts of financial investment into renewables, positioning the company at the forefront of developments in solar power.

In a seminar last month at Cambridge University, he accepted that the corporate world must take on some of the responsibilities formally in the hands of govern ment in recognition of company's growing size and power. He said: "Globalisation has certainly increased the scale and reach of companies. The 20 largest companies in the world have market capitalisations greater than the GDPs of all but 20 of the members of the UN assembly."

But BP's willingness to put its head above the parapet has made it a target for those campaign groups. It also appears to have only served to antagonise these groups by beginning talks and failing to deliver on perceived expectations.

Troublespots - The record of blame

Alaska

As one of the four main oil companies operating in the North Slope region, BP has faced widespread public criticism in the US over damage to the fragile Arctic environment. According to Greenpeace, the company has suffered four "significant" oil spills in the area this year and has been fined for illegally drilling toxic chemicals back into the ground. It has also been a key player in moves to open up the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil exploration.

Sudan

In a damning Christian Aid report last month into the role of foreign oil companies in the depopulation of parts of Sudan for oil exploration and human rights atrocities against civilians, BP was criticised for retaining its connections with the China National Petroleum Company, one of the main oil extractors in Sudan.

Colombia

In 1998, the Guardian revealed that a security company employed by BP to protect Ocensa oil pipeline had given lethal training to a Colombian army brigade implicated in two massacres during the civil war. The company sacked its chief security officer in the Casanare region and launched an internal investigation.

The revelations came two years after Amnesty International called on BP to reviews its operational policies in the country amid growing human rights violations against members of the local community protesting against the company.

Rhodesia

BP was rocked by a scandal in the late 1970s after the Bingham report into sanctions busting revealed that its local offices in southern Africa, along with those of Shell, had been breaking the government's oil embargo on Ian Smith's Rhodesia almost from the moment it was imposed. Senior executives were criticised for failing to monitor what local employees were doing.

webTitle: Activists protest at BP general meeting

fields.headline: Activists protest at BP general meeting
fields.trailText: Oil giants BP Amoco today faced pressure from campaigners calling for it to sell a controversial stake in Chinese firm PetroChina.
fields.body:
Oil giants BP Amoco today faced pressure from campaigners calling for it to sell a controversial stake in Chinese firm PetroChina.

Protesters from the Free Tibet Campaign demonstrated outside the multinational's annual general meeting at London's Royal Festival Hall.

The campaigners are trying to get a resolution passed at the AGM for BP to sell its 2.2% interest in PetroChina, whose parent company is building gas pipelines in Tibet.

Protesters held a Tibetan flag and chanted "BP - out of Tibet".

Gedun Rinchen, 52, who said he was a former political prisoner from Tibet, claimed the developments would promote jobs solely for Chinese nationals.

BP also faced pressure from Greenpeace, which is putting forward a motion calling on the group to publish a report showing how it will make the transition to renewable sources of energy.

Stephanie Tunmore, 46, from Greenpeace, said: "We want them to report on how they will move away from fossil fuels."

And the firm was also criticised by US campaigners Public Interest Research Group, which attempted to get a motion heard calling on the firm to assess the impact of drilling for oil in the Arctic.

Rene Wendell, 30, from Massachusetts, USA, demonstrating with a blow up caribou, said: "We want BP to live up to their environmental image and cancel plans for drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge."

He said it was estimated caribou numbers - currently150,000 - would diminish by 40% if exploration went ahead.

fields.headline: In praise of disputation, and drink
fields.standfirst: Peacock got his priorities just right. We should celebrate him
fields.trailText: Thomas Love Peacock got his priorities just right. We should celebrate him.
fields.body:
The first conference of the Anthony Powell Society, commemorating the creator of the 12-novel sequence A Dance to the Music of Time, takes place on Monday. The venue for the occasion is Eton College.

This is a big mistake. The very first aim of such a society ought to be to rescue Powell from the slur that he was an Old Etonian whose books are all about Old Etonians and the kind of aristocratic snobs who move in their circles. Yes, there are plenty of them. But the world of these novels is also full of people to whom Eton would have been utterly alien, even repulsive. The right place to stage this occasion would have been the modern equivalent of one of those none-too salubrious restaurants, pubs and clubs in Soho or Fitzrovia where so much of the action takes place: Foppa's, the Mortimer, the Hero of Acre.

Sadder still is the news that the first conference of the Thomas Love Peacock Society is to be staged so far away from his native land, in Hobart, Tasmania. You can't blame the organisers for choosing Hobart, since that is where the society started. But somewhere like Upper Halliford, on the south-west edge of London, where Peacock lived in his final years, might have done more to erase his neglect in his native land. Certainly you will find the best known works - Headlong Hall, Nightmare Abbey, Crochet Castle, Gryll Grange - on the shelves of your local Waterstone's, but other characteristic novels such as Melincourt, in which an orang-utan becomes a Tory MP, and The Misfortunes of Elphin are more elusive.

Peacock cannot compete with Bridget Jones, and that is scarcely surprising. He wrote for himself, and made few concessions, even by the standards of the early 19th century. His erudition is frightening. Headlong Hall, the first of these novels, is festooned in footnotes. Even within the text he will suddenly slip in a line of Menander, quoted in the original Greek. The sections of Melincourt which feature the orang-utan are liberally annotated with the observations of zoologists. But you don't have to read them unless they interest you; any more than you need to know that Mr Cypress in Nightmare Abbey is Byron, or Mr Flosky is Coleridge. It helps, but it isn't essential.

Disputation and anecdote, fuelled by fine wine and interrupted now and then by a song, are the essence of Peacock. The books are full of impossible breakfasts and long lavish dinners, with the role of the host confined to keeping conversation flowing and glasses full. "When I open the bottle," says a typical Peacock cleric, the Reverend Mr Portpipe in Melincourt, "I shut the Book of Numbers."

Melincourt, I have seen it alleged, is too topical to be read today. In that some of it is a satire on the opposition to parliamentary reform in the opening years of the century, that may be true. But much that is mocked still survives. The reactionary Tories who assure the people of the populous city of No-vote that they're better off without parliamentary representation have their present day successors in the hereditary peers who, before the last reform, warned in the House of Lords of the terrible times the country must suffer were they to lose their privileged places.

Or take the second chapter of the Misfortunes of Elphin - it is on the Peacock website - in which Elphin, son of the king, tries to persuade Seithenyn, keeper of the embankment, of the terrible things which will happen if his embankment is not repaired. Seithenyn, as ever, is feasting, and drunk - though not as drunk as he will be later, since almost every sentence he speaks ends with the instruction: "Cupbearer, fill." Is the embankment decayed? So much the better. "Our ancestors," he says, "were wiser than we; they built it in their wisdom; and if we should be so rash as to try and mend it, we should only mar it ... The parts that are rotten give elasticity to the parts that are sound. There is nothing as dangerous as innovation." Peacock's target is Canning, railing against constitutional reform. But the attitudes are immortal: you can still read this kind of thing any day of the week in a Daily Telegraph leader.

The Peacock conference ought to be held in somewhere like Merionethshire, in some ramshackle house where an old cracked bell sounds the hours from a ruined tower, and melancholy walks may be taken through landscapes of deep ravines and thunderous waterfalls, with a groaning table and ample supplies of good red wine to finish the day. Life is a curious business, and not in Peacock's view to be taken too seriously even by serious people. Its drollness is what redeems it. Shut up the Book of Numbers. Cupbearer, fill.

The venue for the occasion is Eton College. This is a big mistake. The very first aim of such a society ought to be to rescue Powell from the slur that he was an Old Etonian whose books are all about Old Etonians and the kind of aristocratic snobs who move in their circles. Yes, there are plenty of them. But the world of these novels is also full of people to whom Eton would have been utterly alien, even repulsive. The right place to stage this occasion would have been the modern equivalent of one of those none-too salubrious restaurants, pubs and clubs in Soho or Fitzrovia where so much of the action takes place: Foppa's, the Mortimer, the Hero of Acre. fields.headline: Crows with attitude invade Tokyo
fields.standfirst: Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: Could it be a Hitchcockian portent of doom or simply a warning of the danger of neglecting the urban environment? Either way, Tokyo is suffering a plague of giant crows. Growing volumes of rubbish and excessive energy consumption are blamed.
fields.body:
Could it be a Hitchcockian portent of doom or simply a warning of the danger of neglecting the urban environment? Either way, Tokyo is suffering a plague of giant crows. Growing volumes of rubbish and excessive energy consumption are blamed.

According to a recent survey by the Wild Bird Society of Japan, the crow population of Tokyo has risen from 20,000 to 30,000 since 1998. In the past 15 years it is believed to have more than quadrupled.

The Japanese capital has been taken over by Corvus macrorhynchos - south-east Asian jungle crows - which have wingspans of up to a metre, sharp beaks and a feisty attitude.

Signs in Hibiya park, close to the Imperial palace, warn pedestrians to beware of the birds, which reportedly make hundreds of attacks each year, mostly during the April to June breeding season.

The domestic media report that in the worst affected areas many women carry umbrellas to protect themselves.

During the lean new year period, when the country closes down, the birds have been known to prey on kittens and small dogs.

The rise in the number of crows has been attributed to two environmental problems: rubbish and heat.

Tokyo produces a vast and growing amount of refuse, which the residents carefully sort. But the authorities' insistence on the use of transparent binliners to ensure that the rubbish is sorted correctly is believed to have made it easier for the sharp-eyed birds to find food.

The city's temperature is also to their liking, thanks to the "heat island" effect produced by the dense population, high volume of traffic and a concrete environment which traps the warmth.

After a growing number of complaints, the metropolitan government has distributed nets to protect rubbish sites from the birds and dispatched exterminators to destroy their nests.

But the governor, Shintaro Ishihara, admits that the problem is getting out of hand. "Maybe we need to encourage people to eat crow pie," he said, half-jokingly.

fields.headline: Doctors blow whistle on jail health crisis
fields.standfirst: Special report: prisons
fields.trailText: The British Medical Association yesterday blew the whistle on a crisis in prison health care that is denying inmates effective treatment and failing to address drug and alcohol addiction that will cause many to reoffend after release.
fields.body:
The British Medical Association yesterday blew the whistle on a crisis in prison health care that is denying inmates effective treatment and failing to address drug and alcohol addiction that will cause many to reoffend after release.

The BMA blamed prison governors for interfering in the clinical judgment of doctors by prohibiting use of the most cost-effective medications in order to divert more resources into jail security.

Other problems included inadequate staffing and excessive reliance on agency nurses. Prison doctors were often professionally isolated and not allowed enough time for training to update their skills, said the BMA report entitled Prison Medicine: a Crisis Waiting to Break'.

Prison authorities were often reluctant to pay the cost of sending prison officers to accompany inmates needing specialist treatment in NHS hospitals, the report said.

The government responded with a promise to spend £25m at jails in England and Wales.

There are 230 prison doctors, of whom 135 are directly employed by jails. The rest are GPs contracted to work part-time. Sir David Ramsbotham, chief inspector of prisons, said the BMA was confirming "horrendous examples" of defective prison health care.

fields.headline: Army wanted to act sooner
fields.trailText: Senior military officers said yesterday that the army ought to have been brought in much earlier to help cope with the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
Senior military officers said yesterday that the army ought to have been brought in much earlier to help cope with the foot and mouth crisis.

Publicly the army has been reluctant to comment. Yesterday, Brigadier Malcolm Wood, deputy director of Whitehall's foot and mouth coordination committee, told journalists the army had "responded quickly and appropriately" to requests for help. He declined to elaborate, saying any decision was a matter of policy, and, as such, for ministers to comment on.

Other officers privately made clear they believed the army should have been asked much sooner. "I don't think any of us doubt we should have been called in earlier", said one.

It was not until March 23, after Tony Blair had announced he would personally take charge, that the army set up a command and control operation to organise logistics. This was more than a month after the first case in Essex.

Officers yesterday pointed to an army report after the outbreak in 1967, saying in any future outbreak it should be brought in straight away "to ensure [the disease] did not develop into a major problem".

By the time in 1967 the army was called in, 12 days into the crisis, "there was already a large backlog of carcasses awaiting destruction, and of farms awaiting disinfection", and Maff was unable to cope, said the report. "Once the army were called in to assist," it added, "there was a rapid improvement... It became possible to establish a proper system of operational control."

The report concluded: "In a national emergency of this nature, the earlier the military can be called in the better."

Iain Duncan Smith, the shadow defence secretary, last night accused the government of having ignored the 1967 report because it did not want the present outbreak to look like a crisis and have to move the election date.

fields.headline: Cut the blah blah blah
fields.standfirst: Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Labour and environmental side-agreements tacked on to the North American Free Trade Agreement have a spectacularly poor track record. Today, 75% of Mexico's population lives in poverty, up from 49% in 1981.
fields.body:
The labour and environmental side-agreements tacked on to the North American Free Trade Agreement between the US, Canada and Mexico have a spectacularly poor track record. Today, 75% of Mexico's population lives in poverty, up from 49% in 1981.

Trade may be creating jobs in Canada but not enough to keep up with the number that have been eliminated - by 1997, there had been a net loss of 276,000 jobs.

Total pollution has doubled in Mexico since Nafta was introduced, according to the Sierra Club. And the US has become a climate change renegade, chucking out its Kyoto commitments wholesale. It turns out that defiant unilateralism is the ultimate luxury item in the free trade era, reserved for the ultra rich.

There is always a ready excuse for why the wealth liberated by so-called free trade is stuck at the top: a recession, the deficit, the peso crisis, political corruption, and now another looming recession. There is always a reason why it should be spent on another tax break instead of social or environmental programmes.

Only economists worship wealth creation as an abstraction, only the very rich fetishise it as an end in itself. The rest of us are interested in those rising numbers on the trade ledger for what they can buy: does increased trade and investment mean we can afford to rebuild our healthcare system? Can we keep our promises to end child poverty? Can we fund better schools? Build affordable housing? Can we afford to invest in cleaner energy sources? Do we work less, have more leisure time? In short, do we have a more just, sustainable society?

The opposite is the case. We have stagnant wages, economic disparities and a deepening environmental crisis. And when economic growth is severed from meaningful measures of social progress, thinking people begin to lose faith in the system. They start to ask difficult questions not only about trade, but about how economists measure progress and value.

Why can't we measure ecological deficits, as well as economic growth? What is the real social cost in cuts to education, in increased homelessness? These are the types of questions that will be heard in Quebec City at the Summit of the Americas this week.

They will come from people such as Jose Bove, the French cheese farmer whose campaign is not against McDonald's but against an agricultural model that sees food purely as an industrial commodity, rather than the centrepiece of national culture and family life.

They will come from healthcare workers questioning a trade system that defends patents for Aids drugs more vigorously than millions of human lives. They will come from university students, paying more for their "public" education every year, while their schools are invaded by ads and their research departments privatised one study at a time.

The slogan "people before profits" is dismissed as unfocused by free trade defenders, but it neatly encapsulates the sentiment running through the campaigns that are converging in Quebec.

The argument for barrelling ahead with the Free Trade Area of the Americas is based on an unshakeable ideological belief that what's good for business will be good for everyone - eventually. Even if that dubious argument is true, the timeline is unacceptable. According to the governor of the Bank of Mexico, at the current rate of economic growth, it will be 60 years before Mexico doubles its per capita income and ends its extreme poverty.

Rather than one solution, there are thousands, slowly coalescing into an alternate economic model.

In Brazil that means free generic Aids drugs for anyone who needs them. In Cochabamba, Bolivia, it means insisting that water is not a commodity but a human right, even if that means throwing out the international water conglomerate Bechtel.

In Canada's British Columbia, it means demanding the right to manage "community forests" which combine selective logging, tourism and local industry, as opposed to granting industrial tree farm licences to logging multinationals. In Mexico and Guatemala it means coffee farm cooperatives that guarantee a living wage and ecological diversity.

Some defenders of free trade say that if the protesters were serious, they would be on the other side of the chain-link fence politely negotiating side-agreements on labour, democracy and environmental standards. Indeed the fence itself is being justified by the summit organisers on the grounds that a handful of "civil society representatives" have been issued personal invitations to enter the gated city.

But 13 years after the first free trade agreement with the US it's not the details of the deal (we still don't know them) but the economic model itself that is under fire - the numbers just don't add up. Last week, Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien was quoted as saying that thousands are coming to Quebec City to "protest and blah blah blah". Quite the opposite. They're coming to Quebec to protest because they've had it with the blah blah blah.

 Naomi Klein writes a fortnightly column

webTitle: Bush v Bush in a clash of family and oil loyalties

fields.headline: Bush v Bush in a clash of family and oil loyalties
fields.standfirst: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Now he is in the White House, George Bush is proving that to a Texan with campaign debts, oil is thicker than blood.
fields.body:
The help Governor Jeb Bush gave his brother during last year's disputed presidential election in Florida was a reminder that blood is thicker than water. But now he is in the White House, George Bush is proving that to a Texan with campaign debts, oil is thicker than blood.

His interior secretary, Gale Norton, has rejected an appeal from the younger Bush sibling to halt the auction of 2.4m hectares (6m acres) of seabed off the Florida coast to oil companies for exploration and drilling.

The appeal put the president in a delicate position.

On the one hand, his government is trying to open up the Arctic national wildlife refuge in Alaska and parts of the Rockies to oil exploration, on the grounds that the country is facing a critical energy shortage.

With the potential yield of up to 2bn barrels of oil and billions of cubic metres of natural gas, the Gulf of Mexico site is even more important.

Oil companies looking forward to bidding in the auction of leases later this year made generous donations to the Bush election campaign.

On the other hand, giving the green light to drilling could destroy Jeb Bush's chance of being re-elected next year: a chance already damaged by the well-publicised intervention of his officials in his brother's favour during the Florida recount.

In an impassioned letter to the interior department in January, three days after his brother's inauguration, Jeb wrote: "Florida's economy is based upon tourism and other activities that depend on a clean and healthy environment. It is my hope that [the] interior will recognise that the entire eastern Gulf of Mexico planning area contains many sensitive marine and coastal resources, and not advance any new leasing in this area.

"Few other issues so completely unite Floridians."

But in a response reported in yesterday's USA Today newspaper, Ms Norton said the auction of exploration leases would go ahead, adding: "I must consider our nation's energy needs and appropriate management of the American public's natural resources."

The governor's office and Floridian environmentalists are still hoping to stop the drilling. The interior department has to make an environmental impact assessment before a final decision on the auction is made in October. But Ms Norton's letter is being seen as a strong sign that a green light is likely.

Jeb Bush's spokeswoman, Elizabeth Hirst, said: "This is not a pitting of one Bush against another. This is the governor fighting for the people of his state."

 Mississippi voted by a nearly 2-to-1 margin on Tuesday to keep the Confederate battle insignia on its state flag, defeating the alternative proposition to replace it with a cluster of 20 stars.

It is the last state to display the emblem prominently on its flag.

The vote was 488,630 in favour of keeping the 1894 flag and 267,812 for replacing it.
