webTitle: Jenny Colgan on life in Hollywood

fields.headline: Gone west
fields.standfirst: How to meet the stars (almost) and jump the theme-park queues in the land of the freeway
fields.trailText: How to meet the stars (almost) and jump the theme-park queues in the land of the freeway.
fields.body:
OK. Think for a second of all the cool people I could possibly be in a bar with in Los Angeles. Let your imagination run free. Perhaps Julia Roberts and Benicio Del Toro would be having a big, secret Oscar gossip right next to me. Perhaps Tom Cruise would be lonely and looking for love in the next booth (although I don't think Tom goes into booths - he can't see over the table). So who do I sit next to having cocktails at a chichi seaside hotel? The one who isn't Robson from Robson and Jerome. I know! Control your excitement please. It's ridiculous. This is supposed to be Los Angeles, not the Eastbourne summer season.

And speaking of tenuous celebrity connections, I had dinner with my agent at Harrison Ford's son's restaurant. Uh-huh. It was full of middle-aged women, Harrison-hunting. Then I get home and pick up the paper. In their "celebrity spot" column ( you have no idea how tragic American papers are) it says: "Spotted in Harrison Ford's son's restaurant: Madonna and Rupert Everett". Dammit.

Of course, one of the best reasons - definitely top five - for being a writer is the ability to go to theme parks on weekdays out of season, where you can join all the other shifty-looking adults without children to excuse their desire to do lots of things that make them go "Oooh!" Surprisingly good was a jetski show based on Kevin Costner's bloatathon Waterworld. "It is the future," intones the voiceover. "The poles have melted and flooded the earth." "Because of George Dubya," I add, helpfully.

Also, here you can teach your children good and useful values by buying them a VIP pass which automatically puts them at the front of the line for all the rides. Fortunately this is levelled a little bit by the regular chorus of teenage boys who chant "VIP sucks!" every time this occurs. But let's face it: VIP does suck.

There's also America's biggest rollercoaster park. Normally you have to wait about an hour to get on to each ride, but not in chilly early April. We did 14 in two-and-a-half hours. I'm hoping my nose will stop bleeding some day soon, but unfortunately doctors are saying Henry's eyeballs are going to have to stay like that. America is very, very good at theme parks. Not only this, but Santa Monica is hosting a "Dinosaur Carnival". Can you imagine anything more fantastic?

And my ongoing fascination with the terrifying insularity of the American news media grows apace. Israel in flames; Europe under quarantine. Global recession looming. And, on the front page of the LA Times this week: two pieces about possible rolling power blackouts and the snappy "Bow Ties May Not Be For Everyone - But They Work For Me!" And "me" wasn't even anyone interesting - just some LA Times hack.

Speaking of rolling blackouts, we got one at dinner. All the Americans sensibly went home, which was nice of them because it left us Brits the whole restaurant to play sardines in. Dark restaurants are a good thing, I have decided, although sadly nobody was a) caught in flagrante or b) brutally murdered. However, one of the chaps did something worse - he decided that, since it was pitch black, he was going to smoke indoors, an incredibly shocking thing here. The waiting staff let him, as he was performing a service by providing a beacon of light. It's also great to see British people: I love it here, but every so often I miss hearing people say things like "Well, when I saw Jessica at Isabel's party ..." and "Crap! I'm overdue with my VAT return."

As for the writing, it's going well, I think. There is a slight problem. If you write a book, you finish it, you fiddle around with it, then three months later an exciting parcel comes in the post and - ta-dah! - there's your book. If you were really egotistical, you might immediately take it into the bath and pretend it wasn't yours and that you were reading it for the first time.

But with screenplays and sitcoms, there will be no way of telling - possibly for quite a long time - if I might as well have just sent everything into a vacuum, or simply spent my time here sitting on my bum eating pastrami sandwiches and drinking Jamba Juice. The more industry people I meet, the harder the process appears. I met someone who has been lugging around his pilot sitcom since 1994. Contact was due to be made in 1981 and was made in 1997. I wonder if I could handle the uncertainty - although a life of uncertainty seems a lot more tempting when you get 263 days of sunshine a year.

 Jenny Colgan is seeking fame and fortune in Los Angeles. She will report fortnightly on her progress.

fields.headline: Chicken feed
fields.standfirst: Burghead
fields.trailText: Burghead.
fields.body:
Bags of potatoes were needed for the daily cook-up for the hens, ducks and geese, but we wondered if our source, a farm shop near Kinloss along the east coast, would be open. We were going past the farm anyway to do a sea watch further along the coast, so we decided to just go and see.

Woodside is a farm where apart from crops and cattle they also have a shop, which sells mostly their own produce, including six varieties of potatoes. Inside there is a fine display of a model farm, with miniature machinery and animals, which always fascinates children, and me. A field near the road is used every Sunday for a car-boot sale, which brings in a little more income, and occasionally there are also some majestic Clydesdale horses to be seen. The farm itself was closed, and there was no car-boot sale, both of which we expected, but the farmer was not to be beaten as far as the income from the shop was concerned, as there, parked near the road, was a huge trailer with the contents of the former shop inside, so our poultry would get their potatoes.

At Burghead we were greeted with an amazing display - the tide was full and the great waves that we could see forming some way out were crashing over large boulders of the sea defence only a few feet away. The noise was extraordinary.

The backcloth to this impressive sea were the hills beyond the Moray Firth, still covered with plenty of snow, reminding us just how cold the past few months have been. The highest hill, Ben Wyvis, at 1,046m, had the most, but all the lower hills also had extensive snow fields, which glistened in the sunlight, despite being so far away.

fields.headline: The silent majority
fields.trailText: Raped | Ground Force Goes East | Ground Force Goes East
fields.body:
It is like some perverse maths exam question. If 8,000 rapes are reported each year - and this figure represents one quarter of the total of actual offences committed - but only 9% of reported rapes result in convictions, how many rapes, both reported and otherwise, go unpunished?

If, like me, you spent most arithmetic classes masticating bits of graph paper and throwing them at the ceiling for no apparent reason (no secret desires to become a plasterer or nuffink), it will take you a while to alight upon the answer. When you do, it is so horrifying, you are likely to check your maths in disbelief rather than acknowledge such hourly atrocities. Some 31,280 rapes go unpunished every year. Of the 80 women raped every day, only 20 report it.

Some of those women were featured in Raped (BBC1), Rachel Coughlan's well-crafted but unpretentious, sensitive but wholly unsentimental documentary. Statistics are like kindling, dry but necessary. The stories of Denise, Julie, Rachael, Pat and Susie - from their descriptions of the event to their experiences with the police and in court and beyond - were the fuel that ran the engine of this film. Powerful stuff.

Denise, for example, could see the chimney of her house when she was raped in a field by a man brandishing scissors. She remembered thinking as she was attacked "If I don't get him off, I'll be found naked by joggers like you see in the paper and how humiliating would that be." Pat, meanwhile, was raped by her husband after years of abuse and heartache. "He tied me up and did a lot worse,"she said, trapping a sob in her throat and refusing to let it out.

It goes without saying (or rather it doesn't) that these women were chosen for their eloquence but something that always gets me is the extraordinary composure of contributors to programmes such as this and last week's Positive Women. I know there is definitely a therapy in the telling and retelling of the story - by capturing a trauma in language, codifying it, it can be subdued and controlled - but still, it is quite mind-blowing that they have managed to get their heads round their situations, albeit some more successfully than others. Unflinching and honest, one of the most harrowing moments in Raped came when Julie said solemnly "I wish someone would tell me why I hate myself."

Coughlan deserves further credit for making a documentary about such a subject without resorting to cliche. Protecting rape victims' identities necessitates silhouettes and footage of things other than their faces, but thankfully Raped resisted ponderous shots of fidgeting hands, its subjects looking mournfully out of windows and the worst trick of all, crude reconstructions of women being grabbed from behind, eyes wide with fear. Yes, there were silhouettes and close-ups on the detritus of domesticity - mug trees, spider plants, net curtains - but these served as reminders that trauma can't always be neatly packed away, even with retelling, and that misogyny is as much a part of our culture as kitchen roll holders, sewing scissors and portable tellies perched on breakfast bars.

Ground Force Goes East (BBC1). Unfortunately, it is coming back again but not before Alan, Charlie, Tommy and the other one inflict their own particular brand of horticultural imperialism on the good folks of the Palna children's home in Old Delhi. There were to be water features (one of which looked like a toilet), avenues of palm trees and a sandstone patio. All of this was to complement a tree in the middle of the garden, which was to be its focal point, Alan explained, shortly before it was almost knocked down by a JCB.

More worrying than this, however, was Tommy's choice of trousers. Evidently nonplussed by all the attention Braless Charlie has been getting, he has taken to wearing the tightest denim shorts in the world, not to mention dressing to the left. Surely that can't be comfortable? With all that heavy lifting, he is bound to pop something and no amount of crazy paving will divert attention from a man from Hackney in agony.

"What do you say to a woman," asks Alvin Hall on Ground Force Goes East (BBC2), "who wanted to spend her entire adult life relying on her husband?"

This is a multiple choice question.

a) Are you mad?

b) Haven't you heard of feminism?

c) Love the shoes, Imelda?

d) All of the above?

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Shallow Grave | The 13th Warrior | Live Test Match Cricke
fields.body:
Films

Crazy People
(Tony Bill, 1990)
8pm, Sky Cinema

A comic swipe at the honourable profession of advertising. Dudley Moore plays an ad-man who starts writing the truth (shock, horror) about his products and is naturally enough carted off to the asylum, where he galvanises fellow patients, including Darryl Hannah. It's all a bit obvious, but charming.

Lock, Stock And Two Smoking Barrels
(Guy Ritchie, 1998)
10pm, Sky Premier

This tale of four East End lads losing out to local villain 'Atchet 'Arry (PH Moriarty) in a fixed card game, and their attempts to drum up the half-million they owe him, has prompted umpteen Brit gangster movies aiming to cash in on its extraordinary success. There are big pluses - Vinnie Jones's enforcer, Lenny McClean's gruesome Barry the Baptist, a stonking soundtrack and some rich gags.

Shallow Grave
(Danny Boyle, 1994)
10pm, FilmFour

Boyle's debut is a nerve-straining thriller with a macabre sense of humour and a trio of powerful acting talents. Ewan McGregor, Chris Eccleston and Kerry Fox are the flatmates left with a couple of problems: a case full of cash and a corpse. Friendship dies quickly amid increasingly bizarre events - a dismembering; a loony in the attic; and the sadistic thugs out of a sort of Brit Pulp Fiction.

The 13th Warrior
(John McTiernan, 1999)
10pm, Sky Movie Max

This atmospheric saga has a 10th-century band of Vikings - a sort of dark ages dirty dozen - travelling to help countrymen beset by a people-devouring, Grendel-like "ancient evil", which proves to be a tribe of ferocious cannibals. With them on their quest is Antonio Banderas's Arab emissary, the 13th warrior, and recorder of heroic deeds. At times the film's grim sense of epic matches Braveheart, but there were production problems, and it appears to have been hacked about by one of the Norse axemen.

The Pawnbroker
(Sidney Lumet, 1965)
1.30am, Sky Cinema

Sol Nazerman, a middle-aged survivor of the Holocaust, owns a run-down pawnshop in Harlem. Alienated, mired in memories of the rest of his family, who died in the concentration camps, he lives in his own cold world, conducting a passionless affair with his best friend's widow (Marketa Kimbrell), until events conspire to bring him back to reality. Lumet's drama at times looks rather theatrical, but it is bleakly compelling. Quincy Jones's music adds to the harsh urban tone, but the film belongs to Rod Steiger, and his towering performance as Nazerman.

Sports

Live Test Match Cricket
4pm, 6.30pm, Sky Sports

Extra In England it's back to the drudgery of county cricket. But elsewhere, on sunnier shores, there are test series to complete. Today sees the start of the fifth and final test beween West Indies and South Africa. Like so many of the winter series, it's been an often fascinating battle. But the visitors have already won it, taking a 2-0 lead by winning the fourth Test, which perhaps explains why Sky have hidden it on their digital-only channel.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Crossing Continents | The Material World | Evening Concert
fields.body:
The Indian government was very wary of getting involved when, after independence, a few brave souls launched an indigenous film industry. Delhi was convinced it would be a financial black hole. As we all know, Bollywood was a runaway success, and now churns out 20 new films a week. But, as Lucy Willmore reports in Crossing Continents (11.0am, Radio 4), its original seed money came from organised crime syndicates, and they now ruthlessly control studios and stars.

In The Material World (4.30pm, Radio 4) Quentin Cooper hears how learning to tie a clove hitch or bowline may help unravel some of the mysteries of the universe. According to Professors Keith Devlin and Ian Stewart, the mathematical theory underlying the nature of knots may help scientists with several current mysteries. These range from the behaviour of DNA strands to the composition of string-like space-time particles, which some think necessary for a convincing Grand Unified Theory.

With Holy Week well behind him, Nicholas Tresilian feels safe enough to opt for a diabolical theme for the Evening Concert (9.0pm, Classic FM). All tonight's pieces have been inspired in one way or another by the Devil. The greatest proportion, of course, are settings of Goethe's Faust. Among the many who produced orchestral versions of the tale were Wagner, Gounod, Sarasate and Boulanger.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst:
Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk
Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments, please.
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
Patent greed
Software is not like Albanian (Bob Young of Red Hat, quoted in your Free Agents article on open source/free software, April 12). Software is like a story written in Albanian. And if I wrote stories in Albanian, I would like the right to protect them. That is not to say that everyone who read them would have to pay, but that if someone made a blockbuster Hollywood movie out of one of them, I would at least like my name on the credits.

I take the trouble to stake that small claim in the context of Linux/GNU because my suspicions are aroused whenever big business announces its support for anything, as it has for Linux/GNU: I suspect the dollar signs are flickering before its corporate eyes.

When the lawyer Justin Watts so angered Richard Stallman by suggesting patents for the free software movement's work, perhaps that was what he had in mind, particularly as we stand, gobsmacked, watching big business being allowed, effectively, patents on human beings, in the form of DNA sequences. I plan to consult Mr Watts about the possibility of patenting a system of blood oxygenation by muscle-powered thoracic intake and expulsion of air via the nasal and oral passages.
Martin Hillman
marthillman@yahoo.co.uk

Digital delay
Digital radio may or may not be "on the move" (Online April 12) but if the new generation of digital baseband chips and digital receiver modules are to make a difference, they will have to be produced in greater quantities than the industry has yet been able to manage. Over the last few months, one major retailer in central Manchester has managed to have two different varieties of digital audio broadcasting tuner more or less continuously on display, but while Classic FM continues to run promotional commercials for "Digital radio - tomorrow's wireless!" few specialist hi-fi retailers have the equipment available for purchase. There are two specialist retailers in central Manchester who only occasionally have DAB tuners and the best hi-fi outlet in Bolton simply can't get equipment from the manufacturers. Are there problems on the production side? I think we should be told. Peter Johnston
peter.johnston@bolton.gov.uk

No substitute
I feel I must comment on Andy Howell's letter regarding his experiences with Telewest's interactive TV. He says he is pleasantly surprised. I have NTL's digital TV system - it is appallingly slow and unreliable. And unless it is much improved, I cannot see myself being able, never mind willing to use it instead of a PC. Lee Yarkess
lee@brierfield.co.uk

Poor service
As a Telewest Active Digital subscriber for some time, I had to read Andy Howell's letter twice to make sure I hadn't dreamt what it said.

Was the service I had tried and given up on really "clearly reliable and useful"? In case they had upgraded it in recent weeks, I tried it out again.

No. It's still incredibly slow, with each "page" taking between 5 and 30 seconds to refresh. Many pages still fail to appear at all and the content is usually less useful than either teletext or the internet.

For a while, Telewest had us in a stranglehold as, when they persuaded us to move from analogue to digital, they assured us that the suddenly absent teletext service for terrestrial channels would be restored "very soon". I think that the fact that these have only just reappeared is because their substitute Active Digital info pages still don't bear comparison for speed, reliability or usefulness. If it's just my region that is affected (the South West), I await a visit from a Telewest engineer with eager anticipation.
Colin Malsingh
Bristol

Sound tradeoff
On page 5, April 12, Ashley Norris wrote: "...digital tuner... with sound quality that is superior to FM transmissions.." The alleged superiority of DAB over FM is highly debatable. But don't take my word, look at Hi-Fi News (May). Just one quote: "Even more than CD, digital radio has a thin, cold character. The original studio-quality sound has been considerably reduced before transmission, to around the level of the MP3 music traded on the internet."

The potential of the technology is being wasted to maximise use of the transmitting bandwith. As with CD, "the perfect sound forever" which only now is being finally improved, with super compact audio disc and DVD-Audio, commercial considerations will give us a poorer product than the existing analogue one.
Roger Perry
roger.perry@tesco.net

Radio request
You report on the availability of new Digital Audio Broadcasting chips to fit handheld devices. Most of us waiting to switch to DAB radios would be happy for one of the long promised portable radios to appear. Michael Pritchard
mpritchard@cix.co.uk

fields.headline: Mobile phones
fields.standfirst: Hans Snook is founder and adviser to Orange, the recently floated mobile network operator
fields.trailText: Hans Snook is founder and adviser to Orange, the recently floated mobile network operator
fields.body:
When did you first use a mobile? In 1986 in Hong Kong just after I joined Hutchison. It was the world's first true portable, the Motorola "brick", which really took off there. But it wasn't until I came to the UK for Hutchison [which originally funded Orange] that I saw how mobiles would change everyone's lives.

Did Orange overpay for its 3G licence? No. The price operators paid will ultimately be seen as conservative, once the true potential of mobile services is clear. Penetration growth curves could reach 300% and beyond.

What will 3G be used for? One of the biggest uses to begin with will be voice. In Scandinavia, more than 50% of all calls are made on mobiles, and within five years 50% of all UK calls will be made from mobiles. Buying the licence gives us lots of extra radio spectrum, so we will be able to promote mobile harder as a replacement for fixed telephony .

Are mobiles the new wallets? Yes, and this will create a major new revenue stream for 3G. Mobiles will become like a Mastercard or Visa card, enabling users to buy things in shops or online. With the addition of Bluetooth, the short-range radio technology, they will even be able to read the barcodes on products. Charges of less than 1% a transaction will let people buy low-cost items such as newspapers, but with trillions of transactions we will still make money.

Will mobile data take off? It already has. Text messages now account for 8% of Orange's revenue and 3G will give users the ability to be constantly online. So if I like the music I'm hearing on an online radio station, I can get an SMS saying what it is and asking if I want to buy it. With 3G's higher data speeds, email will increasingly be used on mobiles too.

So, will data replace voice? No. I see voice as being at the centre of what we do. We already have a voice-activated assistant, Wildfire, who can answer the phone for you. But the plan is to combine that with the search technology we acquired when we bought the virtual newscaster Ananova from the Press Association. That will turn Ananova into a personal assistant, so you'll be able to say: "Ananova I'm going to the US next week, I want details of flights." Or "I want the business headlines." She'll search the internet and come back with what you need.

Will 3G spell the death of the newspaper? I think people still like the tactile quality of a newspaper. But eventually you'll have a sheet of plastic that you project the news on to using Bluetooth. Video over 3G will be useful too - for travellers wanting to catch the TV news or Jennifer Lopez's barely-there top at the Oscars.

What kind of mobile do you have now? A Motorola Timeport with a silver, metallic finish. I travel a lot so it's useful having a phone that can work on any European mobile phone network and on some US networks. It's also a Wap phone. It's a bit flash, but I'm not really.

fields.headline: Text poem competition
fields.trailText: What next
fields.body:
A big thanks to the thousands of readers and others who entered Online's pioneering interactive text message poetry competition. The competition, done in association with our web site, Guardian Unlimited and Consult Hyperion, ended last Friday. Since then our specialist team has been sifting the entries down to 100 to present to our expert panel which meets today (April 19).

The panel - poets U A Fanthorpe and Peter Sansom accompanied by Guardian Unlimited's books editor, Justine Jordan - will winnow them down to the best seven entries.

What next

On Sunday, April 22, every entrant will be sent a text message to remind them that the interactive stage is about to begin.

April 23 to April 29:
Each day every entrant will be texted one of the final seven poems to their phone. They will be asked to give a mark out of 10 for each one (numerals, please) and send it back as soon as possible. Only entrants who have replied to the first entry will be sent subsequent poems.

May 3:
Results and samples from the final 100 entries will be published in Online.

Details:
www.theguardian.com/mobilepoems

fields.headline: Games watch
fields.trailText: Burned | Great British
fields.body:
Burned
Judge Bray at Leicester Crown Court put the boot into the British games software industry, though he did sentence a pirate to 30 months' imprisonment for defrauding BT by "chipping" mobile phones.

The judge said: "Counterfeiting of games is now so widespread and the reason is the public feel that there is gross overcharging by manufacturers of discs."

Another defendant in the case was ordered to do 150 hours of community service and pay £5,500 compensation: he admitted selling several thousand games discs to friends for £5 each.

Terry Anslow, the chief inspector of the Elspa (European Leisure Software Publishers Association,) crime unit, said: "Many of the remarks made by Judge Bray were uninformed, his know- ledge of the games industry is not what it should be."

Great British
"A New Britannia shall rise!" Lord British, the game name of Richard Garriott, plans to get some of his old team together and start coding, according to an interview in Computer Games Online. Garriott's company, Origin, was taken over by Electronic Arts, but it was not a happy experience. EA recently dumped Ultima Online 2 and its development staff.

"We will pick up the pieces and start again. I believe that we have the right idea, the right time, and the right people to do it again," said Garriott. The American games guru also claimed to be "the world's only private owner of an object on a foreign celestial body". He bought Lunakod 21 from the Russians. It is on the moon.

The movie
Final Fantasy, the movie, will reach UK screens in August. The film is a photo-realistic animation based on the series of role-playing games, and is being puffed as a "cinematic breakthrough [that] heralds a new era in digital storytelling".

It "raises the standard by which all other animation films will be judged". The plot concerns the efforts of the few surviving humans to hang on (this is Earth, 2065). For a brief synopsis and a tiny trailer in QuickTime format, go to www.finalfantasy-themovie.co.uk.

Nose news
DigiScents, which planned to add smells to software, closed its offices in California last week.

The two-year-old private company has not shipped a product and has been unable to raise more capital, though it still plans to license its iSmell technology. Synthetic smells could have added a new dimension to a number of video games, including SimFarm and Sega Bass Fishing.

fields.headline: Games reviews
fields.trailText: Shadow of Memories | Unreal Tournament | Banjo Tooie
fields.byline: Greg Howson, Mark Hill  and  Mike Anderiesz
fields.body:
Shadow of Memories

Sony PlayStation 2 £39.99 Konami **
Poor Eike - he can't turn his back without someone sticking the knife (or dagger) in. Luckily, he has a digipad - a time-travelling gadget that lets him go back through the ages and prevent his recurring murder.

Yes, for once we can forget about aliens, orcs and racing cars - Shadows of Memories is set in a German town full of ageing museum owners and shy waitresses. But it is not only the characterisation that is refreshing. SoM's time-travelling mystery premise is nothing if not original.

For example, one level sees you transported back to the 16th century to prevent the planting of a tree that will be used as cover by your assailant 400 years later. Everything you do in the past has an impact on the future and some lateral thinking is required to succeed.

However, keeping such a tangled plot together means there are a lot of cut-scenes, which while beautifully animated, don't involve interaction. You'll often feel like you are watching a film or reading a book - not exactly what you'd bought your PS2 for.

Then there is the incredibly linear progression of the game. You are often told where to go to find the next clue (and cut-scene) and although your choices do influence the ending, the handholding quickly becomes irksome.

Konami has described SoM as a digital novel, which isn't too far off the truth, and it is likely the title will appeal to the type of non-action games player who enjoyed Myst.

An admirable attempt at offering something new, Shadow of Memories' narrative is engrossing, it is graphically impressive and genuinely different. What it isn't, alas, is much of a game. (GH)

Unreal Tournament

Sony PlayStation 2 £39.99 Epic/Infogrames ***
The bloodthirst that made gladiatorial fights the sport of choice for ancient Romans hasn't abated, it has merely become digitised.

In Unreal Tournament the gladiators chase each other around futuristic arenas, medieval castles suspended in space and dark coliseums of steel, with high-powered pistols, rocket launchers and laser rifles.

And although their deaths often leave splashes of gore on the walls and chunks of flesh on the floor, they are instantaneously resurrected until a victor achieves a certain number of kills or frags.

Like the faster Quake III and the more sophisticated Counter-Strike, Unreal Tournament was originally a huge PC success. On a computer you can take part in colossal battles with dozens of other players, as part of a team or in a vicious and relentless contest where everyone is your enemy.

But the PlayStation 2, designed as part of your living room's entertainment centre, can never hope to recreate that online experience. Sure, you can invite your mates over to share a small portion of the screen or even link a couple of machines together, but it's not quite the same.

The single-player game is shortlived and the fun of shattering a bot's skull with a well-placed sniper shot is virtually removed by the auto-aiming system. And let's not forget that playing a fast and furious multiplayer first- person shooter with a gamepad is like eating tomato soup with chopsticks.

The PC's mouse and keyboard combination has evolved into a perfect interface in the hands of experienced players, allowing a degree of control that is swift, natural and accurate.

Unlike Quake III, UT allows you plug in a USB mouse and keyboard, but who wants to sit in front of the TV with that sort of office furniture?

Amid constant talk of the battle of the consoles, with Microsoft still hard at work on the Xbox and Nintendo yet to raise the portcullis on the Game Cube, it would be good to see some imagination poured into the Sony machine rather than polished but unnecessary conversions. (MH)

Banjo Tooie

N64 £44.99 Rare/Nintendo ****

It is fitting that this game should be released so close to Black & White. If Peter Molyneux is Britain's finest games designer, then Rare is certainly the best development team, having churned out impressive titles since the days of the ZX Spectrum. Banjo Tooie is the belated follow-up to Banjo Kazooie, released a couple of years ago to favourable reviews.

Kazooie fans will be in seventh heaven, as the game features most of the old characters, moves and locations plus a truckfull of new ones. In describing the plot, suffice to say that Banjo and Kazooie are still a bear and a bird who travel and work together but now have an increased tendency to separate and develop their powers independently. Between them they have around 80 moves and attacks, a baffling number of options that are easy to execute and never available at the same time.

Predictably for an N64 game, collecting some kind of token is essential to making progress - in this instance "jiggies" - which are randomly strewn across every level. As you might expect from Rare, everything looks and sounds terrific. Vast sugar-coloured 3D levels, intelligent and imaginative enemies, a smattering of puzzles and breathtaking set-pieces.

The platform game setting is merely a shell for cramming in as many genres as possible, from shooting games to driving, flying and racing. Be warned, however, that some of the puzzles are fiendishly cryptic Despite the technical magnificence, BT remains an acquired taste. I find the two main characters strangely charmless, especially compared to other platform- poseurs such as Zelda, Mario or even Sonic. Yes, the game rewards persistence with a constant supply of challenges but the controls remain fiddly, the camera angle sluggish and I was content to play the game for just an hour or so - hardly my definition of a true classic.

If you love arcade adventures, check it out, if you're expecting the next quantum leap in platform gaming wait and see what Rare are planning for the Nintendo Gamecube later this year. (MA)

fields.headline: John Fahey
fields.standfirst: Legendary acoustic blues guitarist and pioneer of vernacular music
fields.trailText: Legendary acoustic blues guitarist and pioneer of vernacular music.
fields.body:
The guitarist John Fahey, who has died in hospital after a heart bypass operation aged 61, was a rebellious spirit who pioneered a new strain in American music. Fahey's explorations and inventions, initially animated by the blues but eventually drawing upon other vernacular forms, inspired many of the guitarists involved in "new age" music, although some of his last playing was alongside spiky rock bands less than half his age.

He was born in rural Maryland, where as a boy he fished and raised turtles, creatures with which he felt a special bond: they recur in the titles and artwork of his early albums. His parents were musicians, and the family often visited the New River Ranch country music park in Rising Sun, Maryland, where Fahey heard bluegrass and country stars.

The music marked him permanently - years later he would publish an essay collection, How Bluegrass Music Destroyed My Life - and his direction in life was further determined by meeting Frank Hovington, a black singer and guitarist whose delicate fingerpicking led him to take up guitar himself.

Falling in with the collectors Joe Bussard and Dick Spottswood and joining them in record-hunting trips through the suburbs of Washington DC, Fahey encountered the African-American blues and gospel artists of the 1920s and 30s. His first hearing of the singer and slide-guitarist Blind Willie Johnson, he said, made him physically sick; the second time, he was "smote to the ground by a bolt of lightning".

He made a number of recordings for Bussard's private label Fonotone, some under the pseudonym Blind Thomas, then embarked on what may have been a full-blown hoax, recording an album of blues and blues-like tunes in the persona Blind Joe Death. On moving to Berkeley in 1963 he and a friend, Ed Denson, created the Takoma label to issue The Transfiguration Of Blind Joe Death - which has been called the most famous obscure album of recent times - and other collections of Fahey's instrumentals, in which blues tonalities cohabit with an almost Buddhist meditativeness.

In 1964, he was one of the first graduates of the University of California at Los Angeles's new folklore course; his MA thesis on the blues musician Charlie Patton, when published in 1971, was the first monograph on a country blues artist. He was also part of the group of collector- researchers who located, and briefly revived the careers of, the bluesmen Skip James and Booker White.

Takoma Records became a home for guitarists with similar interests, such as Leo Kottke and George Winston, while Fahey himself was taken up by larger labels such as Vanguard and Reprise, his recordings uniting with those of Kottke, William Ackerman, Robbie Basho and others to form the gene pool of new age guitar music.

Fahey suffered from erratic health and alcoholism, and for a period in the 1980s and early 90s seemed to have disappeared. Journalists tracked him down in Oregon, where he was washing dishes in shelters for the homeless. When he recommenced playing in public, it was not in his old idiom, but closer to the distorted electric-guitar music of bands like Sonic Youth, although his last tapes include tunes by Irving Berlin and George Gershwin.

To many of those who met him, Fahey seemed brusque and odd. The journalist Eddie Dean described him as "contentious, cantankerous ... exile and alienation [were] what he identified with in his heroes, loners such as Patton, restless revenants".

Appropriately, one of his last projects was to create, with record-collector Dean Blackwood, another label dedicated to obscure American vernacular music and call it Revenant.

fields.headline: Dennis Curry
fields.standfirst: The electronic goods magnate whose passion was geology
fields.trailText: The electronic goods magnate whose passion was geology.
fields.body:
Dennis Curry, who has died aged 88, became distinguished in two totally different walks of life: as managing director and chairman of Currys Ltd, the high-street chain, and visiting professor of marine geology at University College, London.

Born in Leicester, Dennis was the eldest son of a family of six. His grandfather had founded the family business - initially as a one-man cycle-making operation - but it was his father, Albert Curry, and three brothers who built it up. Dennis's early life was spent in Brighton and Bournemouth: he was quite exceptional at school, and passed all his exams a year early. His life-long obsession with geology started when his father took him on fishing trips near Newhaven. When he became bored, he took to examining the nearby cliffs for fossils.

In 1930, he got a scholarship to Jesus College, Cambridge, and gained a double-first in natural sciences. He was awarded the Harkness scholarship, which enabled him to stay up for an extra year and gave him the time to undertake the research for his first geological paper (1937).

At the time, the university department was a remarkable array of established names and enthusiastic youngsters, so Dennis was keen to stay on.

However, as the eldest son, it was the family tradition that he must follow in his father's footsteps into the "firm". There was a huge row, but in the end Dennis buckled under and joined Currys as a 21-year-old member of the buying department at head office in London, concentrating on the radio side. In 1938, he was appointed a director.

He joined the RAF in 1942, making use of his expertise to spend the rest of the war training recruits in the use of the latest developments in radio and radar equipment. After the war, he became one of four joint managing directors. Great expansion followed, with sales of televisions, fridges and washing machines taking over from bicycles. Finally, in 1967, he became chairman, before retiring from the company in 1984.

However, all this time Dennis had been attaining equal prominence in geology. He often commented that, in retrospect, he was always glad that he had joined Currys, as it had given him more time to devote to geology than any academic career would have done.

Early in his business career, he would spend the evenings working on his "hobby" in his London hotel, then commuting back to Bournemouth at the weekends. Later, as a family man, any trip into the countryside, any holiday overseas was an excuse to investigate the local geology. On the return trip, the car would be laden with rock samples and fossils, while the children sat on top of them: the family quickly learned to tolerate these idiosyncrasies.

Dennis's research interests were wide, including fossil molluscs (such as clams and snails); the beautiful, but tiny foraminifera (simple, single-celled animals with shells); and the chalk and overlying Tertiary rocks of Britain, France and Belgium. He helped produce the first detailed geological maps of the English Channel. With French geologists (he was fluent in French), he greatly advanced the study of radiometric dating of the Early Tertiary.

In all, he produced more than 50 scientific papers, was president of the Geologists' Association (1963-65), and was for many years a prominent member of the International Sub-Commission on Palaeogene Stratigraphy (a body set up to oversee the naming of rocks deposited about 25-65 million years ago).

It is fitting that he was made a visiting professor at University College, London, in 1971, and had the rare honour of receiving a key to the Natural History Museum, London, which over the years has been the recipient of his research material.

To everyone who knew him, Dennis was a gentle, honest and kind man. As a philanthropist, he set up charitable trusts which have helped the Geologists' Association, the Geological Society of London, the Maritime Trust (he was also a keen yachtsman), and the St Richard's Hospital, Chichester (he had retired to nearby Itchenor), to name but a few. His huge fossil collections, and his research library have now all been donated to the Natural History Museum, with money to assist in their curation.

His wife, Joyce d'Arcy, whom he married in 1937, predeceased him. He is survived by a son and two daughters.

Dennis Curry, businessman, geologist and philanthropist, born May 18 1912; died March 3 2001

fields.headline: Error of judgment
fields.standfirst:
Sharon tests the limits of US support

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, destroyed four Palestinian border posts during Tuesday's ill-fated reoccupation of territory in the Gaza Strip. The damage he did to Israel was infinitely greater.
fields.body:
The Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, destroyed four Palestinian border posts during Tuesday's ill-fated reoccupation of territory in the Gaza Strip. The damage he did to Israel was infinitely greater. The repercussions of that adventure, which lasted less than 24 hours and resulted in the death of one Palestinian and injuries to 38 others, will be felt in Israel and internationally for a long time to come.

Mr Sharon sent his troops into a Palestinian autonomous area in Gaza at dawn and pulled them out again by nightfall under pressure from the US secretary of state, Colin Powell, who described the action as "excessive and disproportionate". By US standards, it was a harsh judgement.

The initial reaction within Israel yesterday was surprisingly subdued. Right-wing Jewish settlers protested that Israel, by bowing to US pressure, had ceased to be an independent country. That was a minority view. There was little criticism, even from the left, for his calamitous action. But there should be a clamour of criticism coming from within Israel. Mr Sharon was elected on a ticket of bringing security to Israel after the uncertain touch of his predecessor, Ehud Barak, and he has failed.

For the Palestinians, one of the most potent images leading up to their uprising was the disarray that accompanied the Israeli withdrawal from south Lebanon last year. The message they can draw from Tuesday's events, perhaps wrongly but dangerously, is that Israel is weak, susceptible to international pressure.

The Palestinians have reason to hope that international opinion may be tilting in their favour, even in the US. In spite of the seemingly friendly reception given to Mr Sharon by President Bush, the new administration may have one eye on Arab public opinion and those countries' huge oil deposits. It is not just the US which is showing signs of impatience with Mr Sharon. International agreements are supposed to be sacrosanct. Israel signed up to the Oslo accords, agreeing that parts of Gaza and the West Bank would be under the autonomous control of the Palestinian authority. To the dismay of world opinion, Sharon breached that agreement.

The Palestinians will take comfort from the disarray within Israeli ranks. Mr Sharon, astonishingly for a former general, shifted part of the blame on to the general in the field who had said publicly the army would remain in the Palestinian autonomous area for "days, weeks or months". Mr Sharon's spokesman, rather than admit that the prime minister had succumbed to US pressure, criticised the general for his remarks.

The Sharon adventure failed even at its most basic level. If it was intended to stop Palestinian mortar attacks, as the Israeli PM said, then it had no impact. The Palestinians opened fire again yesterday. Israel is right to place responsibility for such attacks on the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat. Part of the Oslo accord was that the Palestinian authority should ensure that attacks were not launched from its territory against Israel. If Mr Arafat is to create a truly independent Palestinian state, he must ensure that that state alone has a monopoly of military and police control and curb groups such as Hamas, Islamic Jihad and his own Fatah. Mr Sharon may have a more ominous reason for Tuesday's short incursion. He could be adopting an incremental approach, preparing Israeli and international opinion for a lengthy reoccupation. If that is his long-term aim, it is a colossal misjudgment, on par with his invasion of Lebanon in 1982, a bloody mistake that cost Israel dear.

webTitle: Flashing can lead to sex offending

fields.headline: Don't look now
fields.standfirst: It's the stuff of Benny Hill sketches and seaside postcards. But flashing can be the first step on a slippery slope of sex offending.  Anita Chaudhuri reports
fields.trailText: It's the stuff of Benny Hill sketches and seaside postcards. But flashing can be the first step on a slippery slope of sex offending. Anita Chaudhuri reports.
fields.body:
There is something about flashers, is there not, that brings out the type of nudge-nudge innuendo more commonly associated with a Benny Hill sketch than the sense of threat attached to a sex offender. This week, we were reminded of this by the antics of two "zip experts" battling it out at Maidstone magistrates court. Andrew Chatfield, a 45-year-old police officer, has pleaded not guilty of deliberately flashing at a group of women in the lounge of an old people's home. The case rests on whether the corduroy trouser flies, which had a tooth locking mechanism, could have come undone accidentally.

The case raises an important issue. Should we be trivialising a crime that is classed as a sexual offence? Little is ever discussed about the motivation of flashers beyond the neat stereotype of the sad loner in a grubby mac. A common response among women on the receiving end of this most unwanted revelation is to laugh and walk away. Perhaps this is why so many cases go unreported, despite the fact that, on anecdotal evidence, the crime appears to be prevalent.

Most women of my acquaintance say they have been flashed at on at least one if not several occasions. The Home Office doesn't record indecent exposure figures annually but the number of men being proceeded against is declining sharply. In 1997, the most up-to-date figures available, the numbers had fallen by half to 1,315 cases. It is not clear why this is, but a major factor must surely be that we are taking the crime less seriously.

According to police and sex therapists who treat flashers, the "harmless old git" tag is wildly off-beam. The flasher is more likely to be a young man - they start offending in their teens and, unless treated, continue throughout their lives - who may, over time, branch out into more serious contact sex crimes, including rape. Flashers are also highly likely to become involved in crimes against children. The law is widely regarded as being ineffective and the Home Office has been preparing for a judicial review since 1974.

Flashers tend to be arrested under Section 4 of the 1824 Vagrancy Act which states that "every person wilfully, openly, lewdly and obscenely exposing his person with intent to insult any female ... shall be deemed a rogue and vagabond." The maximum penalty is three months in prison on summary conviction, one year on a second conviction. Even if a woman does go to the police - and they do advise women to report every incident, no matter how trivial - under existing law there is not much hope of the culprit being caught. Police usually need to catch the man in the act before they can make an arrest.

Women's personal reactions inevitably vary according to context. Lorraine MacDonald was on her way to a party with two female friends on a Saturday evening a fortnight ago. After a couple of beers in the pub, they headed off to a nearby station where they stood waiting for a train to take them from south London into town. It was 8pm and reasonably busy. MacDonald was idly looking down the platform to check the train indicator board when something attracted her attention. She abruptly squealed with laughter, nudging both her friends to take a look. Soon they, too, were convulsed with giggles.

"I've seen better on the end of a cocktail stick, mate," yelled one of the friends. "Yeah, that looks like a penis, only smaller," heckled the other. The man parked on a nearby bench did not conform to the recognisable stereotype of your common or garden flasher. He was in his 20s, reasonably attractive and seemed nonplussed by the volley of insults from the women.

"At first I couldn't believe my eyes - it was sticking right out of his trousers. He was looking straight at us, too. Laughing seemed to deflate him, though - at any rate it made him put it away," MacDonald says. "After a couple of minutes he got up and walked out of the station. Our train arrived and although we laughed about it throughout the evening, we didn't give much thought to the guy. It certainly didn't occur to us to report it to the police."

But sometimes there is a greater sense of threat. Mary Dunn was flashed at while taking a rest from jogging in Regents Park in her lunch hour. "I was standing having a drink when this guy appeared from behind a tree. At first I thought he was relieving himself but he stood there waving it at me. My first reaction was to laugh. It was fairly busy, so I didn't feel threatened, although he was only a few yards away."

To Dunn's surprise, though, a few days later she found herself dwelling on the incident. "I couldn't get the image out of my mind and that began to make me feel anxious and upset."

Walking home from the station the following week - a route she had taken many times before - Dunn says she suddenly didn't feel as safe as she usually did. "It began to dawn on me that I did feel violated by what had happened, even though I'd thought it was a big joke at the time."

In fact Dunn is not alone in reacting this way following an encounter with a flasher; although most will regard the event as too trivial to take to the police, many women feel offended, ashamed and even guilty afterwards. A study cited in the Home Office review paper supports this view, stating that in 100 victims of indecent exposure, "fear, shock and disgust were the most common reactions, and that the fear concerned was the fear of death."

"We see a lot of women who have been victims of flashers," says Tamara Wilder of Victim Support. "Just because it is a fairly common thing, as an offence it seems to have been trivialised, which does not necessarily reflect what a woman goes through when it happens to her. Depending on the circumstances, it can be a very uncomfortable experience, primarily because you don't know what the man is going to do next. A lot of women do not want to report the offence to the police. They may well be asking themselves if they were in some way to blame for what happened, if they could have subconsciously encouraged the flasher to have behaved that way because of the way she was dressed or the way she looked at him."

As a general rule, ought we as women to be taking the crime more seriously? "Yes," says Daniel Wilcox, a forensic psychologist in Birmingham who treats sex offenders, including flashers, for the probation service. "Where a person gets into deviance, they are very likely to move into other offences. Typically, flashers have the highest crossover of all sex offenders into crimes against children. With flashers, people tend to focus on the jokes, but other behaviours will develop, such as rape, bestiality, assault."

This is not to say that the flasher you see on the railway platform today is a rapist. "They work up to committing more serious crimes over time," Wilcox says. "However, flashers are prone to stalking, rubbing themselves up against women in crowded trains (frottage) and sending offensive pornographic letters and photographs to targeted women; it's part of the offender profile."

So, given all of that, here's a final dilemma for us all. How do you deal with the flasher? Is it wise to shout abuse or should we not react at all?

"Ignore him and walk away," Wilcox advises. "Flashing is an angry act. These men are so unskilled at communicating with women, they tell me they would find it easier to flash at a woman than to go up and say hello. Remember, he wants a reaction and if you do react, he may well convince himself that you secretly like what he's doing. For example, if you walk past a garden where a flasher operates regularly, he will tell himself that you are going that way because you desire to see him."

Perhaps the solution rests with a team of clinical psychiatrists in America. They recently pioneered successful treatment of flashers by lining up a row of female volunteers at a clinic. The flasher was told to expose himself. The women stood there poker-faced and didn't react at all - the ultimate trauma for a flasher. Such programmes could be effective here, too, but for one crucial problem. Volunteers.

The maximum penalty is three months in prison on summary conviction, one year on a second conviction. Even if a woman does go to the police - and they do advise women to report every incident, no matter how trivial - under existing law there is not much hope of the culprit being caught. Police usually need to catch the man in the act before they can make an arrest. Women's personal reactions inevitably vary according to context. Lorraine MacDonald was on her way to a party with two female friends on a Saturday evening a fortnight ago. After a couple of beers in the pub, they headed off to a nearby station where they stood waiting for a train to take them from south London into town. It was 8pm and reasonably busy. MacDonald was idly looking down the platform to check the train indicator board when something attracted her attention. She abruptly squealed with laughter, nudging both her friends to take a look. Soon they, too, were convulsed with giggles. "I've seen better on the end of a cocktail stick, mate," yelled one of the friends. "Yeah, that looks like a penis, only smaller," heckled the other. The man parked on a nearby bench did not conform to the recognisable stereotype of your common or garden flasher. He was in his 20s, reasonably attractive and seemed nonplussed by the volley of insults from the women. "At first I couldn't believe my eyes - it was sticking right out of his trousers. He was looking straight at us, too. Laughing seemed to deflate him, though - at any rate it made him put it away," MacDonald says. "After a couple of minutes he got up and walked out of the station. Our train arrived and although we laughed about it throughout the evening, we didn't give much thought to the guy. It certainly didn't occur to us to report it to the police." But sometimes there is a greater sense of threat. Mary Dunn was flashed at while taking a rest from jogging in Regents Park in her lunch hour. "I was standing having a drink when this guy appeared from behind a tree. At first I thought he was relieving himself but he stood there waving it at me. My first reaction was to laugh. It was fairly busy, so I didn't feel threatened, although he was only a few yards away." To Dunn's surprise, though, a few days later she found herself dwelling on the incident. "I couldn't get the image out of my mind and that began to make me feel anxious and upset." Walking home from the station the following week - a route she had taken many times before - Dunn says she suddenly didn't feel as safe as she usually did. "It began to dawn on me that I did feel violated by what had happened, even though I'd thought it was a big joke at the time." In fact Dunn is not alone in reacting this way following an encounter with a flasher; although most will regard the event as too trivial to take to the police, many women feel offended, ashamed and even guilty afterwards. A study cited in the Home Office review paper supports this view, stating that in 100 victims of indecent exposure, "fear, shock and disgust were the most common reactions, and that the fear concerned was the fear of death." "We see a lot of women who have been victims of flashers," says Tamara Wilder of Victim Support. "Just because it is a fairly common thing, as an offence it seems to have been trivialised, which does not necessarily reflect what a woman goes through when it happens to her. Depending on the circumstances, it can be a very uncomfortable experience, primarily because you don't know what the man is going to do next. A lot of women do not want to report the offence to the police. They may well be asking themselves if they were in some way to blame for what happened, if they could have subconsciously encouraged the flasher to have behaved that way because of the way she was dressed or the way she looked at him." As a general rule, ought we as women to be taking the crime more seriously? "Yes," says Daniel Wilcox, a forensic psychologist in Birmingham who treats sex offenders, including flashers, for the probation service. "Where a person gets into deviance, they are very likely to move into other offences. Typically, flashers have the highest crossover of all sex offenders into crimes against children. With flashers, people tend to focus on the jokes, but other behaviours will develop, such as rape, bestiality, assault." This is not to say that the flasher you see on the railway platform today is a rapist. "They work up to committing more serious crimes over time," Wilcox says. "However, flashers are prone to stalking, rubbing themselves up against women in crowded trains (frottage) and sending offensive pornographic letters and photographs to targeted women; it's part of the offender profile." So, given all of that, here's a final dilemma for us all. How do you deal with the flasher? Is it wise to shout abuse or should we not react at all? "Ignore him and walk away," Wilcox advises. "Flashing is an angry act. These men are so unskilled at communicating with women, they tell me they would find it easier to flash at a woman than to go up and say hello. Remember, he wants a reaction and if you do react, he may well convince himself that you secretly like what he's doing. For example, if you walk past a garden where a flasher operates regularly, he will tell himself that you are going that way because you desire to see him." Perhaps the solution rests with a team of clinical psychiatrists in America. They recently pioneered successful treatment of flashers by lining up a row of female volunteers at a clinic. The flasher was told to expose himself. The women stood there poker-faced and didn't react at all - the ultimate trauma for a flasher. Such programmes could be effective here, too, but for one crucial problem. Volunteers.

fields.headline: Star's cars
fields.standfirst: Sir Elton John spring cleans his garage
fields.trailText: The famously profligate pop star Sir Elton John, who faces a £8m legal bill after losing a high court case against a former manager last week, is selling 20 of his expensive cars.
fields.body:
The famously profligate pop star Sir Elton John, who faces a £8m legal bill after losing a high court case against a former manager last week, is selling 20 of his expensive cars.

The Aston Martins, Bentleys, Jaguars, Rolls-Royces and Ferraris he keeps on his 37 acre Windsor estate have been costing him more than £5,000 a week to maintain. Recently the singer created a castellated stable for his donkeys there - but it seems things are not yet so bad he will be going to one of his extravagant balls on the back of an ass.

Christie's, due to auction the cars in June, stressed that Sir Elton was not selling out of financial necessity. "Simply, he is away so much he does not get to drive them enough," a spokeswoman said. The star still has a garage full of classic British cars - "you can't beat them for beauty and workmanship" - and is also one of the few Britons to own a Jaguar XJ220.

The sale, however, does not augur well for Watford football club, into which Sir Elton refuses to sink any more of his £140m fortune, despite the possibility of their promotion to the Premiership. One of the cars to go under the hammer is an Aston Martin V8 he calls "The Beast" which he once had painted in Watford's colours.

Sir Elton acquired his first Aston Martin in 1970, trading in his Ford Escort. He claims that "once you've driven a great car, you never want to go back".

In the sale is a 1973 Rolls-Royce Phantom VI, expected to fetch between £110,000 and £150,000, and a 1987 Ferrari Testarossa, a 40th birthday gift.

fields.headline: Airline attacker gets four years
fields.standfirst: Drunken passenger to pay £6,000 damages
fields.trailText: A drunken British holidaymaker who smashed a vodka bottle over an airline steward's head and stabbed her repeatedly, was jailed for four years yesterday by a Spanish court.
fields.body:
A drunken British holidaymaker who smashed a vodka bottle over an airline steward's head and stabbed her repeatedly, was jailed for four years yesterday by a Spanish court.

The court in Malaga, southern Spain, passed a four year and two month sentence on Steven Handy for his attack on Fiona Weir, the Airtours International steward.

Handy, aged 40, had admitted the attack but pleaded in court that he was so drunk he could not remember what had happened. He was ordered to pay £6,000 in damages to Ms Weir, 33.

Handy also admitted assaulting a Spanish police officer at Malaga airport and was ordered to pay him £610.

Ms Weir, from Wimbledon, south-west London, was discovered by police lying on the runway of Malaga airport in a pool of blood after the attack. Handy had broken the bottle over her head while the Airtours charter airplane taxied to a standstill at the airport. He then stabbed her in the back with the broken bottle.

She needed 18 stitches and was scarred for life by the attack. She told the court that she was no longer able to work as an air hostess because she was too scared. She said that the attack had also made her frightened of parties and crowds. "The last two and a half years have been an extremely painful and traumatic experience," she said after yesterday's verdict. "I call for all airlines and governments to cooperate in establishing methods to ensure no air crew or passengers' lives are put at risk like this ever again."

Handy told the court that he was so drunk, after drinking several pints of lager before getting on the aircraft at Gatwick airport, that he thought he should never have been allowed to board the plane.

"I deserve a bit of punishment," he told the Spanish judges. "I was totally drunk at the time. I remember hitting someone but I don't know why." Witnesses said that he had secretly kept drinking from the vodka bottle throughout the flight. On landing, the aircraft's captain announced that the police had been called. Ms Weir tried to calm all the passengers but Handy then plunged the broken bottle into her back as she lay in the aisle. She finally escaped by leaving by the emergency exit and collapsed on the runway.

Last year, Handy was extradited to Spain from Britain. He has already spent more than a year in prison. Under Spanish law he should be freed from jail within two years.

Yesterday, Ms Weir said she would now sue Airtours over the attack. "I can now concentrate on my civil legal case against Airtours with my lawyers. Although I tried to return to work after the assault the emotional and psychological scars caused by the attack are still healing."

Airtours International yesterday welcomed the sentence for Handy. "In line with other airlines we will not accept any behaviour that puts the safety and well being of planes' crew and passengers at risk. We are delighted that justice has been done," said Airtours spokeswoman Deborah Sadler. "We were very concerned about the incident and we have tried to give Ms Weir all the support that was necessary."

fields.headline: Policeman guilty of exposure
fields.trailText: In the end it was an open and shut case. Andrew Chatfield, 45, a police custody sergeant, was yesterday found guilty of indecently exposing himself to elderly women at a residential care home, after a two day trial that heard from two master tailors about the efficiency of Marks & Spencer's zips.
fields.body:
In the end it was an open and shut case. Andrew Chatfield, 45, a police custody sergeant, was yesterday found guilty of indecently exposing himself to elderly women at a residential care home, after a two day trial that heard from two master tailors about the efficiency of Marks & Spencer's zips.

Magistrates at Maidstone, Kent, heard that while visiting his father at the Old Downs residential home in Hartley, Kent, Chatfield, 45, was captured on a concealed camera turning to face the women, one of whom was 93, with his genitals on show.

Chatfield, of Sevenoaks, claimed that his zip had failed but he was unable to spot the exposure over his stomach - he was 21 stone at the time of the incident last March.

The magistrates heard that as soon as it was pointed out to him, by an 86-year-old woman who told him he was "flying low", Chatfield rearranged himself. "I just presumed that the zip was undone, I had no idea it was anything more than that," he told the court.

But the chairwoman of the bench, Margaret Ivell, said: "We are satisfied that this was a deliberate act and it was conducted in a lewd, obscene and insulting manner."

Earlier master tailor John Hawksley told the court that it was possible for the zip on the Chatfield's M&S cords to disengage leaving the wearer uncovered and unawares. Many overweight customers returned similar zips to his shop.

But Barbara Kilbourne, a uniform fitter with Kent police, said it was highly unlikely a zip could open without help. "They are a locking zip. They would not even come down if you had not fastened the button."

Chatfield was caught by a police surveillance operation after the home's owner warned him about his behaviour.

The case was adjourned until May 10 for sentencing.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Hospital deputy suspended
fields.body:
Hospital deputy suspended

The deputy chief executive of the top security Ashworth hospital in Merseyside has been suspended pending a independent inquiry. Allan Menkin, had worked at the hospital as finance director before his promotion last August.

Man charged over brawl

A man was charged with violent disorder, police assault and criminal damages after an alleged brawl among 40 Muslim worshippers which began in a mosque in Oldham, Greater Manchester. Mokus Miah, 26, will appear before Oldham magistrates on April 23. Five men were being interviewed in custody.

487 'big cat' sightings

Scotland has had 78 of the 487 recorded sightings of "alien big cats" in the past three years, according to research in Fortean Times magazine. In England there were 55 sightings in Gloucestershire, 52 in Cornwall, 45 in Sussex and 42 in Devon. In Wales there were 41.

Study to look at surf wave plan

A feasibility study of a scheme to build Europe's first artificial reef to create year-round "perfect waves" for surfers could begin next month. The £1m reef is proposed for Fistral beach in Cornwall. Kerry Black, surf wave specialist of Waikato University, New Zealand, will do the study.

Missing British soldier found

A British soldier who got lost on Mount Kenya has been found after a four day search by 150 army colleagues. Lance Corporal David Sheridan, 25, disappeared while descending the mountain last Friday on an exercise with 33 Engineer Regiment in Kenya.

Paint for all seasons

Heat sensitive paint that cools the house in summer and warms it in winter has been developed by Chinese scientists at Tongji University, Shanghai, New Scientist magazine reported.

fields.headline: Pedal power for paramedics
fields.trailText: Britain's flattest city launched a pioneering new ambulance service yesterday - speeding to heart attacks and broken legs on two narrow wheels and 18 gears.
fields.body:
Britain's flattest city launched a pioneering new ambulance service yesterday - speeding to heart attacks and broken legs on two narrow wheels and 18 gears.

The country's first emergency bicycle tore down the narrow medieval streets of central York to prove that pedal power can be quicker and more efficient than four wheels or even a health authority helicopter.

The experiment's manager, Paul Brown, said: "The bike can get from one side of the walled city to the other much more quickly than a conventional ambulance.

"York lends itself very well to this initiative because there's a big pedestrian area."

The modified mountain bike also has blue flashing lights and extra baskets to carry life-saving equipment, mobile communications and a defibrillator for cardiac victims.

Patients will not, however, be slung over the back of the saddle in cavalry style, but will wait for a back-up ambulance if they need to be taken for hospital treatment. Nicknamed Life Cycle, the experiment is being run for six months by the Tees, East and North Yorkshire Ambulance Service.

fields.headline: Afghans face hijack retrial after jury admits deadlock
fields.trailText: A jury at the Old Bailey was discharged yesterday after failing to reach a verdict on 10 Afghans accused of taking part in Britain's longest hijack at Stansted airport.
fields.body:
A jury at the Old Bailey was discharged yesterday after failing to reach a verdict on 10 Afghans accused of taking part in Britain's longest hijack at Stansted airport.

An 11th man, Aminullah Mohamedi, was cleared of all charges following the three-month trial that is estimated to have cost more than £5m.

The jury of six women and five men had been deliberating for 40 hours when Mr Justice Butterfield was handed a note from the jury saying it was "absolutely deadlocked" on 49 charges involving the 10 remaining defendants.

Bruce Houlder QC, prosecuting, said the crown would seek a retrial of the men who are alleged to have taken control of an Ariana Airlines flight after it had taken off from the Afghan capital, Kabul, on what was supposed to have been a 40-minute internal flight in February last year.

The aircraft, carrying 173 passengers and 14 crew - including 21 children, touched down in Tashkent, the Uzbek capital, Kazakstan and Moscow before arriving at Stansted at 2am on February 7 last year. The siege ended after three days of tense negotiations.

The defendants, Ali Safi, 35; Abdul Shohab, 21; Taimur Shah, 29; Muhammed Kazim,28; Waheed Lutfi,23; Reshed Ahmadi,19; Nazamuddin Mohammidy,27; Abdul Ghayur,25; Mohammed Showaib, 21; Aminullah Mohamedi, 41; and Mohammed Safi, 33; all denied hijacking, two charges of false imprisonment, possessing firearms with intent to cause fear of violence and posessing explosives.

After hearing submissions that there was no evidence to support the charges of hijacking and false imprisonment, the judge ordered the jury to acquit Mr Mohamedi, 41, on both counts. Not guilty verdicts were returned on the other three charges. He had told police he was employed by one of the other defendants and did not know anything about the hijack until he boarded the plane.

Waheed Lufti was cleared by the jury of hijacking but they were unable to agree a verdict on the other four charges. A 12th defendant, Khalil Ullah, 31, who fell ill during the trial faces a retrial at a later date.

The defendants were represented by a team of 24 defence barristers, including 12 QCs, while a further three barristers, including a QC, were used to present the prosecution case.

webTitle: Test case likely after boy dies in graveyard

fields.headline: Test case likely after boy dies in graveyard
fields.trailText: Councils may face a legal test case over unsafe gravestones after an inquest yesterday on a schoolboy who was crushed to death by a stone memorial.
fields.body:
Councils may face a legal test case over unsafe gravestones after an inquest yesterday on a schoolboy who was crushed to death by a stone memorial.

North Yorkshire coroner, Jeremy Cave, said that he hoped lessons will be learned from the tragedy at Grove Road cemetery in Harrogate where Reuben Powell, six, died last July while playing with friends.

He recorded a verdict of accidental death after hearing from safety officers that only a small push or tug would have been needed to dislodge the heavy sandstone slab.

The boy's parents, Jeanette and Richard Powell, are considering a test case after launching a campaign for safer graveyards following their son's death. In a statement after the inquest in Harrogate, they said that the council had failed to act soon enough to prevent their son's death, and possibly others.

David Smith, an inspector with the health and safety executive, told the inquest: "Only a small force would have been necessary to cause [the gravestone] to fall, because it had not been built on a rigid foundation."

Councils nationwide have been in touch with Harrogate, which was in the midst of a five year programme of improving safety in cemeteries when the accident happened. A spokesman said that the project had since been hastened.

webTitle: Letters: Is digital TV a switch-off?

fields.headline: Is digital TV a switch-off?
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee is right to question the BBC's approach to digital television (Digital TV must cast off its shell suit, April 18).
fields.body:
Polly Toynbee is right to question the BBC's approach to digital television (Digital TV must cast off its shell suit, April 18). Proposed budgets show £95m will be spent on BBC3 in its first full year, while only £31m will be spent on the proposed BBC4 arts channel. BBC3 is aimed at 16 to 34-year-olds, who are extremely well-served by commercial channels and hardly need further support from the licence fee.

In seeking permission to launch its new services, the BBC argued its new channels would help attract new viewers to digital television. But homes with children and those in the 16 to 34-year-old age group are already more likely to have digital TV - and less likely to watch BBC services. So three of the four proposed channels are unlikely to make any difference. If the BBC genuinely wants to extend the reach of digital television, then it should develop services that appeal to those who are not attracted to the current offerings.

Meanwhile, the BBC is refusing to sell programmes to commercial rivals, like the many children's channels, depriving licence-payers of the right to see programmes they have paid for, and the BBC and its programme-producing partners of additional commercial revenue.
Kris Jones
Producers Alliance for Cinema and Television (Pact) kris@pact.co.uk

 Top marks to Polly Toynbee for setting out some ideas about what digital could actually deliver for the viewer. A forward-looking debate on public service broadcasting (PSB) that is content, rather than broadcaster led, is vital. The industry may be piling on the pressure to increase digital take-up, but many consumers retain a healthy scepticism. On its own, an unregulated commercial sector will not deliver universal and affordable access to a range of good-quality programming.

It is a pity then that the government is opting for a piecemeal approach on whether to approve proposed new BBC channels. Far better to set out a holistic vision for PSB, taking in the BBC and other public service broadcasters, and a clear framework for funding and delivering it. That's what we've been arguing all along.
Anna Bradley
Director, National Consumer Council

 "In a world where one in three young people are graduates, the future is up-market," Polly Toynbee says. But most of the extra entrants to higher education take vocational courses, where her "cultural bravery" doesn't enter into the equation. The perception that more twentysomethings have been switched on to Aristophanes, Giotto or Wittgenstein at university is a red herring.
Tim Footman
Croydon, Surrey

 So digital TV is "young, brash, vulgar, sports-pub and Sun-reading". Presumably it needs to become old, staid, country-inn and Guardian-reading. And while we're at it, why does all pop music sound the same and how come policemen are getting younger?
Gerard Melling
Community Channel (Sky Digital, channel 655)

 Matt Wells reports (Digital giveaway planned, April 16) that before the analogue signal can be switched off in an area almost all households must be digital-ready. However, to maintain the present choice, there must be one decoder per TV set, not per household, or else families will be back to the old days of congregating round one screen in the corner to watch a choice of one programme, while all other sets in the home are instantly reduced to worthless junk. Politicians had better plan the date of the election after next with care.
John Horsley
Cottingham, E Yorks

fields.headline: Vaccination booster
fields.trailText: Leonard Black makes some misleading observations regarding vaccinating animals against foot and mouth (Slaughter is still the best medicine, April 17).
fields.body:
Leonard Black makes some misleading observations regarding vaccinating animals against foot and mouth (Slaughter is still the best medicine, April 17). The demands for vaccination supported by, among others, the Soil Association are for ring vaccination around outbreaks instead of killing healthy animals, followed by vaccination in other areas. It is irrelevant that the effect of the vaccine is for a limited time, as the outbreak would be over long before the vaccine ceased to be effective. Or it would be a simple matter to give a booster dose. Recent case histories in Turkey and Macedonia confirm the effectiveness of this approach.

Since the strain of the current outbreak is known, it is irrelevant that a vaccine against one strain gives vari able protection against others. The vaccine used would be for the O-type virus we are suffering from.

The rules set by the Office International des Epizooties (OIE) are very clear that disease-free status may be reclaimed if there "has been no outbreak of FMD and no vaccination has been carried out for at least 12 months" (Animal Health Code 2000 Article 2.1.1.2), not three years as Mr Black states.

Of course ring vaccination within too small a ring would leave the risk of infection "jumping" to farms outside the ring, but then so does the present cull. At least the vaccinated ring would be much larger than the cull ring, and could be then extended over a greater distance at low cost.
Michael Ritchie
Clynderwen, Pembrokeshire
