webTitle: Letters: Drop debt, not the IMF

fields.headline: Drop debt, not the IMF
fields.trailText: Drop the Debt is not campaigning to abolish the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, or to exclude them from the international partnership needed to fight poverty (Brown insists IMF can't drop all the debt, April 16).
fields.body:
Drop the Debt is not campaigning to abolish the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, or to exclude them from the international partnership needed to fight poverty (Brown insists IMF can't drop all the debt, April 16). On the contrary, we want to bring those institutions into line with other lenders who have agreed to cancel 100% of the debts they are owed by the poorest countries, so that payments can be used to help reach the 2015 poverty reduction targets.

Accountant Chantrey Vellacott has shown that the World Bank and IMF can afford this with no adverse impact on their ability to function as lending institutions. Equally, if their rich G7 shareholders were to fund the write-off, it would cost only a dollar per person each year in the richest seven countries.

In the last years of the 20th century, spurred by the Jubilee 2000 campaign, lenders and borrowers set out to end the debt crisis in the very poorest countries. Yet, as the new century begins, those countries continue to spend more on debt payments than healthcare.

The role of the World Bank and IMF is not at issue. The issue is whether they will be expected to fulfil their responsibilities as lenders and global citizens by recognising that it is no longer morally acceptable or economically rational to keep collecting the historic debts that the world's poorest countries have paid many times over.
Adrian Lovett
Director, Drop the Debt adrian@dropthedebt.org

fields.headline: Road rage
fields.trailText: Labour MP Michael Foster appears to be living in cloud cuckoo land when he reckons that the Hastings bypass has "total local support" (Society, April 11).
fields.body:
Labour MP Michael Foster appears to be living in cloud cuckoo land when he reckons that the Hastings bypass has "total local support" (Society, April 11). There is massive opposition to the bypass and he is beginning to realise that it is likely to cost him his marginal seat. When I wrote to John Prescott recently threatening to vote for the bypass candidate if she stands, or in any case not to vote Labour for the first time in my 70 years, Mr Foster actually phoned me to remind me of Labour's wonderful record.

But Labour cover-ups about GM food, the appalling handling of foot and mouth and its intention to turn the countryside over to agribusiness, the disgraceful ageism and abusive treatment in the NHS which I experienced recently, and the neglect of senior citizens means many of us will not be voting Labour.

The first time I published my opposition to the bypass was in 1992. There is no stopping us now.
Fay Godwin
Hastings, E Sussex

fields.headline: Gore lost without any help from Nader
fields.trailText: As Ralph Nader's New Hampshire state coordinator last year, I would like to correct one point in Gary Younge's piece (Comment, April 16). Nader did not cost Gore the state.
fields.body:
As Ralph Nader's New Hampshire state coordinator last year, I would like to correct one point in Gary Younge's piece (Comment, April 16). Nader did not cost Gore the state. Exit polling data showed that Nader took more votes from Republicans than Democrats in NH, by a two-to-one margin. CNN's polling data showed that if both Nader and Pat Buchanan had not run, the results in NH would have been Bush 48%, Gore 47%, with 4% not voting.

A post election analysis showed Nader's support was evenly split down the middle between Bush and Gore. Nader's NH effort also received the support of seven municipal officials, all Republicans, including the mayor of Rochester.

In Florida, CNN's exit poll showed that if Bush and Gore had been the only candidates, Bush would have taken 49%, Gore 47%, with 2% not voting. The data also showed that Nader took just as many votes from Democrats as he did Republicans: 1%. While there is a good chance that votes for Nader could have gone for Gore, there is no guarantee. And the statistical data that is available proves otherwise. Gore lost the election on his own, with or without Nader. If liberal Democrats want someone to blame for Bush winning, they can look no further than their own party. CNN's exitpolling showed that registered Democrats in both NH (6%) and Florida (13%), abandoned their own candidate and cast votes for Bush.
Anthony Schinella
Boston, Mass aschinella@aol.com

fields.headline: Gap years
fields.trailText: We have a New Labour government with a record majority. Yet the gap between rich and poor is wider than ever (Report, April 18).
fields.body:
We have a New Labour government with a record majority. Yet the gap between rich and poor is wider than ever (Report, April 18). And it is not a statistical quirk. It is the inevitable consequence of a central plank of New Labour thinking.

For New Labour, low income tax is a sacrament. But income tax is a key lever in redistributing wealth between rich and poor. In Hackney we have had a blizzard of government "initiatives". But, so long as Millbank believes nothing is more important than keeping income tax low for the middle classes, the gap between single mothers on council estates and City dealers (less than a mile away) with their million-pound bonuses will continue to grow.
Diane Abbott MP
abbottdj@parliament.uk

fields.headline: Clever Trevor
fields.standfirst: But the National needs more than cash cows
fields.trailText: To lift a phrase from his latest theatrical smash, Trevor Nunn has had more than a little bit of luck.
fields.body:
To lift a phrase from his latest theatrical smash, Trevor Nunn has had more than a little bit of luck. Gossips reckon the National Theatre's outgoing boss has amassed a cool £43m, most of it from moneyspinners like Cats and Les Miserables, where he proved he had as keen a commercial eye as an artistic one.

At the National he has notched up a couple more musical successes: revivals of Oklahoma! and My Fair Lady, which stand to make big bucks for both him and the NT. In the pipeline is South Pacific, which will doubtless leave the cash registers ringing even louder.

Despite that starry track record, Mr Nunn's departure in September 2002 is not wholly to be regretted. Running the country's flagship public theatre is not just about selling tickets with inevitable crowdpleasers. It is also about innovation and surprise, qualities which commerical theatre can struggle to achieve. Mr Nunn scored well here, too: not many would have predicted that a play about nuclear physics could be a smash, but Copenhagen has run and run.

Still, Mr Nunn's critics say these were the exception rather than the rule during his stewardship. The emphasis was on "bankers", shows which draw in the crowds but hardly extend the bounds of theatre. His exit now gives an opportunity to bring in an artistic director who may not generate the same bank balance, but who could fire off more sparks.

The field is unusually open, but it is a tribute to British theatre that there are a clutch of exciting names to choose from. The dream ticket of Sam Mendes and Stephen Daldry is probably a dream too far, but Nicholas Hytner and Howard Davies are both proven talents. Jude Kelly would be the first woman director of the National, a worthwhile innovation in itself. Only one thing is clear about this race: the winner should immediately commission a play about the intrigues, plotting and scheming that are bound to come in the year ahead.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: In the Mood for Love | Following | What Lies Beneath
fields.trailText: In the Mood for Love | Following | What Lies Beneath
fields.body:
In the Mood for Love
Retail (£15.99) and DVD (£19.99)
Tartan Cert PG

Hong Kong's great stylist Wong Kar-Wai only seems to make films about love affairs, yet each is as distinctive as it is memorable. This subtle, elusive piece about a couple drawn together when they realise their partners are having an affair has more in common with Brief Encounter than his cheeky, inventive Chungking Express or his delirious, lurid Fallen Angels. It leaves much of its story unsaid and unseen, leaving you to concentrate on its central couple, a relationship that might have flowered in another time and another place. It's languid, full of quiet, still moments, and impeccably played by Tony Leung (also in Wong's last film, Happy Together) and Maggie Cheung. Where Chungking Express was full of youthful high spirits and the Mamas and Papas' harmonies, this is a film of middle-aged regrets with a haunting score by Michael Galasso making a perfect fit. It's about stilted conversations, lost opportunities and possibilities drifting away like the smoke from Leung's countless cigarettes. Wong, the director, producer and writer, ended the film "physically and financially exhausted" but he won two awards at Cannes. Can't wait for his next, a foray into sci-fi.

Following
Retail (£15.99)
Momentum Cert 15

A 70-minute, black-and-white film noir debut with a micro budget and unknown actors, Following is a little gem of subterfuge, with a twisty, pitiless, unpredictable plot, amoral characters worthy of Patricia Highsmith. The director, photographer and writer was Christopher Nolan, who made this in 1998 and went on to the highly rated Memento (out to rent on April 30). An unemployed loner starts following people for something to do and discovers his target is a burglar who steals things for obscure purposes: "You take it away, you show them what they had." Lots of violation, voyeurism and intrigue follow. In a world of bloated, vacuous star vehicles, you hope a sharp, jagged little switchblade like this will find an audience.

What Lies Beneath
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Fox Pathe Cert 15

It's a surprise to find Robert Zemeckis dipping a toe into the horror genre, but even more of a surprise that the Roger Rabbit/Back to the Future man brings such a dearth of imagination to it. This is sub-sub-Hitchcock or sub-De Palma. At least the latter brought some flair to his Fat Alf rip-offs but this is horribly second-hand - Rear Window with a torn shower curtain and borrowings from Hitchcock's genius composer Bernard Herrmann that get more and more blatant towards an ending that is as contrived as it is mundane. If it weren't for the A-list cast, Harrison Ford and Michelle Pfeiffer, this is the sort of thing you might stumble across blearily on a minor TV channel at 1am. Ford has been through this sort of thing before in Polanski's Frantic, which at least had the semblance of a proper plot. The only frissons of genuine chills come from Pfeiffer, paler than ever and looking authentically spooked. Her eerie, tormented performance deserves a far better film.

fields.headline: Keane gets blunt about United's broken edge
fields.trailText: Manchester United's financial marriage with the New York Yankees was supposed to provide Sir Alex Ferguson with the funds to build a side capable of conquering the world. But after his team were again left stranded on third base in their attempt to reign supreme in Europe, a tetchy Ferguson refused to expand on pre-match hints that he might have to strengthen his side, saying: "I'm not answering that question."
fields.body:
Manchester United's financial marriage with the New York Yankees was supposed to provide Sir Alex Ferguson with the funds to build a side capable of conquering the world. But after his team were again left stranded on third base in their attempt to reign supreme in Europe, a tetchy Ferguson refused to expand on pre-match hints that he might have to strengthen his side, saying: "I'm not answering that question."

His captain Roy Keane was much more forthcoming. "We are just not good enough," he insisted and he strongly suggested that this United team needs to be broken up and new players brought in.

Keane had suggested before last night that heads might roll - among them his own - if United failed in their Munich mission. Now he said: "You have to face the facts and I think the signs have been there this season PSV, Anderlecht, Panathinaikos - while we were also lucky to get to the first stage even.

"The players gave it their all tonight but we are just not good enough and maybe it's time to move on. Maybe it's the end of the road for this team, although I'm not sure.

"It's no good winning the Premier League. We need to step up a level in Europe. I keep going on about Real Madrid but they're setting the standards we have to match."

Ferguson said: "You are all entitled to your opinion about which team was the best over the two legs but I think we are as good as Bayern, no question. They were the better side in the second half at our place, and I think we were the better side tonight.

"It was very bad defending that cost us our place in the next stage. The first goal was down to our defensive errors and that was the last thing we wanted to happen, conceding early. And the second goal was a killer.

"We had plenty of time and we created some good chances. Oliver Kahn also made some good saves to keep us out but I felt that if we had scored a second goal we would have gone on to win."

Bayern's manager Ottmar Hitzfeld disagreed. "It was a defensive battle in the second half but we lived up to the challenge and the pressure," he said. "We did not see it as taking revenge, merely as winning a match to progress to the semi-finals. I thought we deserved to win on our performance."

Bayern face Real in the semi-finals after the champions overcame Galatasaray 3-0 in Spain, Raul (twice) and Ivan Helguera scoring in the first half, to triumph 5-3 on aggregate.

Hitzfeld and Ferguson were agreed on one thing: whoever wins the European Cup will have to overcome Real, whom Ferguson believes have become even more powerful because of Luis Figo's signing.

United's manager sounded almost wistful as he mentioned this, perhaps wondering whether his employers would be willing to loosen the purse strings to the extent where he can spend £37m on a single player who might make his side European champions again.

Given Keane's much publicised fears about players' futures in the event of elimination Ferguson made a point of praising his captain's contribution.

Ferguson has only one more chance of winning the European Cup for a second time before he retires from management at the end of next season. So it is a question of whether he is prepared to put personal ambition before loyalty to his players, and whether, in the cold light of day, he adheres to his belief that his squad really is good enough.

 Real Madrid are 6-4 favourites with Hill's to lift the European Cup ahead of Bayern (13-5), Valencia (11-4) and Leeds (9-2). A repeat Real-Valencia final is quoted at 8-5.

fields.headline: Avenging Bayern destroy red dream
fields.standfirst:
No late heroics for United as Germans lay the ghost of 1999
Elber 5, Scholl 40 | Giggs 49
Bayern win 3-1 on aggregate
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText:
There were no late heroics for Sir Alec Ferguson's men as Bayern Munich lay the ghost of 1999 and dumped them out of the competition thanks to goals from Giovane Elber and Mehmet Scholl.
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.byline: David Lacey at the Olympic stadium
fields.body:
For Manchester United last night 1999 and the Nou Camp belonged not so much to another century as to another life. Though United's latest European Cup aspirations died bravely enough in the end their hopes of overhauling the 1-0 lead Bayern Munich had brought home from Old Trafford all but disappeared once Sir Alex Ferguson's defence had twice fallen apart before half-time.

At the start of the second half a goal from Ryan Giggs stemmed the collapse and United increasingly dominated the match as they sought to repeat the outstanding recoveries that had won them the trophy two seasons earlier. Yet Bayern, having been pipped by United during four minutes of stoppage time at the end of the 1999 final, made sure they did not throw everything away in the four extra minutes allowed.

To stand any chance of reaching the semi-finals United had to combine their noted ability to score important goals with defending of sufficient discipline and resilience to curb Bayern's penchant for breaking through on the counter-attack.

The latter United palpably failed to do. In fact they might have been four goals down by half-time rather than two. It was not so much a case of the back four letting the side down as the midfield allowing Bayern space to bypass Roy Keane and Nicky Butt and get players into threatening positions.

Again Stefan Effenberg, solidly supported by Jens Jeremies, gave Bayern a momentum that, even when United were throwing everyone, including Fabien Barthez, forward in the closing minutes, still promised the German side further goals. Had United been able to raise the tempo of their football half an hour earlier they might have achieved yet another astonishing turnaround, but for too long their responses were too sluggish.

To stand any chance of winning United needed to recall a sharpness lost in their canter to a Premiership hat-trick. Swapping goals with Coventry was hardly relevant to the levels of concentration demanded here.

United's manager had predicted Bayern would exert pressure on his team from the start in an effort to kill off the tie. In this he was not mistaken, except that Ferguson had trusted his defence to hold out for a little longer than five minutes.

The goal followed Bayern's first coordinated attack and exposed a fault in the reorganisation forced on United by David Beckham's suspension. From his own half Willy Sagnol, one of the replacements for Bayern's two suspended players - Hasan Salihamidzic and Bixente Lizarazu - exploited a wide corridor of space that was partly the result of Paul Scholes being switched to the right flank.

Michael Tarnat, the other replacement, was left with plenty of time to provide the low centre that was missed by Carsten Jancker, who had moved in between Jaap Stam and Wes Brown, but arrived nicely for Giovane Elber to send the ball into the roof of the net.

"The worst thing that could happen to us," Ferguson called it, but things might have been even worse. By the 17th minute United could have been three down. First Jancker, set up by Mehmet Scholl, saw a shot deflected against the crossbar. Then the burly striker was thwarted only by the speed of Barthez off his line.

Ferguson and his players had memories of a famous recovery against Juventus two years earlier to sustain them. Then, United, having been held 1-1 at home, came from 2-0 down to win 3-2 in Turin.

Though the untidiness of United's attacks did not suggest a repetition they all but scored after 25 minutes. From Giggs's corner on the right, Butt headed down towards goal and Andy Cole helped the ball towards the net, only for Scholl to clear off the line.

Then five minutes before half-time Jeremies sliced through United on the right to find Elber. The Brazilian's pass came off Alexander Zickler, who had just replaced Jancker, to set up Scholl for a shot inside the near post. Giggs was United's best hope of salvation and in the 48th minute he lobbed the ball over Oliver Kahn, who had been caught in no man's land by Scholes's precise chip forward. Eleven minutes later Kahn almost turned himself inside out touching a volley from Giggs over.

A dribble by Luke Chadwick, on for the last six minutes, might have brought them a second goal had Jeremies not whipped the ball away before Ole Gunnar Solskjaer could shoot and Teddy Sheringham, who had replaced Dwight Yorke, and Scholes went close. But this time the two goals United needed to beat Bayern were just not there.

Bayern Munich (3-4-1-2): Kahn; Kuffour, Andersson, Linke; Sagnol, Jeremies, Effenberg, Tarnat; Scholl (Paulo Sergio, 88min); Elber (Roque Santa Cruz, 65), Jancker (Zieckler, 33).

Manchester United (4-4-2): Barthez; G Neville, Stam, Brown, Silvestre; Scholes, Keane, Butt, Giggs; Cole, Yorke (Sheringham, 66).

Referee : V M Melo Pereira (Portugal).

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: English yes, but equal language rights first

fields.headline: English yes, but equal language rights first
fields.standfirst: Robert Phillipson argues that the European Union's bid to create unity will remain an ideal without a better policy on languages.
fields.trailText: The 11 official languages of the 15 member states of the European Union have equal rights. These languages are Danish, Dutch, English, Finnish, French, German, Greek, Italian, Portuguese, Spanish, Swedish. The languages of each member state are official and working languages of the European Parliament and the Commission in Brussels.
fields.body:
The 11 official languages of the 15 member states of the European Union have equal rights. These languages are Danish, Dutch, English, Finnish, French, German, Greek, Italian, Portuguese, Spanish, Swedish. The languages of each member state are official and working languages of the European Parliament and the Commission in Brussels.

Since there has never been a close fit between language and state in Europe, three of Belgium's languages are in use, Dutch, French and German, and two of Finland's, Finnish and Swedish, whereas the only language from Spain is Spanish, even though there are more speakers of Catalan than of Danish or Finnish. Demography is less important than political clout, nationally and internationally. Many languages in Europe have no EU rights.

EU languages permeate the ongoing processes of creating a "union" of EU states, a new supra-national economic and political entity. Language is a sensitive political issue, as it is a profound symbol of national and personal identity. As language, culture and education are in principle matters for individual member states rather than the Union, language policy at the supra-national level is largely implicit and covert. As some languages are more "international" than others the equality of the 11 languages has in fact always been a myth.

The existing rights to translation are essential, because documents emanating from Brussels have the force of law in member states, overriding national legislation. The right to an interpreter is often restricted, except for senior politicians and Members of the European Parliament. Working documents are seldom available in all 11 languages. In 1970, 60% of texts in the Commission were initially drafted in French, and 40% in German. In 1989 the figures were French 50%, German 9%, and English 30%. By 1997 the figures were French 40% and English 45%, leaving only a sprinkling in other languages. In external communication, English is generally used. These figures reveal the de facto hierarchy of languages in Brussels and Strasbourg. English has gradually eroded the monopoly of French. Ironically enough this has happened during a period when successive British governments have kept "Europe" at arm's length. The language policies of EU institutions are influenced by many factors, the most important of which is globalisation. The advance of English reflects American commercial, political and military might, and the impact of Hollywood, CNN and McDonald's. The British have always been keen to capitalise on English as a strategic and commercial asset. English is the most widely learned foreign language in Europe, because Britain's partners recognise it as is a necessary communicative tool. In reality English is no longer a foreign language in several member states. It is widely used internally in many fields, and increasingly as the corporate language of big business. It is a fact of working and social life for many EU citizens. The market forces that are propelling English forward impact on the vitality and viability of other languages. English is capturing some of their territory, despite EU treaties and summit meetings proclaiming a commitment to diversity. The Amsterdam Treaty, Article 128.4 reads: "The Community shall take cultural aspects into account in its action under the provisions of this Treaty, in particular in order to respect and to promote the diversity of its cultures". The Nice summit acted on this to approve a programme to strengthen the European film industry. In several member states there are voices protesting against Americanisation and cultural and linguistic homogenisation. Ulrich Ammon has recently written a book exploring whether German, the leading language of the natural sciences a century ago, can still be considered a language of science. The Norwegian Minister of Transport has protested about the website the SAS airline, which has the three Scandinavian governments as majority shareholders, being exclusively in English. The Swedish government recently commissioned a major survey of Swedish in all key domains in Sweden and in European Union institutions. The study documents how English is taking over from Swedish. Work is now under way to ensure that Swedish remains a "complete" language. Investigations of domain loss to English in all the Nordic languages are currently being commissioned. Several countries are thus following in the steps of the French in registering that the advance of English is a problem, and identifying strategies to strengthen local languages. No-one is suggesting that English should not be effectively learned and used, but policy should ensure that people learn and use English in addition to other languages rather than at their expense. Language policy ought to be taken seriously because it is likely that big business is doing so. A recent doctoral study in international law in the United States concludes that French language protection measures are in conflict with the principle of a common market with free movement of goods, services, labour and capital. Such an interpretation could soon lead corporate lawyers to challenge national language legislation, and demand an English-only market throughout the EU. Countries applying for EU membership have probably assumed that their languages will have the same rights as other official languages. This is most unlikely, since the present interpretation and translation services are ineffective, and will be even more unworkable when new states join the EU. There needs to be a re-think of attitudes. Scoffing at French efforts to shore up French is myopic. If native speakers of French and English can use their mother tongues, how can one ensure equivalent rights for others? What is urgently needed is clarification of the criteria that should guide an equitable language policy, and mechanisms that permit real equality of communication between speakers of different languages. We need imaginative and realistic scenarios. We need to see a coming together of the relevant constituencies in the political, business, academic, cultural and human rights worlds. There is a need for hard-nosed analysis of how to ensure efficient, cost effective and democratic strategies for increased multilingualism. In this way English can be appropriated without other languages being marginalised.

webTitle: Minority voices show strong instinct for survival

fields.headline: Minority voices show strong instinct for survival
fields.standfirst: John Walsh explains how the best protection for 'small' languages in Europe lies in evaluating their economic strengths
fields.trailText: The debate about dominant and dominated languages in Europe concentrates almost exclusively on the position of English versus the 10 other official languages. Yet the simplistic claim that English - the "international shark" as one commentator has dramatically called it - is about to devour other state languages, ignores a far more diverse tapestry of linguistic diversity. According to the Brussels-based European Bureau for Lesser Used Languages, about 40m people in Europe speak a language other than the dominant language of the country where they reside. These languages range in strength from the Catalan pike, with about 7m speakers, to the minnow of Saterfrisian, a minority language in Germany spoken by about 2,000 people. In between are more than 60 other language minorities, each finding itself in entirely different circumstances and faced with its own specific predator.
fields.body:
The debate about dominant and dominated languages in Europe concentrates almost exclusively on the position of English versus the 10 other official languages. Yet the simplistic claim that English - the "international shark" as one commentator has dramatically called it - is about to devour other state languages, ignores a far more diverse tapestry of linguistic diversity. According to the Brussels-based European Bureau for Lesser Used Languages, about 40m people in Europe speak a language other than the dominant language of the country where they reside. These languages range in strength from the Catalan pike, with about 7m speakers, to the minnow of Saterfrisian, a minority language in Germany spoken by about 2,000 people. In between are more than 60 other language minorities, each finding itself in entirely different circumstances and faced with its own specific predator.

Basques in the south of France are concerned at the continuing refusal of the French government to grant their language adequate protection in education and the media. An island in a sea of Dutch, Frisians have been shocked by a recent study revealing poor standards of teaching their languages in schools. Slovenes in the southern Austrian province of Carinthia are alarmed at government cutbacks which threaten to close bilingual Slovene-German radio stations. In the Italian minority region of Slovenia, the Italian parts of bilingual roadsigns were recently painted over. No-one replaced Italian with English. English is not the main concern of these minorities.

Yet despite these examples, it is not the case that all minority languages across Europe are being swallowed up by their own national sharks. The recent establishment of a bilingual private Breton-French television station was a kick in the teeth to those on the French right who have fought, as far as constitutional level, against recognition of minority languages in France. Linguistic minorities in Italy have had a good year, with far-reaching national legislation allowing them to finally begin consolidating their education and media. Protection of minorities in the Danish-German border region is conducted on the basis of international reciprocal agreements between both countries. And the European Bureau for Lesser Used Languages brings together representatives of all minorities three times a year to exchange experiences and to press the EU for funding and recognition. This does not mean, however, that minority language communities are ignorant about the dominance of English, oblivious to anything other than their own regional struggles. Notwithstanding their problems with education, the Frisians last year began a pilot project dividing primary school hours between their own language, Dutch and English. A similar project was recently launched in the Basque Country with equal emphasis on Basque, Spanish and English. And in Luxembourg, English is indeed the first foreign language taught to schoolchildren, but not before they master Luxembourgish, French and German. This latter point is worth making because it underlines another important element of the dynamic. Speakers of minority languages cannot afford to be against learning the dominant language surrounding them. They have no choice in the matter, as this language is essential for communication with their neighbours, sometimes literally in the next house. This does not mean, however, that they should discard their native language as if it were an impediment to progress. It is true that this has happened, dramatically in the case of Ireland, and still continues to happen in some of the smaller minorities. But acquisition of English or any other dominant language does not have to occur at the expense of the language of the home or community. Most theorists agree that language remains the primary identity marker. The slow yet perceptible development of academic theories exploring the links between identity, language and socio-economic development is becoming another important support mechanism for minority language communities. The Brussels-based Research Centre on Multilingualism has recently urged the development of "econolinguistics", a new academic discipline linking multilingualism and economic development. The centre's research could also point towards ways of developing an equitable language policy at EU level. It suggests the development of a language policy based on the same compensatory principles already used in agricultural and regional economic policies. This would form the basis of an EU programme for all languages with limited geographical bases or facing other threats to their future vitality (which could, of course, include "smaller" languages such as Danish or Finnish). The central planks of such a programme would be: positive discrimination, such as providing financial support for producing materials or training personnel in the language; decentralisation, to allow enhanced use of the language at local level; and the overall promotion of multilingualism where no language is developed at the expense of another. Such a suggestion could help overcome the current narrow debate about the future of official languages in an enlarged Union.

Finally, to an issue which is increasingly gaining attention in the language debate, but with which EU leaders are showing little enthusiasm to engage: languages of immigrant communities. Most of the discourse about lesser-used languages focuses solely on indigenous or autochthonous minorities, referred to in some states as "national minorities". In a country such as Germany, where Turks far outnumber any indigenous language group, the issue can no longer be ignored. Quite apart from the fact that the "new" immigrant communities will be the "old" minorities of tomorrow, their languages often face similar, if not more acute problems than "national" groups. In the Netherlands, itself containing a high percentage of immigrants, research has begun into the common challenges facing both "old" and "new". Whether or not the EU is willing to include the thorny issue of immigration in a future language policy remains a point of debate, but neither "old" nor "new" are displaying willingness to be eaten by the international shark of English.

fields.headline: Bolton's hopes fall another 10 yards
fields.trailText: Dean Ashton's controversial winner for Crewe left Sam Allardyce's side with a mountain to climb if they are to overtake Blackburn and claim second place in the division.
fields.body:
Ten yards could prove to be the difference between promotion and another season in the First Division for Bolton after Dean Ashton's controversial winner for Crewe left Sam Allardyce's side with a mountain to climb if they are to overtake Blackburn and claim second place in the division.

The referee Peter Walton's decision to force the Bolton wall back a further 10 yards following dissent from the visiting players allowed Crewe to score from Kenny Lunt's 88th-minute free-kick. Lunt's square ball to Ashton was fired into the net by the teenaged striker.

"I didn't think it was a free-kick in the first place," Allardyce said. "The referee's decision has cost us dearly. We now need to win all of our games and hope that Blackburn slip up to get second place."

Crewe's manager Dario Gradi was delighted with his team. "If we had lost the game I'd still have said it was a magnificent performance. We are on 53 points now and that should be enough for us."

Bolton's hopes rose in the 62nd minute when Dean Holdsworth, who replaced the ineffective Ian Marshall at the interval, created a goal out of nothing. Paul Warhurst fed the former Wimbledon striker midway into the Crewe half, and he turned on his heels and shot from 35 yards. The goalkeeper Ademole Bankole should have saved, but credit to Holdsworth for having the audacity to attempt such an effort.

Bolton's lead lasted a mere five minutes, however, as Crewe and equalised through Rob Hulse. Phil Charnock's far-post cross appeared to give Hulse little chance of scoring, but he directed a header past Matt Clarke.

fields.headline: Vieira fires warning to 'average' Arsenal
fields.trailText: Patrick Vieira has claimed that Arsenal "made a mistake" in selling Emmanuel Petit and Marc Overmars, and says the club's season is best "forgotten".
fields.body:
After seeing Arsenal surrender the title by Easter and bow out of the Champions League, Patrick Vieira could contain his frustration no longer. Yesterday the midfielder criticised the club, insisting a stronger squad was needed and attacking the summer sales of Marc Overmars and Emmanuel Petit to Barcelona.

Vieira's comments, which came with a refusal to commit his long-term future to Highbury, reflect annoyance at a season he will see as "average" and best "forgotten" even if Arsenal win the FA Cup. Having questioned the ambition that saw Overmars and Petit depart for £30m, the Frenchman hopes Arsène Wenger will make the big summer signings he feels Arsenal require to match the best.

"We need some more quality players," Vieira said after the 1-0 defeat at Valencia prevented Arsenal reaching the Champions League semi-finals. "Losing Manu and Marc Overmars was a mistake of the club. Of course it was good business but it was a big disappointment for me.

"If we still had the same team now and put Overmars and Petit in it, we would be even better and stronger. It's not that I miss Petit - the team needs him.

"Players like Lauren, Sylvain Wiltord and Robert Pires are fantastic. We have a really good team but that doesn't stop us missing Petit and Overmars. They have contracts and if the club wants to keep them they can. If you want to win the Premiership and Champions League you have to keep your best players."

Vieira's reluctance to commit himself to Highbury will worry the fans, particularly as Juventus have been casting covetous glances.

Above all, the 24-year-old is likely to want guarantees that stars such as Thierry Henry will be kept and top-quality signings are imminent to enable him to win the trophies he craves. The FA Cup is small bière in his eyes, and he may be keen to learn whether Wenger will stay beyond next season.

"I have a contract with Arsenal until 2004," Vieira said. "But, as we know, anything is possible in football. From today I will say nothing more about my future."

Impressively as Vieira has played since Petit left, he must have felt at times that he has been carrying the burden of more than one man. Edu's season was reduced to farce by passport problems and injury, and other partners have come in: Gilles Grimandi, Ray Parlour and Lauren, none world class.

Wenger hopes that Edu will settle and says he plans only "one or two" signings in the close season, with a goalkeeper and a centre-back expected to be his targets as time runs out for David Seaman, Tony Adams and Martin Keown.

He may wonder, though, whether a new striker is also needed after the lack of decisiveness and presence in the penalty area that cost Arsenal in their 1-0 defeats at Bayern Munich and Valencia.

On Tuesday promising counter-attacks produced little end product, and Arsenal scored only twice in the last four Champions League away games, losing three of them.

Although unfortunate to go out on away goals to Valencia, their displays since the first group stage - when they took four points off Lazio - have not merited a semi-final place.

But after they scrambled into the last eight with fewer points than any other side, Vieira felt there was a "great opportunity for us to play in a Champions League final" because all the Italian sides had been eliminated. "That might never happen again," he admitted.

Arsenal must now ensure they finish second in the Premiership and beat Liverpool in the FA Cup final. "But I have to be honest," Vieira remarked, "even if we manage to reach these two objectives, I would qualify our season as average.

"In the championship we are 15 or 20 points adrift of Manchester United, so for me it's really a season to be forgotten."

webTitle: Chesterfield gamble on appeal against points cut

fields.headline: Chesterfield gamble on appeal against points cut
fields.trailText: Chesterfield have confirmed they will appeal over the nine-point deduction recommended for misconduct, but now risk the possibility of seeing the punishment increased.
fields.body:
Chesterfield have confirmed they will appeal over the nine-point deduction recommended for misconduct, but now risk the possibility of seeing the punishment increased.

The Third Division leaders had until 4pm yesterday to confirm their appeal, which will be heard by a Football Association board on April 30. However the FA has revealed that one of its options is to increase the penalty recommended by a joint Football League and FA disciplinary panel.

There was criticism of the panel's decision to find Chesterfield guilty of only two of 90 misconduct charges after a Football League inquiry. The other charges, including allegations of irregular payments, were deemed "not proven".

Once the FA has ruled, the Football League must decide whether to ratify its own panel's recommendation to dock the nine points and impose a £20,000 fine for a breach of regulations in a transfer and under-reporting of gate receipts. Chesterfield are still the subject of a police inquiry.

Chelsea could sign Bradford's striker Benito Carbone this summer if his close friend Gianfranco Zola leaves Stamford Bridge. "Zola would still have a role to play if he decides to stay," said Chelsea's manager Claudio Ranieri. "However if not, then I must have a replacement ready and Carbone certainly would be a player we would consider."

The FA has rescinded Paul Dickov's three-match suspension for being sent off at Everton this month. The referee David Elleray reduced the Manchester City forward's punishment to a booking after reviewing the incident on video.

Dickov, who has just completed a two-match suspension for picking up 10 bookings this season, is now available to face Manchester United on Saturday.

Paul Gascoigne has resumed training and is in contention for a place in the Everton squad to face Bradford on Saturday week. The midfielder was given the all-clear on his knee by a specialist on Tuesday.

The First Division champions Fulham are reportedly chasing the Monaco defenders Philippe Christanval and Martin Djetou, valued at £8m apiece, and Paris St-Germain's £7m-rated winger Laurent Robert.

Dundee are resigned to losing their 33-year-old Argentine striker Claudio Caniggia at the end of the season. Peter Marr, the club's chief executive, said: "With Claudio's ambition to play in Japan in the World Cup and possibly the chance to play in the Champions League to show he is worth a place with Argentina, I think that's what's behind his move."

The Crystal Palace midfelder Jamie Pollock has extended his loan at Birmingham City for another month. The Londoners have also lost their captain Fan Zhiyi, who looks likely to miss the last four games playing World Cup qualifiers for China.

Charlton's Sasa Ilic has been called up by Yugoslavia for the World Cup qualifier with Russia in Belgrade on Wednesday. The 28-year-old keeper has won one cap, as a substitute against Israel three years ago.

Football League clubs will observe a minute's silence before this weekend's matches in memory of the referee Mike North, who collapsed and died during Monday's match at Southend. The match officials will also wear green shirts with black armbands.

webTitle: Andorra game offers Quinn a chance to rewrite the records

fields.headline: Andorra game offers Quinn a chance to rewrite the records
fields.trailText: Niall Quinn has been handed the best chance he will ever get to set the Irish goalscoring record after being included in the Republic's squad for Wednesday's visit of Andorra in a World Cup qualifier.
fields.body:
Niall Quinn has been handed the best chance he will ever get to set the Irish goalscoring record after being included in the Republic's squad for Wednesday's visit of Andorra in a World Cup qualifier.

Quinn, 34, shares the Irish record of 20 goals with Frank Stapleton but a back injury has limited his recent appearances. "At the moment I am more concerned about our big derby against Newcastle on Saturday," Quinn said. "Providing I have no problems in that match, it will be great to join up in Dublin on Sunday."

Mick McCarthy last week named a 30-man squad but reduced the party to 22 yesterday. Dean Kiely, Damien Duff, Keith O'Neill, Curtis Fleming and Gary Kelly were ruled out with injury and Barry Quinn, Gareth Farrelly and Graham Kavanagh were omitted.

There was a place for Manchester City's Mark Kennedy, however, after he had been omitted since being arrested in Dublin after a late-night incident prior to the Republic's 2-2 draw with Holland in September. "Mark would have returned once the court case had been completed," said McCarthy. "It was only injuries that ruled him out of our recent games against Cyprus and Andorra. I'm happy that he is back."

Fifa has repeated its call for a ban on pitch-side fences following the recent Ellis Park tragedy in South Africa where 43 people died. Despite prolonged opposition by the game's world governing body, fences are common in many countries and Fifa cannot even guarantee fence-free stadiums at its World Cup tournaments.

At France 98 three grounds had fences and for the 2002 World Cup in South Korea and Japan the Seoul stadium, which hosts the opening match, and the Yokohama ground in Japan, where the final will be played, will both be equipped with fences as well as moats.

Republic of Ireland squad : A Kelly (Blackburn), Given (Newcastle), Colgan (Hibernian); Staunton (Aston Villa), Harte (Leeds), Breen (Coventry), Dunne (Man City), Cunningham (Wimbledon), Doherty , Carr (Tottenham); Roy Keane (Manchester United), Kinsella (Charlton), Carsley (Coventry), McAteer (Blackburn), Holland (Ipswich), Kilbane (Sunderland), Finnan (Fulham), Delap (Derby), Kennedy (Manchester City); Quinn (Sunderland), Robbie Keane (Leeds), Connolly (Feyenoord).
